name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the preparation of the extraordinary European Council of 20 February 2020 on the Multiannual Financial Framework (2020/2538(SDR)). I would like to thank the President of the Commission, Mrs Ursula von der Leyen, for being here, and I give the floor, and I thank her and thank her, to Minister Brnjac for her speech.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it is my pleasure to address this assembly today to discuss the preparation for the special European Council meeting on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) that will take place on 20 February. Following the presentation by the Commission of its proposal for the next Multiannual Financial Framework, the Bulgarian, Austrian, Romanian and Finnish Presidencies worked hard at the technical and political levels to prepare the ground for an agreement. We have now entered a decisive phase. Following the discussion at the December European Council, the President of the European Council has carried out extensive consultation with his counterparts. On this basis, he will submit, with a view to the General Affairs Council (GAC) on 17 February, his proposal for a deal at the level of the European Council. The Croatian Presidency fully supports the view that a deal must be found swiftly. This will not be easy, as we all know, but there is still, in many parts, an expectation gap between what we want to achieve at EU level and the funds to achieve these goals. However, postponement would not make things easier, quite the contrary. The departure of the UK creates a budgetary gap, further tightening the situation, with the Union facing, at the same time, a number of new challenges and, hence, priorities. A balanced agreement reflecting the ambitious objectives of the strategic agenda at the level of the European Council in February is necessary to open the way for concluding the negotiations on the many pending sectoral codecision files so as to be ready for the beginning of the new cycle in January 2021. The urgency to adopt the draft MFF regulation at the Council level also stems from the fact that this will not be the end of the road, since the European Parliament must give its consent to this regulation. We are aware of the concerns and the positions expressed by the Parliament. That is why, all along the process, the successive presidencies have taken great care to keep Parliament informed, for instance, through regular meetings both before and after the General Affairs Council meetings discussing the MFF, which will be the case next week as well. The Croatian Presidency will continue with this practice whenever the MFF is on the GAC formal agenda. Moreover, that is also why the President of the European Council has had several high-level contacts with the representatives of the Parliament. Once unanimous agreement is found at the level of the European Council, the Croatian Presidency will work very hard with the Parliament to ensure a positive outcome when the House votes on this regulation. Reaching a timely and balanced agreement on the whole MFF package, including the own resources part, is in the common interest of all institutions, Member States, and their citizens. I very much hope that we will achieve that objective. The Croatian Presidency will do all it can in that respect.

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: Präsidentin der Kommission. Herr Präsident, meine Damen und Herren Abgeordneten! In der Tat, wir werden nächste Woche den außerordentlichen Europäischen Rat haben, und das ist ein wichtiger Moment für Europa. Die Ausgangsposition ist im Prinzip gut, denn alle drei Institutionen – das Parlament, der Rat und die Kommission – sind sich einig über die strategische Agenda. Wir wissen alle, was auf dem Spiel steht. Wir haben sehr klare gemeinsame politische Ziele: Europa soll 2050 der erste klimaneutrale Kontinent sein, und zwar nicht nur, weil es um die Gesundheit des Planeten geht – das ist das Hauptziel –, aber auch, weil wir wissen, dass dahinter, wenn wir eine saubere und umweltfreundliche Wirtschaft entwickeln, neue Jobs stehen, die nachhaltig sind und die damit auch Zukunft bedeuten. Wir wollen vom digitalen Wandel in der Welt profitieren, und zwar nicht nur passiv, sondern wir wollen auch aktiv Akteure sein. Und wir wollen die Menschen in Europa stärken, indem wir einerseits den Übergang, der durch die ökologische und digitale Transformation ausgelöst wird, abfedern und andererseits genau das machen, was richtig ist, nämlich investieren in die Bildung und Ausbildung, gerade mit Kompetenzen auf dem ökologischen und digitalen Feld. Doch uns läuft die Zeit davon, und lassen Sie es mich noch einmal ganz deutlich formulieren: Wenn der Haushalt nicht bald beschlossen wird, dann werden wir im nächsten Jahr nicht in der Lage sein, mit dem neuen Haushalt die neuen Prioritäten tatsächlich auch so zu finanzieren, wie wir uns das alle vorstellen. And, therefore, after nearly two years of deliberations it is high time now. All of us must be ready to find common ground. And what is important: we have to find the right balance between old priorities and new priorities. Because if you look at the negotiations, while there are many, many Member States that strongly defend cohesion policies, and rightly so. And there are many Member States that strongly defend the common agricultural policies, and rightly so.  But I also expect to see the same dedication when it comes to defending our new priorities. Because the day the budget will be signed, the day we have agreed on a budget – and I know that – everybody will turn around towards the Parliament and towards the Commission and will ask for: Horizon Europe, will ask for Erasmus, ask for migration funds, for defence, for digitalisation, for infrastructure, you name it. And, therefore, we really have to make sure that these new priorities get the attention they deserve.  We have to deliver on a European budget that is able to invest in digital start—up, to explore the potential of artificial intelligence, to anchor Europe’s position as the world’s leading research region, to offer young people a better future and all parts of Europe, to address the root causes of migration, to allow us to demonstrate solidarity in cases of humanitarian or natural catastrophes, to allow to build the European Union of security and defence. But, most of all, we need a budget so that citizens and companies see that we are able to act on climate change. For citizens this is the top priority. For us, it’s a challenge, but it’s our duty to turn this challenge into an opportunity. Le succès de ces négociations budgétaires dépendra des moyens que nous nous donnerons de financer notre pacte vert pour l’Europe. Moi, je n’accepterai aucun résultat qui ne garantisse pas qu’au moins 25 % du budget soit consacré à la lutte contre le changement climatique. J’attends un budget qui alloue les nouvelles ressources nécessaires au mécanisme pour une transition juste. La raison en est simple: si nous ne nous donnons pas les moyens nécessaires pour soutenir les régions et les travailleurs les plus exposés aux conséquences économiques et sociales des politiques relatives au changement climatique, nous ne réussirons tout simplement pas à atteindre la neutralité climatique. Le pacte vert pour l’Europe se fera avec les citoyens européens, avec les chercheurs européens, avec les entreprises européennes, ou il ne se fera pas du tout. Je pense, tout comme vous, que de nouvelles ressources propres pour l’Union constitueraient une avancée importante. Pour cela, j’ai instamment prié les États membres de tenir pleinement compte de la position du Parlement européen à cet égard. Je suis convaincue que cela donnera un coup d’accélérateur à notre programme commun et allégera la pression exercée sur les budgets nationaux, rendant ainsi possible l’allocation des fonds supplémentaires nécessaires. Ainsi, c’est véritablement une solution gagnant-gagnant que nous recherchons.  Honourable Members, we all know the negotiations will not be easy. As a Union of 27, as you said, we have fewer resources. It’s about EUR 75 billion less for the whole 7-years period, but more common challenges that no Member State can solve on its own. And at the same time, expectations towards the next long-term budget of the Union could not be more diverse. As Members of Parliament, you are well aware of the discussions in your home countries, while you also see the different positions in the Member States of your colleagues. Arriving at an agreement will therefore be a serious challenge. We all know this. But we also know that citizens will not understand it if decision-makers fail to make the funding available for policies needed. It’s our common responsibility in the European Council, and in the European Parliament to deliver for Europe. (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Madam President, Madam President of the Council, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. When we talk about money, we talk about budget, we talk about politics, about the future of Europe. Where can we focus? I would like to begin by stressing that, from our point of view, it would have been good if Charles Michel had been here today. Listening would have been good. We know that he is in close contact with our Steering Group to meet with the experts, but coming to plenary has another meaning; that is why I would like to say at the outset that it would have been nice if he were there. But what is positive is that he has set February 20. He puts pressure on the MFF discussion, he tries to give answers, he tries to achieve security for the citizens. The farmers, the students, the researchers – all are waiting for clarity as to what will happen in the next few years. That is why we wish him every success for the 20th. It is the right moment to do this: we have a fresh mandate – we, as Members of Parliament, from the electorate, the Commission has a fresh mandate. We are all equipped with new momentum, and we know what the people have given us after these European elections, and that is what we need to do together now. The first point is that we, as a European level, make it clear that it is not just a question of defending the existing funds. I would like to make it clear that we too are capable of self-criticism, and it must also be possible in budget negotiations to start by looking self-critically at whether the existing money is being properly spent. Both Günther Oettinger and Johannes Hahn have done so in their responsibility with the proposals that are before us. That means looking at it in a really self-critical way in the areas. One issue that is important to us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats is budgetary control: the possible limitation of payments to an individual. If a person in Europe gets large sums from the EU budget, then that cannot be right. We are in favour of a kind of anti-oligarch law in the European Union, where we make it clear that the money must not end up in one hand. A second issue for us is that we also defend the existing funds and make it clear that they are well invested. Farmers need support in global competition, rural areas need support in globalisation. Regional support means that Europe is growing together. That is right, and solidarity is still necessary. In the field of research: Erasmus shows Europe the European added value, the additional European advantage. Thirdly, it is important to us that we do not save on the future. Agriculture is important, regional development is important – we have always stressed this in our positions – but the momentum must not now be created for cuts in the European Union's future fields. I would like to see a one-per-cent discussion in the Council now, not just a percentage discussion on the ceiling, but also a concrete discussion of content. If the European Council decides to put into force 10 000 Frontex officials who better protect our external borders, then it is unacceptable for the Finnish Presidency to reduce this share of the budget by one third. Either you stand by your promises or you do not stand by your promises. This also applies to research. Our project, for example, which is very important to us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, will also need the necessary resources to succeed in the fight against cancer. I have already mentioned this in Erasmus, and I would like to thank Johannes and also Ursula von der Leyen for the clarity that these issues must not be allowed to go under the table. I would also like to see – and I say this as a German – that we finally end the net contributor discussion. Ladies and gentlemen, if we establish proper border protection in Europe, if we establish a Marshall Plan for Africa, then these are not money that will go back to the Netherlands, Austria or Germany, but it is in the deep interest of the Germans, the Austrians and also the Dutch. That is why we should stop discussing the net contributors. The best approach to overcome them would be to finally get started in own resources, if European tasks are financed with European funds, that the common interest of Europeans is also financed by European funds, then that would be the best answer we can give. I would like to say explicitly that the Council should know that, for us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, the issue of own resources is also a red line. We need a systemic change in the financing of the European Union, and we will underline this in the further discussions. Another systemic issue is rule of law: European taxpayers' money can only be spent if legal principles are respected. An independent judiciary, a free media landscape, is the best guarantee that money will be properly spent. That is why we take the view that a combination of rule of law and the MFF makes sense. And last but not least: in the last discussion on the MFF, David Cameron campaigned hard for it: only one per cent, only one per cent, only one per cent! In doing so, he could convince the British that Europe would then be efficient, sustainable and lean. We have seen the Brexit example: if we feed the populists, if we give in to the populists, it will strengthen the populists and not weaken them. That is why we now need an ambitious approach – not the lowest common denominator, but ambition for Europe! (Applause)

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are in one of the most important debates which will mark the whole European legislature, but also the future of the Union. It's no use setting goals by 2050 if we tie our hands for the next seven years.  That we are at a crucial time for Europe we all know. So is the Council. That Europe really needs to put in place a major transformation to lead sustainability in the world, a transformation in economic, social, environmental matters. Of course, that agenda of transformation is necessary. We all know this, and so does the Council.  Now we only need to be able to put on the table the means necessary to carry it out. This Parliament's proposal is very reasonable and faces this need: 1.3% of gross national product, more additional resources for new policies to be put in place, such as addressing the right transition in this area.  This Parliament's proposal is very clear and has a large majority of support from the various political groups. President Von der Leyen has insisted very much on the need for this to be a geostrategic Commission and to have our position in the world. And so has the President of the Council, Mr Charles Michel, alluded to the need to lead the fight for climate neutrality in the world. Now all we need to do is convince his Council partners — and I would also like to say at this point that we would have liked Mr Charles Michel to be here today; you may still have little to say, but you have a lot to listen to. In order to convince the Council partners, I believe that it is necessary to understand the great responsibility we face and it is necessary to have an agreement in front of us in which there are no winners and losers because then it will be losing Europe. This is not going to take money from some policies to put it on others. This is not going to take money from some regions to put it on others. I would like to remind you here of one thing: it was Jacques Delors who launched the first multiannual programme. He did so in view of the need to make a great European agenda and that it should be above national interests. That it was much more important to move forward in the solidarity of the European project. And that's the ambition we should have right now.  I ask the Heads of Government for a European vision, because we are at an important moment and we are also playing the future of the Union project right now. It is important that we understand that it is necessary to address once and for all the discourse of own resources for those additional funds that we need. It's a strong and ambitious budget. We can't do anything else with less.  We need to address European policies for young people. We need to address European policies for the primary sector, for farmers and for farmers. We need to address European policy to support new entrepreneurs, researchers. There are so many policies that Europe can respond to right now that we will not give in to the attempt to continue this issue.  Time passes and the clock runs. And for us we can say, "In this Parliament we are patient." I'm just going to say two last questions. Parliament decides on an equal footing together with the Council and we will not give in to the pressure of time because the future of the European Union is in our hands and is the most important responsibility we have at the moment.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have seen in recent years how much Europe is expected to provide answers to the challenges we face - the financial crisis, the migration crisis, climate change... Crisis after crisis, Europe is increasingly being called upon. More than ever, Europe appears to be necessary; it is therefore necessary, too, to adapt the budget to this new reality. I would like to welcome the determination and commitment of Charles Michel who, alongside the Croatian Presidency, is seeking agreement on the European budget. He has our full support to do that, but only if it is a good budget. Europe is not just a matter of commitment, as we have made many political commitments in recent years. We also need to ensure that these commitments translate into tangible facts for citizens. The adoption of a good budget shows the determination to act together. It is only when we give the budget to our political ambitions that we are credible. The effects of climate change are tangible and require solutions, as well as digital transformation, but we also need to modernise our common agricultural policy and our cohesion policy. All this calls for urgent action on the part of the European Union. I want to highlight three key points for my group. First, the size of the budget. We need the means to meet current and future challenges, and we cannot agree on great ambitions one day and, the next day, limit our ability to achieve our ambitions. It is a matter of the credibility of the European Union before the citizens to agree our political statements and our capacity to act. Second, new own resources. The 'revenue' part of the EU budget must now be modernised and aligned with the treaties. A real European budget calls for solid own resources. The last reform on this subject was made in 1988. Now is the time to rethink and modernize this budget. Third, a strong rule of law mechanism. We must have effective measures to protect the European budget, as long as European values are attacked. My group is not ready to compromise on the rule of law. Erasmus, youth employment, security and defence, border protection and migration management: all this requires a solid budget. After Brexit, after the crises we have been through, we agree on the need now to renew the euro, and the decision on the budget must be proof that we are capable of doing so. The European Parliament must not accept a compromise that undermines the credibility of a Europe capable of acting for its citizens.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a pity that President Michel is not here with us to discuss this important point, because I think he has put on the table, convening this extraordinary meeting, so much so that he has earned the initial political credit he has earned from his appointment as President of the European Council. We are therefore waiting for the new proposal to see the numbers, to see if anything has changed, but from the news we receive and from the bilateral meetings it does not seem that this proposal differs much from what was presented by the Finnish Presidency, which was a proposal that had displeased almost everyone, both the Member States in the Council, this Parliament and the Commission.  I believe that, a few months before an important deadline for the new Multiannual Financial Framework, it is appropriate to close an unnecessary dream book and have more pragmatism and realism and to accept the fact that resources are limited. The resources are limited because – and I agree with what my PPE colleague said – very often this Parliament and these institutions have not been able to implement the budget in a concrete and positive way. Not only cases of fraud, but in many cases the programmes on which much political action had been taken have not produced positive results. This is clearly reflected in a more conservative attitude on the part of the Member States. If we are unable to demonstrate the efficiency and added value of the European budget, it is normal that we should be more reluctant to give money. And then this same Parliament and these same institutions repeatedly adopted resolutions directives and regulations calling on the Member States to regulate the budget. Then we also need some consistency in order to have discipline in the management of our budget and in the management of our resources.  I believe that the priorities that are there, those that are fundamental, those that are entered in the European Treaties can be financed without requiring added resources. Agriculture, fisheries, support for regional development and cohesion policy: I believe that there is room in this budget to finance these priorities without asking for additional resources.  We can cut the EUR 20 billion of an unnecessary programme of support for structural reforms, which will only result in a constraint on the choices made by the Member States, and the EUR 13 billion allocated to pre-accession funds, especially turkey, can be drastically cut. In short, we have room to make a truly pragmatic proposal and to reach an agreement as soon as possible. To do this, however, we need pragmatism, realism and stop dreaming because the resources are not there.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the budget is a tool. But you know, you can argue about the size of the tool - a big hammer, a small hammer will always be a hammer, and when you need a screwdriver, well it doesn't help you to have a big hammer. What I mean is that what matters first is what we want to do with the European Union budget.  I very much liked what you said, Madam President, at one point. When you say', 'I will not accept a budget of less than 25% of which is spent on the fight against climate change', I would add: and if the other 75 per cent exacerbates climate change, we are obviously off the mark. I know that is not what you think, but I believe it is important to ensure that the whole European budget is coherent with the ecological and solidarity transition. And I would agree with almost 100% of what Manfred Weber said, but on the common agricultural policy, I do not agree. The aim of the Common Agricultural Policy is not to help our farmers in the globalization of agribusiness; the aim of the common agricultural policy must be to help our farmers transition to agroecology. That is where we will make the difference. The same goes for the Structural Funds, the same for the European Union's research programmes: everything must contribute to this effort.  And so the question of coherence is the first element that will allow us to judge the quality of the Council's proposal. I would remind you that this would be a proposal, not a record - just because the Council approves something does not mean that Parliament behaves like a recording chamber.  Second, as Manfred said, is the link between the budget and respect for the values of the European Union. The European Union is a union of values. Before being an economic and monetary union, before being a financial union, it is a union of values, and one cannot take advantage of the economic and financial benefits of belonging to the European Union if one does not play the air according to the rules of the game, that is, respecting the values of the Union. And we're still a long way off.  And then there's the volume. Of course, volume is a real question. I think, as Iratxe said, that Parliament's proposal is reasonable - 1.3% of GDP! Everyone knows very well that, macroeconomically, we are in short supply of investment. The Green Pact is precisely what I think will stimulate investment in the coming years. Of course, the bulk of the investment will be private investment, but there is no denying the driving and driving role that public investment must play, if only in infrastructure, such as rail. And so, of course, we need a budget that is large enough to carry out the new missions.  So I would say to the European Council, either you sign for 1.3 or 1.5, or you give us the own resources, but you cannot continue to say 'we are tightening the kiki on volume and on top of that, you are not given the opportunity to set up own resources', that is, European taxes. Last point, and I end, Mr President: I was here seven years ago and I heard at the time Joseph Daul, Martin Schulz, Guy Verhofstadt say with Daniel Cohn-Bendit: "Over our dead body! We will never accept a declining multi-year budget for the period leading up to 2020 compared to the previous period." What happened in the end? The first three accepted what they considered unacceptable.  I urge all of us to be consistent, and therefore to stand firm if the proposal that the Council will put forward after the extraordinary summit does not meet our criteria. We must not be afraid to go to conflict. There is agreement only when both agree. Parliament is not a Registration Chamber of the Council and Charles Michel would have been well advised to be present to hear this.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to add my support to the reference made by previous speakers to the desirability of President Michel being here with us today in order to have a direct talk with him on the issues we are talking about.  I do not want to make a speech listing the priorities. How can we disagree with the objectives or most of the objectives that have been set? The speeches we listen to and make are a fight against climate change. There's no one who disagrees with that, maybe we can discuss how. An intervention on innovation, an increase in resources for our young people, for researchers, I too could join a list of priorities that draw up a more beautiful, better Europe, as we all want it to be. The theme though and the knots are coming to the comb. The problems are a situation in which we have to deal with a different budget and, above all, with risks that may fall indirectly on some States, unlike others. It is clear that we are heading straight for a debate which will inevitably bring back the risk that, in order to guarantee a large part of the policies to which reference has been made as a Commission programme, we will go and cut back on certain items which are fundamental and which constitute points for this Parliament on which we cannot back down. I am thinking in particular of cohesion policy and agricultural policy. There is a lack of courage to look – as some of my fellow Members have said, and I agree – at what was the effectiveness of the previous budget. There is a lack of courage to intervene with drastic and clear cuts on certain items that have not produced any kind of result. There is a lack of a strong idea of how to develop and relaunch investment. In this sense, the debate that opened on Monday on the reform of the Stability Pact seems to me to be far removed from the rapid objectives that should also accompany the adoption of the budget.  I will close with one final thought. This morning, too, the subject of the rule of law is echoing in this House. We have who is the custodian of European values, because there is this presumption, and so we have the conviction that we can explain the criteria that stand for the rule of law and even link these values of which someone is the depositary to the possibility or not of using resources. I find all this cloying and above all not respectful of the will of the voters, because everyone in here speaks because they have popular legitimacy.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Charles Michel's absence from today's debate is unacceptable and is also a bad sign for what will come next. Mrs von der Leyen, you have presented a five-year programme and you have taken a vote of confidence from the European Parliament. It is therefore not right what Mr Hahn, sitting next to you, says that you are merely an 'honest broker' in the debate between the Council and Parliament. In order to finance the programme that you have presented, it needs at least 1.3% of European GDP, which the European Parliament is asking for by a huge majority. Otherwise it is not possible to implement the Green Deal without drastically cutting cohesion policies or the common agricultural policy, and there will be no money for innovation and investment. And we must deal not only with the slowdown in the European economy but also with the possible crisis that is coming, and we can only do this with a more ambitious budget.  And because we must speak practically, in order to achieve — the three co-legal officers — a satisfactory compromise, we must look for it on the side of what Parliament is proposing, above what the Commission is proposing, which is now obsolete, Mrs von der Leyen. Because the budget presented by the Commission, a year ago as a proposal, is 5% below the current financial framework. If we are to succeed, Mr Weber, you must be able to convince Mrs Merkel and Mr Kurz of what you have said here. You, Mr Ciolos, can convince Mr Rutte of what you said here, and you, Dear Iratxe, convince the Prime Ministers of Denmark and Sweden. Otherwise the European Parliament will be forced to vote on an unacceptable budget and this, in our opinion, must not and will not happen.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at the moment the proposal closest to our vision of the Multiannual Financial Framework is precisely that of the European Commission. We are fully in favour – as previous speakers have already said – of making a substantial contribution to the Green Deal and to policies aimed at increasing competitiveness and innovation. How could you be against it?  We also believe that the fight against migration must be supported in proportion to the real commitment of the States committed to this, but also by combating the root causes and integration policies. But all this cannot be at the expense of traditional policies, with cuts in cohesion policy and cuts in agricultural policy being the beating heart of a people's Europe. That is why the concept of an index of relative and correct prosperity and the concept of external convergence must be improved.  In any case, national contributions may not increase. The European Union must have the courage to finance itself from its own resources, finally introducing a carbon tax and introducing and implementing a genuine courageous web tax.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The budget debate is never a purely financial debate, because we are talking about the issues of future policies. Let us remember that we are in the post-Brexit period. This moment is a time when many say that you need to revise, you need to improve, you need to make up something. Only that we have different ways of reviewing. The European Parliament is strongly saying that, once the United Kingdom leaves, the European Union should, however, maintain and broaden its scope for action, and should maintain its level of ambition. The programme should correspond to what it was by adding new tasks for the future.  But in the Council we see a different approach. Some countries not only want to reduce the budget, but simply want to reduce their activities and reduce the scope of the European Union. He wants to return very often to the old idea of the British people, namely the renationalisation of certain policies. That's where the slogan comes from: we won't give more money. It is not just about the budget, but about the fact that the Union is simply going to be smaller in terms of its actions after Brexit.  The European Parliament definitely says 'no' to its majority. No, the Post-Brexit Union cannot give up its ambitions, because it will only prove that it cannot cope. The European Union must find a way to complement certain elements and find resources for new tasks, e.g. through own revenue. Once again, I wanted to say: Parliament will defend the European Union and its ambitions and will not agree to the measures leading to its gradual reduction.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Madam President, President, Secretary of State, Commissioners, the purpose of the multiannual financial framework is to reconcile political priorities with expenditure, i.e. to mobilise the resources necessary for political commitments, for commitments to citizens. We know the expectations of citizens in the European Union. They elected us so we could keep them. And the institutional cycle that has just begun has a fundamental challenge ahead: to regain the confidence of citizens in the European Union. In negotiating the multiannual financial framework we are faced with an exercise in which each Member State needs to get out of its national selfishness. But it is possible, as we have almost always shown throughout the history of the European Union, to make national interests compatible with European interests.  An opportunity that allows the political priorities that we advocate and that we have heard, systematically repeated in the political discourse of all, or almost all, European political leaders, not to be vain words, but to reflect a real political will. Just a few examples. We want to promote investment, economic growth and job creation: we have the InvestEU programme. We want to promote cohesion and combat inequalities: we have cohesion policy. We want to generate innovation and promote the transition to digital: we have Horizon Europe and Digital Europe.  We want to promote cooperation between identity education systems in each Member State and the mobility of young people: we have the Erasmus programme. We want to tackle climate change: we have cohesion policy, the CAP and the Just Transition Mechanism.  And i could go on! But for all this we need adequate funding. The direct contribution of the Member States is not sufficient. We need to compensate and increase EU funding by using own resources without penalising citizens. Finally, we don't want an institutional crisis. We are only prepared to give our consent, as we have been saying, if we have a budget that is up to political priorities and if we have a political agreement on own resources.

name: Valérie HAYER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, after two long years of procrastination, a wind of urgency is blowing in the backs of the Heads of State and Government. And it's happy. This is fortunate, because Europe is at a turning point in its history; this has already been said. The collective challenges before us are enormous; they require quick and unparalleled efforts - we all know that here. Yet, after more than 60 years of living together, the dogma of a budget of around 1% of GDP is not in question at all. As every seven years, states scramble and lock themselves into apothecary accounts: how much will I give? How much will I get, especially? Plus 0.01% here? Certainly not. Less than 0.02% there? Oh yes, definitely! It is a fact that for some states, the quest for the Grail is the reduction of their national contribution. And this obsession is facilitated, even encouraged by our funding system. Sitting at 80% on national contributions, this current funding system is perverse. To satisfy each other, we compete with ingenuity, we introduce complexities and discounts of all kinds. The task of the President of the Council is not simple, but he has our full support, as does the Commission. To solve the squaring of the circle, only one fight: that of own resources. With its own resources, once a mark of identity, national contributions will be reduced - this is the win-win solution that the President mentioned earlier. The Union will also be strengthened, with more financial autonomy to meet the priorities of Europeans. Today, let us say, this is a serious time. Stripped of its original philosophy, our financing system is experiencing an existential crisis. Let us be clear: without reform, it risks taking away all the hopes that we have based on our Union. Colleagues, the summit on 20 February will be crucial. Crucial to measure the reality of the ambitions of states before the big face-to-face with Parliament. As a negotiator for Parliament, I am committed to defending this reform for the good of our Union and the citizens of Europe.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Madam President, the multi-year financial framework and our budgetary projects are normally the financial translation of political choices and priorities. To increase the EU budget to 1.1 or 1.3% of gross national income, i.e. EUR 1,100 to EUR 1,200 billion over six years, is indeed a leak forward. The British withdrawal, which represents 12 billion annual contributions, should lead us to reduce the budget, to refocus on the essentials, that is to say on concrete projects, at the service of our peoples and our citizens. What can our citizens think of the rest of the world as a European Union that the United Kingdom has just left and which is about to question itself, but to rush to expand to Albania or Northern Macedonia? Over the past six years, the European Union has spent less than 1% of its budget on border control and the fight against immigration. Today, the draft MFF presented by the Finnish Presidency and the Commission's objectives are to sacrifice our agriculture - minus 17% of the budget allocated to it - and to increase the budget for climate targets to 25 or even 33%. But painting everything green won't solve anything. Three hundred billion euros to add standards, constraints to our companies whose competitiveness is already terribly weakened by the logic of free trade, this will further weaken them on the world stage. Mrs von der Leyen, you are telling us that you want to build this budget with the citizens of Europe, but then we have to listen to them. They expect economic protections, they wait for control of our borders, they do not want own resources that will in fact be a European tax, an extra layer to the tax mile of countries such as France, which are already at 47% of GDP in compulsory levies. It's totally unreasonable! Finally, citizens do not want a European Union which today, in order to mask its impotence, is multiplying the lessons given to the whole world: lessons of the rule of law to its Member States, conditioning the payment of financial aid on certain criteria, and lessons in human rights to the rest of the world.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Billion-poker for the EU budget – now Merkel has to fight for Germany's discount. The headlines about the multiannual budget have it all. But when the Heads of State and Government hide behind rebates and mountains of numbers, the future of the EU is really at stake. Do we want to make the EU climate neutral? Do we want to combat youth unemployment and poverty? Do we want to invest more in research and digitalisation? We Greens want this, and we therefore want to judge the proposal that Mr Michel is now preparing and which will be on the table next week, precisely on the basis of this and nothing else.  Because we know that 1.0% or 1.07% is far too little. It means cuts for the EU budget and for the issues of the future. We need more joint investment in the EU in order to make the EU climate neutral, but we also need to spend the funds in a more climate-friendly way. Less for coal and industrial agriculture, more for renewable energy and climate-friendly agriculture. For us, however, the EU is not just a money machine where everyone gets something, but for us the debate is about democracy and values, and anyone who tramples our democracy underfoot must not get money from the EU budget. That is why we need a strong rule-of-law mechanism, and we are saying quite clearly that if Viktor Orban, together with others, kicks the rule-of-law mechanism, then we will not, in the end, vote in favour of the financial framework as a Parliament as a whole. No country benefits more from a strong EU than Germany, and that is why we find the position of the German Federal Government particularly petty. Germany would be much weaker without the EU. German companies export extremely much to other EU countries and benefit from investments in all member states. That is why we want the German Federal Government to commit itself to a strong EU budget. Germany invests just 87 cents per day per Citizen of Germany in the European Union. We believe that it would be good to spend 20 or 30 cents more. We are looking forward to next week; we Greens are fighting for a strong budget and for more climate spending.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: Mr President, we are being given a huge opportunity by the current constellation of the European institutions. We have a newly elected parliament with 60% new members, there is a new Commission with steep ambitions and a freshly appointed European President. It is actually unique that we are seeing such institutional convergence at the start of the negotiations on the MFK. I would like to say once again to the Council that a majority in Parliament – with 60% new Members, as I said – cannot simply be taken for granted.  The Von der Leyen Commission sets ambitious climate targets, on digitisation, on its geopolitical role. These are priorities that are of great importance for our future, for the future of the welfare state, for our competitiveness. But there must also be resources for this. Hence the importance of this budget.  I also want to warn you about financial adventures. When I hear some Commissioners say that the Green Deal will be pushed forward in any case, whether there is funding or not, I think that is quite irresponsible. With statements like that, I think you chase away – I think – investors that you absolutely need rather than attract them.  Finally, I would also like to stress that we must ensure that the performance of all programmes is guaranteed. Every euro spent by the EU must provide added value for European citizens.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Madam President, what strikes me in these negotiations on the MFF is the lack of sense of history shown by the Heads of State. The European Union, as you know, is at a crossroads. And when the economic, demographic and climatic shifts of the world force Europe to leap forward, when the temptations of withdrawal grow everywhere, we have in the European Council heads of state who are not up to the task of this moment and who behave as small managers of a syndicate of co-owners. In the Council, there are no more great voices, nor courage for that matter, to open the way to a Europe free of austerity and able to make the most of the promises of this century and to protect peoples from the dangers that lie ahead. To not move forward is to back down and with a small budget, Europe will fall back for the next ten years - because the cost of cuts in the CAP and cohesion budget will be very high. Less cohesion will mean less growth, less investment, fewer jobs, more fractures and more poverty.  I want to end by saying that cohesion policy is a policy for the future. Of the 2014-2020 programming, almost EUR 100 billion has been invested in the environment and climate through this policy. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171, paragraph 8, of the internal regulation).)

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, I say to Mr Omarjee: in my country, in Portugal, we did turn the page of austerity, we did bring hope to our country and also to many Europeans that it was possible to turn the page of austerity.  And as you say in this new budget, it is about a new hope for Europe. It is about us delivering on the promises that we made to the Europeans that we will have a Europe of more ambition, and also the modernisation, but defending the policies in which we believe, millions of Europeans.... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: answer 'blue card'. "Dear Colleague Pedro Marques, I believe that our visions are quite convergent. It is true that cohesion policy is a policy that will participate in the new priorities set out today. And this distinction between traditional and new politics, in reality, is a distinction that has no real basis.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the budget debate is marked by great interests and mined for the people. The militarisation of the European Union is intensifying with funds and mechanisms, countries, sectors and groups are being forced to benefit more from their competitors in the brexit territory. Groups are subsidised in the name of digital transition, in order to widen work-life, redundancies and poverty. In Greece, with Trojan horse funds from the European Union, the New Democracy government — followed by SYRIZA — closes the lignite units leading to unemployment of more than five thousand workers and depriving the country of the possibility of exploiting domestic sources, while strengthening the dependence on imported energy that the people pay for. The Green Deal and the new — even more reactive — CAP promote the profitability of groups and the integration of bio-populist farmers by reducing their aid. We are not surprised by the class unpopular nature of the budget, which is why we support the workers' struggle for their own needs against business groups and unpopular policy. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, my dear colleague, I understand that you are opposeing the common agricultural policy, you say that someone would benefit. Do you think that from the new budget, in the new financial framework, we should reduce the money for this budget, or would it be better to find, to bring money from tax evasion, from economic crime, from VAT evasion, so as not to reduce the budget on Agricultural Policy?

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, in any case, the beneficiaries of the new CAP will also be the business groups. After all, it is the pillar of capitalist investment that is being strengthened and what is shrinking is the proportion of aid to small and medium-sized farmers. Small and medium-sized farmers are the victims, once again, and it is the groups that win. This is the new line, which is a continuation of the previous CAP and will further intensify the problems for small and medium-sized farmers, whose only way is to organise their fight before it is too late.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Madam President, we have been waiting for the Council meeting since November 2018. Better late than never! We need sufficient financial resources to have a cohesive, supportive, competitive, productive European Union, a European Union where there is sustainable and environmentally friendly growth. The new own resources are the solution. New own resources that have to put an end to the logic of just retour and which will allow us to have the necessary level for the European Union budget and which cannot penalise the citizens of the European Union. And so there is a very simple principle: those who do not pay must pay. That is why we defend the fee on financial transactions. That is why we also advocate a tax on the big digital companies. In addition, the carbon market, the emissions of that market, and, moreover, at borders, the carbon market will also be an important recipe for the European Union. I hope that the Council will be up to it and that it will not betray the citizens of the European Union, that it will not harm farmers, the poorest regions, rural development and also help to grow that is environmentally friendly. This is an obligation of the Council which, if not respected, we will reject its proposal.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: – Madam President, the truth is that we have been talking about the financial framework for two years and, of course, now that the time for truth comes, we do not start very well. We do not start well because Mr Michel did not want to come and listen to this Parliament. And we do not start well because what comes to us from the Council is not very positive. If your discussions are going to focus on how many hundredths we are going to save here or there, what can be saved is the Council, because this Parliament is going to reject that proposal. What they have to discuss on 20 February is what policies we want to do at European level and how we are going to finance them. And there are many reasons to make policies at European level: because the results are better if they are done at European level than at national level, that is, because Europe is more efficient; because inequalities are reduced, i.e. Europe is more supportive; or because it can only be done at European level and therefore Europe is the only solution. And in all cases we win, all of us, all of Europe. So, frankly, I do not understand why the Council's discussions continue to be based on false premises. But, beyond this accounting debate, what we have and what concerns me is the political debate because how do you intend to carry out all your discussions and all your Council agreements? And I will take one example: the European Green Pact. How are you going to fund it? Because if some of you believe that the transition to a carbon-neutral economy is going to be made without supporting our farmers, without supporting our companies, without supporting our regions and without supporting our workers, you have a real problem. And I only tell you one thing: if we do not have a reasonable budget, the alternative is political irrelevance, economic irrelevance and the failure of the European project.

name: Moritz KÖRNER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Most people here are just talking about a bigger budget. I think we need to talk about a better budget. And that is possible if we really prioritise expenditure with real European added value. It is about the worker in an industrial company who is worried about his job. He can expect and hope that we will invest in innovation and digitalisation, so that better and good jobs and added value will also be created in Europe in the future. It's about the old lady who is worried, scared of terrorism. They can expect us to fund Europol and Eurojust decently so that they can fight terrorism and crime. And it is about every student, every trainee in Europe, who can actually make a trip abroad with Erasmus throughout Europe, so that Europe can grow together at this point. Incidentally, it must also be clear that if we carry out meaningful additional tasks at European level, it sometimes also means that we in the Member State must also think about where we can then make appropriate savings. We must also discuss this, and the Member States must discuss this at this point. It is also clear, however, that there must be no rebate in Europe on the rule of law. It is unacceptable that some states should be happy to take European money and then trample European rules and values underfoot. That is why we need a robust rule of law mechanism, not one, the game ball is of any political games, but where it is objectively stated that if the rule of law is not respected, then there can be no money. This is also what taxpayers in Europe expect us to deal with European money in a decent way.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to say to all the EU fanatics who are now calling for more and more millions for the European Union: it cannot be the right reaction after the British have left us as a large country to call for even more money. A smaller Union logically also requires fewer resources, and that is something that should be prepared for.  Nor have you answered the question of whether we now want to transfer more competences to Brussels or whether more competences are returning to the Member States. In fact, this question has not been answered since 2016, when, after the shock of the Brexit referendum, the Commission presented five scenarios for a possible future and no answer has been given to this day. Now, in 2020, after a frightening second of more than four years, a future conference is finally beginning. However, it does not start at the beginning of the year, but sometime in the middle of the year and will last until 2022. So the question of calling for more money now is a completely unnecessary one, since the answer cannot be given as to where the European Union is going.  However, there is clarity in the Lisbon Treaty, for example: the Commission's reduction of one third. They are all in default to deliver accordingly. Fewer Commissioners, that is, less directives, less bureaucracy and therefore less costs. As a representative of a net contributor, I am not prepared to hand over one cent more to this European Union.

name: David CORMAND
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the budget debate is a debate about our future. Its technicality sometimes puts off citizens, so I mean things as simply as possible, so that it is no longer possible to ignore the issues. The European Union's budget for the next seven years is the one that will or will not enable Europe to respond to the climate and social emergency. It must therefore necessarily be a combat budget.  A combat budget is an overall budget that increases at least 1.3% of gross national income to give the European Union the means to carry out its ecological transition. A combat budget is a budget of which at least 50% is spent on environmental protection to preserve the climate. Finally, a combat budget puts the tax tool at the service of social justice and ecological transition, for example by properly taxing carbon emissions, kerosene and financial transactions. These taxes will then be able to feed into their own budgetary resources. For two euros raised by these taxes, one euro would go into the national coffers and the remaining euro would be returned to the European budget. It would be both a victory for political Europe and a mark of a desire to break out of an irresponsible model that leads us straight into the wall. It is high time to go down this road.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: – Madam President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs First of all, if there are countries in the European Council that do not want to contribute more than 1% of national income to the budget but want to see a federal European development, then it should be recalled that it will not work: the US federal budget is well above 20% of national income. Unfortunately, in the budget spending debate, the lines are being contrasted: old policies, such as cohesion and agriculture, against new, more prospects, which should be given more money. Although, if we analyse, for example, research and development of the military industry, it would be better to finance from national budgets, because it will also remain in a few countries. But, going back to cohesion, if we think of it: a new ambitious citizen of the Cohesion Of the European Union learns that his cohesion envelope will be 25% less in this new perspective than in the old one, then he will leave. He will go to development centres in Western Europe, and with it the demographic situation and development opportunities on the periphery of cohesion countries will become even worse than they are now, and demographics in general.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: – Madam President, the Commission and the Council came here today to announce cuts in cohesion and agriculture, to mislead citizens about the new Green Pact and to blackmail Parliament with the specof of an institutional crisis. There is no new money for the new Green Pact. What there are are cuts, proposals for cuts, in the policies that could implement it and a budgetary quidthat is counting the old money twice. There is still money, yes, for the old Brown Pact and fossil energy financing. And there is new money, yes, but for the militarization of Europe, that is, for the German and French arms industry. If there is an institutional crisis it will happen because the Commission and the Council do not want to put the money from the European Union where they put their speeches, because they talk about social and environmental objectives, but that is not where they really want to invest.

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Madam President, I would also like to start off by expressing my regret that the President of the Council is not present in this debate. I was extremely happy to see the priorities of the Commission last year, especially the ones that were designed to improve European competitiveness through strengthening European solidarity via the social pillar. It would be a disastrous message if the adoption of the budget were to be delayed or if there were not sufficient funds to cover the implementation of the objectives. Ms von der Leyen said that it is extremely important to get the balance right between all the new priorities and all the new objectives. However, new objectives, especially the ones that seek to improve the EU’s positions in global competition, can only be achieved if the old objective of cohesion is completed. Europe cannot function with economic and structural differences. They have to be eliminated or reduced. We cannot possibly look bravely into the future if a social and a wage gap exists between Member States. Therefore, we must strengthen our cohesion instruments and the EPP ought to fight corruption.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, the person preparing the budget of the European Union for the next seven years is the President of the European Council, Charles Michel. He has to be in Parliament. If he has no mandate, if he has nothing to tell us, at least he should come and listen. Why? Because the last word on the EU budget for the next seven years lies with the European Parliament. We will only give our approval to the EU budget if our priorities are in. And what are our priorities? Firstly, cohesion and agriculture: finance them properly, they continue to be important all over Europe. Secondly, finance the new priorities of the Union, in line with the political ambition. The Commission asks for support in financing future-oriented priorities. Let me tell you what happened to the budget for research this year. The Council says research is important. What does it do? It cuts it by EUR 500 million. Parliament says research is important, but we increased it by EUR 700 million. We need to put our money where our statements are, and we should not play farmers against Erasmus students. We should not play researchers against the security of the European Union. And let’s be honest: the position of the European Parliament is the only position which enables us to finance properly what we have agreed to do. It’s the only position which enables the von der Leyen Commission to implement its programme. Dear colleagues, the Parliament can be included in the negotiations before the European Council on 20 February. Or we can reject the agreement of the Council and we should be included afterwards, but we prefer it to be included before. And let me say very clearly, if we are to choose between a delay of two months and a poor budget for the Union for the next seven years, we will choose to reject a bad Council compromise and have a delay of two months. But we are ready to negotiate since November 2018. Council, stop dragging your feet.

name: Elisabetta GUALMINI
text: – Madam President, it is really time to stand up and act and the Multiannual Financial Framework is really the last opportunity we have to change Europe for the next seven years and to shock our European citizens – yes, to shock them, to shock every single person in the EU – because we have to increase the total amount of available resources, not renounce it to 1.3 of GNI in order for our promises to become true: a Green New Deal, the additional unemployment benefit and the Child Guarantee of six billion. No one dares to take away from children what are their basic rights – food, health and education – and the traditional mainstream European programmes have to be financed as well, so we cannot deal with a war between the poor – agricultural policies, cohesion policies, Erasmus, have to be financed as well. And on the revenue side, let us think also of a digital tax and the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax for multinationals.  On this side of the Hemicycle we believe in more Europe and not less. We believe in more public investments and not in cutting down and downsizing. We believe in a good society which is a society for the many and not for the few, so the European Council has to listen to our voice.

name: Clotilde ARMAND
text: – Madam President, I want to talk about three issues relating to cohesion funds. The first aspect: the volume of these funds. If from a hundred euros a country like Romania absorbs 60 euros, from 60 euros it will absorb 36 euros. The investment will be insignificant, the impact will be small. The second aspect: co-financing and pre-financing rates. If the level of these pre-financing and co-financing rates increases, there are some States that will simply give up cohesion funds. The third aspect is the length of time during which payment applications may be submitted. At present it is three years. If it drops sharply to two years, in the context of delays in the current budget, it will also have an impact on absorption – a negative impact.

name: Paolo BORCHIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, every seven years we see this game of the parties, where on the one hand there are the pragmatics, the realists, the ones who have to make ends meet, on the other hand there are some smoke salesmen who, on the other hand, pretend to be ambitious. But these days it's realism that's needed. This morning, frankly, I heard little realism. I have heard wishes for a thousand and one nights. I have heard about a budget that reduces inequality, pollution and unemployment, in short, a long and expensive wish list.  But those who have the ability to administer public life first begin to reflect on waste and inefficiencies. In fact, for years now, we have been stressing the need for priority to be given to the most effective budgetary policies, from business to agriculture, research and innovation. But on time, when it comes to cutting funding for the External Action Service, for example, which is an unnecessary duplication of national embassies, or reducing contributions to Turkey, of which the European Union has become the ATM, this House suddenly becomes deaf.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Madam President, I say to the Presidency: don’t you feel it’s Groundhog Day? Some are defending in the Council the cohesion funds, the others the agriculture funds, and then you have countries that want less money. But where is the fundamental discussion about modernisation? Where is the discussion that we are really preparing our economy for a green deal? Where is the discussion on the fundamentals of the rule of law? Where is that discussion? I challenge those countries that will have a big mouth about modernisation afterwards. I challenge Finland, Sweden, Denmark, Germany, Netherlands, Austria. If you want modernisation, if you want a new economy, if you want to have rule of law, you cannot exchange that for just a penny or some percentage points. This is about the fundamentals of our future. This should not be about 0.1% more or less. That is what our British friends would call ‘penny wise, pound foolish’.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. We Conservatives believe that cohesion policy funding for the period 2021-2027 should be the same as in 2014-2020. Co-financing at current pre-financing rates should also be maintained. A reduction in cohesion appropriations is unacceptable and will cause turbulence between the two programming periods. In addition, we have Brexit. It gives us the opportunity to lift discounts from 2021. All Member States should contribute on the basis of the same principles. The reasons behind the current correction mechanisms are no longer valid. The structure of expenditure has changed and there are no Member States with an excessive burden. Currently, countries benefiting from rebates contribute around 0.70% of their gross national income, while other Member States, mostly less developed, contribute 85%. A Fair Transition Fund should be introduced, although its funding should not come at the expense of other policies.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Unlike the Commission and many of my fellow Members who are always crying out for more European money, we believe that Europe must put its mouth right for the packed lunch. We do not accept an increased EU levy or a runaway EU budget. The EU budget must be converted within the existing framework, nor must it be 'boosted' by its own increased resources. We are not opposed, for example, to climate taxes, of course, but they are needed for the welfare of the Member States. Other demands that must be imposed on the EU's long-term budget are as follows: all funds must be climate tested, not a single euro for climate-damaging activities, the Structural Funds must resubmit in order to deliver climate justice, the EU's corrupt and inefficient agricultural policy must be fundamentally redesigned, no funding for Fortress Europe, Erdogan, the border police, and no funding for the European war industry. It is a shame that the new Commission wants to militarise EU cooperation. Finally, make the EU budget conditional on the rule of law and democracy. No money for Member States that do not respect fundamental values.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: Madam President, we are calling for a better, bigger budget and a Commission with greater powers. But this implies greater democratic legitimacy. We will only achieve a genuine European budget, in line with our ambitions, if we are able to give the Commission direct democratic legitimacy. This multi-year financial framework represents at best 11% of continental GDP. How can we build a united Europe with such a low budget? Catalonia is a net contributor to the European budget and we want to continue this way, but without the intermediation of Spain. For the 2021-2027 financial outlook, a few priorities: focus on research and innovation, which are the oil of our century; conditioning the allocation of cohesion funds on respect for the rule of law and democracy; Combating climate change combating social and economic inequalities, etc.  Similarly, when will we have the courage to build a real system of own resources? The carbon tax, the digital tax, the financial transaction tax should be used to feed a European budget. Democratic legitimacy, political powers and financial capacity are the three sides of a triangle on which the future of the Union depends.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The way in which the Council is currently handling the multiannual financial framework is extremely problematic. A bit of cohesion, a bit of agriculture, no ambition for science and research, preferably less Erasmus, 1.0 is the maximum, as many programmes as possible, but underfunding as much as possible – that is the motto. Each one on its part, just me for myself. That is not enough! We must approach the EU in terms of tasks. This means that we need to invest more in science and research, we must also get the cohesion countries to invest more in science and research, and we must help them to invest more in science and research. Because if we do not invest in the sector, then – quite dry and sober – we will no longer be competitive with China, then we will not be competitive with the United States, then we will not be able to do our job either. We must have a task-based approach. If we carry out tasks such as external border protection, this must be properly financed and also given proper competences. If they want to pay less, then please let the Council say what tasks it wants to delete, which agency it no longer wants, what tasks it no longer claims from the European Union. But giving more tasks and then lower funding – that cannot work. Wanting to tackle climate change, but at the same time not going into science and research, cannot work either. The Just Transition Fund cannot solve everything. I would ask the Member States to finally move away from national spectacles and to deal clearly with the European perspectives and with the tasks that are ahead of us.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Madam President, because we are combining less and less budget with more and more expectations, we are getting more and more disappointment and less and less Europe. This is the situation we are in, when we need more Europe to bring more efficiency, more cohesion and improve the daily lives of European citizens.  But to make more Europe, we need to invest in this Europe. However, it is clear that the opposite is happening. The European Green Pact and the mechanism for a just transition that we expect so much are scuttled from the outset, and with them the cohesion policy and the future common agricultural policy, which we will have to reform in the light of global warming. Yes, because global warming is there, very real, and the Green Pact must be a real opportunity to profoundly change the economic model.  In this context, it is crucial to associate the own resource agenda with that of the Green Pact. Europe must give itself the means to reform itself, but I note that, despite the Commission's support in this fight, the Council is not up to the task of the general interest, as the general interest is often subordinate to special interests. So I appeal to the presidency of the Council. It is no longer time for selfishness, nor to sum up special interests, nor for cosmetic retouching or small measures that solve only small problems of consciousness. It is time for a real European ambition. There are concrete actions to raise the bar and give ourselves the means. And these means is first of all to obtain a financial framework and a budget to live up to this ambition.  Ladies and gentlemen of the Council, stop playing with your little arms! At this level of power and in view of the legitimate expectations of European citizens as well as the urgency of the situation, this is no longer acceptable - it is even now irresponsible.

name: Ondřej KNOTEK
text: – Madam President, let me say that the proposals for the financial framework presented so far do not correspond to the ideas of a large number of citizens. And please, that has to change. The 17 EU countries belong to a group that advocates maintaining funding for cohesion policy and agriculture at its current level. We cannot agree that less developed countries should draw less money in the next period than they have so far. It is also unacceptable that investment in cohesion, infrastructure and agriculture should fall and, at the same time, central programmes should be increased, quite fundamentally. It is important that Member States can, to a large extent, decide for themselves what to use the money for. The European Commission must listen more closely to the needs of the Member States and should set their priorities as little as possible. The 17 EU states want cohesion, investment, including investment in basic infrastructure. Please, this must not be overlooked.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for I am a little surprised at the tone of the debate, because the subject is actually: preparation for the special European Council on 20 February on the Multiannual Financial Framework. But what are we doing here? We are really damaging the relevant party here, the Council, by complaining that Mr Michel is not here. I do not know whether this is conducive to the outcome, and whether it is also conducive to the negotiations. I think we just have to get back to what we really want, what we really want. And it is clearly a question of having only a limited framework, only limited funds, which we must use. Let us finally stop chasing the sparrow in our hands now – or not be satisfied with the dove chasing after the dove on the roof. Let us be content with the sparrow in our hands and let the Council decide now what happens. The 1.7% or 1.11% is really enough.

name: Petra DE SUTTER
text: – Madam President, the next seven years will be crucial. They will determine how our children will live on this planet. Our societies have to undergo a digital and ecological transition in a socially fair way, and we need sufficient funds for this. The EU budget is more than a membership fee. It is the mirror of our political ambitions. Therefore, a massive investment boost is needed without necessarily increasing Member States’ resources. We shouldn’t be afraid to go and get own resources from plastic polluters, carbon emissions, big financial transactions, and a fair share from multinationals and kerosene because, if we don’t find additional money to realise the ambitions of the Green Deal, citizens will feel it. They will see fewer infrastructure works happening in their region or have fewer opportunities to get reskilled after they have lost their jobs. If we want our citizens to embrace the European project, this must be reflected in our budget.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: Mr President, the multiannual budget is clearly out of control, we have seen that. The British are leaving and the budget is suddenly going up again. The Netherlands has been the largest net contributor per capita since 2000. And now that contribution is even increased by 62%, to 13 billion gross. That's a huge amount. That means 1 600 euros per year per household in the Netherlands. That's priceless.  Then I wonder: where are the members of the CDA and the VVD to stand up for that Dutch citizen? I've been sitting here all morning and I haven't seen anyone. I'll grab my glasses for a minute to see where they are. There's one. Have you spoken, ma'am, because you're sitting there like a pudding now?  So let me make it clear, and then let me stand up for the Dutch citizen. I say Prime Minister Rutte, use your veto. Show courage, as Austria does, and finally say no, and flush this budget down the toilet.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, at the Table of the European Council the so-called "net budget taxpayers" who, with more ownership, should be called 'net beneficiaries of integration', know that time is running out of time. They are playing with the pressure of the delay in cohesion funds and the damage it would cause to the countries that depend most on these funds to make inevitable a proposal that is, in fact, unacceptable. Now, if it's unacceptable, it can't be inevitable.  For the countries of cohesion this is the time to turn the game, remind those who refuse to make the right contribution to the budget that an integration that only produces inequality and divergence is doomed to have no future. Remember that if cohesion policy has not been enough to halt the divergence in the past, then it needs to be strengthened and not weakened. Denounce that the so-called "new priorities" of the budget are a way for the wealthiest countries there to get more money. For the countries of cohesion this is the time to realise that on the day they decide to assert their dignity and sovereignty, they will have much more to gain than what can come from the budget.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, Mrs von der Leyen, speaking here about financing and financial policies, I cannot help but say how environmental policy in Croatia is financed, i.e. I will focus on the waste management system.  We in Croatia plan to build 11 waste management centers, two of which have already been made, Marišćina and Kaštijun, and we have received nothing from them except pollution and a large increase in bills. Now you're forcing these other nine. Why are these capital failures coming? First, the common environmental policy is wrong. Let's just consider Germany and Croatia. Croatia has only 75 inhabitants per kilometer squared, Germany 230. There is also a large income gap. We can't pay what you can. After all, we don't need to, we have some specifics of our own. There's also corruption, everything we do backwards. Instead of being recycled as much as can be done, it's like nothing's being recycled. The centers are oversized, of course they are overpaid, because the point is to get as much money as you can for the clients of the Croatian establishment. The end product will be rdf that we will have no one to sell to. All this will spill over into the accounts of the inhabitants who go to heaven and thus empty Croatia.
