What was not achieved in the Homeland War, Croatia is emptied through the accounts of the expensive.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab History is supposedly not repeated, but in the case of the MFF, it is repeated in a way that is unfavourable to the European Parliament. Since the commission's proposal, which has been in place since May 2018, Parliament has been in a very uncomfortable wait and see position and rightly does not continue to negotiate sectoral projects, because it is difficult to talk about rules if the figures are not known. Budgets are numbers, not declarations.  Now everything is in the hands of President Michel. He is absent today, so we will not know whether his meetings with the leaders of the Member States, known as confessionals in budgetary slang, have led to a rapprochement or not. If they led, then some chance of success has an extraordinary peak on February 20 and a new negotiating box, but I remember that we never managed to reach an agreement the first time, so we will not find out today.  What we know, however, is that the delay is greater than ever. The 2014-2020 perspective was agreed between governments on 8 February and Parliament in June. This calendar seems little real this year. However, the worst case scenario is a long-term tender between the institutions. People don't like it, it builds a bad image in the European Union, because the beneficiaries want to be predictable to invest. This is the biggest advantage of the European budget.

name: Pierre LARROUTUROU
text: Madam President, 'whatever it takes': in 2012, Mario Draghi explains that the central bank is ready to do whatever is necessary to save the eurozone. And the central bank is going to put $2,600 billion on the table. 2,600 billion euros in four years to save the eurozone. And to save the climate, how much are we going to put in? Saving the single currency, of course, was very important, but saving our unique planet, saving our unique humanity, is it not even more important? Are we, too, prepared to do, whatever it takes, whatever it will be needed to succeed in the Green Pact, a just transition? The Commission itself says that between 300 billion and 500 billion euros are needed each year to succeed in the Green Pact. Every year, there is a shortfall of between 300 and 500 billion euros and, for the moment, what is concrete is a fund for a fair transition with 7 billion over seven years. The solution would be to develop their own resources to have a very ambitious 'climate' budget, without asking for a euro from modest families or Member States. When I was a kid, the income tax was 45% in Europe. Today, income tax has fallen to 20%, while dividends are exploding. It is time to move forward on own resources. A real green pact or greenwashing: it is in the coming months that it is decided.

name: Jérémy DECERLE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, those who know that I am not only French, but also a farmer and former agricultural representative, will not be surprised if I stress the crucial issue of the budget for the common agricultural policy. However, I believe that it is in the interest of the whole of Europe that I am speaking.  That in order to finance the new legislative ambitions of the European Union, one is tempted to make cuts in historical policies, I can imagine. However, this would be a serious mistake, for three simple reasons. All the world's major agricultural powers strongly support their agriculture and we have a responsibility to be up to the task. The ongoing agroecological transition, which the Green Pact will accompany, cannot be successful without a CAP that gives itself the means. The CAP budget also depends, as I recall, on the quality and diversity of our food, the balance of our rural areas, and also the maintenance of many farmers.  These are not small issues. The CAP budget must not go down. Thank you for listening to me; I will thank you even more for hearing me.

name: Ivan DAVID
text: – Madam President, the European Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Policy is unhappy with the low economic growth in the euro area, just 1.1%.  I would therefore expect a number of measures so that the EU does not be so behind China and the United States in growth. But what does the EU propose? Donate 40% of the budget to the Green Deal chimeric project, which will not help the environment and will harm the economy. By switching to electromobility and renewables, the European Commission is going to subvert energy and transport at the same time, the the thus reducing Europe's competitiveness. Then let him show satisfaction over stagnation or rather decline. The effort, directly from Brussels, to support unelected pressure groups, called non-profit organisations, points to a stance on democracy. Migration is to be encouraged instead of its own inhabitants. Agricultural and rural expenditure is to be reduced. In 2004, following the accession of the new Member States, it promised to balance European agricultural subsidies by 2013, but this has not yet happened. How much longer is such a policy supposed to take to summon the righteous wrath of the citizens?

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: –Dear President, I would like to call on everyone to step back from the figures. The objectives are key to deciding on the multiannual financial perspective. Will we no longer seek a good standard of living for the population in all regions? Looking at the numbers, it seems that this is the case, because cohesion is being cut very significantly. Will we tolerate some farmers being considered second-class? This seems to be the case, as the Commission's proposal does not harmonise direct payments. Are we the most important of individual countries, not common goals? This issue also concerns the debate on the level of the Member States' contribution to the general budget. I agree that the European Union has new challenges, but new challenges and need to be financed with new money. Because funding from specific areas can only be withdrawn if there is a general consensus that it makes no sense to carry them out.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. The cuts proposed by the previous Commission in the EU budget for the two most important policies, cohesion by 10% and the CAP by 15%, have just been rejected in a position adopted at the beginning of February in Portugal by 17 countries from the Group of Friends of Cohesion. It is therefore necessary to increase the budget both by increasing membership fees and by eliminating existing rebates, and perhaps also by mobilising new sources of own revenue.  A compromise in the Council in this regard is possible, but provided that we move away from negotiations based on the 'net payer vs. net beneficiaries' design, and we also take into account the benefits of individual EU countries from participation in the common market, as well as capital flows. Net payers generally benefit very heavily from the share of the common market. Germany, for example, pays EUR 27 billion in contributions per year and the benefits of the common market amount to as much as EUR 210 billion per year. In addition, western European countries are benefiting from the enlargement of the Union. One of them is dividends and interest on capital. Only taking all these flows into account gives me the opportunity, in my opinion, to have a rational conversation about the shape of the future budget and a chance for an agreement.

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: – Dear Chairman, colleagues and colleagues, a successful Europe of the next generation is only possible through even stronger investments in both entrepreneurship and research, development, youth and education. We need to ensure that our continent adapts to the digital revolution, but also prepare for an accelerated race to implement new technologies with increasingly powerful global competitors.  At the same time, the next seven-year budget of the European Union must continue to reduce the economic and social disparities that unfortunately still exist between Member States, as this is precisely one of the key objectives that has been enshimied in the very foundations of the European Union. This is also why the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union explicitly emphasises that special attention is paid to regions exposed to serious demographic difficulties, as well as to areas affected by the industrial transition.  We cannot ignore the negative demographic trends that threaten the development of much of Europe. It is time for the European budget to recognise that both for cohesion and for the real equality of all European citizens, it is also necessary to support demographically disadvantaged parts of Europe through European instruments.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, next week the Special European Council will address a straight issue: what resources the European Union will have at its disposal from 2021 to 2027 to meet the new challenges we face and to give European citizens a more environmentally sustainable, fairer, safer and more modern society. Parliament has called for an adequate budget. So far, the response from governments has been insufficient. On the one hand, we assign new tasks and responsibilities to Europe, which governments cannot cope with on their own, but then we keep our purse strings tight. As if to say: do more but without resources. The perfect recipe to allow us to continue to use the European project as the best of scapegoats for things that are wrong. What we are doing here is not a budget, but the credibility of the Union itself. We therefore call on the Presidency of the Council to take the message of this House to the Heads of State or Government. We immediately expect a reversal of the trend, just play with the future of the Union, with the future of all of us.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We must ask ourselves: what challenges do we actually face? That challenge may sound like this: we are facing the challenge of creating a new industrial ecosystem. So this is not science fiction, this is not Jules Verne, this is not Aldous Huxley, this is not Isaac Asimov, but this is the reality we are facing. Firstly, we need a budget that is Paris-compliant, a green deal financial framework for the coming years. In addition, we need a research budget that stands up to the challenges we face, and that research budget must be in line with the Research Budget of the Member States. This is therefore no small task for the Council, but if the Council cannot resolve it, we are in shame.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I ask you: do you think that the Italians are stupid? Are you going to make fun of the citizens endlessly? Do you think that the Italians should be subjected to the robberies carried out by Europe in silence? You are completely off the road, dear European bureaucrats, because the Italians are tired of being europe's ATM and being robbed of billions of euros every year. We are all tired of seeing how Europe gives our money to The Islamic dictator Erdogan's Turkey, or to some NGO that takes illegal immigrants home.  It's a big shame, but you're preparing even worse! For the next seven years you are ready to put a new tax on our citizens, a tax that you are trying to disguise as 'own resources' and ultimately you want to rip us off with the ESA as well. Be careful, however, the patience of the Italians is over! And we will do everything we can to stop the madness of this Europe.

name: Veronika VRECIONOVÁ
text: – Madam President, I am a Member of the European Parliament from the Czech Republic, a country that ranks among the so-called friends of cohesion. Nevertheless, in all this, I am much closer to the European Commission's original proposal than to the European Parliament's version. The reason is simple, the higher expenditure that the European Parliament is currently counting on means higher revenues. But clean payers do not want to increase their contributions to the common budget, and one of the strong countries, Britain, left last week. Efforts will therefore continue to make additional own resources for the European Union, and we are hearing this in today's debate, and I consider that to be wrong. The European Union is not a state, it is an international organisation created by individual states, which should act according to the commissions of these states. We cannot circumvent the will of these states by taxing their people directly. We will not increase the Competitiveness of the European Union through further redistribution, we will increase it by promoting innovation and better infrastructure. The final version should thus be similar to the original version of the Commission.

name: Niclas HERBST
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for When we look at the gallery, we see many young people who are pinning their hopes on Erasmus, in research and development, on the fight against climate change. I am also particularly pleased that we see many soldiers who are ready to give their lives. We owe them an answer in the area of foreign and security policy, and that can only be done with a properly equipped multiannual financial framework, because it sets the planks. Charles Michel now says that he does not want to leave the negotiators until a solution is found on 20 February. He must not forget that he must also take us into account. When we hear, for example, that the cohesion states – that is, the states that particularly benefit from cohesion policy – should be given more flexibility in the implementation system, that is a good thing, but it is not a solution for sufficient resources. When we hear that we, as budgetary legislators, should be given more flexibility, that is a good thing, but it is not a substitute for a lack of resources. It is now very important that we do not play a game, such as 'we, as the European Parliament, give you too little resources for too many tasks, and you may end up with budgetary flexibility to decide who you are hurting most'. We are all in the same boat here, and I would ask that Charles Michel be set up if any of my colleagues were to meet him by 20 February. This is very important: we are sitting together in a boat; and we must now move forward step by step, systemic issues can be resolved afterwards. Now the real focus is on the issue of equipment.

name: Rovana PLUMB
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, of course, the Budget of the European Union must be a solid one and reflect our ability to support the necessary developments in each of the Member States, but also the response to new challenges. Moreover, I believe that it should not be limited to a mathematical exercise, but to continue the projects we need.  Cohesion policy – cohesion policy for which the European Parliament has already expressed its view \u2012 must not be reduced or relocated in any way as a result of the emergence of new initiatives, such as the Fund for a Just Transition, which, of course, must have all the necessary resources so that this transition is fair.  And, if we refer to the field of transport, the main financing instrument, the Connecting Europe Facility, also for him, the European Parliament has expressed its position and also it must not be diminished, because everything that means budget is a matter of our credibility in the face of challenges, in the face of European citizens.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: – Madam President, Europe is now facing an existential crisis. We see populist matches grow in every election - right now we've just seen it in Ireland with Sinn Féin. We see that, in the case of economic growth, this week all the data we have had is bad: European economies are severing. We see that we don't have the banking union finished. We see that, really, with the uk's exit we lose a key member for Europe. And in the midst of this existential crisis, we find a budget that we fear may be the lowest in history in proportion to GDP. We have a lot of challenges and we're not going to have the resources to deal with them. Part of the problem is this ongoing discussion between net contributors and those who receive, which in the end does not allow us to move forward.  We need a system of own resources. A system of own resources that helps us solve the problems we face: climate change and tax evasion. This Parliament will not approve an MFF agreement that does not address these problems while solving the problem of Europe's financing forever, which cannot depend on these negotiations which always leave us below our needs.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Madam President, the European project will not be stronger with a weaker European Union. That is why the news coming to us from the Commission and the Council on a proposal from the Multiannual Financial Framework is not good. Reducing the CAP, reducing the Cohesion Funds or the European Social Fund is driving those who need it most away from the Union. Spanish farmers and ranchers suffer from the growing demands, including the European Green Pact, and with one hand they demand more competitiveness but, with the other hand, it is intended to reduce the funding they need, such as the CAP. Or, for example, young people, who are the most harmed in Spain, reaching an unemployment rate of 30%. On the one hand, they are told that they are the future of Europe but, on the other hand, they aim to reduce the European Social Fund, dedicated to the employment of these young people. And, in the face of the digital challenge, depopulation, the need to promote industry, SMEs and the connectivity of our regions, it is incoherent to try to leave our regions with fewer funds for their development and cohesion. Member States play a key role. Therefore, as a Spanish delegation of the European People's Party, we demand that the Government of Sánchez not remain crossed-minded, that the battles that are not lost are lost, and the socialist governments are too accustomed to us to return to Spain empty-handed. The cuts in Structural Funds, Cohesion Funds and agricultural funds would particularly hit Spain and, therefore, the People's Party, we will be firm, as always, in defending the interests of Spain's productive and economic sectors. We're going to give the battle.

name: Erik BERGKVIST
text: Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for After all, this is strange. We have great opportunities. We have never had such great opportunities as now to create a better Europe. 70 years of cooperation and joint efforts have created a prosperity, peaceful development and opportunities that we probably never thought we would have, and everything indicates that continued cooperation and joint efforts will actually make everything even better.  The threat or what sometimes creeps out of the sewers is fear, nationalism, populism. If we fall back to it, it is clear that nothing is possible. But if we think it away for a while, we are actually the world's largest economy – a huge welfare region with a technology that actually makes it possible to solve the challenges that we face today. But it has to be done fairly. This must be done with a actually expanded and stronger cohesion policy. We must never fall back to greater nationalism. François Mitterrand said: Nationalism is war. War is a thing of the past, but it can also be our future. You are the guarantor of peace and security.

name: Caroline NAGTEGAAL
text: Mr President, the European Union is entering a make-or-break phase in its existence at the moment: are we going to give in to yesterday's vested interests, or do we finally dare to choose the shared interest of all Europeans of this future. If it's up to me, it'll be the last. Let the Union dare to focus on the common challenges we face: migration, security, infrastructure, climate. For that, Europeans are looking at this Union and they want to be able to count on this Union of 27 Member States for that. An automatic reflex for a higher budget is not appropriate for a smaller Union. Take a very good look at how we can spend the money better and ensure that countries with an equal level of prosperity can also contribute equally to the European budget. Let us work hard for strict conditions on this European funding. For example, if there is fraud or corruption in a country, or the rules on democracy and the rule of law are not observed, turn the money tap on as far as I am concerned. Let's stay away from a discussion between East and West, North and South, but bet on a future-proof Europe that fits this: Let's make it together.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support First of all, the Finnish Government has really messed this up. Thanks to the suboptimal performance of the Finnish Presidency, we are now further away from the agreement than in the work of the Bulgarian, Romanian and Austrian Presidencies. The permanent President of the Council has a great job and the Croatian Presidency has a great task. The essence of the problem is that, in the context of the work of the Finnish Presidency-in-Office, there is an unfair and unfair budget proposal on the Council table, which is unfair and unfair in its basic thinking, logic and system, and that is what the Heads of State or Government will have to work on. An approach that draws money towards richer EU Member States from poorer EU Member States, regardless of the total amount of the seven-year framework budget, is unfair and unfair. That's absurd. Secondly, allow me to be formulated, in the context of a budget debate, let us finally talk about numbers in addition to very important principles, values and political statements. If you look at the difference between the proposal for the minimum budget amount and the largest one, this is EUR 350 billion, a lot of money at first sight. In fact, this means that every EU citizen would have to pay around EUR 9 per month into the budget. We are talking about EUR 9 per month, I think that this kind of money is worth the Future of Europe.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In the last negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework, the Heads of State and Government reached an agreement on 8 February 2013. This was preceded by a first summit in November 2012, which was preceded by a dispute over the multiannual financial framework. We already know the rest of the story: the MFF was formally adopted on 2 December 2013. Only then could the operational programmes be written, and this delay left project promoters on dry land and had to be supported by other bodies. 2014 was a lost year for the EU budget – as former Budget Commissioner Günther Oettinger quite rightly said, because there was almost no outflow of funds. In other words, we are already too late today and well on the way to making 2021 a lost year again. After Brexit, with a view to the President in the White House, in view of the climate catastrophe and the global goal of achieving sustainability in all policy areas: do we really want to afford this? And to all those in the national budgets who look at their budgets, which I can understand: they are cordially invited to look at this House's proposals for a better own resources system. I think that could be a solution. On 20 February, it is a question of showing the ability to act. Anyone who thinks European puts the solution of common tasks at the centre. That is what we should be doing.

name: Mircea-Gheorghe HAVA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union needs access to the money from the future MFF as quickly as possible, as predictable and simplified as possible.  EUR 130 billion annually is the amount with which states contribute to the budget proposed by the European Commission for the future programming period. According to the same institution, more than EUR 923 billion is returning to the Member States of the European Single Market – a fantastic report. It is about the fact that at one euro invested nine euros are returned to our countries.  Figures from Commission sources show that Belgium, at EUR 4.36 billion invested, recovers EUR 56.49 billion, the Netherlands at EUR 6.85 billion, recovers EUR 84 billion, Austria, which invests EUR 3.84 billion, recovers EUR 35.61 billion, Finland will contribute EUR 2.22 billion and will collect EUR 13.2 billion, and my country , Romania, will contribute 2.41 billion euros and earn 16.59 billion euros. We want green pact, we want the money of the European Investment Bank in clean energy projects, we want money invested in the decarbonisation of industries, we want Europe digital superpower, to approve the MFF as soon as possible, because that's where it all starts, from the political agreement that is quickly assumed.

name: Paul TANG
text: Mr President, if you read the newspapers, you forget it quickly, but once every 7 years the EU has a huge opportunity. The huge opportunity to find answers to the challenges of our time. The opportunity to make agriculture greener, to set up European rail links or to have our science run globally. However, the newspapers do not report on this huge opportunity, but of the level of the EU budget.  Mr. Rutte, Mark Rutte, this call is for you. Firstly, do not give companies a free subscription to the single market. Don't let the citizens pay, but the biggest corporations. A quarter of a million for the largest companies quickly yields EUR 5 billion. Second, don't focus on single comma zero, zero, zero percent. Rather, just over 1% of our income that is well spent. Don't look at the percentages, but choose the odds.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I call for more sincerity and seriousness in the budget debate, because it is about our future. That is why the European Parliament is also launching an information offensive, because the vast majority of citizens believe that the majority of the money goes primarily to administration, even though 94% of the total budget is spent in our regions, in the municipalities: for our universities, for rural areas, for our businesses, for the development of the future. Each euro produces three investment euros at home, because the argument of most Member States is misleading. They conceal the fact that the added value of membership is many times greater than the membership fee. There are no net contributors because The Member States talk about percentages rather than tasks, projects, content and value. I think it is irresponsible that Ursula von der Leyen's programme should not receive the necessary money.  Finally, where are the biggest differences? In education, research, investment in the Green Deal, rural development, security, own resources and social cohesion. Loosen the shackles, Commissioner and dear Members of the Council! If we place a future bond – with the citizens – and if we create a European crowdfunding model and own resources, then we can close the gap.

name: Vangelis MEIMARAKIS
text: Madam President, in the coming years the European Union is called upon to implement the Green Deal, an extremely ambitious policy. The success of this policy will be judged by our ability as legislators to ensure the equal transition of our societies to the green economy. In order to achieve this without inequalities, the contribution of 1 % from the annual national budgets is not sufficient. Until now, with this amount, the European Union has implemented landmark policies such as the Common Agricultural Policy and cohesion policy and now some want with the same funding to implement the most ambitious policy of recent years. You can't do that. New policies require new funding. Parliament's proposal of 1,3 % therefore seems to me to be very sensible. It ensures the implementation of policies that vindicate citizens' visions for the Europe of the future without cutting the necessary funding for the implementation of agricultural and cohesion policy, and can — at the same time — provide greater funding to meet all these needs. That is why it is not responsible for national governments to make momentous announcements without them being accompanied by bold initiatives and funding. Parliament's proposal is waiting — and must — for it to be accepted.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: – Madam President, our position here in Parliament has become extremely clear, indeed, unequivocally clear. We do not accept a small financial framework, where the cuts that are presented are in policies crucial to the economic and social development of our countries. I do not accept, we do not accept, cuts that are highly penalizing for our country, for Portugal. We are dealing with a number of proposals which clearly affect both cohesion policy and common agricultural policy. These are crucial sectors for the development of our countries. And there are two issues here which I would like to make clear and which are a huge concern for Members from three Member States: Portugal, Spain and France, which have their outermost regions and which may see the possibility of developing these regions cut off here. We are talking about fishing issues, economic issues, tourism issues and what we can see at stake in what is presented to us.  We want a Union that looks at people, their regions and does not allow these cuts.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, almost two years ago I was discussing for the first time in the Council of the European Union, at the time I was Minister of European Affairs in Romania, about the European budget. Today it has been almost two years since that time, and here we have no solution, no clear solution, no proper proposal even though it has been two years, and perhaps it is time to think about the future of the European Union, because if we want to build a future, we need an adequate budget and a greater contribution from the Member States to everything that this European project means.  There are no old priorities or new priorities, as was wrongly said earlier. There are simply priorities of European citizens to which we must respond.  We need a budget focused on the development of the European Union and that also means money for cohesion and money for agriculture and money for research and money for the environment. All these things can be done if we are willing to make decisions today.  That is why European leaders at the European Council must adopt a solution. There are solutions on the table, there are ideas on the table, they have to adopt them, they have to take responsibility for supporting this further European project. I believe that European citizens expect us to come up with an appropriate budget for the years to come.

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, this debate in plenary session has shown three major coincidences apart from ideological differences. We are all aware of the added difficulty and complexity of negotiating the budget in a post-Brexit context, and that is why we are committed to a quick agreement, which provides legal certainty to the main sectors of our economy. And we demand, beyond figures and percentages, a budget that reflects the new priorities of the European Union.  The Green Pact is going to be the legislative player for the next five years. But this Pact and all the measures to be derived from it, such as the farm-to-table strategy, are only going to get the accession of European citizens if, instead of cutting budgets and asking for more environmental contribution, we are able to offer farmers the necessary support, not just to pursue more ambitious environmental objectives , but so that they can develop a profitable economic activity. We must face the abandonment of our rural areas and the fed-up and frustration of our farmers through a budget that does not marginalize the challenges of the rural world and its remarkable contribution to sustainability.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, if the EU wants to sufficiently fund the Green Deal, clean food production, cohesion and maintain peace, we should take the opportunity presented by the exit of the UK, one of its most militaristic and belligerent members, and we should use the opportunity to move away from the mindless militarisation of Europe. We should scrap the European Defence Fund, the Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO) and other measures that have been brought forward and propelled by those that have been the victim of corporate capture by the military-industrial complex. Even the European Court of Auditors have said that it is a waste of money. If we want our farmers to move away from the use of chemicals and pesticides and towards the production of clean food, we must help them to do so. It will cost money. We must stop enriching the bigger farmers that don’t need our help and instead fund the farmers that do need our help to produce cleaner food and to survive in the process. We don’t need a bigger budget, but we need a much better budget. And the notion that we are increasing defence spend at the expense of the citizens of Europe is not acceptable.

name: Ljudmila NOVAK
text: – Madam President, with less money, we cannot achieve more projects and joint tasks. While we can be more rational, we can save, we can reshape our budget, but we must keep everything that is good, and there are many good projects in the European Union.  But we also have new projects needed. Together, we can do more, in climate policy, in security policy, in research, in new technologies, in the fight against cancer and so on. These are projects for people. We also need to think about our shared values as to why we are together. Net contributors must not forget solidarity and that they also benefit from the loss of money from being given to the less developed. The more German cars will be sold, more will be sold in Spar stores or Dutch tulips. And net receipts must not forget where the money comes from, because they sometimes behave too self-sufficient and also do not respect European rules.  We must not forget the future, so we must have a good budget.

name: Isabel CARVALHAIS
text: – Madam President, what I am about to say has basically been said, but I feel that obligation and it is an ethical obligation. In fact, the European Commission presents us with a very ambitious work plan to respond to the great challenges that Europe, our societies face, but it is essential that in this response there are no policy sacrifices that are absolutely structuring our societies. In a wrong dichotomy between traditional policies and modern policies, and I speak here, in particular, of the need to maintain or strengthen the budgetary appropriations of policies as important as agricultural policy, fisheries, regional cohesion, because, indeed, if we do not, our citizens will not understand in what sense we want the European project to remain a project of solidarity and cohesion. And I leave here my call for these structuring policies to continue to be of strong investment in the European Union.

name: Mauri PEKKARINEN
text: – Mr President, more money from the Member States for the EU budget, that has been the clear message of the debate. In my opinion, 1.07% may be a little too little. However, it is my hope that we will also have the courage to assess the priorities for which common resources are spent, as well as the division of labour between the EU and the Member States on a number of important issues.  I believe that the Member States themselves must have greater responsibility, for example, for evening out regional development differences in their own country. The development differences between the various countries have converged, but within many countries the differences in development within the country have not converged. Member States must therefore, through their own actions, ensure that EU money and own money are spent in a way that promotes genuine regional and balanced development.  Or research and innovation funding: The EU's success requires a substantial increase in resources. Here, too, responsibility also applies to the Member States. Many countries' own investment in education, research and innovation is far too low. The Member States themselves must also prioritise and invest in what is wisest for the common interest of both the Member State itself and the Union.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, I believe that we must be honest, both with ourselves and with European citizens. If we are real Europeans, if we really want and demand a better and stronger Europe, if we really want Europe to have a future and a perspective and to be able to finance its great visions and ambitions, such as green policy, the fight against cancer, the European army and the single defence and security, then there is one way; : increase the budget from 1 % of the contribution of the Member States to 1,3 %. We can't help but have big ambitions, big visions and big words. These cannot fit into a budget where States contribute only 1 %. I support the position and the view of the dear chairman of my group, Manfred Weber, that countries which do not apply the rule of law and European and international law cannot receive even one euro from the European Union. The first and best thing to exclude from these funds is Turkey, which does not respect and does not implement them. So, in conclusion, if we want this Europe to have a strong future, a strong perspective and to be proud, we need a strong budget that meets the demands of the times.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, today's debate is obviously about the future of Europe and sure, it is regrettable, it has been said here that the President, the new President of the European Council, is missing. He's just going to have a meeting on this subject.  But let's return to the importance of the budget of the new financial framework. The President of the Commission was telling us that we need to strike a balance between the old priorities and the new priorities. In my view, the old priorities remain in the news: the common agricultural programme, also, cohesion cannot be missed even if we add priorities, such as, of course, the green pact. But we cannot fail to stick to those two priorities – the common agricultural policy and cohesion – because, Commissioner, there was talk here of those who have net contributions.  In my country, the top ten capital, investments, in all areas, from banks, energy, trade, are those who are net contributors, so they have a market at their disposal. We have to go to achieve real cohesion because only then do we secure the future of Europe through solidarity, through a better life, and in the common agricultural policy I want to say something else, because we could not with the question: if we do not end up with the same subsidy to farmers, France with Romania with the Czech Republic with Slovakia, we cannot talk about a single market.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Madam President, the problem we face is that the British have left the European Union, but their mentality has been left behind. What Thatcher was saying — 'I want my money back' — and Cameron's negative logic unfortunately have a big influence on the European Council, even after Brexit. The continuation of the British method creates problems. It prevents the effective functioning of the European Union and prevents the effective implementation of the necessary new policies. Above all, however, it sends a message of resignation with regard to our common European future. I believe that the European Parliament's proposal does not solve all the problems;

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Madam President, yes, the fight against climate change is probably a future top priority. However, it should not be forgotten that the addition of new priorities does not mean that older priorities, such as cohesion, lose importance, quite the contrary. Citizens, the inhabitants of our more backward regions, expect that it is the european Union's assistance that will contribute to increasing the level of their regions. That is why we must do everything we can to find new instruments to finance new priorities, that is, new money from the state budget, whether it would be achieved by increasing contributions from Member States or by new own resources, such as a carbonisation carbon tax. Therefore, everything must also be done so that we can communicate this well to our citizens. I understand the so-called net payers in the European budget, that they do not want to be paid more, that it is difficult to communicate. But it must also be stressed to their people that their economies also benefit from our European Union, because it is not only about the budget, but about our cohesion, it is also about our cohesion, and it is also about being credible.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, today we had a debate showing how far we are from each other. Moreover, we note that the level of ambitions of new projects is broadened and the funding resource for old and new projects is being reduced.  I think we're in an extremely curious situation. The right solution is for both the Council and the Commission to take Parliament's point of view into account: 1.3% funding in order to enable us to maintain the cohesion programmes of the common agricultural policy, and in particular, to be able to implement the new extremely important programmes. I would make one last remark: the reluctance of net contributors is unjustified. They must take into account that the new Member States have given them a market, they must take into account the fact that at the moment, for example, Romania has lost 16 000 doctors and 220 000 engineers who are in the non-contributory states. It is unfair to reduce cohesion programmes.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Hahn, I would remind you as Commissioner for Regional Policy, sensitive to the outermost regions and, now, Commissioner for Budgets. You have heard this in all languages and in every corner of the spectrum of this European Parliament, including the group from which you come — the popular one — and the group from which I come — the socialist. It is not acceptable that, in the face of the greatest ambitions, the European Union will propose the most stingy financial framework in its history. So the conclusions are very clear. The first one, you can't do it anymore with less. Secondly, it is not permissible for the new policies, which are necessary, to take place at the expense of europe's policies: cohesion policy; regional policy, which protects less-favoured and remote regions, such as the outermost regions, and the most disadvantaged sectors, such as farmers and producers. And the third, very clear, the European Parliament has the final say. Don't let anyone forget, don't let anyone ignore you in this House. We're decisive. Without this European Parliament and its final approval, there will be no financial framework. It must therefore be changed and done upwards, meeting the needs posed by this European Parliament in its very large majority. Because the alternative is not simply the blocking of the current financial framework, but the impotence, irrelevance and failure of the European project.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the MFF to the European Union is like oil to an engine. Without oil the engine can’t function; the better the oil, the more efficient the engine. The same applies to the European Union. Without a budget we can’t function; the bigger the budget, the more efficient we can be. So it is appropriate that the House should call upon the Member States, and especially the Prime Ministers, to show some vision and broad-mindedness to ensure that we have the budget to do the things that we can do best in the interests of their own Member States and their own citizens. The evidence is there: the added value, the economies of scale in relation to things like CAP, cohesion, climate change, Erasmus, research and so on. The return to Member States is in the region of three-to-four to one for every euro put in. It’s logical. It’s sensible. It’s in the interest of citizens. All we want is for the Prime Ministers to show genuine broad-mindedness and I’m pleased to say that our Taoiseach, Leo Varadkar, has indicated that Ireland is prepared to increase its contributions. But all 27 Member States must do so.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this very fruitful exchange of views. Discussions on the next MFF, over many months, have underlined how passionate we are about the positive impact of policies on our citizens. We don’t agree on all the details, but we see a lot of consensus on our shared priorities. The budget is the policy cast in numbers and it needs to be big enough to meet our ambitions. Yet compromise is needed and, as President Ursula von der Leyen has made clear, time has run out. Next week it is crucial that an agreement is reached. We all want to see an ambitious budget, but we cannot ignore the reality that filling the gap of now being a Union of 27 comes with its challenges.  This is why I would urge you to aim for a budget that can deliver as of day one. This is why it is important to continue working on the sectoral proposals. Moreover, we should also work together towards a better outcome for a budget that is able to deliver on our common Strategic Agenda for Europe by focusing on, first, equipping ourselves with the means to deliver the Green Deal for climate neutrality, and, second, ensuring new own resources are created, for example plastics and ETS to help finance European public goods. We also look forward to a constructive and productive discussion at the European Council on 20 February and an outcome that’s good for Europe. The Union cannot deliver on its ambitions when cuts are in areas where European citizens expect us to do more. Many of you have mentioned examples – climate, borders, digital, Erasmus, defence, you name it – and therefore the Finnish negobox is not yet the finish. Why the urgency? We are already very late, as several speakers have said, even later than 2013, where that delay led to a lost year for many programmes. I am talking about 2014.  Our focus must be on making sure that all the new programmes are up and running by 1 January 2021. Let’s avoid delays, let’s be positive and let’s stay united. We owe this to ourselves and to our institutions, but, most importantly, to our citizens, who expect results. The Commission remains committed to a continuous dialogue and to engage fully to support the forthcoming negotiations. By the way, regarding the negotiations, I have been asked in the past couple of days and even today by many people if I believe that it is possible or likely to strike a deal next week, meaning that, according to tradition, it is unlikely that only one meeting will be sufficient to get the deal. But I think it’s time to break with this tradition and to work for a deal struck in one meeting. I have been travelling to many Member States, participating in many meetings and conferences during the past couple of weeks, and I believe there can be a consensus amongst Member States, even already next week, provided there is some goodwill and energy and – may I say and this is very important – that, in particular, bigger, leading Member States become more active and work for a deal. In that respect, I urge all of you to use your contacts and your networks to put some pressure on the European leaders, your party leaders and your party friends in order to work for a deal which, finally, is in the interest of all of us and enables us to enter into negotiations with the European Parliament. The Commission, and I myself, we will do everything to support all these negotiations.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you Commissioner Hahn, and I hope the goodwill continues.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, to conclude, I wish to thank you for a very useful debate. I have taken good note of your expectations and concerns and I will convey them to President Michel. It is important that Europe continues developing and its socio-economical gaps are being reduced, meaning that our Treaty-based policies are effective and need to be continued, while also taking into account new challenges outlined in the EU’s strategic agenda. Furthermore, one of the biggest EU Member States and budget contributors has left, so we need to find a compromise that will address the budgetary gap while at the same time ensuring sufficient resources to achieve objectives, priorities and challenges arising from the ambitious strategic agenda. We are therefore committed to a balanced, efficient and effective budget in line both with our strategic agenda as well as the citizens’ expectations. I am confident that, in cooperation with you, it will be possible to ensure a smooth transition to the next long-term financial cycle. As soon as our leaders reach agreement in the European Council, the Croatian Presidency will be ready to step up our work with you in order to deliver for our citizens and for the future for our Union.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed.  Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Writing. – Regrettably, the budgetary negotiations have once again focused on the volume of the budget. Four Member States (three now) are rigidly holding on to a maximum of 1.0 % of the total national income and the European Parliament requires a capacity of 1.3% of GNP. I consider rapid progress in the budgetary talks to be very important, I voted in favour.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 are causing increasing friction between Member States. An EU budget weakened by the UK's exit requires a more united attitude among the Member States. The traditional division into beneficiaries and net contributors will not help us to finance current and new programmes. Until we understand that we all benefit from the single internal market, it will be difficult to convince all countries to pay more than 1% of GDP.  During one of the recent debates, my colleagues from net contributor countries were not afraid to see how beneficial it is for their economies to be in the common market. The final balance sheet is not only contributions and receipts to the EU budget, but also the income of small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as economic giants benefiting from the facilities of the common market.  It is hard for politicians to talk about increases, but citizens should know that programmes like the New Green Deal have no limits, that without agreements on their funding, we are all losing out. Polish and European science, students, people investing and developing start-ups are losing out.  Another form of compensation for the budget hole should be the reform of the EU's own resources, but we have still not seen sufficient progress since the establishment of the Own Resources Group in 2014.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – The European Council is approaching, where the issue of the multiannual financial perspective will be the main theme. We very much hope that progress will be made in the negotiations and that the European Council will be able to find an agreement on a negotiating mandate. Our priorities for the next multiannual financial perspective are clear: to ensure adequate funding for the creation of a social Europe. The negotiating position presented by the Finnish Presidency does not satisfy us and is completely at odds with the priorities that we have adopted. We must bear in mind the need to also provide funding for programmes that have not yet begun, such as the European Guarantee for the Child, which will only be presented in the coming years, but funding must be agreed now so that this programme can function properly and that support reaches the needy children. We will not accept cuts in funding in the social sphere, because our citizens expect a lot from Europe, and the multiannual financial perspective must meet the expectations of our citizens, especially the most vulnerable.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – In the light of the budgetary negotiations of the European Council, I stress the importance of establishing a budget proportional with our objectives. The Von der Leyen Commission has an ambitious programme ahead, which requires an ambitious budget. As Chair of the Committee for Industry, Research and Energy of the European Parliament, I am particularly concerned about an eventual cut in the Horizon Europe budget. This instrument is a key factor for the success of the Green Deal and EU’s assumed mission to fight cancer. Proper investment in digital research and innovation will be critical for increasing the global competitiveness of Europe’s industries while helping them to achieve carbon emissions reductions in line with our climate—neutral objectives. Europe needs to support uptake of innovative technologies in relation to the development of CO2 absorption capacities, develop innovative negative emissions technologies, and enable digital technologies such as artificial intelligence, 5G and supercomputing in order to better design climate and environment policies. These actions cannot be performed without an adequate budget and their financing should not come at the cost of EU cohesion policy, which is crucial for a uniform transition process.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – When negotiating the next Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027, the leaders of the Member States meeting in the European Council should bear in mind that the EU budget is intended to ensure an adequate level of funding for ambitious and pro-development EU policies and programmes, which have been presented by the new European Commission and approved by Parliament. Social programmes providing for assistance to children at risk of poverty, combating youth unemployment, research and innovation, digital transformation and environmental and climate change investments (European Green Deal) are particularly important in this respect. Adequate funding should also be maintained in the field of cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy.  A key element of the ongoing negotiations on the 2021-2027 MFF is also the reform of the EU's own resources system providing for the establishment of additional sources of union revenue. Currently, the lion's share of the Union budget (around 70%) are contributions paid by Member States; consequently, their final amount is always the subject of difficult intergovernmental negotiations. The rest are direct revenues to the EU budget from customs duties, agricultural levies, sugar levies and VAT-based payments.  Deepening the Process of European Integration requires an increase in the union's budgetary independence. I therefore share Parliament's view that an additional source of own resources should be m.in. revenue from the abolition of rebates and corrections and the taxation of multinational companies operating in the single market based in tax havens or digital giants outside the Union.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – Negotiations on how much of the European cake each country will be provided are in the final stages. There is too little money for all projects, so the race for European money is very hard. My country, Slovenia, is in a very awkward position at this point, because at a crucial moment it has no operational government.  Cohesion funds are an important resource for our development, and we should fight them with all our strength, just as other countries do. I call on the Leaders of the Member States to take into account the fact that Europe is as strong as its weakest link. However, I am pleased that the European Parliament has the final say on the decision.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. – Negotiations on the EU's multiannual budgetary framework must now be speeded up in the Council. The Commission's original proposal, which had moderately reduced the share of agriculture and regional aid and increased resources for research, education and security, provides a good framework for further negotiations.  Unfortunately, the Council proposal prepared by the Finnish Presidency does not reflect the position of either the Commission or the EUROPEAN Parliament. Firstly, the framework is too tight, 1.07% of gross national income. In addition, funding has been reduced from exactly where future needs are: security, digitalisation and the fight against climate change.  The notch in the EU budget caused by Brexit is, of course, considerable. Part of it must be covered by increasing member states' funding, others by savings, but the share of own resources must also be strengthened in the future. In addition to agricultural and regional policy, the new budget must be able to meet the challenges of the future: industrial renewal and sustainable growth, in particular innovation, digitalisation, support for SME growth and education, and, to a large extent, security policy.  Personally, I would like to highlight in particular the two 2021-27 programmes in which I have held positions of responsibility in Parliament. Firstly, the Connecting Europe (CEF), which finances cross-border transport, energy and digital infrastructure: as rapporteur for the Committee on Industry, Youth, Research and Energy, I find it scandalous that the Council is proposing cuts to the programme, while both Europe's competitiveness, a functioning internal market and the fight against climate change require fast, modern links. Secondly, the research programme Horizon, in which I was the responsibility of the Committee on Transport: investment in European science, research and innovation is needed to strengthen the competitiveness of industry and to meet global challenges. The EUROPEAN Parliament proposes to increase the programme by 50%. We're going to hold on to this.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – The Extraordinary European Council of 20 February dedicated to the multiannual budget 2021-2027 is the first relevant test of EU solidarity27. Negotiating the EU's multiannual budget is always a tough exercise, but never in the last 20 years have tensions between east and west, north and south been greater than now. Digital transformation, the Green Pact, new security and migration needs are new tasks for the EU27, which must be properly funded. The vision of the group of austerity states to finance the new challenges at the expense of the Cohesion Policy and the CAP is unacceptable. For increased burdens we need an increased budget, not irrational cuts at all. The EU's proximity to the citizen also means action, not just talk. In Romania and eastern Europe, the EU is personified through three programmes: cohesion, with visible investments in the smallest communities, the CAP, which brings wealth to millions of farmers, and Erasmus+ for young people. These programmes cannot suffer any budget cuts. I welcome the EPP's position in the European Parliament that the priority is a sound budget rather than the rapidity of its adoption. I will campaign for a vote against any budget proposal that would reduce the funding of the Cohesion Policy and the CAP.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The EPP Group has notified the President of decisions relating to changes to appointments within committees. Those decisions will be set out in the Minutes of today’s sitting and shall take effect on the date of this announcement. Mr Glucksmann, on a point of order.

name: Raphaël GLUCKSMANN
text: Madam President, yes, it is a reminder of the rules. I refer to Article 10, paragraph 4, which stipulates that in parliamentary debates, Members refrain from any offensive remarks. But yesterday, during the debate on Syria, a member of the National Rally, Mr Mariani, urged Europe to support Bashar al-Assad to bring peace by exterminating the rebels. I stress: by exterminating the rebels. Not the terrorists of the Islamic State organization, but the rebels. Not "fight," but "exterminate." This call to extermination is an offence. This language, characteristic of fascism, has nothing to do in this chamber. We cannot let Vladimir Putin's little telegraphists, the man who wants to kill his enemies into the toilet, import his abject language into our Parliament. We may have deep, virulent disagreements, but we cannot, in our chamber, tolerate the apologies of war crimes or crimes against humanity.  These words constitute hate speech within the meaning of Article 10, paragraph 4, of the regulation, and I ask you to sanction them. It must not pass and it will not pass.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Glucksmann, thank you for bringing that to our attention. We will indeed look at the transcript and advise the President about this. Mr Mariani, on a point of order.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Paradoxically, I would like to thank Raphael Glucksmann for his intervention, the last word of my... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: This is not a debate on Mr Glucksmann’s intervention. I will continue with the order of our business. That point is now covered. We will move on.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I now have to read a statement which will generate the ire of some colleagues, so I will do it in a calm way and please just listen to what I have to say. I am obliged to remind Members that under the Rules of Procedure, the display of banners and flags is not allowed. I would invite the ushers to ask those Members who have flags to remove them from the desk, or indeed I would invite colleagues to respect the Rules of Procedure as I have just outlined.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: José GUSMÃO
text: – Madam President, we follow the general meaning of the report with regard to the protection of the rights of European citizens in the United Kingdom, but, as is well known to all Members, the implementation of what has been agreed with the United Kingdom is facing a number of problems in the daily lives of European citizens living, sometimes for decades , in the United Kingdom in accessing basic services, entering into employment contracts or leasing contracts. That is why we have drawn up an oral amendment which enshrines the automatic status of the regularisation of the situation of these citizens and ensures the delivery of a physical document that can prove the residence status of those citizens. The amendment is as follows: "calls for the automatic allocation of permanent residence visas to all European citizens living in the UK by 31 January 2020. It underlines the need for these visas to include a physical document proving their residence status." These two sentences would be added to Article 50 of the resolution.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: – Madam President, this morning we voted in favour of the agreements with Vietnam. It has not been an easy process but, after due consideration, I have decided to vote in favour of these agreements. While the situation in Vietnam is still far from ideal, the Vietnamese Government has taken valuable steps in the right direction. The FTA and IPA with Vietnam will not only improve the trade relationship between the EU and Vietnam, it will also create a platform for continuous dialogue on human rights with the Vietnamese that will benefit the people of that country. Our trading partners should keep human rights and environmental standards to the highest level. I would like to recommend the Commission investigate how the use of a set of objective and transparent criteria would serve as guidance to find trading partners, thus enabling the negotiated FTAs to benefit from broader support amongst all political colours in the EU.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, congratulations, you have just voted on a free trade agreement with Vietnam that tramples on the environment and human rights, with the sole aim of satisfying the lobbies that have otherwise watered you with champagne. You are directly responsible for an ecological disaster that will increase the transport of goods between the European Union and Vietnam by 20-30%, accelerate deforestation and worsen the development of polluting industries such as leather and steel. But talking about a green pact with tremolos in your voice doesn't stop you from voting for such an agreement, climateicide. You are directly responsible for a social scandal that aims to take advantage of an exploited workforce, caught between the hammer of globalized capitalism and the anvil of authoritarianism. In addition, a state that turns a blind eye to forced labour, bans trade unions and imprisons political opponents in turn. The NGOs alerted you, you could not ignore the disastrous ecological and social impact of this agreement. If you didn't know, you're guilty of follow-up. And if you knew, it's even worse: you're guilty of cynicism.

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: – Madam President, this deal will boost our trade exchanges and will deliver more jobs and growth into this continent. We badly need more jobs for people within Europe and we must support job creation and innovation. I want to say that I believe that closing the door does not get any closer to improving Vietnam’s human rights record or indeed the policies and attitudes on climate change. The UN and some NGOs have already acknowledged the improvements and indeed there is a chapter on workers’ rights in the agreement, which is fully compliant with ILO standards. So we want to engage rather than isolate and, of course, we still have to be very cognisant in relation to human rights and climate change and there has to be ongoing monitoring. This is also allowed for. We do need to keep our businesses and get our businesses involved in new regions and countries, and of course this is the way that we spread the standards and the values of the European Union.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to explain why I abstained on this free trade agreement. I generally support – and very strongly – free trade agreements, because I know that this is a great mutual opportunity. At the same time, I am also aware that this agreement treats relatively well those provisions relating to standards of work, the working environment, the environment, but unfortunately this agreement was not a strong enough impulse for the Vietnamese Government to release at least some political prisoners. There are 140 political prisoners in Vietnam, and the Vietnamese government was unwilling to make this gesture to make it clear that it was serious about improving human rights. I am not against this agreement, I voted in favour of postponing it, and in the end I abstained precisely to make clear our clear position on human rights in Vietnam.

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour. The hysteria I hear across the street makes me think I voted the right way. Nevertheless, I admit that it was not an easy consideration, because I am a person who still remembers from the communist era that playing it hard sometimes with a regime that closes people down, hard, makes sense. And Vietnam plays hardball with people back home.  I believe that free trade can help, but at the same time I consider it important to implement what is in the accompanying resolution, and in this sense I would like to ask the European Commission to bring up the human rights problem in its negotiations with Vietnam and to finally present us with the impact assessment, which, unfortunately, we did not receive as a basis for this negotiation.

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, our Parliament has just adopted, for the first time since the inauguration of the Von der Leyen Commission, a free trade agreement, the one with Vietnam.  This agreement is harmful to democracy, workers and the environment. Negative for democracy, because this agreement with an authoritarian and repressive regime enshrines the triumph of arbitration tribunals that systematically favour multinationals and shareholders at the expense of peoples. Negative for European workers , in particular the two million textile workers who will suffer the brunt of social dumping - and Vietnamese - because this agreement will strengthen their exploitation by multinationals and a government that do not care about ILO conventions, freedom of association and the right to strike. Finally, this agreement does not provide any mechanism to ensure compliance with the objectives set by international environmental agreements. Not to mention the increase in greenhouse gas emissions that will result from the intensification of these trades.  That is why I strongly reject this bad agreement.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: – Madam President, the rule of law and respect for fundamental democratic principles and the protection of human rights, including workers' rights, are values on which the European Union is founded.  In a world where international cooperation and respect for the rules are increasingly being replaced by political pragmatism and populism, the EU does not have better leverage to promote these values, such as trade and investment agreements with third countries.  I am, unfortunately, in a minority of MePs who are convinced that the EU must not turn a blind eye to gross human rights violations and the poor state of democracy in Vietnam because of economic interests or simply to bring the problematic negotiating record off the table. For all these reasons, I voted against the recommendations and resolutions that distance the EU as Vietnam's third most important economic partner from the principle of respect for human rights. Unastyling is just something that we cannot and must not compete with Vietnam's first partners – the US and China.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, if the situation regarding human rights in Vietnam has improved so much, then how is it that journalist Pham Chi Dung is detained in prison now on anti-state charges for having the audacity of what? Contacting this Parliament and asking us to postpone the vote. Seriously. And for those people who say, ‘oh well, sure, look, if we don’t do business with them, how can the situation ever improve?’ that’s an affront to the tons of people who’ve contacted us and begged us to postpone this vote. It’s an outrage that we have betrayed them and that’s why I stood by them and voted against this agreement. For that reason and, critically, because we’ve just shown ourselves up as being an absolute bunch of hypocrites. We passed a resolution on 15 January, regarding the European Green Deal, saying we would only enter trade agreements with strong, binding, enforceable agreements on sustainable development and the Paris Agreement. We’ve done the complete opposite here. Shame on us.

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the vote on this agreement has been an infinitely difficult issue. All the objections that have just been raised here have meaning, of course, and in particular those concerning the state of human rights, which are of great concern, in Vietnam. However, we are not starting from scratch, we are not starting from a non-existent situation. We are already trading today with Vietnam, which is a major trading partner of the European Union - largely to the benefit of Vietnam, which is commercially surplus to us. The real question we are asked is: should we maintain this state of affairs, or should we try to tie Vietnam to our side to adopt, as it has been, ecological objectives, human rights objectives and, of course, also by trading with us, according to rules that open up its markets with a real requirement of reciprocity? It seems to me that this agreement allows us to go in the right direction in that regard, and if we had not signed it, we would have risked letting Vietnam go to its great neighbour, China. Is this really the world we want? Should Europe give up on action? I don't believe it.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, I voted against the proposed free trade agreement with Vietnam, because I believe it will have a negative impact on our economy and on our jobs.  Vietnam is already flooding us with its low-cost products, as evidenced by the European Union's trade deficit, which stood at 27 billion euros in 2018. The virtual removal of tariffs in the agreement will inevitably exacerbate this deficit. It will also encourage our companies to relocate to this country. Vietnam is also a communist dictatorship that does not respect human rights or the environment; it is therefore hypocritical to claim that this agreement will miraculously make it exemplary.  In the end, it is necessary to conclude that the European Union has once again betrayed the values it claims to defend.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Madam President, the EU—Vietnam Free Trade Agreement is the first of its kind by the EU with a developing country. Vietnam is not a perfect or easy partner. It has a long way to go with improving human, civil and political rights but, for a developing country, Vietnam has made very ambitious commitments in this deal, an arrangement which will bring opportunities for both European and Vietnamese workers and businesses. With this agreement, Vietnam commits to high—quality rules. On labour rights, for example, it commits to following all core International Labour Organisation (ILO) Conventions. So this agreement is of great importance, also from a geopolitical point of view. This will enforce its reliance not only on China. The country’s Government is, however, now clearly committed to reform. The EU needs to continue. It is not an end to agree on the deal, but we have to continue cooperation and dialogue during the implementation process.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Madam President, I supported the resolution today and am supporting a trade deal with Vietnam because I believe that trade agreements offer opportunity to engage on all areas, such as the environment, human rights and social standards. Trade agreements benefit consumers, they benefit companies and they create jobs on both sides. I recognise that Vietnam is not ideal in terms of human rights. Nonetheless, I think the engagement that the European bloc will have in terms of trade – companies engaging at that level and, indeed, individuals – will certainly benefit. I think it’s important that we have monitoring in place to ensure the effective implementation of all the commitments that have been made in these negotiations with regard to environmental standards, social standards and human rights. So I support a rules-based trade agreement with Vietnam because I think that’s far better than having no rules and no trade. We must recognise that we already do trade with Vietnam as a bloc.

name: Veronika VRECIONOVÁ
text: – Madam President, I supported the EU-Vietnam Free Trade and Investment Protection Agreement. At a time when many countries are introducing tariffs and declaring trade wars, I think this is a great moment in international trade policy. Of course, as a person who grew up in communist Czechoslovakia, I was very much considering the issue of human rights in Vietnam. I am monitoring the situation there and I know that human rights violations are taking place, that there are political prisoners there, but I believe that it is with this treaty that the EU is gaining an instrument to improve the human rights situation or also the environment. We have never had such an instrument in our hand before. I believe that, in addition to improving trade between them, there will also be improvements in this area.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, I was rapporteur for both of these agreements from 2012 to 2019 and gave up reporting after a series of false accusations against me by the Green faction, including the Czech Pirate Party and their friends in the media, because it was clear to me that this would serve as a pretext to postpone or sink both of these agreements. That's why I'm glad it didn't. I am glad that the EP approved both of these agreements with a strong solid majority, and I am glad that the EP has realised that it has a chance to lead the campaign for free trade at a time when protectionism is growing in the world, and that it has also realised Vietnam's growing geopolitical role in the South-East Asia region.  Of course, I supported both of these treaties and I am really happy that they have come through.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I’m delighted to fully support the Free Trade and Investment Agreement with Vietnam. As the PPE standing rapporteur for the Southeast Asian region and having guided the agreement with Singapore through this House last year, I’m well aware of the enormous potential these agreements have to boost our trade exchanges with this region, bringing positive effects on growth and employment and in terms of a secure investment environment.  The new agreement with Vietnam opens new perspectives, especially with the elimination of 99% of tariffs and non-tariff barriers. For example, it will be much easier for EU exporters of dairy and livestock food products, such as skimmed milk, cheese and meat, like pork and beef, to trade there. Finally, I welcome the huge opportunities for Ireland, in particular, with this agreement and of course in reverse for Vietnam. This is a good agreement and I hope it gets into operation as soon as possible.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: – (Due to technical issues, Ms Rafaela was asked to repeat her earlier speech) Madam President, this morning we voted in favour of the agreements with Vietnam and it has not been an easy process, but after due consideration, I have decided to vote in favour of these agreements. While the situation in Vietnam is still far from ideal, the Vietnamese Government has made valuable steps in the right direction. The free trade agreement (FTA) and investment protection agreement (IPA) with Vietnam will not only improve the trade relationship between the EU and Vietnam; it will also create a platform for continuous dialogue on human rights with the Vietnamese that will benefit the people of that country. Our trading partners should keep human rights and the environmental standards to the highest level. I would like to recommend that the Commission investigate how the use of a set of objective and transparent criteria could serve as guidance to find trading partners. Therefore, the negotiated FTAs can benefit from broader support amongst all political colours in the EU.

name: Caroline ROOSE
text: Madam President, the vote on the free trade agreement with Vietnam is very bad news.
