My colleagues explained yesterday why this agreement is in complete contradiction with the desire to fight global warming and with the European Green Pact. They also explained why it was unseemly for the Greens to vote against the agreement, given the human rights situation in Vietnam, an authoritarian country where even ILO rules are not respected.  We also rejected this agreement because of its very negative impact in the fight against INRI fishing - illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. Since 2017, Vietnam has been under a "yellow card" procedure by the European Union for failing to comply with its obligations to combat illegal fishing. Although Vietnam has been cooperating with the EU for a few months, it is still not in compliance with international conventions on illegal fishing. By voting on this agreement, Parliament is weakening the yellow card system and the fight against illegal fishing. Moreover, the free trade agreement could lead to imports of products from illegal fishing. It was therefore impossible for me to vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, it really was not an easy decision to make on this matter. Indeed, it is very difficult for us, who come from former communist countries, to conclude a trade agreement with a communist country, given the issue of human rights. In the end, I decided to do so because the positives, in my opinion, prevail. It is, of course, better to trade according to the rules, according to certain secured standards than without rules, without any possibility of influencing the internal affairs of the country, and let us face the fact that we are already cooperating with Vietnam in the current situation. I firmly believe that trade will have increasing potential even while maintaining environmental standards, and I also hope that investment protection, the protection of country of origin designations, will be truly respected. All the positive steps that have been contained in these proposals. That's why I supported them, though not with a very light hand.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, this agreement has a lot in common with many free trade deals before it, like CETA, the Japan and South Korea agreements, and  Mercosur. These deals have much the same effect. The scant protections the EU still has in place are routinely undermined in the name of free trade, and the climate, our health and our indigenous industries always suffer. As the Commission is a revolving-door catastrophe, we see the powers of the corporate sector all over these deals, again and again, with a scant look in for those looking to protect workers’ rights and stop this being used as a back door to a further race to the bottom that would devour the planet and ensure that we see climate system breakdown in our lifetime. This system of unfettered capitalism is locking us into the corrosion of environmental protections and public health standards, and the attached system of globalised trade is sending carbon emissions skyrocketing as we ferry the cheapest (meaning the most exploitative) goods around the planet in order that corporations make buckets of money. There’s no such thing as a free trade deal. This system is costing us the Earth.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I supported this investment protection agreement between the EU and its Member States and Vietnam. It's a deal that's different in character than the last one. The point is that the EU is already the fifth largest investor in Vietnam. Vietnam is therefore an important partner for the EU and it is important that European investors and their investments are protected in Vietnam. And this agreement lays down clear rules. At the same time, these investments in Vietnam will enable new jobs to be created, and we therefore expect Vietnam to approach the EU not only economically, but also in terms of human rights and the standard of living of the population. There are about 60,000 Vietnamese communities in the Czech Republic and we know that their situation is not easy. I believe that this agreement could motivate the Vietnamese Government to bring European values closer together.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Madam President, I look at Vietnam with sympathy and friendship, having been a Member of Parliament for the French abroad, and in particular for the Asia-Pacific region for five years. I know the suffering of this people and the efforts they are making to recover. However, the relationship between nations and with reality must be the case: we must work with objective data and succeed in establishing relations with all the countries of the world. Finally, it is our conception of international relations, in principle, not that of the European Union, that raises the issue of human rights at every opportunity. I voted against this agreement, because it does not benefit Europeans, because it is always marked by an ideological conception of free trade and because the European customs union has long ceased to serve peoples. We must not sign any agreement that would go against the relocation of industrial activities in Europe, which would not give to our own before helping the development of others. On the other hand, we cannot accept that a private arbitral justice system replaces national justices. These are the reasons for my vote on the texts concerning the agreements between the European Union and Vietnam.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I voted in favour of the resolution and therefore also against the list of Projects of Common Interest. Why is that? I would like to make it clear once again that this list will support around 50 gas projects – 50 gas projects, in the age of climate change. The aim is to support projects in all Member States that are actually harmful to the environment. If we look at this in more detail, we have to say that this is not compatible either with the Paris climate agreement or with other agreements that have been concluded. And it is also a sign of poverty, because it is the declaration of the climate emergency in the EU that we have made here – this declaration is practically being chased to the devil. Instead, money from the European budget is to be spent on gas, and we do not agree in any way with it. Instead, we need money for renewable energy, for example for cross-border power lines, which have to be paid for. I am thinking, for example, of solar power from Spain, which can be transported to the north of the European Union, or even smart grids, which really need to be promoted. That would be important and incompatible with what has been done so far.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: While the European Commission has just presented its Green Pact with great fanfare, you have just voted, ladies and gentlemen, to vote on a list of investments ironically called 'common interest', which includes no less than 32 gas projects. Yes, that's all it is. What is your common interest when you support the development of gas infrastructure, when gas accounts for 20% of global CO2 emissions? What is the common interest when you choose to pour out 29 billion euros of public money to finance these climate projects? What is the common interest of you, finally, when these projects will include gas from hydraulic fracturing, which endangers the planet and the health of local communities? You are totally discrediting this Parliament by applauding with both hands the state of climate emergency, while signing a blank cheque to the polluting multinationals. The common interest is the complete opposite of these absurd and useless projects, it is to face the climate catastrophe and it is to give us a chance to respond to it, starting by leaving fossil fuels underground.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: – Mr President, I voted against that list because it contains a number of projects based on fossil energy sources. Even if natural gas is to be thought of as a transitional option, the fact that these life cycles of investment can be between 40 and 50 years must be recognised. That cannot be the length of any transition period.  We cannot create a new energy infrastructure based on fossil fuels. It is completely contrary to the Paris Agreement and completely contrary to the stated climate targets set by this Parliament for itself and for the Commission.  As these projects now move on to further processing, I hope that the Commission will look at these projects in further process, bearing in mind that this Parliament has declared a climate emergency, this Parliament is committed to complying with the Paris Agreement and this Parliament is committed to a carbon-neutral Europe. That is why projects that conflict with climate objectives must be extracted from this list.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This is very good news. This vote is very good news for many countries, because gas is a much-needed and extremely sustainable source of energy for many countries, including post-communist countries. And that's where gas investments are underway to help bring these countries, the post-communist countries, out of the very sluggish issues of the old energy system. With this vote, the European Parliament has shown that it is possible to agree together on understanding the starting points of the various European countries and on energy responsibility. This vote will continue to finance gas connections between Poland and the Czech Republic, Poland and Slovakia, Poland and Ukraine, Poland and Norway, Baltic Pipe, and liquefied gas systems will be built and constitute energy Polish.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, I am against this list of projects because there is, among other things, an LNG terminal in Omišalj on Krk.  When you bring any good project to an uncouth country, it'll probably be good. Now imagine when you bring a bad project to a corrupt country like Croatia, which is just happening here. So, when implementing such projects we have bribery, overpaid projects, suffocating the profession and science, favoring relatives. It's looking at the concept of me making money now, and everyone else suffering damage in the long run, I'm not interested in that. That approach is disastrous. I am against all projects that burden Croatian households.  In Croatia, due to the failure of waste management systems, we are already paying increasing prices for garbage and water, medicines and their prices compared with the richest countries in Europe. We have an expensive and slow telecom and are among the worst in the digital development index. Petrol is close to our price in Austria or Italy with multiple reaches. Taxes are very high and now we are still paying for the missed Plenković projects that will increase the price of gas and electricity. No thank you!

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, I voted strongly against this report against this objection, because this folly must be put to an end. You vote, dear colleagues on the left, against nuclear power, proven the safest and cleanest, you vote against gas pipelines, you vote against coal energy. With every action you take, you deindustrialise European countries, you export jobs outside the European continent. You are destroying the ability of societies to support themselves, work and have prosperity, and most of these changes affect the countries of Central and Eastern Europe. I am aware of your desire to make energy from violets and daisies, but I assure you that will not happen. It is very nice to dream of sunny parks, but at night the sun will not. It's very nice to think that with Karlsson's wind fins you're going to achieve something, only the wind is something variable. Therefore, I am glad that here is put a pole in the wheels of this political madness, which becomes the so-called "Green Theme".

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, this PCI list, which is the list of applications for eligible projects on which we voted today, is part of a larger package, part of the TEN-E regulation, in which we urgently expect a better regulatory framework from the Commission.  Personally, I was the Connecting Europe (CEF) negotiator for this upcoming financial period. In it, we were better able to meet the criteria with the political will of the European Union to respond to climate change challenges. Today, an important signal was sent from the Chamber and from this week's discussions to the Commission that these lists must also be made compatible with their political objectives, so that the transition to a low-carbon economy and the 2050 carbon neutrality target are realised. I myself voted in favour of this list, although it is not perfect, as it also includes three quarters of electricity network improvement projects.  In my opinion, attention must now be drawn to the fact that these projects are being sought. I do not know whether many MEPes have examples here of projects that have not been funded. They have not been applied for and now we need to get energy efficiency, smart grids and others much better involved in the new legislation.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I was one of the 443 MEPs who did not support this objection to the 4th PCI list. I believe the projects on this list are important for the creation of a well-functioning internal energy market in the EU, as I support the ambition of a stable, secure and affordable supply of energy. Additional investments will, of course, create jobs and growth in the regions concerned. The list of energy projects comes as a package, and I support it as a package. This list contains a number of key projects across the European Union that will help us meet all objectives of the Energy Union. In Ireland, these include a number of important new projects, including the Celtic Interconnector (Ireland’s proposed electricity interconnection with France), additional electricity connections between Ireland and the UK, and the proposed Silvermines renewable hydroelectric power station. These are all important elements of Ireland’s move towards renewable energy and, notably, our objective of reaching 70% renewable electricity by 2030. While I understand concerns about the inclusion of gas projects, projections show that gas will play an important role in transition by reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the power-generating industrial and commercial, residential and transport sectors by replacing more CO2-intensive fossil fuels like coal and oil.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this resolution, and I also spoke on this particular issue in 2011 when Ireland brought forward legislation to the parliament to ban this insidious barbaric act.  Regardless of culture, religion or creed, this is something that goes against the fundamental principles of bodily integrity and of right to life and a right to health, so from all these perspectives, I welcome the resolution, and I ask the Commission, and I ask Member States in particular across the European Union, to ensure that legislation is robust in national parliaments to address this particular issue, to ensure that there are prosecutions of people who partake in female genital mutilation and encourage it and facilitate it.  Equally, we have to ensure that we have in place support through our health services so that victims – people who have been genitally mutilated – have the confidence to seek support, to seek assistance if they need it in the context of the damage that it does to their health. I commend the motion and I ask national parliaments to endorse it as well in legislation.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Madam President, of course I voted in favour of this resolution. FGM is violence that is very often linked to degrading and unacceptable conceptions of women, or to certain Islamist sects.  A horror that has been imported on European soil and scandalizing our societies, since it is associated with mass immigration. Inviting people from different cultures and then being surprised that they practice different customs is really the lot of the naïve. This horror cannot bear the ideological assumptions enshrined in the joint resolution - one only has to say simply and clearly our disgust at practices that damage human nature.  We must then distinguish what shocks our universal principles and what endangers our continent. Six hundred thousand young women run the risk of these practices on our continent, a practice that until now was ignored. In order to implement a European strategy for the defence and promotion of the European way of life, which refuses any such practice, it is of course necessary to study the causes. And the causes are our lack of control over the origins of immigration, our emphasis on out-of-age multiculturalism that justifies increasingly revolting practices and, of course, justifies the vote for this resolution.

name: Anne-Sophie PELLETIER
text: Madam President, I welcome the adoption of this resolution for which I voted in favour, of course. After the adoption of the resolution on the European Union's accession to the Istanbul Convention in November 2019, I think it is yet another strong message that we are sending on violence against women and gender equality. While the UN has included the eradication of genital violence by 2030 as part of its sustainable development goals, genital mutilation still affects 200 million girls and women worldwide, and 600,000 women are exposed to it in Europe. Genital mutilation is an attack on the flesh and spirit of women. This resolution shows that female genital mutilation is a manifestation of inequalities between women and men, and I will be against what Mr Mariani is saying: we are not going to stigmatize religions. As such, a systemic approach should be taken to combat this phenomenon, which must be based on the prevention and economic emancipation of women.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I strongly oppose all forms of violence against women, especially genital mutilation. This practice also exists in the Countries of the European Union. It is a bestial form of mutilation, mainly of young girls, which is why I voted in favour of this resolution.  Unfortunately, some political groups have not refrained from promoting their ideological ideas in this resolution as well. That is why I did not support the majority of Mr J.'s recital: Genital mutilation can be put on an equal footing with forced marriages, especially child marriages, but this cannot be compared with the lack of comprehensive sex education. The provisions in recitals J, paragraphs 5 and 21, which use the words 'sexual and reproductive health', also raise doubts. While in fact the perinatal care of mutilated women requires special efforts, we strongly oppose the understanding of this wording as access to abortion. Furthermore, I do not agree with paragraph 20, which deals with the union's ratification of the Istanbul Convention.

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The European Parliament today adopted a resolution expressing our determination to combat female genital mutilation. Unfortunately, once again, it is nothing more than a mere symbolic policy, and it is again just empty lip service. Female genital mutilation is not combated by giving speeches or attaching stickers to your chest, but at the same time, as happened here in December, i am scrapping my initiative, with which I wanted to extend the resolution to include the Istanbul Convention on Female Genital Mutilation. Nor does it help to establish a prioritised asylum claim for girls affected by FGM. This only creates further motives for exposing even more girls to this inhumane practice by being able to send them to Europe as anchor children. Nor is it useless to pretend that this cruel crime has nothing to do with a particular culture or religion, because we all know that Islam is contempt for women in pure culture. Those who do not clearly state this cannot solve these problems, and that is why I say quite clearly that female genital mutilation does not belong to Europe any more than Islam, from where it comes from.

name: Annika BRUNA
text: Madam President, 500,000 women are reported to have been victims of genital mutilation. While female genital mutilation exists in Europe, it is not European. It is not found in the history of our countries, nor in traditions or religious requirements. There were only a few marginal cases in a 19th-century Russian sect, yet it was self-harm. FGM in Europe is the exclusive result of immigrant populations that have not been assimilated and have not adopted civilizational values and European mores. Their development is a demonstration of the migratory submersion we are experiencing and the lack of integration of certain populations. If we can fight this barbarism in some countries outside the Union, we must do so in those countries and not import this issue into Europe, as the Istanbul Convention suggests. Thirty million women worldwide are at risk of female circumcision. Let us protect them in their country, but let us not make genital mutilation an additional reason for immigration.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I, of course, supported this resolution because FGM is completely unacceptable, it is a crime against humanity, against human rights. It would be good if, on the basis of this resolution, at least in Europe, the states cooperated more and fought against this crime. If we could significantly reduce the number of these crimes on the territory of Europe, and if this resolution were not just left to the words on paper, but would have a de facto impact on the level that the police of individual Member States, the law enforcement authorities of individual Member States, would be more likely to seek out this crime and be able to judge it more in the European courts.  This is probably the only way to eradicate this heinous practice on EU territory in the future. From the point of view of third countries, I believe that economic support must be made for states according to their approach to human rights and thus to the protection of women's rights.

name: Jessica STEGRUD
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The girl who is to be mutilated is usually in primary school. First, she gets her legs tied. Then you take one half of a razor blade and cut off her clitoris. With the other half, you then cut off the labia and then sew together what is left. The result is always psychological trauma, lifelong pains and often major problems later in life during childbirth, menstruation and intercourse. Sometimes the consequence is death. Amnesty International equates genital mutilation with torture and believes that the perpetrators, regardless of where the crime is committed, should be brought to justice and punished. Although the first law against genital mutilation in Sweden came back in 1982, we now have, 38 years later, the most mutilated women per capita, and only three perpetrators have been convicted. We are, of course, voting in favour of the resolution today, but we are once again noting that the Swedish Government has done far too little, far too late.

name: Guido REIL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We have voted today on a resolution on FGM. What are we talking about? Who does it concern? It concerns young girls who are usually five to 13 years old. These girls are removed from their clitoris without ananalysing with a razor blade, the outer labia are cut off, the inner labia are cut off, and then they are usually sewn, from top to bottom, until only a very small hole remains. On the day they are married on their wedding night, they are cut open by their husband – with a knife. This incredible barbarity has had to endure 200 million women – in the 21st century, 200 million women. And where does that happen? It happens to them in Islamic countries; and we must finally talk about this and we must realise that it is happening in Islamic countries. With immigration, this incredible barbarity has also come to Europe. 600 000 women are now also affected here. We must finally put an end to this madness.

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: – Madam President, I support this resolution. I am delighted to see so many people in the European Parliament supporting it. FGM is an act of physical, sexual, and psychological violence and mostly carried out against infants and young girls up to the age of 15 years of age, and of course beyond. There are 200 million worldwide. It’s not something that just happens, for example, on the African continent. People often think of that, although 97% of women in Guinea have undergone FGM, including 45% of girls below 14, and in Ethiopia 65% of women, but of course it is happening in countries around the world. It is happening in Indonesia, Malaysia, South America and so on, and here in Europe. Let’s remember that 180 000 young girls, attending our schools, attending our youth clubs and involved in our communities are at risk of FGM in Europe. We have to take action to make sure that we have zero tolerance. I’m delighted to see across continents – and we saw this in Nairobi at the recent conference – young boys and men working to eliminate FGM. That’s also very important. We have to have this comprehensive strategy to end FGM now.

name: Margarita DE LA PISA CARRIÓN
text: – Madam President, our vote has been abstention. We are totally against female genital mutilation, but it cannot be considered just a way to discriminate against women. Putting it in the same sack, as this document proposes, is part of the problem. It goes much further. It is a way of not considering the woman person, of wanting to kill her initiative, her desires, her essence. He has the sole intention of turning women into a slave and, although this text denies it, it is a matter of religion; it's a completely cultural thing; not only is it male versus female, it's also female versus female, women's versus women. This painful issue has been used to mobilize en masse towards the feminist agenda, while bleaching those who promote this appalling practice. In the environment of Western values, of Christian values, women have never had this kind of unprotection. To excel these values is urgent, it is our compass in the face of such confusion. There can't be a successful strategy if we ignore the causes of the problem.

name: Vlad-Marius BOTOŞ
text: – Madam President, human beings are not property. Children are not property. We all state very loudly and clearly that we want to make our own choices, especially when we are talking about our own bodies. Four million girls every year are in danger of having that right taken from them. Four million girls between the ages of 1 month and 15 years old are at risk of undergoing female genital mutilation (FGM) for no reason other than that the parents or the grandparents or somebody in the family considers that it is nice to do it, or it is culturally appropriate. There are no health benefits from this procedure, and there are too many health hazards involved – from infection to excessive bleeding, from physical discomfort to sterility and to child death. We cannot allow these practices to go on in Europe. We cannot allow these girls, who have become European, to be taken away in countries where the practices are still in high fashion, to be mutilated. We have to protect their human rights – and not to be mutilated is one very important right of girls, of women. If we want them to become strong, healthy members of our society, if we want them to become protectors of human rights, we have to protect them now, when they need it most. I voted for this resolution, and I think this is a big start.

name: Veronika VRECIONOVÁ
text: – Madam President, female circumcision is one of the most horrific acts that can be included in violence against women. In addition to physical pain, it is also related to many years of mental and, of course, health problems. It is appalling that in the 21st century this act is still practiced in several dozen countries around the world, and tens to hundreds of thousands of women pass through it every year. Even in the EU, there are over 600 000 women who have undergone circumcision, and almost 200 000 young girls and women are at risk from this procedure. If we want to protect women and promote gender equality, steps to end this cruel practice will help women far more than media-quota quotas for the number of women in politics or in companies. Of course, I supported this resolution.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, I think we can all agree in the EP on the need to combat this inhumane, inhumane practice.  In this context, I would just like to remind you that it was our European Conservative faction and our N-VA MEP Assita Kanko who proposed for last year's Sakharov Prize a group of activists from Kenya known as The Restorers, who are actively fighting against this inhumane practice both in Africa and elsewhere in the world.  We will, of course, continue to do so, we have plans. In particular, I would also like to invite you Vice-President to this activity, and you will soon receive a proposal from us on this matter, and I hope that you will support it. Of course I supported this resolution.

name: Anne-Sophie PELLETIER
text: Madam President, I voted in favour of this resolution which is a step in the right direction for me, namely the protection of data freedom and consumer protection, and I would like to recognise the commitment of the Chair of the IMCO Committee.  You know, Rabelais used to say, "science without consciousness is nothing but soul ruin," and that's why it seems to me that we need to remain vigilant about artificial intelligence technologies. Indeed, these are not algorithms that can now manage whole sections of society and our daily lives - I want to think about public services, claims, banking - and that is why I draw your attention to two points where the text could, in my opinion, have been more ambitious in terms of transparency. Transparency is an essential fact for the confidence of our citizens. We can also strengthen this text by ensuring that software will never discriminate against the most vulnerable.  So yes to science, yes to progress, if and only if they are combined with ethics and morality.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I voted in favour of the resolution on ensuring consumer protection and the free movement of goods and services in the field of automated decision-making, because I believe that AI has the potential to provide facilities for citizens' lives.  AI systems are used in a variety of industries because of their ability to improve performance. They are innovative and simplify complex processes, but it is important that they are safe for consumers and work as intended. It is equally important that regulations are not unduly burdensome and do not discourage European companies from implementing and adapting these solutions. This resolution is a step towards finding such a balance.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: – Madam President, the general definition of automated decision making is the process of making a decision by automated means without any human involvement. This decision can be based on factual data as well as on digitally created profiles or inferred data. Let’s give examples here: an online decision to award a loan or an ability test in recruitment using pre—programmed algorithms and criteria. There are a number of benefits to such decision making – a quicker and more consistent decision among them – but what about risks, the risk of profiling, misuse of data, limiting consumers’ choices. We must be aware of these risks. That is why I voted for the resolution, which calls on the Commission to closely monitor developments in this area.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Madam President, I also voted on this resolution. I think it is very important to pay due attention to the whole mechanism of automated decision-making processes, and I believe that technology influences our daily lives in a positive way, but we need to think very carefully and find the necessary mechanisms to regulate this process to protect consumers.  Firstly, artificial intelligence is extremely important and has penetrated all areas, but end consumers, especially children, must be protected. Because transparency is the key to this mechanism, the end consumer must have access to how artificial intelligence and automated processes influence our daily lives. More transparency is therefore needed, which is why I supported this resolution.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, the shift towards automated decision-making and artificial intelligence will change the way in which consumer markets and our societies in general function. We need to ensure that people are protected from unfair or discriminatory commercial practices and we need to ensure that these processes are transparent and do not involve profiling. In this respect, auditing of automated decision-making should be carried out by independent third parties. People need to be able to contest these types of decisions. The Commission needs to ensure that the EU safety and liability frameworks are fit for purpose and that market watchdogs and other competent authorities are properly resourced and empowered to act. We need to be extremely wary of the concentration of data in the hands of a few private companies and we need to adhere to the principles of the GDPR, specifically in terms of purpose limitation and privacy by design.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Madam President, artificial intelligence makes it possible to process much more data than humans can do in a fraction of the time. It’s becoming increasingly common in finance, healthcare, education and the legal system. It’s increasingly evolving algorithmic decision systems. In many situations, the impact of the decision on people can be significant, such as access to credit, employment, medical treatment and judicial sentences. So I was happy to support this resolution, as it urges the Commission to examine whether additional measures are needed in order to guarantee a strong set of rights to protect consumers in AI decision-making; to ensure that consumers are protected from unfair and discriminatory practices, as well as from the risks entailed by AI-driven professional services; to guarantee greater transparency in these processes; and to ensure that only high-quality and non-biased data sets are used in algorithmic decision-making systems. The bottom line is we need to ensure that EU rules on safety and liability for products and services are fit for the digital age.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Madam President, just to say at the outset: I welcome the opportunity to speak on this very important issue, particularly in the context of Ireland itself and the citizens in Northern Ireland, in particular. While this is primarily about a trade deal with the UK and the European Union over the next number of months, it is critically important that Irish citizens are kept at the heart of this particular debate. There are hundreds of thousands of Irish citizens – who are European Union citizens as well – who are now living in Northern Ireland, outside of the European Union. I think that we have to when debating these issues – and I make no apologies for consistently raising the concerns of many Irish citizens living in Northern Ireland, so it must be at the heart of it. The integrity of the Good Friday Agreement must be upheld in any future deal as well. Finally, professional qualification recognition is something that will have to be to the fore to ensure that people can work on both sides of the border and that professional qualifications are recognised on both sides  – in the UK and the European Union – and that is critically important to the free movement of people on the island of Ireland.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Madam President, our British colleagues have left our Chamber. We owe them good memories. Nigel Farage thus symbolized for a long time the excellence produced by the attachment to a land and an identity, against all those who dream of a great void where nations should drown.  So how can we entrust a negotiating mandate which would be structured on something other than the arrogance of the European institutions and which would avoid, contrary to the resolution, provocative childishness denying Britain's sovereignty?  In reality, the behaviour of the European institutions during Brexit is an additional argument against any progress of their prerogatives: inability to respect the balance between nations, imbalance between objectives and assets... Nothing has been approached with the tact and measure that must prevail in this kind of situation. The Brexit debates were a kind of playground; the most unknown and least supported voices in their own countries lectured british-based personalities.  This is where arrogance can lead us at times, when people who want to be respected simply ask to be listened to. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of the resolution establishing the European Parliament’s position on the future relationship between the UK and the European Union. Establishing a new trade agreement with the UK must be of the utmost importance to the EU in this period, ensuring that as close and prosperous a relationship as possible can be established. This will of course require commitment from both sides and it’s certainly not helped by ambivalent statements that we hear at times from the UK. It will be key for the European Union, but particularly for Ireland and Northern Ireland and I welcome the ambition in this resolution to see such a relationship through a level playing field as part of an economic partnership and I hope that we can work with the UK, to ensure that we have a close and mutually beneficial relationship. I stress mutually beneficial because the UK’s trade with the EU is very substantial.  What is even more crucial is the continued preservation of the peace in Northern Ireland. The final agreement cannot in any way jeopardise the peace established by the Good Friday Agreement, and the final future relationship can in no way undo what has been previously agreed to in the Withdrawal Agreement and that will need ongoing monitoring in the months ahead.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Post-Brexit relations between the European Union and the United Kingdom must be settled. This resolution contains recommendations from the European Parliament to the Commission to negotiate a new partnership with the United Kingdom. The resolution covers a wide range of policies concentrated in three main categories: economic partnership, specific sectoral issues and thematic cooperation, as well as security and foreign affairs partnerships. While it is clear that a non-EU country cannot have the same privileges, rights or benefits as a Member State, we must remember that the future relationship between The United Kingdom and the European Union should be as cooperation-based as possible. Even if it is outside the Union, the UK remains a great European country linked to other European countries by history, the economy or security cooperation. It is in the interests of both the Union and the United Kingdom to ensure that our relations are as good as possible. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, although I did not agree with the departure of the United Kingdom, we have no choice but to vote in favour of a mandate that will allow for the creation of an agreement with the United Kingdom on the next cooperation, partnership. I think it is important that the EP has found a very broad consensus on this across the political spectrum and countries, and that is that the EU remains united on this. I am also very happy that we have agreement that this cooperation must be as close as possible.  The EP takes note of the UK's decision to conclude a free trade agreement with the EU and, of course, we are taking the conditions to keep these barriers to a minimum, and we will demand that access to the internal market for food and agricultural products is conditional on compliance with all internal standards – quality, safety, labelling, limited use of pesticides, etc. EP calls for the rights of EU citizens and their families to be preserved , who live in Britain and come from the EU.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I also supported this mandate and consider two things in the mandate to be very important. Firstly, that we are talking clearly about the rights of citizens, citizens of our countries, but also of the rights of the British, of their right to free movement. This needs to be clearly confirmed in future relations and therefore that these agreements are beneficial for our citizens. There are 30,000 citizens living in the UK from the Czech Republic and our aim is to provide them with maximum protection and support.  In addition, there is a free trade agreement in itself, which must be set up to be beneficial for both sides, for exporters from both sides. In short, we must do our utmost to ensure that exports from the EU to the UK are not damaged by Brexit. A number of companies export to the UK from the Czech Republic and we must do our ermue not to harm these companies and their business interests.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I was unhappy about Brexit and I have to say that I wish great Britain every success, but on the other hand I supported this mandate for many reasons. Firstly, I believe that the risk of a hard Brexit is still not averted, because unfortunately the British Prime Minister is taking a very special approach to these post-Brexit negotiations, and I think it is impossible to say that we are able to agree with the UK on trade relations at all costs.  My colleague Shoidrová has already spoken about this, there are a number of demands that we must insist on. There are a number of sensitive areas, securing the rights of the Republic of Ireland, the issue of Northern Ireland, agricultural products, compliance with standards, these are things that we will have to monitor. And I do not think that we should be blackmailed by the deadline for the end of these negotiations, which is due at the end of this year, and a number of regional parliaments are to be involved in this negotiation. I think that is something that we need to consider very carefully, and we should not be pushed into a corner.

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the negotiating mandate with the United Kingdom is preparing the largest free trade agreement ever concluded by the European Union.  Of course, as always, this mandate is wrapped in fine intentions on the European social model and wishful thinking on respecting our standards, but we are not fooled, because behind the beautiful varnish, what do we find? An obstinacy in the ideology of free trade that crushes the peoples of Europe and destroys our ecosystem, the introduction of an arbitration mechanism that usurps the sovereignty of European peoples for the benefit of private courts, the attachment to the system of greenhouse gas emission quotas - as if market mechanisms could respond to the climate crisis - and the ambition, finally, of enhanced cooperation in the military field in partnership with NATO. , a bellicose and outdated alliance.  Colleagues, while the British have just left the European Union, everything is going on as before. But what will it take for this Parliament to finally learn from it?

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, I supported today's resolution because there is a need for a comprehensive agreement between the United Kingdom and the European Union. Michel Barnier must continue with his good work to find a common position of the European Union, but also to deepen the relationship between us and the United Kingdom... (President interrupts speaker) Thank you, Madam President, I supported today's resolution because there is a need for a comprehensive agreement between the United Kingdom and the European Union. I find it ambitious and thorough. Let's remember for the sake of what the purpose of Brexit happened. The most important thing among them was for the UK to be able to sign so-called "Big Trade Deals" on its own. This is exactly what the European Union itself offers – a comprehensive and fair trade deal, duty-free, quota-free, but also without dumping and lowering European standards. But Prime Minister Johnson wants something else, a Canadian-type deal or even, I heard, from an Australian. In one case, there are restrictions and the other is subject to World Trade Organisation rules. Here is the place to say, whatever deal there is between Britain and the European Union, the country will be third for us. It is important that we continue our cooperation. The challenges ahead will require it more and more.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Madam President, we are in a situation where we are already talking in the past about the United Kingdom, which is no longer in the European Union, but we have an obligation to build a special relationship with the United Kingdom.  That's why I think we need to look at this in three keys. First, there are many Britons in the UK who did not want Britain to leave the European Union. Secondly: there are 3.5 million European citizens in the Kingdom today and they must not suffer because populist politicians have brought Britain to this point. And thirdly: all our political action must start from the premise that, at some point, Britain will return to the European Union.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: – Madam President, I still regret the fact that the United Kingdom has left the European Union. The weight of this departure for both sides is yet to be revealed, but I am pleased that no deal has been prevented.  I don't expect easy negotiations. In any case, there must be a close-up of the European Parliament, which, as the only European institution, directly represents European citizens and is obliged to ensure that their rights are adequately protected. I voted in favour of the resolution on the mandate to negotiate a new partnership because the mandate is very clearly based on the rights and obligations arising from the future partnership and on the fact that the UK cannot enjoy the same advantages as it had as a member of the EU.  It is very important that the resolution includes the most important concerns expressed by the European Parliament's committees, in particular the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, regarding the withdrawal agreement reached.  With the adoption of this resolution, the European Parliament has set out its red lines, which it will have to stick to when it delivers its opinion on the new partnership agreement.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This is a situation without precedent. The European Union after Brexit is an important but weaker organism, and things need to be called by name. Nevertheless, today is also the day and we are starting a discussion on the United Kingdom's agreement with the European Union. I wish Commissioner Barnier the best possible, but above all I wish the people – and the United Kingdom and the European Union – a good relationship with each other. It is very important that we are able to put out this fire and that we can look to the future together. The UK is a permanent element – always, in any situation when it comes to security. I believe that the security of the citizens of the United Kingdom, of the European Union and of the world should be discussed in the first place, because we all need a secure Europe and a safe world.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Madam President, the future trade agreement – when and if it is finalised – must have the approval of this Parliament and so I welcome the resolution today that I supported that sets out our priorities and what we see should be included in that agreement. Particularly the Good Friday Agreement and the unique situation that exists on the island of Ireland must be protected. The common travel area between Ireland and the United Kingdom, mentioned by the Commission in setting out their mandate for negotiations, must also be recognised. And a significant trade deal that would be mutually beneficial is needed for both sides. We need to ensure that European companies are not disadvantaged and put at a competitive disadvantage and we need to protect European consumers as well and recognise that this is unique; it’s with the sixth largest economy in the world, a former member of the European Union and a close neighbour.

name: Radosław SIKORSKI
text: – Madam President, I voted for the agreement because it adequately protects our interests. But given what it is and given the British Government’s red lines – no customs union, no jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice and no freedom of movement – I think this will lead to a barebones agreement on goods. The pyramid of lies peddled by europhobes in Britain is beginning to crash. The British Government is beginning to acknowledge that there will be customs and other checks on the border between us from January next year. Therefore, in the name of freer trade, Britain will be erecting barriers with her biggest trading partner. What a disaster.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I too am pleased to support this important resolution on the draft negotiating mandate. This is a key step towards the opening of negotiations in the future EU—UK relationship.  It is very welcome that the draft reflects the breadth and ambition of the scope of the political declaration for a broad and deep partnership with the UK. It is also important that the effective implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement continues in parallel with the negotiation of the future relationship and that this is reflected in the mandate. There is a continuing focus in the draft mandate on protecting the Good Friday Agreement and the Common Travel Area. Protecting the Good Friday Agreement and maintaining the Common Travel Area in all circumstances continue to be key priorities for Ireland and also, thankfully, for the EU 27. I thank my colleagues for their continued support of Irish priorities and I am hopeful that, with genuine cooperation from the United Kingdom, a good outcome can be reached.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, the Irish Central Bank is still destroying the EUR 31 billion promissory note bonds that resulted from the bank bailout in 2008. The banks in question were eventually liquidated, but the European Central Bank (ECB) still insist that the entire EUR 31 billion be taken out of circulation by the Irish Central Bank. Irish people have suffered a decade of austerity and as head of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) at the time, Ms Lagarde was front and centre of this imposition of austerity on Ireland. The eurozone crisis also provided an excuse for the previous head of the ECB, Mr Mario Draghi, to introduce a fiscal compact in 2012. It institutionalised and made permanent what were supposed to be emergency austerity programmes. It accomplished a lifelong neoliberal dream – the complete separation between the democratic process and economic policies. As Germany’s Finance Minister said in 2015 elections change nothing, there are rules. The ECB and Ms Lagarde as Managing Director of the IMF, brought Ireland to its knees. I don’t recall any ECB annual report in recent years mentioning this. It should never be forgotten. Of course we opposed it.

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Today, the majority here in the European Parliament, you have repeatedly called for Sweden to adopt the euro. In the annual report of the European Central Bank, you write that it is compulsory to adopt the single currency. Let me inform you that Sweden had a referendum on EMU in 2003 in which a massive majority voted against Swedish membership. Today, only one in five Swedes wants your euros. We do not want to fertilise money over countries that cannot take responsibility for their own economies. We want the Swedish crown.  What don't you get? You call yourself democrats, but you act like arrogant, undemocratic bullies with no respect for the will of the people. We may have had a weak government that did not negotiate an official Swedish exemption, but respect the Swedish people's will. We do not want the euro, and we will work to vote for a Swedish derogation.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: Madam President, a few months ago, everyone applauded the appointment of a woman to head the European Central Bank. But make no mistake: it is the tree that hides the forest, as sexism still reigns supreme in the European economic institutions.  to those who doubt it, I have brought here some pictures of those who decide today on the economic and monetary governance of the euro area. Here is the ECB's executive board: two women out of six people. The Governing Council of the European Central Bank, even better: two women out of 25 people. The list is still long and our committee on economic and monetary affairs does no better, with only 11 women out of 60 members. So there would be no woman competent enough for these positions, as a right-wing Member of Parliament in our committee dared to answer? Frankly, this is not serious, and such a lack of parity is unacceptable. It is time for this to change, by finally taking binding measures. Be sure, women will no longer be intimidated or marginalized. We have our place at the helm of European economic governance and we intend to take it.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, I was very glad to see Madame Lagarde here yesterday and very disappointed that I didn’t get the chance to put these points to her myself, because she is, of course, a household name in Ireland from her role in the IMF and the crushing austerity imposed on the citizens of Ireland. The result of that has been, in effect, a lost decade. The official cost of the bailout was EUR 64.6 billion, but the human cost is still being paid: the welfare cuts, the housing crisis, infant malnutrition, dying family members on hospital trolleys, and a generation of young people who left our shores. But last weekend the price was paid back by the Irish citizens when Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael, the two ruling parties responsible for that austerity, were given an almighty hammering in the election, and I think that is the face of things to come. The neoliberalism at the heart of the ECB is something that will not be tolerated by citizens.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: – Mr President, the main fiscal problem in the euro area is the Stability and Growth Pact, which makes countries miserable, makes it impossible to have an active cyclical policy and makes it impossible to invest in social welfare, which in the long run is the smartest economic policy ever. At the moment, it also makes it impossible to investment in the climate and move towards a carbon-neutral society.  The ECB has exactly the same obligation as everyone else to participate in climate work, and it is perfectly possible to do so within its mandate, because if the mandate is to maintain price stability, carbon risk is a major risk to price stability.  Billions and billions of money have been created out of thin air in recent years, pumped into the financial markets to support the problems caused by financial gamblers. It should also be possible to direct that same force and that same amount of money to climate work. One way that, unfortunately, was rejected today in the vote is for the Central Bank to commit itself to buying the Bank's green bonds. This would be entirely within the mandate, and it is a pity that Parliament rejected this proposal, which is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Madam President, just to say at the outset that I welcome the opportunity to speak on this particular resolution, and I would ask that immediate steps be taken by the Commission to address the issue of illegal trade in cats and dogs, primarily in the context of industrial-scale breeding farms across the European Union whereby animals are incarcerated for years and years and years just to produce puppy dogs and kittens. I believe we have an obligation as a civilised society to, at the very least, ensure there is some form of registration of these particular puppy farms and cat farms, that this trade is registered in some way and that there are regulations governing it. There’s no doubt that there is a large criminal element involved in the smuggling and moving of animals within the European Union. It has public health implications, but most importantly of all it is an animal cruelty issue, it is an animal welfare issue, and the Commission itself must ensure that the internal market governs these particular farms to ensure that there are standards of decency in them.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, I am absolutely delighted to be able to support this motion and to really welcome the initiative taken to address the illegal pet trade, which is a phenomenal problem in Ireland, actually, where a number of individuals have been finally brought to court for treating animals so appallingly and for their own private profit. This issue has evoked huge sympathy from the Irish public and grave concern about the lack of enforcement by our regulatory authority. I do think that the motion was very much strengthened by the addition of the amendments calling for mandatory identification and registration, which will be an assist, but also calling on the Commission and Member States to take measures to prohibit breeding and marketing practices that are detrimental to the health and welfare of these animals. This is a great step forward and I’m delighted to be able to support it.

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Last year, little Astrid came to our family – an adorable Cavalier King Charles who was full of love. When we bought her, we found out that she was imported into Belgium from Slovakia, and when we came to the vet for a routine check, they told us, who were untreated dog owners, that there was systematic cheating. So what are they doing in the countries of origin? What would they have done to Astrid? They cheat with the dates of birth. They bring the dates ahead so that the puppies can get on the market faster. They are separated from the mothers far too early, long before the eight weeks required to provide security for the puppies. It creates a lifelong trauma that manifests itself in stress behavior. The puppies are vaccinated too early, so that it does not provide adequate protection. The problem here is that many rogue operators, illegal operators, get away with it. I therefore voted in favour of European coordination of the registration and identification of pets in the hope that other animals, other cats and dogs, will get off to a better start than our Astrid got.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I am very glad that over 600 Members supported the motion for a resolution against the illegal transport of animals in Europe.  This is a very strong signal that the EP wants to tackle this terrible activity by smugglers and illegal breeders, and I hope that, on the basis of this resolution, the EC will prepare clear measures to prevent tens of thousands of puppies and kittens from the eastern part of the EU from being transported to western EU countries every year under terrible conditions and sold there in this way.  It is good that this resolution has such support, and I call on the Commission to stop trivializing this issue at last and really start paying attention to this subject. As I said yesterday, no Member State can resolve this issue on its own. This is a European problem and I thank the rapporteurs for tabing this proposal.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I, as co-rapporteur and rapporteur, have, of course, also supported this proposal. I am very glad that only 3 of our colleagues were against it, otherwise this proposal found clearly cross-cutting support. I also agree that this is not in the ambition and possibilities to deal only in isolation in individual Member States. This – illegal behaviour, a profitable business for a group of smugglers – must indeed be dealt with by the EC together with the Member States. The cross-border effect there is quite clear - animals are suffering, consumers are being misled, unfair competition is taking place, our internal market is being disrupted, these are all negatives that really call for action, especially from the EC. I was a little disappointed with the Commissioner's speech yesterday, I firmly believe that the Commission will realise how many hundreds of thousands of consumers, I would say millions of cheated families, are now staring at the EC and I firmly believe that the Commission will act.

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, animal trafficking has plagued Europe for years. According to Interpol, it is the third largest in the world, just behind arms trafficking and drug trafficking. Since the 2000s, the rise of pet shops, online ads and social networks, the situation is getting worse every day.  According to the NGO Four Paws, about eight million puppies are needed each year to meet European online demand and the market generates more than one billion euros in revenue. The big losers are the animals. Most are raised illegally and in battery by organized chains, under undignified conditions. They are females treated in machines to reproduce until exhaustion, they are tens of thousands of small puppies and kittens torn far too early from their mothers, little or not cared for, not vaccinated, raised sometimes without regard for their basic needs before being transported across Europe in conditions to which some simply do not survive.  It is high time that our countries adopted a mandatory and harmonized identification system to counter traffickers. It is time to frame animal sales on the internet as a first step towards, we hope, their outright ban. That is why I voted for this resolution.

name: Vlad-Marius BOTOŞ
text: – Madam President, two weeks ago, I had the pleasure to organise a debate in my hometown of Arad, Romania, regarding this issue, with animal lovers. I am glad to see that pets, our best friends, have come to the attention of the European Union and that today we are voting on a motion on this. It is time that we stopped the illegal pet trade. Trade in cats and dogs must have at the centre the welfare of the animals and the joy they bring to their new owners, not just financial gain. They become part of our families. They are not just objects to buy. Because of that – because of the role they play in our lives – I think it is time to do much more for them. We cannot stop at regulating the trade. We need to consider the lives of the pets too. There are many dogs and cats that are abandoned when humans do not want them anymore. It is a sad reality and any NGO dealing with abandoned pets can give you many sad details about this ugly side of being a pet. This must be regulated, too. What do we do with the litters of the dogs that the owners do not want? What do we do with the kittens found in sealed bags, discarded at the side of the road? They are not in the trade market. We have to think of European legislation to protect them, too. These unwanted puppies and kittens also deserve our attention. We should be doing something for them. *****

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I would now like to give the floor to Thierry Mariani, who would like to make a personal speech to Mr Glucksmann before the vote.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Madam President, I would have preferred to respond to this personal questioning immediately after Mr. President's remarks.  Glucksmann, but thank you for giving me the floor, even if the Chamber is a little sparse. This would have allowed me to apologise for a clumsiness that I sincerely regret, with regard to the very last words of my speech yesterday. As the video shows, I was speaking under the logical pressure of the hammer that signalled the end of my speaking time. I was no longer reading my text and I sincerely regret speaking of "rebels" instead of saying "the elimination of terrorists". Having said that, these words are in no way hate speech and I conclude that it is time to acknowledge that there are no more rebels for a long time, but Islamists in this region. I leave the final word to the UN report, which said last June: "Idlib is now the largest dump for terrorist fighters in the world". I repeat my sincere apologies.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the topical debate (Rule 162) on A Social Europe in a Digital World (2020/2550(RSP)). I would like to inform Members that for this debate there is no catch-the-eye procedure and that no blue cards will be accepted.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: author. – Madam President, first of all, thank you for this opportunity. I guess that digital technologies provide us with a big opportunity of possibilities at our fingertips and never before have people had so many opportunities to learn, to communicate, to participate or to create. Unfortunately, a lot of Europeans still lack the necessary digital understanding and skills in order to fully embrace the opportunities of the digital revolution.  Yesterday, we celebrated the Safer Internet Day, but one day a year might not be enough to stress the importance of media competence and safety. European education systems, therefore, must be modernised across Europe to prevent a digital divide in society. I would like to thank, in particular, the Finnish Presidency at that time for providing European citizens with free access to online courses on artificial intelligence (AI). AI can have enormous benefits for people and society, but we have to put humans – and this is important for us – in first place.  Employment and social policies must keep pace with the digitalisation of our labour markets. We need a social contract for the new world including minimum wages, strengthening collective bargaining and, in particular, the right to disconnect. We need, also, to create fair working conditions for workers, no matter whether offline or online. And we have to tackle the tech giants, their abusive market—dominant power and create a level playing field and taxes should be paid where profits are generated.  The European Union to needs to have a new legal framework on artificial intelligence and robotics, including a guarantee for upholding fundamental rights. The EU Commission will present the White Paper on AI next week. It should tackle this ethical aspect of AI, legal safeguards and liability. The algorithms must be free of bias. AI must not discriminate on the grounds of gender or ethnicity, and we say, ‘no AI without ethics’. Therefore, we urge the European Commission to come forward with a regulatory framework for this. Large sets of data are key for AI applications. They will fuel them. Cambridge Analytica and Clearview – these companies are the most prominent examples for the invasive use and abuse of their personal data. Voter manipulation and deepfakes, for example, are serious threats to our democracies.  The digital revolution is nothing new, and it has been going on for years, but we constantly need to find new answers to the new technologies. Just a reminder, the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), for example, took almost six years from the start until adoption and this shows us that artificial intelligence, surveillance and facial recognition are already rolled out across the European Union and we need to hurry up in structuring them. It is our duty as the European Parliament and representatives of the people of the European Union to make sure that nobody is left behind. The European digital agenda must be based on our European values and should offer opportunities for everyone.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity to participate in this debate today. It is indeed important to reflect on how the Union can, within its competences, help to ensure that an increasingly digitalised Europe remains recognisable as the social Europe we know. Our social market economy is our competitive advantage globally. We need to defend it but also to adapt it to the changing world. Digitalisation is a broad and cross-cutting transformation process which presents opportunities and risks. It can be an engine for innovation and the creation of new quality jobs. It can increase labour productivity. It can enhance the well—being of workers, thereby also contributing to the reconciliation of work and private life. It can also offer new opportunities to people from vulnerable groups, including persons with disabilities. As with any change, however, there are also risks which we need to be aware of. The EU stands at the forefront in efforts to ensure that technological developments result in social equitable benefits and in protecting those at risk of falling behind. EU Member States played an important role in the 2019 ILO Declaration on the Future of Work, which they promptly endorsed and promoted. Today I would like to address three aspects related to digitalisation, which we can already see will have a significant impact on our lives: first, required skills; second, the platform economy; and third, the broader social impact of digitalisation. On skills: the impact of digitalisation on the labour market is twofold. First, it increases the demand for highly-skilled workers and other workers with the right skills. Second, certain jobs change significantly or even disappear. This risks increasing structural unemployment, creating new inequalities and leading to the polarisation of the labour market due to a loss of intermediate-level jobs. We already observe a skills mismatch today with the skills shortage, notably in ICT but also in related fields like engineering, mathematics, science and technology. In these fields, we also observe a high gender imbalance. This is likely to get worse if we do not react. To face this, we need to take into account the impact of the digital revolution over the whole human life cycle, from early childhood to old age. No one should be left behind, and well-being is an important factor in this regard. Both women and men are needed to fill the shortage in ICT skills across all occupations and sectors. Education and training systems should systematically prevent and combat stereotypes and discrimination. Collaboration between all stakeholders is vital for the successful management of tomorrow’s job requirements. The social partners play a crucial role in this process, helping to maintain the adaptability of the labour force. Regarding the platform economy, we all struggle to clearly define what is meant by this widely-encompassing term. Digital platforms bring service providers and their customers into direct contact. Many platforms work with people who are formally self—employed but who depend economically and organisationally on the platform. This form of organisation often has a negative impact on the level of pay, social protection, occupational health and safety, the right to paid leave, and other aspects. Effective social dialogue at all levels and a balance in the bargaining power is indispensable for securing a fair and equitable future of work, but it is difficult for platform workers to organise their presentations, as they often do not know each other. The Council has already addressed a number of issues related to new forms of work. Decent working conditions must be ensured for all, regardless of changes in employment patterns and, where necessary, by adapting the national legislative frameworks. At Union level, a first step has been made with the Directive on Transparent and Predictable Working Conditions adopted in June last year, which notably protects on—demand workers. The Recommendation on access to social protection for workers and the self—employed, adopted by the Council in December, makes explicit reference to platform workers. It recommends that Member States provide access to social protection for all, including the self—employed. The Council also highlighted that social protection policies should be balanced with making work pay policies. In this regard, it is important that people in a non—standard employment relationship can also benefit from collective bargaining. On a number of occasions, the Council has made it clear that workers in new forms of work should also be adequately protected in terms of occupational health and safety, irrespective of the size of the enterprise or the type and duration of the employment relationship. The Council also stressed the need to ensure an effective implementation and enforcement of EU law on working conditions and health and safety, including for new forms of work. A better understanding of platform work is a prerequisite for defining further policy responses. In this respect, we look forward to the platform work summit organised jointly by the future German Presidency and the Commission in October 2020. Thirdly, and finally, regarding the social impact, changes related to digitalisation have different impacts on different actors. On one hand, people can organise their work more flexibly and, on the other hand, face—to—face interactions decrease and constant connectivity means that people can never truly disconnect. New job opportunities can be created, for example for rural populations or people with disabilities. Working people have access to better tools to perform their jobs more efficiently. At the same time, employers are provided with better tools to monitor and optimise output efficiency. To conclude, technological development is inevitable and should be embraced. Fostering the development of new technologies will give us more control over the direction it takes, to make it more ethical and human-centred. As policy-makers, we should be aware of the full picture and make informed decisions, without forgetting that our social market economy remains one of our strongest assets.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: membre de la Commission. – Madame la Présidente, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, la transformation numérique va avoir, est déjà en train d’avoir, des répercussions sans précédent sur nos économies, nos sociétés, notre façon de travailler, de communiquer, de consommer. La question de l’emploi est sûrement au centre des interrogations. Combien d’emplois vont disparaître, remplacés par des robots? Ce qui est d’ores et déjà certain, c’est que la majorité des emplois vont être transformés. De nouveaux emplois vont apparaître quand d’autres disparaîtront ou connaîtront de profonds bouleversements. Il est prévu que l’intelligence artificielle et la robotique créeront à elles seules près de 60 millions d’emplois dans le monde au cours des cinq prochaines années et déjà aujourd’hui, cela a été mentionné, près d’un million d’emplois TIC sont vacants, faute de candidats ayant les bonnes qualifications. C’est d’ailleurs le principal souci de nombreuses entreprises, surtout de PME, qui ne trouvent pas de personnel qualifié. C’est aussi un défi majeur pour nos politiques de l’emploi et de qualification.  We have acted on the green transition by launching the Just Transition Fund for regions and people most affected by these changes. Likewise, we need to strengthen much more our employment and social policies to anticipate and manage the disruptive changes expected from digitalisation. There are – and it has been already mentioned – a lot of very good opportunities, but there are also risks of widening inequalities and more precariousness. Over 90% of jobs now require some level of digital skills, as does participation in society at large, yet 43% of the EU population have an insufficient level of digital skills and 17% have none at all. Next month we will propose a new skills agenda to address the skills challenges through concrete instruments and this challenge is huge because, according to a lot of forecasts, about half of the European workforce, meaning more than 120 million people have to be re—skilled or upskilled. So, we have three major aims. The first one is engaging employers to upscale their training provision, and for that purpose, we want to launch a skills pact committing companies, committing the business community to invest in their workforce. Second, we have to step up public and private investment in training according to this need I just mentioned. And third, we have to empower people to invest in their own skills and qualifications. Many of our initiatives post 2020 will address these challenges linked to digitalisation. The European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) will support projects, such as the creation of e—schools with digitally trained teachers or training unemployed people for ICT jobs. And I’m working on a reinforced Youth Guarantee to provide a much stronger coverage of digital skills. Non—standard forms of work are on the rise, and come with flexible but also very often with inadequate working conditions, insufficient access to social protection, decreased coverage by social dialogue and absence of a right to collective representation. This challenges our labour laws and social protection systems and calls for a rethink of existing models to match the needs of old and new work arrangements and ensure decent working conditions, inclusion and high level of social protection. The digitalisation is changing notions of work of employer—employee relationships and of workplaces and it is absolutely indispensable that we create some clarity in this new world of work. New technologies also blur the lines between work and private life. This creates new physical and mental health risks and, therefore, the right to disconnect has to be dealt with. The use of data in employment has led to new algorithm—based management and an increased profiling in social protection provision. These can improve productivity but also increase control on individuals and surveillance of workers’ performance. It raises questions of protection of personal data; we should pay attention to this in the context of the regulation of artificial intelligence. We need accessible and interoperable digital technologies in order to exploit the potential of digitalisation to increase the autonomy of persons with disabilities and to boost their participation in society and the economy. The digital transformation must also be an opportunity in the context of the demographic challenges we face in particular in relation to our aging population and the existing rural and remote areas. We also should devote special attention to the gender gap that exists in the digital world. Europe has to be a competitive and innovative player in the digital economy. New initiatives on the Digital Services Act and artificial intelligence will play a key role, while also addressing risks of bias and discrimination.
