On 22 September I’m organising together with Executive Vice—President Vestager, a summit on platform work where we discuss how to improve working and social conditions on online platforms. Beyond this, we have launched the process leading to an action plan on the European Pillar of Social Rights, because the principles of the pillar should also apply fully to the new digital world of work. The pillar frames our social strategy to make sure that the transition towards a digital and climate—neutral society is socially fair and sustainable.

name: Dennis RADTKE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, I would like to thank Mr Ertug for putting the issue on the agenda here today, and thus, so to speak, to reconnect the social dimension and the discussion we are having here on social Europe with this important issue, digitisation. Thank you very much for that. I share much of what has already been said here. In the discussions that we still have to have, we must not overlook the fact that over the last 20 years we have seen fundamental upheavals in the world of work within the European Union: on the one hand, employment relationships that have changed completely – namely on-demand work, but also crowd workers and click workers – but on the other hand, we now have a very different way of working in many places. We all have these devices in our pockets, and we all know how difficult it is when you have such devices in your pocket, to have some work day and to be able to switch off at some point. It is very important to me, in the discussions that we are now having, that, on the one hand, we assess the opportunities, but also the risks, in a very sober and objective manner, and look at where we need to intervene and where we need to support them. For it is clear to me that whether it is about technology, whether it is about the economy – and the opportunities, I think, have just been pointed out correctly – both have a serving function towards human beings. This must also be the leitmotif for our political work in this field.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Mr President, in 10 years' time, people's work will look completely different thanks to digital techniques that we do not even know yet. That can provide a lot of opportunities, but then we have to push the changes in the right direction. Already, platform workers, such as the Uber drivers in Amsterdam, are asking for a fair income. They ask for normal working hours and they ask for an influence on the ratings, because with one bad rating – they know – they are the jackass. They know what it means when algorithms determine your work. There's another way. That is why, in Europe, we must focus on digitisation, which is about people, with good work and with a decent income. We need strong and social European rules for the platform economy and we would like to make agreements on them at the Platform Work Summit announced before 22 September.

name: Dragoș PÎSLARU
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, we Europeans believe in democratic values and a citizen-oriented democracy means an inclusive society in which citizens have access to and benefit from the opportunities offered by the EU. We owe this to our citizens. The European Union is well known as a champion of legislation, regulation, directives that have brought positive changes alright, but this time law is not enough. It must be accompanied by concrete action for a bold objective to transform the EU into a champion of innovation in digital. Alas, we are lagging behind. We cannot do this when almost one out of five EU citizens had no digital skills in 2017 and the situation is no different now.  Digital literacy and skills are key pillars of adapting European citizens to a labour market that is constantly transforming and changing our work arrangements. This is the priority, the key priority of today and tomorrow. We need to answer the daily concerns of European citizens by providing them ways of adapting to the new challenges and opportunities to develop new skills and access to the labour market. The question is how, and the best way we can do this is by literally investing in people this time. We need investments that can bring together expertise and capital from the public, private and non-profit sectors together in order to ensure the digital transformation that we want to put forward is paving the way for all citizens to achieve a high level of well-being and overcome inequalities of technological use at EU level. What if we established an EU public-private fund that will invest immediately and massively in digital literacy and skills, based on the principle of social impact investment? We have investEU. We have the private sector recognise the importance of digital education. What do we wait for? The impact is also easy to monitor the measure. I launch hereby, a call for action to invest in digital education for a more competitive and social Europe and thus expanding opportunities provided by digital technology so that the children of today successfully shape the renewed digital Europe of tomorrow.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a social Europe in a digital world: it is astonishing that everyone here has taken the side of not simply talking about social Europe before addressing the digital world. Does this social Europe exist? I know this, because here all my colleagues from the Employment and Social Affairs Committee are present. We know, for example, that the coordination of social security systems is particularly difficult and I know that some here believe that digitizing our data would be a panacea. I would say that artificial intelligence and robotics do have risks and that a regulatory framework is absolutely necessary. But I would like to warn you about such projects that would seriously undermine our national sovereignty. Such projects where data protection is all the less assured because the European Union has ignored digital sovereignty and made us totally vulnerable to China and the United States. I would add that the principle of consent to the collection of data from our workers, social insured or retired is seriously questioned. This could drift towards systematic coping, commercial data traffic, or worse. So yes, we must work and move towards cooperation between States and digitisation and make efforts to do so, but ladies and gentlemen, we now face more immediate and profound challenges, such as social dumping, tax dumping or the excesses of globalism. Above all, let us settle the essentials here, this is what our compatriots expect.

name: Alexandra GEESE
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has You have just mentioned this briefly: digital technologies are increasingly discriminating against poor people. Globally, we are all increasingly monitored. But it hits people who need support from society. In Europe, such a system was put to an end in court last week – for human rights violations. It is the Dutch SyRI system, which is designed to predict which beneficiaries are more likely to be scams. For this purpose, comprehensive, very personal data is brought together and analyzed with a secret algorithm without democratic control. But the welfare state is social because it is there for the people, and digital systems that humiliate and spy on people have nothing to do with it. Counter-question: Why has no one yet come up with the idea of looking at where the state lacks the very large sums that we now need to invest in digital education? Why don't we use artificial intelligence to detect tax evasion? The standards that would be applied by such a system are already urgently needed.

name: Elżbieta RAFALSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We are constantly hearing that there must be man at the heart of the digital economy. How do you reconcile these ambitious challenges with new digital technologies and the feeling that this best solution and change is good for the worker? The fact that robotics and artificial intelligence are an opportunity for new jobs, we know that, but we also need to see risks. We also want these to be quality jobs offering new forms of employment and an attractive place of employment.  We must ensure that this is an opportunity for all the countries of the European Union and that digital exclusion does not affect Central and Eastern Europe, the countries that are on the acquis. The European Union must support poorer regions more. However, before these changes, there is no turning back. In the digital economy, it is not the regulations themselves, the directives will be decisive, but a new professional reality that guarantees social protection, good working conditions and social inclusion.

name: Leila CHAIBI
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, modernity is not disposable, underpaid workers without social protection. This is called a return to the Middle Ages. All over the world, in Spain, Belgium and as far as California, justice comes to the same conclusion: digital platforms cheat and exploit the most precarious. Deliveroo was convicted of concealed labour for the first time in France last week. In fact, the court recognized that, under the pretext of freedom and flexibility, Deliveroo was defrauding the labour code by forcing its bicycle delivery drivers to be false independents rather than giving them an employment contract. Commissioner, outside this Parliament, outside, on the streets of all our cities in Europe, these new digital convicts are looking at us, they are looking at you and they can't wait any longer. What are you waiting for, what are we waiting for to force platforms to recognize delivery drivers, to recognize drivers as what they really are, that is, employees? Employees to whom we must guarantee the same protections and access to collective representation as to all other employees.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Madam President, the European Union's estimates are of great concern about a new recession and crisis. In this environment, you present as a solution — among other things — the digitisation of the economy. However, in the context of the capitalist economy, these innovative applications are the subject of intense competition between European, Chinese and American technology giants over who will lead the race for profitability — and with billions of euros in subsidies.  Instead of innovative applications relieving workers and improving working conditions, they will bring thousands of workers into unemployment — according to your forecasts. Wages will be broken and hours, contracts and insurance rights will be dissolved. This insoluble contradiction is the same as the system of exploitation that you zealously defend and which the European Union and its governments serve, and in Greece both New Democracy today and SYRIZA previously.  It is only labour power and the centrally designed economy, taking advantage of scientific and technological progress, that will free peoples from suffering; this is the future of humanity.

name: Sara SKYTTEDAL
text: – Madam President, the European Union is a social success and the single market is the main reason for this. Since my own country, Sweden, entered the Union 25 years ago, we have seen an exceptional increase in our GDP which has given us the opportunity to increase our welfare spending. Our real wages have almost doubled and social protection is at an all time high. The same pattern is also visible in newer Member States. So the EU has a role to play in terms of social welfare, partly through legislative proposals but especially by championing a social market economy that makes the Member States prosper. As we enter a new world of work with opportunities and challenges rising in the wake of digitalisation, we must look at what we have done and ask ourselves how we can do the same again. We should strive for social protection and welfare for our citizens. However, if the EU loses its competitiveness in the digital era due to bad regulation there will be no jobs to go to, let alone welfare for our citizens.

name: Alex AGIUS SALIBA
text: – Madam President, yes, digital technologies have changed every aspect of our life, including the existing working and business models and the way we communicate with each other. There are no physical boundaries in the digital world, but there are also no clear rules. A few big companies are setting the new digital values and ethics, shaking up existing rules, raising questions of equal conditions, responsibility, safety and protection of employees. It’s time that we delivered a strong social dimension and a safe online environment for our citizens. What is not allowed offline should not be allowed online, especially if it is done to the detriment of the people.  New working models in the digital age must not become a synonym for exploitation and surveillance of workers’ performance. One way to address this is through the digital right to disconnect. Just like the eight-hour working day, workers and employees should have a mandatory minimum level of digitally disconnected time per day. The Commission must also examine the new digital risks and consequences for the wellbeing of workers, including the issues of additional working hours.

name: Sylvie BRUNET
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Secretary of State, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to stress two points.  First of all, one of the most visible consequences of digitisation in the social and employment field, as we have said, is the emergence of new forms of work, particularly through the development of platforms. In practice, these platforms cover very different realities, which can make our task as legislators more complex. We must strike the right balance between the opportunity of new employment opportunities and the protection of these workers, avoiding them a possible precariousness.  In this regard, I think it is my priority to guarantee them decent working conditions, as well as access to social protection - in the event of illness or accident at work. I have no doubt, Commissioner, that you will do so with determination. We must also allow these workers to organize collectively to defend their interests. Finally, ensuring training opportunities is essential to ensure the quality of service delivery and individual career prospects.  The second point I would like to emphasise is the very poor positioning of the European Union in terms of digital skills, since 40% of our workforce currently has little or no digital skills. It seems to me that it is time to update our training software. Let's invest heavily in digital skills! There is an urgent need, particularly on the eighth of the key competencies, which is digital competence. Why not a digital passport in the European Union, which would be visible and on which we must invest heavily.

name: Jean-Lin LACAPELLE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at the time of 5G, some territories in peripheral France do not yet have access to the digital world. What has the European Union done? On these and so other issues, it is far behind and its current functioning does not allow it to serve nations. Finding a Europe of nations, which proposes a social policy towards the digital world in the interest of nations, must now be a priority. in contrast to the current European Union, which acts in a logic of free trade that is ever less just and less egalitarian. The social Europe we want is coordination between European nations and equality between the territories. The globalism advocated in this assembly, which concentrates all its activities in a few metropolises, we do not want it, we do not want any more. We oppose your ultraliberalism to the right exchange. We oppose localism of proximity to your urban concentration. All this in a democratic and modern Europe, which relies on digital technology to make peoples and nations shine, if not submit to the European Union and its Commission.

name: Kim VAN SPARRENTAK
text: – Madam President, the Commission has promised us a more social Europe time and time again, and if we want to deliver on these promises we need to look at the real life effects the digital economy has. Finding an affordable place to live has become nearly impossible in many European cities. Mayors of major cities such as Amsterdam, Prague and Barcelona have declared that short-term rental platform such as Airbnb and Booking are one of the main causes of the housing crisis we are currently in.  Airbnb wasn’t set up to let private investors buy dwellings in big cities to turn them into illegal hotels, but we have moved far beyond the initial idea of the airbed and occasional renting out of a spare room, and due to intensive lobbying European market rules are currently protecting the billions these platforms are making, rather than ensuring that people have an affordable house to live in.  We need to make sure that a social Europe will be at the core of our efforts towards a Europe fit for the digital age, and that this isn’t an opening, a back door, for the big corporations to undermine a social Europe.

name: Margarita DE LA PISA CARRIÓN
text: – Madam President, today we can recognize the importance of digital technologies in our lives, the impact on our productive and social model. States will have to make important decisions to prepare for this transition. Digitization cannot cause dehumanization. We are facing a new model of work. We should prevent automation from creating a large number of jobs. The training of young people and workers must adapt with agility and flexibility to the new professions. We must ensure real and adequate protection for workers in the face of these new challenges, while promoting the competitiveness of our companies, their investments and their growth. We have the great opportunity to revitalize rural and depopulated areas through access to the digitization of its inhabitants, in order to achieve greater economic, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Dino GIARRUSSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, no one must lag behind the opportunities offered by the digital revolution. As there are disparities, we must take immediate action to ensure that digital Europe is a chance to reduce inequalities, not to increase them, and this also applies to entrepreneurs, not just individual citizens. Oligopolies have been created which, in the European tradition of free competition, must be regulated, ensuring that the digital giants pay taxes and avoiding excessive concentrations and a type of unfair competition, I am thinking in particular of digital trade in the traditional economy.  Finally, digital medicine, agriculture, information: in the coming years we should be able to use digital to better protect health, to implement agricultural production and certify the origin and quality of our products and to fight fake news, since it is true that a lie on the net can travel faster, but just as quickly it can be unmasked and we have a duty to create structures and systems that can do it quickly , continuous and effective.

name: David CASA
text: – Sinjura President, it-teknoloġija qed tbiddel il-mod ta' kif naħdmu, kif nistudjaw, kif nitħarrġu. Qed toħloq ukoll tipi ta' xogħlijiet ġodda u l-konnettivitá tagħtina opportunitajiet ġodda, imma tfisser ukoll sgre sfidi ġodda għalina.  Id-Direttiva tal-bilan大 bejn il-ħajja u x-xogħol li nnegozjajt b'su大大大ess fil-leġiżlatura li għaddiet tindirizza dan l-iżvilupp skull. Se tkun aktar faħan-nisa li jidħlu u jibqgħu fid-dinja tax-xogħol biex innaqqsu l-qgħad kif ukoll biex innaqqsu d-differenza gravi li għandna fil-pagi u fil-pensjonijiet bejn l-irġiel u n-nisa. Jien nilqa' l-impennl tal-Gumsjoni li qed tagħmel l-istrateġija, għaliex qed niffa大大jaw sfidi psikoloġi大i f'dak li għandu x'jaqsam mal-użu tal-mobile phones u l-laptops. Id-dritt magħruf bħala r-"right to disconnect" għandu jkun parti minn dan il-progas. Għal dawn ir-riskji ġodda l-ħaddiema Ewropej għandhom ikunu salvagwardjati u jkollna salvagwardji ġodda. U rridu nkunu aħna fuq quddiem biex nassiguraw li d-drittijiet ikunu a大大essibbli għal kulħadd.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: – (beginning of speech without microphone) ... it will be to maintain European social and democratic values in the new digital age of the Internet and the thousand applications and to demonstrate that the citizen is the end of everything. That is our challenge, but that is not a foregone conclusion. New tools will not automatically make this leap in quality. We therefore need the policy, the good policy that guides and makes the right rules. Indeed, there will be no real digital justice if citizens and workers do not have training and updating for their skills, as the Commissioner said, for new jobs, for which we should guarantee fair rights and conditions of work, I am thinking in particular of platform workers. There will be no digital social justice unless we set minimum rules of legal liability for those online operators who have enormous and worrying market and financial power and who must not become the absolute masters of the available data. There will be no digital social justice if the web giants do not pay taxes on profits made in Europe, and here we are still waiting for a decision from the Council.

name: Jordi CAÑAS
text: – Madam President, 47% of current jobs are likely to disappear over the next 25 years, and 85% of those in 2030 jobs are not yet invented. That's data—they can move in some percentages, but that's a reality.  The digital economy offers opportunities, but it offers us serious risks that we already experience, including the digital divide, a gap that is old, that is geographical, that is gender, that is social. And, in the face of this growth in inequality, what can we do? More social Europe, i.e. more education, more training, more protection.  That means we have to make a holistic approach to the problem. We have approached with the Green Pact a will to transform our economic model. How about we are betting on a social deal, a new social contract that is capable of combining these changes and avoiding collateral damage to people, millions of European citizens who will not be able, without help and without concrete measures, to benefit from that transition, to that change, and they can fall behind. That risk is a certain risk. We have to do everything we can to keep it from happening.

name: Guido REIL
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I am very pleased that we are today discussing the consequences of digitisation for a social Europe. Digitisation brings us huge opportunities, but unfortunately also big, big risks. We must be prepared and we must act. We need to invest in infrastructure, for example. Germany, for example, has one of the worst mobile networks in the world. In France, 13 million people do not yet have the Internet. We need to talk about education. Almost half of the EU's population is not even able to deal with digital media. An incredible amount of work needs to be done. And what worries me most is workers' rights. I would like to address platform work here. In other words, it is unacceptable that more and more people are living in employment relationships in which they do not have rights, where the Working Time Regulation does not apply, where there is no co-determination, in which there is no protection against dismissal. So there's a lot to do, let's tackle it!

name: Raffaele STANCANELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Internet as a mere communication infrastructure in general has become a mass phenomenon of sociological interest. We are living in an era of digital transformation that is changing our habits, undeniably simplifying our daily lives but hiding some aspects that if not constantly monitored can have negative repercussions. The simplicity with which to share and make accessible any type of content is a very powerful weapon for those who want to take advantage of unregulated and easily manipulated situations. That is why we must commit ourselves to constant monitoring of all those technological applications, as well as digital content, which could endanger individual freedom. It is therefore vital ly important that the legal system should lay down clear rules guaranteeing citizens' freedom so as not to sacrifice it by artificial rules.

name: Cindy FRANSSEN
text: Mr President, the digital divide is shifting more and more from who does or does not have the Internet to who can or cannot work with it. Digitisation works like a speedboat: e-learning, e-banking, e-commerce, e-government, ... If we don't look back, people will fall out of the boat. If you're not fast enough, you won't catch up.  We often think spontaneously of people with low education or a lack of financial resources who therefore miss the digital boat, and rightly so: the digital gaps are very pronounced and difficult to close. But the challenges go even further than that. Today my garagist is a computer specialist, the youth care worker a data analyst. More than nine out of ten new jobs require digital skills, but 40% of Europeans are not or are not digitally literate. You cited the figures yourself. That is why the European Commission's Digital Action Plan must invest in computer- people's internet skills and provide alternatives. The European Social Fund must focus on digital training, including in unexpected places, and we must be ready with the Globalisation Fund to help those who lose their jobs through digitisation to find a new job.  The European Parliament has understood. The Commission clearly does, too. I hope that the Council will follow suit.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her When we talk about the social aspects of digitalization, we often think in context of the question: "Is the Internet a public democratic space?" But it is not just a question of freedom on the Internet, but also of workers' rights. For me, social justice on the Internet means, first and foremost, the protection of fundamental digital rights. And there are some things we can do together: we need to strengthen the digital time sovereignty of working people, give more time for families; this can be done by digitization. We must make digital platforms compulsory; they cannot retreat to the fact that they have no responsibility for the people who work for them. And we need to network the trade unions across Europe; this is also much better done via digital channels. A digital Europe is a social Europe if we strengthen the collective bargaining parties in the European Union and not just maximise the profits of the large corporations, and we now have the opportunity to work together on this in all the committees – from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs to the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection to the Committee on Legal Affairs – during this period.

name: Karen MELCHIOR
text: – Madam President, the digital world, the internet, has been removing barriers to work and been removing the power of gatekeepers through many decades now. Digitalisation has provided for more opportunities, more power for the individual and more possibilities. It is also the opportunity to specialise, even in rural areas, to create your own job, to seek your own opportunities where it would not have been possible before. This requires, however, that we have a high—quality internet provided in these areas. That is why we need to extend the network services also in rural areas, so that we provide greater opportunities for the individual to create their own jobs and their own opportunities. We need to remember to embrace the opportunities of digitalisation and not only focus on the challenges, because a digital social Europe is the future and that’s what we will be creating together.

name: Loucas FOURLAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank and welcome all these young people around us. They are the future of Europe; The issue of digital transition is important because it can make everyone's lives easier. The aim is, through new digital technologies, to simplify procedures for the benefit of the citizen and to ensure equal access for all, especially those at risk of poverty and social exclusion. It is an opportunity that we must not miss in order to better integrate people with disabilities into the labour market. Open up new jobs. It is an opportunity that we must not miss and to strengthen health care. Member States must promote policies that will make public services more user-friendly by dynamically tackling bureaucracy. Half of our citizens still lack basic digital skills. What the Member States need is to adapt education systems to the new challenges in order to reduce the gap that currently exists in Europe.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! Digitisation offers many new opportunities. The elderly citizen who falls on the floor of the bathroom can get help with the floor calling for help. Or if we drive and there's a queue, our car can get around the queue. Or we'll have the opportunity to access public services at three o'clock at night. It's really nice, but there are also challenges. We know that very many workers do not have sufficient qualifications for this, nor do they have sufficient rights, especially if they are platform workers. We need to do something about that. We must also ensure that citizens do not invade their privacy as we generate more and more data. Moreover, we must ensure that consumers understand the reasons for the consumption choices they face online. There is much we need to do, but fundamentally it is about adapting our digital society to the needs of people. It's not people who have to abide by the digital.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the initial question is: What is a social Europe? For a social Europe, in essence, is a Europe in which everyone has the capacity to develop professionally and personally, and in which no one is excluded. That's the essence.  The digital technologies, precisely, what they offer is the possibility that everyone can meet those objectives. But what is the fundamental thing for this to happen? There is only one answer, one concept, one idea: training, digital training. Digital training is needed throughout the training value chain. From the beginning, children, young people, those who are in universities, those who are working, those who are not working and the elderly. What's it take? We need an action plan in digital training that is blunt, led by Europe, objective and measurable. This is going to be decisive, Commissioner.

name: Lina GÁLVEZ MUÑOZ
text: – Madam President, Europe must prepare for the digital revolution without leaving, as has been said, no person or any territory behind, nor rural, nor peripherals. Digitization needs to benefit all people, help reduce inequalities, improve public services, and create quality jobs.  We know that a lot of jobs are going to be destroyed, but also that many new ones will be generated, especially, for example, linked to artificial intelligence, for which 58 million jobs are expected to be created. But it is precisely in these digital sectors that women are missing. Only 22% of those employed in these sectors, you said, Commissioner, there is a very significant gender gap - only 22% are women.  We need to invest in comprehensive training and a digital culture that supports the development of appropriate skills and competencies, but we cannot absolutely dispense with any talent. Talents are equally distributed but opportunities are not, and we need to work precisely to ensure that these opportunities reach absolutely all people, including women.

name: Tom BERENDSEN
text: Mr President, digitisation offers plenty of opportunities to strengthen our economy and society. More efficient production processes, better and affordable care, safe traffic: with digitisation, it is within reach. But in the increasing digitisation of our society, we need to keep a close eye on three things.  First of all, no one should be left on the sidelines. People need to be able to cope when their environment is digitizing. Training and retraining are of great importance. Secondly, we must not depend on other parts of the world to develop new technology, because we want technology based on our values. People must be at the heart, not the tech giant or the government that wants to oppress its citizens. Thirdly, technology has to work for people. We must therefore create a framework in the digital strategy for what we do and do not want in our society.  No one on the side, no dependence on other parts of the world and technology that works for people. Then we can protect people and take advantage of the opportunities that digitisation offers for our society and our economy.

name: Marianne VIND
text: Madam President! The digital revolution has quickly crept into every corner of our lives. Two percent of the European population currently receives the bulk of their income through work on digital platforms, and the number is growing. The transition from analogue to digital forms of work challenges our traditional labour laws, such as the minimum wage, but also collective agreements and organisation. Salaries on platforms are determined not by contracts, but by secret algorithms. If we are to prevent uber or Deliveroo from combating in the future that determines the pay conditions of Europe's workers, then we must ensure that the authorities have access to the algorithms of the platforms. This is imperative to ensure that Europe becomes not only a digital but also a social Europe.

name: Barbara THALER
text: – Madam President, we heard wonderful speeches earlier so let me boil down the discussion to the essence. As an IT entrepreneur and as a woman, I was more than once on the receiving end of well-intended advice. However, after 15 years, my employees and my company are proving, day by day, that digitalisation is creating jobs and securing jobs. Needless to say, it also affects very traditional crafts and industries. In my constituency, Tyrol, a carpenter saw these chances, instead of worrying about the risks, and switched the entire production line from analogue to digital. Against all the fearmongering we heard in the past, he did not have to fire his workers. Quite on the contrary, he increased his market share and his workforce. This is the point of view that the economy has and politicians need.

name: Ibán GARCÍA DEL BLANCO
text: – Madam President, digitisation, the implementation of artificial intelligence is a huge, enormous opportunity; we could practically talk about a huge evolutionary leap as it has been virtually unparalleled since the industrial revolution. But it is also clear that it carries risks, which entails changes; and it is also clear that it entails many fears that have to do with control, which have to do with job loss, and there is only one way to confront those fears and underline the enormous opportunity, and thus seize it, which is digital literacy.  Literacy. Which is much more than giving digital capabilities, which is much more than giving digital tools. It means a humanistic approach to the issue to also democratize the implementation of things like artificial intelligence so that people, not just experts, are aware of what those risks are, those contradictions, those values that are at odds, and thus make better decisions and in some way be a society that goes more and more hand in hand and more integrated towards the future. So what I am asking the Commission and the Council to do is to make an effort in this, in a process involved, open, that they can underline and unravel that arcane into something understandable and that can be shared by all.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the digital world offers people a wonderful opportunity now, both in terms of their leisure and work lives. I have seen in my own country towns like Skibbereen developing digital hubs where people can work from, rather than commuting long distances to cities and so forth, and this is a wonderful opportunity. To do that, and also to work from home, you of course need high-speed broadband and that’s a priority right across Europe, which I’m pleased our Government at home has prioritised. Working from home or working close to home means that you are cutting down the time you’re commuting, you’re also cutting down CO2 emissions and you have a better work—life balance. All that’s very positive, but it has been pointed out by psychologists that there can be a negative side, where people can suffer psychologically. I think that has to be addressed, particularly in line with the OECD recommendations for the classification of work and also, I think very importantly, for the development of skills. One think that has emerged is that in Europe, at this minute, there a million jobs lying idle because we don’t have the IT skills. A big challenge for us.

name: Maria-Manuel LEITÃO-MARQUES
text: – Madam President, when, in 1834, the law that created trains in Belgium was passed, a Member warned parliament of the fear that farmers would have to expropriate their land, that coachmen had to lose their jobs, finally, even to the rumours that milk would come in butter to their destination. It seems, therefore, that the digital transition will not be worse than the industrial revolution. But maybe he's more demanding. First, the change it causes is much faster and has no borders. Secondly, it is much more demanding in changing skills. Thirdly, it occurs in societies, fortunately, much more attentive from a social point of view. And fourth, it's not just about the factory, it touches all our lives, the professionals and the personal ones. It therefore requires leaving no one behind, democratising knowledge and ensuring a balanced distribution of financial and free-time benefits. This must be done in great collaboration between social policy, Commissioner, and digital. As if it were a four-handed piece with harmony similar to mozart's sonata.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Madam President, we will witness an historical moment soon. The Commission will present three digital strategies next week, therefore 2020 could very well be the year that gives birth to the digital counter-revolution. We must decide what digital dignity means in the future. Do we let companies break into our private lives through targeted personalised ads or will we make the brave decision to kill this business model? We must decide how we use data for us, in the public interest. In the Netherlands, Google software is used in 70% of all primary schools. Do we want Google to determine how our children learn or do we want to use data to learn about our children’s learning ourselves? In short, we must decide how to defend or to promote the European way of life in a digital era. Let’s work on that.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, honourable Members, after listening to your debates, I note that there is a very broad consensus among you, both on the need to continue to develop the digital economy, because there is no real alternative for Europe to this development, and on the need to give great importance to the different aspects, the different risks that this economy entails , this new economy - social risks, social protection risks, risks of some companies controlling data. There is no fatality between, on the one hand, the promotion of the digital economy and, on the other hand, rights, social protections, data protections. We must not simply undergo developments in technology. We have to shape them. Having listened to your debates, I believe that the Commission is strongly invited to work on both aspects. It is true that we will present both this digital agenda and, at the same time, start work on protections and the guarantee of rights. I have announced that the Commission will convene a major conference on working on platforms. I hope that Parliament will participate - and I am sure Parliament will participate - so that, in fact, the European model of digital technologies is an example. We have already given an example with data protection. Well, we can also set an example in terms of social protection, social rights, to both promote this economy and put it at the service of all.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the principles of equality in the labour market, the role of social partners, the improvement of the health and safety of workers and fair working conditions have been time and again reaffirmed in numerous Council conclusions, Parliament resolutions and in legislation we adopt together. I am, therefore, confident that the EU is on the right track. What we might be lacking are dedicated strategies to set the framework for addressing digital developments but I understand from the Commission that these proposals will be soon on our table. I look forward to the Commission’s proposals and I’m confident that we will continue to have a fruitful and good cooperation with the European Parliament on these important matters.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Josianne CUTAJAR
text: in writing. – The digital revolution we are witnessing entails an endless number of opportunities. I believe that everyone should be able to reap the benefits of this new way to conceive our society, our economy and our daily routine: there is still a long way to go and we need to fight to achieve this result. A still relevant portion of the European population still lacks the basic skills to face this digital challenge; women choosing careers in science and technology are still few; many areas of Europe have not yet bridged the digital divide that reduces their economic potential. We need to be vigilant so that inequalities will not increase. The smart use of data enabling AI applications can be either an ally to improve many aspects of our daily life or a setback in the reduction of disparities. No discrimination based on gender, sexual orientation, disability, ethnic or social background should be allowed. The European Parliament is ready to contribute to the upcoming European Data Strategy and to the future AI legislation, but it will be vocal as nobody should be left behind.

name: Jarosław DUDA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I am pleased that the President of the European Commission, when presenting the work plan for the current year, stressed that the digital transformation, in order to be effective and serve Europe's economic growth and development, must take into account the interests of all groups of citizens, be fair and beneficial to all.  Our society is ageing, and it is in the interest of all of us that older people can remain independent, active and socially independent for as long as possible. It is worth noting that older people have great potential to offer, both in the form of knowledge, professional and life experience, civic engagement. They are also a very important group of consumers. Therefore, when planning the development of a digital Europe, account should be taken of the fact that new technological solutions do not contribute to the exclusion of older people, the reduction of their employability, their independence.  Services, including banking, must be more consumer-friendly and not limited to people who use mobile applications efficiently. New technologies and artificial intelligence can and should aim at levelling the playing field and offsetting age-related deficits or disabilities. I also believe that the new Skills Agenda should include an action plan to develop digital skills adapted to the needs of disadvantaged groups, such as the elderly, the long-term unemployed, people with disabilities and those who left the education system early.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – In the context of digitalisation, we often only stress that robotisation threatens jobs or that workers' digital literacy is low. This is true, so we need to place great emphasis on training. However, let us not forget that the development of the digital world can bring tangible results to users without them knowing how it works. It is now agreed that the autonomy of people with disabilities can be improved by appropriate technologies. My country is a very good example of this: it is unique in Europe that in Hungary people with hearing disabilities can manage their affairs through government windows through accessibility, thanks to contact online video-based sign language interpretation services developed by the National Association for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing (SINOSZ).  In addition, in the care of the Hungarian National Association for the Blind and Partially Sighted (MVGYOSZ), the Remote Eye service supporting accessibility for the visually impaired has already been completed. Of course, we cannot also hide the risks to privacy: on the basis of automatic decision-making, there are fears that discrimination against minorities will be incorporated into algorithms, as we unfortunately see a bad example in AI-based recruitment tools or in the eligibility criteria for insurance or financial services. These need to be prevented, so it is important to provide adequate legal guarantees. We must also address the situation of platform workers: they must also be given adequate social protection and the right to turn off their computers and relax.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The European Parliament has played a key role in defining the legislative framework for digital transition and energy transition, promoting an articulated approach and valuing the social impact of technological transformation and modernisation of processes, using them as tools to combat inequalities and increase opportunities for European citizens. The introduction of the so-called Internet of Things, with exponentially higher processing and transmission speeds and capabilities than those available to date, is not just a technological or economic challenge. He is more than anything a political and social challenge. The debate today promoted by the European Parliament on the social dimension of the just transition is very timely. Shared values in the analogue world must be transposed into the digital world, taking advantage of the transition to correct distortions. This can be achieved through three structuring lines of action. Use the common heritage of shared values and principles as the basis of a practice based on ethics and priority to solutions for citizens, make high-quality Internet access universal and develop networks of widespread qualification of populations to deal with the new technological, social, economic and political context.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on Gender Equality Strategy (2020/2515(RSP)). I remind you that it’s possible to request catch-the-eye and blue cards using both the standard registration and the electronic system. Instructions are available at the entrance of the Hemicycle.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for putting the Gender Equality Strategy on today’s agenda. The first months since the start of the Commission mandate I have had the opportunity to meet many of you already. All the exchanges we have had have confirmed that all of us, together, have so much work to do in this area of policy. I am grateful for the support you have shown me and this Commission on many occasions. The European Union and its citizens need your full support in making Europe an equal place for women and men in all their diversity. Gender equality is a founding principle of the European Union. Europe is a good place to live for many, but it would be an understatement to say that we are still not there yet when it comes to gender equality. Women are still being underpaid compared to men. One in three women in the EU have experienced physical or sexual violence, or both since the age of 15 – and that’s millions of women. We cannot accept these appalling inequalities. President von der Leyen, Vice-President Jourová, and the whole College support me and this fight for equality. Gender equality is a key theme in the mandate of this Commission and the first key milestone will be the launch of the Gender Equality Strategy. The adoption is foreseen for the week of International Women’s Day in early March. The strategy will underpin the political commitment to gender equality and support strategic and systematic work for gender equality in the Union and beyond. We are aiming at an ambitious strategy. In the context of a visible and organised movement opposing progress in women’s rights and gender equality which has emerged in recent years in Europe and internationally, it is more important now than ever to restate in the strongest of terms the Commission’s continuing commitment to gender equality. There has been a wide consultation on the strategy, including a public consultation that gathered more than 1 300 responses. As gender equality is a cross-cutting issue, the strategy will strengthen the Commission’s dual approach of gender mainstreaming combined with targeted actions on specific topics. We aim to introduce a more systematic approach at an early stage of policy design to include a gender perspective in all EU policy areas. As regards content, we intend to present a positive future-oriented vision for a gender equal Europe – a Europe where women and men, girls and boys, in all their diversity, are free from gender-based violence and gender stereotypes, where they have the opportunity to thrive in the labour market, lead our businesses, politics and participate equally in all sectors. Important horizontal considerations that will be emphasised in the strategy are challenging gender stereotypes and intersectionality. In terms of topics, the strategy will address the priorities highlighted in the President’s political guidelines – increasing women’s economic-empowerment by closing the gender pay gap, including by introducing binding pay-transparency measures, getting better gender balance on company boards and improving parents’ and carers’ work-life balance. We also continue our efforts to combat violence against women. EU accession to the Istanbul Convention therefore remains a priority. If EU accession remains blocked in the Council, despite our joint efforts, we will table legislative proposals to strengthen the Victims’ Rights Directive and include or add specific forms of gender-based violence to the list of EU crimes. We shall also address other important and emerging aspects of gender equality, such as online violence against women or the gender perspective in digitalisation, including an artificial intelligence to avoid bias. Together with the adoption of the strategy, we will launch a wide-ranging and inclusive consultation process on binding pay transparency measures which we aim to table by the end of the year. I am aware that introducing binding pay-transparency measures can be challenging, and I want to find the right balance for such EU intervention, taking into account the interests of employers, employees and national administrations. I look forward to hearing your views and discussing with you. I sincerely hope to get your support so we, as the EU, can make the so much needed leap towards a gender equal Europe in a more gender equal world.

name: Cindy FRANSSEN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the entire Commission for putting gender equality so high on the European agenda. Gender equality is one of the fundamental values on which this European Union is founded. Well, a score of 67.4 on the latest European gender index shows that we are far from there. We therefore call for an ambitious strategy that makes strong progress. Women's talents are still an underused source of expertise, creativity and changing power. A comprehensive gender strategy streamlines policy around three main axes: creating opportunities for women, keeping women on board in a rapidly evolving world – we are thinking of digitisation, migration and climate change, and we also need to take into account the new forms of work such as platform workers. And thirdly, pay attention to the vulnerable position of women.  That is why we need to tinker with this new gender strategy that will set out the lines for a gender-equal Europe in the coming years. This means, in concrete terms, eliminating the gender pay gap and the gender pension gap. Strengthening women economically and eliminating poverty. Promoting female entrepreneurship, combating violence against women, breaking gender stereotypes and further implementing the social pillar, in particular the work-life balance directive. It is just a selection of the concrete measures.  One thing is certain: a European Union that gives women the opportunities they deserve will be more social, resilient and stronger.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner Dalli, you have us at your side when it comes to real progress for equality in Europe. I would just like to say to the previous speaker that women are not weaker, but are weakened – by systems, by rules, by traditions. They are being weakened, we are not weaker. But this weakening comes from outside. If we now look at the strategy that we hope will now be reintroduced into Europe after five years of abstinence, then we have very clear demands: we want a new, independent, ambitious strategy. We want a strategy with a clear action plan. We want to see clear progress. We do not want to see any regression and, above all, we do not want attacks on women's rights. We want to focus on equal opportunities and put an end to all forms of discrimination. And, as the Commissioner has also pointed out, we want it in all policy areas, not just in policy areas that are assigned to us. We want it in foreign trade, in tax policy, in digital policy, in environmental policy, in the budget, in research, in agriculture and so on and so on. Gender mainstreaming affects all policy areas, which is why we want to be seen and taken into account in all policy areas. I do not want to talk about the main issues – prevention and combating violence against women – I do not want to raise the main issue of work-life balance or the labour market or sexual rights. I would like to focus on a very different issue. This issue, which I would like to focus on, is the link between equality and democracy. And here, Commissioner, we are at a very, very important point. We call for a study to be carried out analysing the impact of nationalist policies on equality movements. We call for the status of women's rights to be constantly examined in all Member States. Above all, we demand that there should be annual progress reports. Equality has something to do with the rule of law, and anyone who breaks equality must, as a Member State, remember it on the bank statement.

name: Irène TOLLERET
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your commitment and energy in carrying out this equality strategy. It's time. In the face of the great upheavals facing the world and the European Union, it is high time that equality between men and women was a reality. Equality before health, first of all. In my country, abortion was legalized in 1974. However, in 2020, there are still women and men in the European Union who do not have equal, free, caring access to abortion and, of course, sex education. Because yes, the right to abortion is a health issue and all European citizens should be equal when it comes to health. Violations of sexual and reproductive health rights are violations of women's rights, they are violations of human rights, they are unacceptable violence against which we must fight mercilessly.  Equality in the face of violence, let's talk about it! We must eradicate them, starting with economic and financial violence. If yesterday we celebrated the women and girls of science, our financial reality, it is an unacceptable wage gap between men and women in the workplace, which is getting worse in retirement. This is absolutely unacceptable. Equal work, equal pay! Men, women, regardless of background, disabilities, convictions: equal work, equal pay. It is unacceptable for women to see their retirement handicapped by the fact that they are carrying children. The only human being who has won two Nobel Prizes is a woman. It is unacceptable that women are under-represented in STEM sectors. We need a career equality, equal access to power. This strategy, as you have said, must be concrete, mandatory. We have examples in the European Union that do not hinder the performance of companies.  Physical violence must also be combated. Is the Istanbul Convention blocked? Never mind, let's develop alternative solutions. The Council will unlock it. This does not prevent the establishment of a directive that cuts all forms of violence and harmonizes the definitions of different forms of violence, adopting an intersectional approach.  I will end by saying that the Simone Veil Pact has proposed that existing legislation in all European countries that participate in gender equality has been proposed. Let's put it in place to pull European legislation up.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: Thank you, Madam President, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. I remind you to observe the time of your speeches. I ask You to speak to Christina Anderson and at the same time I would like to remind my colleagues that, in accordance with our Rules of Procedure, flags and symbols cannot be placed in the room. I would first of all like to speak to you, who will be speaking in a moment. I would therefore like to ask Members to remove the flags and the room to be personally reminded of this by their colleagues. Please, Madam President, I would like to thank you for your excellent work.

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I note that the Bureau is terribly afraid of national flags, which I think is a great disgrace. I am complying with the request and have now removed my national flag.  However, we are talking about the EU's equality strategy. There is already gender equality, because we were all born equal. Men and women – no one will be able to deny that although men and women have the same value, they have very different inclinations, including strengths and weaknesses. Men and women face different challenges. But instead of blaming men for alleged, sometimes imaginary benefits, why not let the Commission focus on promoting harmony between the sexes? Why not encourage men to be men and encourage women to be women? Injustice in the workplace, which favours either women or men, should not be addressed by nation states and companies? But no, it must be the dictates of the EU's central office. Let families decide for themselves who does the washing-up, who raises children, brings the money home. I am anxiously awaiting the day when the Commission presents an action plan to distribute breastfeeding babies more fairly between father and mother. Why are women being told that they are only worth something if they go to work? This is an incredible reduction and discrimination against all those women who deliberately choose to do family work. But no, you are determined to force women into the world of work. It is interesting, however, that women's quotas are only called in the executive floors. Where is the quota of women among bricklayers, truck drivers or sewer workers? Finally stop making people mere objects of their social experiments. Stop wanting to re-educate people. Stop adapting people to their delusional notions of society. Let people be human again!

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: Thank you very much, Madam President. Thank you also for removing the flag. This is not a matter of concern, but of the Rules that apply to all of us.

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for What must be included in the eu's new strategy for gender equality is, as we hear, a long list – everything from a gender-assured budget to a feminist foreign policy. As a Green politician, however, I miss the obvious focus on the great challenge of our time: the climate. All of us are well aware that it is women who suffer most and most from climate change because of economic and social inequalities. In order to succeed with the Paris Agreement, therefore, an equal change is needed. When Ursula von der Leyen was elected President, she promised to put gender equality first and foremost, at the top of the agenda, but when she presented the green deal, the EU's climate change strategy, there was not a single word on gender equality. The Commissioner for Gender Equality, who has the knowledge and commitment to climate justice, Helena Dalli, had not even been involved in the work. That is why, in talks with the Commission and Helena Dalli, I and the Green Group have called for two things, namely that the EU's green deal must be equal and that climate change must be an integral part of the gender equality strategy. We have now received positive signals, and I look forward to continuing constructive work with Commissioner Dalli.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Equality is a fundamental value of the European Union, so the new strategy for gender equality should be both ambitious and realistic. So what should be its shape? We face many challenges, such as the fight against the wage and pension gap, the broader feminisation of poverty. I would like us to propose legislation that will strengthen women combining work and child-raising, so that we support them in motherhood and appreciate the unpaid work done by women at home. We must also tackle violence against women, including cyberbullying, pornography and human trafficking. Unfortunately, in the European Union, even young girls are exposed to forced marriage and genital mutilation. I would also like, Commissioner, that the new strategy should not enter the area of competence of the Member States. May Parliament respect its motto 'united in diversity'.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, any strategy for equality must necessarily be to combat poverty and social exclusion and will have to contribute concretely to combating discrimination in access to work and wage differences between women and men, in a context where a general increase in wages and pensions is required and working conditions increase. The defence and promotion of universal and quality public services, such as housing and justice and free access to health and education, is also central to equality. The protection of maternity, with 100% paid leave and the protection in the disease are essential so that the strategy is nothing more than a list of good intentions and for it to meet a real reconciliation between personal, family and professional life. At the same time, States must ensure the implementation of mechanisms and instruments to combat all types of violence, whether in the family context, in the labour context or others.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we in this House are very much discussing gender equality and women's rights. But let us face it and admit that there is no equality between men and women. In fact, we allow it to be debased and humiliated. There is no equal treatment, there is no equal pay. Prostitution is legalised in many countries in Europe, and instead of combating this social scourge, we prefer to go the other way. In Europe, there is still enslavement for many women, who are considered to be commodities for sale. In Europe, women are killed and scarred by men.  We can impose rules, but they are merely a palliative because they are mostly based on sanctions imposed on those who violate them. Instead, we must train the new generations, and here I am addressing mothers: teach respect for other people, teach your sons to be men with a capital U and teach your female daughters not to depend on anyone and to defend their rights and their physical and moral freedom.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Madam President, we have finished the European Equality Strategy 2016-2019. We are now facing a new 2020-2024 Strategy. It must be a priority for this Parliament, for the Commission and for the Council to move forward decisively and with a firm commitment to do what Europe demands: equality for all citizens. It's a democratic issue. There is no democracy without equality. There is no prosperous society with a human rights-free future.  Equality is a human right and that is why we have to combat the pay gap, the pension gap, bet on the Directive announced to us by the Commissioner on Wage Transparency or the Conciliation Directive. There are still stereotypes that need to be fought in order to achieve that true equality. There is also no equality in decision-making, so specific measures that are inclusive and accessible will have to be taken.  There is gender-based violence —the latest statistics tell us that two out of three women have experienced violence. We need to talk about artificial intelligence because of cyberbullying issues and, above all, we must get this Strategy to talk about disability and women. You have to have age indicators, disability indicators, women's indicators. We will have thus managed to live up to what European values demand.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: – Dear President, first of all, I would like to thank you, Commissioner, for your active position on the basis of the possible implementation of a specific gender equality strategy. I wish you the best of luck that you will be able to adopt that strategy in the Commission. But we have a very clear position on what should be reflected in it. My colleagues have already mentioned that, first of all, we need to have concrete measures to combat violence against women, how to implement the Istanbul Convention in the Member States. Finally, how to combat female poverty? How to implement the work-family reconciliation directive that we have already adopted in the previous term? This requires specific measures and controls in the Member States to correctly transpose the provisions of the Directive. Finally, in fact, we need to ensure that the salaries and pensions of women and men do not really differ as terriblely as they have been up to now. This requires concrete solutions. I wish it very much to make sure that the strategy does not really remain on paper alone, but is seriously implemented in the European Union.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: – (start of off-microphone intervention) ... this strategy of equality between men and women is very important and today it is more important than ever, when totalitarian ideologies emerge in Europe which, as they have always done, to end the rights of all, begin by attacking the rights and freedoms of women. The worst expression of inequality between men and women is violence and the worst expression of gender-based violence is murders. The murders of women do not cease in Europe. We must therefore be clear: we are stuck in the Istanbul Convention and because of the six countries that refuse to ratify it. But they can't paralyze us. Therefore, in this strategy we need to move forward. And we have to move forward on two fundamental elements. One is the data , Commissioner, it cannot be that we do not have data in the European Union – that we know the figures of the reality of violence in the European Union against women. We have limited data; we have data that is not homologable. Therefore, according to Article 11 of the Istanbul Convention, we need to move forward in order to have homologable data to tell us what the reality of the violence figures is, in order to end it. And so, along with the data, we have to name this violence and the name of the violence is called a crime, a crime that must be in the Treaties of the European Union. I am convinced that we will move forward on this path, and this Parliament is your partner in doing so.

name: Elena LIZZI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we support the importance of gender equality as a common value. If we want to be consistent, let us work to promote it in all the policies of the European Union, as well as of Parliament, but as a cultural revolution and not as an act of taxation. The barriers preventing women's participation in the world of work entail particularly high costs of well-being and growth. Removing obstacles is important. Research by the European Institute for Gender Equality shows that gender equality would foster economic growth. But does the Institute also monetise the role of women in family-work reconciliation? Improvements in gender equality would create more than ten million additional job opportunities in Europe and GDP per capita would grow by almost 10 % by 2050. But what balance for families? Gender equality must also be promoted within the framework of the European Union's new policies – the digital single market, the Green Deal and artificial intelligence – in which the employment gap is even more dramatic.  Now a new Commissioner with exclusive responsibility for equal opportunities will have to change the management of previous equal opportunities policies, not least because the European Court of Auditors will examine gender mainstreaming in the EU budget and, according to what is made public today, the audit report will be released in spring 2021. Then we shall see what fallout the policies of the von der Leyen Commission will have in the world of women.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, it is extremely good news that we will finally have a strategy. Somebody said before that the last strategy came to an end in 2019, and I hope so, because there was no strategy at all in the last mandate. This was extremely shameful, and now we will change that. We will have one, and I hope this will be a truly feminist drive, which is what a lot of people are expecting in the streets I would also like to urge you to be extremely ambitious in different fields. In the socio—economic area, we are very much looking into the proposals for the tax transparency directive. This is going to be extremely important in the first weeks and months of our legislature. We need to continue working on violence; this stopping of the ratification of the Istanbul Convention is absolutely unacceptable. We have a lot of work to do together here. I would like also to urge you to focus on the mainstreaming of all the policies of the Commission. This is extremely important. In the different consultations within the services of the different initiatives of the Commission, we want a gender equality footprint there, and this is also your responsibility. So, Commissioner, we stand behind you. Let’s make this strategy something different and important for the people.

name: Andżelika Anna MOŻDŻANOWSKA
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for It is very good that we are working on a strategy for gender equality. This is a challenge that we have to face. We are talking about the Fourth Industrial Revolution, technological progress, the digital revolution, and we have still not achieved equality in such an important aspect as gender equality. After all, we have hard data. If, by 2030, all countries in the world eliminated gender discrimination and guaranteed citizens equality in this single aspect, global GDP would increase by $6 trillion. After all, the world and Europe cannot afford to give up the involvement of women. It cannot stand either economically or socially. And it is only on those issues that we are talking about today – not just the wage gap, not just the fact that women are at risk of poverty (because the pay gap is 16% and in retirement more than 35%), that they are under-represented in parliaments and governments, that they still face a 'glass ceiling' in the business world – we must pay attention to that. European poverty cannot have a woman's face.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the list of things I would like to see in this strategy is long, but I would like to raise one point that would be very important: sexual health. Sexual health belongs to every girl, regardless of what religion is, what is culture, what is the politics in power. That is every girl's right, and I hope that the future strategy will take a strong stand on this.  On the way to a truly equal society, we need to strengthen many things. One of them is the labour market position of women. Women's position in working life is strongly influenced by caring responsibility, who bears responsibility for children, for caring for children. It is influenced by the way day care is available, how early childhood education and care is available, how high-quality, how accessible. In Finland, the Government has just presented a new model of family leave, which quotas leave equally between father and mother, then improves the labour market position of women, improves their wage development and affects them right up to the development of pensions.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Rita Levi Montalcini said: 'Women have always had to fight twice as much. They've always had to wear double standards, private and social. Women are the backbone of societies." Despite this, we say, or precisely for this reason, there are many women in Europe today who are not fully guaranteed their rights effectively. Commission data: Over the past three years, the difference in the employment rate between men and women is still 11.78% among men and 66% among women. And there is still a gap between men's and women's pay of 16%. Not to mention violence against women.  The social change that women need in order to be able to see their rights fully guaranteed concerns all of us, women and men. If we men do not change our roles, both in the public sphere and in the business world and in the family sphere, it will be impossible for women to get rid of situations where their rights are violated so often. Changing roles, I say this from personal experience. Feminism is not a cause of women, it is a cause of society as a whole.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I think it is a shame that in the 21st century women in Europe and in the world experience so much inequality. I am pleased, Commissioner, that this subject is one of the important priorities of the European Commission. I believe that the strategy should take into account the needs and experiences of women from different backgrounds.  I am thinking of women from rural and remote areas who have to face difficult access to crèches, kindergartens, information, healthcare every day, and have to deal with poverty in old age. I think of women who die of cancer because they start treatment too late because of difficult access to specialists. I am thinking of women who, despite their better education, lose the fight for high-paid positions or receive lower salaries for working in the same position. I think of women who experience violence, sexual violence and domestic violence because they have to face the challenges of economic independence. I think of women with disabilities who have to face barriers every day.  And I hope that we women in the European Parliament, despite many differences, will be able to speak with one voice on this important topic for millions of Citizens of the European Union.

name: Predrag Fred MATIĆ
text: – Dear Chairpers, respected colleagues and colleagues, Commissioners, I am very pleased that the European Union has clearly stated its priorities by creating a new gender equality strategy. It comes at a time when it is important to take strong steps to stop regressive movements and the backs downgrade of women's rights, which send the message that the European Union is not today a union of equality, solidarity and tolerance.  Sexual and reproductive rights are one of the areas where the greatest regression has occurred. The withholding of medical care for personal beliefs, gender-based violence, legal discrimination, lack of sexual education and other harmful practices based on patriarchal patterns undermine the very foundations of European democracy.  I expect that by creating and implementing the new strategy, the European Union will show that it has not abandoned its role as a progressive leader in the protection of human rights and will not falter in front of those who want us in some dark and sad times. It's our responsibility and we can't and won't fail that test.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Madam President, I’m very glad to hear that the EU is working on a Gender Equality Strategy: it’s very important for me. Let me just highlight one aspect of this very broad and important topic – violence against women. When we talk about violence against women, we usually talk about numbers: one in every three European women, right? I would like to talk about people. (Speaker holds up a photograph) For me, she is the face of violence against women. She is Bernadett Orosz, a very brave woman who was brutally assaulted in the privacy of her home by her ex-partner. Afterwards, she was denied proper medical care, she was denied proper police protection, and later on, the Justice Minister of Hungary repeatedly said that ratifying the Istanbul Convention is political hysteria. Well, Bernadett is a brave woman. She has been to the European Parliament; she will be back. She’s advocating for protection of females, and I’d like to echo her voice. I’d like to call on the Commission to act upon their promises and to add violence against women to the list of the EU crimes in the Treaty and also for the European Union to join the Istanbul Convention.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: Thank you, Madam, but please read the Rules of Procedure and do not use the posters for your next speeches. As you know, the Terms and Conditions apply to all of us.

name: Luisa REGIMENTI
