text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, women are a mystery which, in the history of human generations, constitute an immense work for their mission and vocation at the service of humanity and life, for their daily contribution to sensitivity, intuition, dedication and generosity towards the family and civil life, and for the development of a culture capable of combining reason with feeling , characteristic of femininity, with which woman enriches the understanding of the things of the world and contributes to the full authenticity of human relationships. Its dignity is constantly visible in the tireless battles for equal rights of the individual and there is no doubt that there are still many obstacles preventing its full realization. The growth of women's royal emancipation is an issue that can no longer be postponed. This is true for all those women who silently, with sacrifice, engage and hope, even if they are aware of living a complex hostile reality, the same reality that subjects them to injustice on the merits, to ill-treatment, and that often fails to protect even their lives.  Violence and injustice on women feed on silence, stereotypes, loneliness, indifference, ignorance and the sleep of consciences. That is why we welcome the European Commission's initiative to propose a gender equality strategy, which should contain strong commitments, clear indicators and a monitoring mechanism to make accountable... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Madam President, there is actually a long list of things that I would like to put into this Gender Equality Strategy. I will only focus on two, because I believe they are absolutely crucial. The first one is indeed to have a legal proposal on the gender pay gap. It’s long overdue, and maybe we could suggest that it has the title: ‘We only waited 63 – I repeat 63 – years for the EU to make a proposal on the question of pay equality’. I think that would serve the purpose.  The second issue that I believe is absolutely crucial – and colleagues have said this – is to have a directive against gender-based violence. The accession to the Istanbul Convention is not enough. The backlash against women’s rights is getting stronger across the European Union, and we need to have a clear position to stand up to that. I really believe that, with Trump in the US, with Putin in Russia and with Bolsonaro in Brazil, the European Union, despite the problems that we have in this union, is still the beacon of hope and freedom for feminists around the world. This gender—equality strategy really is one of the chances that we have to live up to their expectations, and that’s why we need to make it a success.  (Applause)

name: Jessica STEGRUD
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I am extremely grateful for the women's struggle and achievements of previous nations, from which we Swedish women are now reaping the rewards. For example, women are increasingly dominating in universities, at management levels in the public sector and in social media. I am therefore concerned about the image that continues to be cultivated in the name of equality – a narrative in which women are to be seen as victims and where unequal outcomes are usually explained by discrimination and white patriarchal structures. There are still things to do. However, the risk is that the new strategy is aimed wrongly and instead of increasing gender equality further rather creates privileges for a new group. Moreover, with coercive measures such as gender quotas and shared parental leave, we are not only about to replace an old injustice with a new one, but we are negotiating away what we have also been fighting for for a long time, namely freedom of choice and the right to govern our own lives.

name: Elena KOUNTOURA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, for your strategy on gender equality to succeed, you must first and foremost ensure that the Member States of the European Union commit themselves to a new framework, with guidelines and mandatory concrete measures for gender equality. I propose binding legislation and, in particular, that the Istanbul Convention be ratified and implemented without restriction by all Member States in order to combat violence against women. Binding measures are needed for pay transparency to combat the gender pay gap. Obstacles to the adoption of the relevant directive on equal representation of women in administrative posts, which has been frozen in the Council since 2013, must be overcome. To take preventive measures and to establish effective, transparent and confidential complaint procedures and strict dissuasive new sanctions against perpetrators, in order to prevent and combat harassment in the workplace. Finally, you need to include a separate chapter in the Women's Health Strategy in order to reduce gender inequalities in the health sector.

name: Daniela RONDINELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union and the Member States have been fighting for gender equality for years, but to date the results show that the policies put in place have not been sufficient to overcome the economic, social and cultural damage caused by this discrimination against women. The reason is very simple, because the economic and productive world has never wanted to intervene decisively in workplaces where discrimination finds its systematic and daily application. This strategy for gender equality is therefore extremely positive for us, provided that it is innovative in relation to the major changes taking place, such as the industrial and digital revolution which, if not well managed, will certainly increase the disparities between men and women. We must therefore devote all possible resources and policies to this strategy in order to put an end to all forms of discrimination against women in the workplace and in their stay in labour markets. As European institutions, together with civil society, we must do everything possible to put an end once and for all to this physical and mental violence against women.  Commissioner Dalli, if the strategy lives up to all these challenges, we will support it and together we will win these battles that are civilised, but above all social justice.

name: Maria WALSH
text: – Madam President, I welcome the publication of the Gender Equality Strategy. Promoting gender equality needs to be enshrined as a core activity for the EU. Equality between men and women is fundamental to our shared European values and goals. As our society evolves, it is imperative that we enshrine the principle of consent in our shared values. As many colleagues have already shared right now, violence against women and coercive control are problems that can only be tackled when we face them head on. Not only do we need to put support in place to help women affected, but we also need to address the root causes through education and social development. Women must never feel threatened or coerced over the decisions they make in their lives. Promoting women’s equal status in our society is fundamental to creating a vibrant and tolerant union. Thank you, Commissioner Dalli, for taking the lead on this, for driving it and I also want to acknowledge the many male colleagues that we have in the Chamber right now. Thank you for putting your support behind this because if we don’t work together it is going to fall on deaf ears.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in a few weeks' time, the European Union will have its own strategy for gender equality, and that is good news, and more than that, it is very good news if we take into account that we did not have a strategy for it in the last parliamentary term. We therefore welcome this news, commissioner, because Europe is certainly the part of the world where women have the most rights and where gender inequality is less. But much, too, remains to be done. The statistics, the pension wage gap, the residual percentages, I would say ridiculous, of women sitting in top positions tell us this. But the current events also tell us dramatically. Newspapers and social media are full of reports of discrimination, harassment, bullying, violence against women and girls, which are an unbearable limit to our freedom and our lives.  That is why, Commissioner, we need binding measures, not a list of good intentions. Binding measures and therefore a directive against violence, a directive introducing binding measures, in order to avoid this tragedy of our sisters annihilated first in the soul and then killed by murderers, who have a first and last name, but also by a patriarchal culture.

name: Dragoș PÎSLARU
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Dalli, I have initially come prepared with a formal speech, which I have abandoned in order to send a more direct emotional message.  For all men who still see the issue of gender equality as minor, marginal, I invite them to think about how they would like their mothers, sisters and daughters to be treated. From the importance of equal opportunities to the dramatic problem of verbal or physical violence against women.  As a father of four, all boys, I believe it is my duty to convey to them the basic values and to teach them to actively fight for a society with equal rights and equal opportunities between women and men.  We need to internalise the importance of the problem of gender stereotypes and preconceptions, which are still developing misogynistic attitudes in the European Union, of disregard for women, verbal and even physical violence. It is crucial that we start from here to fight, especially us men, to become guarantors in the fight against violence against women. We all have that obligation. The proposed strategy has exactly the value we will give it by the way in which each of us will personally act further.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The great American President Ronald Reagan once said that the ten worst words of the English language were: "Hi, I come from the government and I am here to help you". The question of the sexes to each other is one of the most intimate, personal and individual affairs of man. And the idea that the European Union now thinks with its own strategy that it must intervene is always wrong, regardless of whether what is in the strategy is right or wrong. It is an attack by the state on individual life, and that does not belong, it is illiberal, it is totalitarian. However, we know – and our colleagues on the left have made it clear – that this is only a matter of advancing our own plan of destroying the family and, ultimately, of a socialist transformation of the most individual we have. That is precisely why we are against it.

name: Kira Marie PETER-HANSEN
text: Madam President! Commissioner. Thank you for your presentation. It is rightly gratifying to see that you are once again taking on the task of an equal Europe. I welcome this strategy to such an extent. I hope that this strategy will end by simply sending empty signals to the women of Europe that we are taking their problems seriously. It's time to put action behind the words, which I know you're ready for. It is particularly important that the strategy should enable us to reach all corners of Europe with the promise that the political will is with women, and not against them. And here I mean everywhere in Europe where there is not complete free access to free abortion, everywhere where women are not protected from domestic violence by the Istanbul Convention, all places where harassment on the street restricts women's access to public spaces, and all places where women are still paid less than their male counterparts for the same work. It has to be over now - it is unacceptable.  The Commission's strategy is a first step. The next step must be concrete legislation, because that is the only way we can make progress. We should not be afraid to sanction, because the last few years have only made it clearer that it is necessary. Europe's women demand action, and we must deliver that. I look forward to following our common progress.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Madam President, gender equality is a matter of justice to women. Even in the most conservative societies, we see brave women putting the issue of their rights on the public agenda, but their demands are not always turned into policies; change does not always happen. Politicians often pay lip service to gender equality, but fail to recognise the genuine role of women in society, the economy, business and politics. If Europe wants to achieve its strategic goals, we cannot miss out on the issue of the participation of half of the population. If we want to make the planned conference on the future of Europe a game changer, based on an authentic dialogue with citizens, we have to listen to the perspective of women as citizens. We have to go beyond the European Union and offer our solidarity to women who are out there fighting for equality in their own cultural and national context. The new strategy presented by the Commission is a good blueprint for action, but it is also a signal that Europe will never give up on human rights and justice. I strongly believe, as a woman and as a Member of this House, that the EU can be the beacon of courage and hope for women.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I have had a different perspective, but once again I am taking part in the debate on equality between women and men, in which women are the main participants. And I have this reflection that every time we talk in this House about big money, about bombs, about rockets, about power, it's a debate room dominated by men. And when we talk about equality, it's women who talk first and foremost. If discrimination, violence, isolation, inequality were to affect men, I am convinced that this strategy would have long since been adopted by the European Union. Yet we are talking about the majority, the majority of our society. We are talking about our daughters who are victims of violence, we are talking about our mothers who earn less, we are talking about our grandmothers who will have smaller pensions precisely because they have earned less than men all their lives. I therefore appeal to my colleagues, both in this House and in politics in general, to stand in solidarity with women who are fighting for their rights, because it will affect our daughters, mothers, grandmothers, girlfriends and girlfriends. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Niklas NIENASS
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for this statement. I have one personal question: what do you think men can do to encourage women, and do you think that there’s more action needed by men? Do you think that men should step down more, or do you think that woman should improve? What is your personal opinion on this issue? Since we are all politicians, what can you do to increase the number of women politicians in your party as well?

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, since we are men and for hundreds of years we have been promoted, we should always look behind us. So many women every day are left behind, and we as politicians have a responsibility for that. So we as politicians, male politicians, have extra power which we can use to liberate women, to help them become equal – nothing more, nothing less – just equal. This is our obligation. (Applause)

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: – Madam President, it seems to me that we are in such a strange paradoxical situation that, on the one hand, we see that massive, growing civil pressure on gender equality, and on the other hand, that situation remains, in fact, still alarming in many Member States of the European Union. If, especially when we look at the figures and the economic indicators, then in fact, in everyone, women are worse off compared to men. They have a 16% lower salary in the same positions as colleagues, are twice as underrepresented in management positions as men, and of course not to mention problems in the work environment, such as discrimination, sexual harassment, which they are often afraid to report. And now it seems to me that it is no longer a question of ideology or big debates, but it is a question of basic social justice. How can we tolerate a situation in which half of the citizens of the European Union do not have a level playing field and a level playing field. So I just hope that the strategy you are preparing will at least help to catch up a little bit with the increasing civil pressure with the policies themselves.

name: Lina GÁLVEZ MUÑOZ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we are very pleased that there is a strategy, that a gender equality strategy will be presented in this parliamentary term; concrete measures, such as wage transparency, are also collected. But I am particularly pleased that you are talking about gender mains in relation to the European Green Pact or artificial intelligence. Because, so far, there has not really been a mainstreaming of the gender perspective into European policies. Rather, there has been a policy of employability, even though women and men are very unequally incorporated into the labour market. So as long as there is really no gender mainstreaming in European policies, we will hardly move forward, especially if we do not succeed in economic policy, where it shines and continues to shine through its absence. Sometimes it's just a icing on the cake, but it doesn't really matter. Commissioner Dalli, let's make it really important. Here in the European Parliament there is a gender mainstreaming network with representatives in all, absolutely all, the committees, which we will be very willing to work with you and make it possible for us to really move forward in a much more egalitarian Europe.

name: Radka MAXOVÁ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, thank you very much for your work on the strategy for gender equality. I feel like it's a tough portfolio, maybe harder than building a multiannual financial framework. In order to implement this strategy, we will need to unblock the ratification of the Istanbul Convention. Unfortunately, Slovakia announced yesterday that it wants to withdraw its signature from this ratification and that it wants to withdraw. I do not agree with this, and we should not stand by in silence. Furthermore, we need to unblock the anti-discrimination directive. What I would like to point out is that in the strategy we are very much appealing to a good school system, to education from the youngest children to university students. I think this is very important, because without a change in the education system and the approach of educators to explaining that equality is actually very beneficial for economic growth, for the economy, we will have no choice.

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Commissioner Dalli for coming here today to outline the future Gender Equality Strategy. It’s extremely important. It’s a very good time. We have the political commitment at the top of the Commission, and hopefully across the Commission. I do want to say to you that I don’t believe that you can do this on your own. It is important that every Commissioner looks at these issues, and that gender equality is mainstreamed.  We can diagnose the issues very clearly. You’ve heard from all my colleagues here today. There are newer issues emerging, but there are very many issues that have been around for quite a long time. We do need to pay attention to climate change, to what’s happening in technology, to the economic empowerment of women, and to dealing with the pay gap and the pension gap. But we also have to, for example, look at the budget and the gender—proofing of all of the budget decisions. That’s also really important, but we do need binding measures, we need strict implementation, and we need monitoring.

name: Maria-Manuel LEITÃO-MARQUES
text: – (start of the intervention with the microphone off) ... the strategy it is going to present, I hope it has concrete measures, has goals and has the means, has the resources to be implemented, or else it will be another beautiful text that will be in the Archive of the European Commission. We need a strategy that fights problems, wins battles that should no longer be on our agenda, such as domestic violence, and a strategy that looks to the future and combats, for example, inequality in participation in technological professions which is currently very unbalanced. We also need this strategy to be present in all European Commission policies, to discriminate against companies that have good policies of equality in public procurement or access to funds, and also to be included in international partnership agreements. Count on us if your strategy is ambitious. Count on our support. Count on our criticism as well and our contribution.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the value that the Union can add to equality policies goes through four contributions.  The first is to require minimum standards in all member countries both in anti-discrimination policies and in tasks of preventing and repression of inequality and especially of gender-based violence. That is why it is essential to homogenize the legal treatment of this problem.  The second, improve statistics and indicators to improve the evaluation of these policies.  The third, to assume that the fight for equality needs global criteria but action at the level closest to citizenship, which requires incorporating the local and regional levels into this work.  Finally, we need to move consciousnesses, apply global ideas that have worked to the task of changing stereotypes and topics that fuel inequality and that must begin to change at the level of each individual.  We just declared ourselves in a climate emergency. Centuries of discrimination, violence, domestic terrorism - ten women in six weeks, in my Member State alone - should encourage a European declaration of emergency for equality.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if we are here talking about gender equality, you must know that in my country, Italy, only 4 % of CEOs are women, despite the fact that the level of education is very high.  There has been talk in this House of wage differences, there is no doubt about that, but I do not believe that quotas are the solution. I don't want to be called a panda or something to protect as a woman. I claim the right to be assessed for my skills and skills and, if I am better than a man, to be paid more, not equally.  I therefore conclude my speech by saying that I would like to avoid this constant campaign by men and women to provide quotas or in some way treat women as if they were a reserve. Instead, we should continue to pursue the idea of women as people and then really assess their abilities and reward them in case they deserve it.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mrs Dalli, I am very pleased that we are now starting this process of strategy with so much energy, and I am also pleased that our parliamentary resolution, on which we are voting tomorrow, has a strong foreign policy dimension. For, on the one hand, solidarity makes us women strong, and on the other hand, we have seen so many peace negotiations, and this has also been scientifically proven: the more women sit at the negotiating table, the longer the peace lasts. At the same time, I think it is important that we also take our own noses. I am often very distressed when we travel abroad with EP delegations, and there are only men; if our European External Action Service does not have a single message led by a woman in the crisis regions. I would simply be very pleased if, in this strategy, we not only take a domestic approach and not only point the finger at others, but also really take our own noses and look at our own structures again. I believe that you have a strong supporter in us Greens, but not only there. Bravely ahead! That would be very nice.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, women must have access to all opportunities that men have. This is the foundation of equality in society, so that everyone under the same conditions can take advantage of certain life opportunities and lead lives of their choice.  But equal opportunities do not necessarily mean equal outcomes. To provide women with the opportunity to do the same jobs as men and to be paid equally does not mean that those in more of these jobs will really want to engage. Diversity in behaviour in social roles and life choices between the sexes is not only socially conditioned but also biological. The elimination of socio-political barriers will not put a sign of equality between women and men because they simply are not and cannot be the same, but they must certainly be equal. There can be no dispute about that.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, I think equality for women is a pipe dream unless women have control over their own bodies, and while I very much welcome the progress made in Ireland and Cyprus in other areas in terms of access to abortion, we have to be careful that in some countries there has been an attempt to roll back some of the gains, with conscientious objection being misused, with regressive preconditions being put on women’s decisions, and even attempts to ban abortion. I think this is something we must take great care of. I note that the strategy singles out women who face multiple forms of discrimination such as Roma and migrant women, and I welcome that, but we should really call this out. I mean it is a scandal that we have, in Bulgaria, Roma women segregated in maternity hospitals, not allowed to use toilet facilities or to eat with other women. We need concrete solutions for this, we need legislation outlawing such discrimination, and we need to facilitate women in the best possible way.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, I have to say that in previous speeches I wished that we would not have to discuss gender equality again, because the European Union could rise to the occasion for this equality and have implemented it to date. I find it an insult that, in the year 2020, in the European Union — for which we pride ourselves; for its culture, for human rights, for principles and values — we continue to fight for something that should be taken for granted: for gender equality. We are discussing this as an objective which we must achieve, and it has not been achieved for so many years.  So I believe — and I really reward Commissioner Dalli for her initiatives — that the European Union must be a pioneer and must take concrete steps to impose this equality with sanctions on countries that do not implement it. To support this effort even from the budgets and to adopt — if possible — a directive from the European Union. Europe without eliminating discrimination and violence against women is not understood and we cannot be proud without it. So it's our first and only goal to fight together for this cause.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Madam President, the strategy for gender equality must be something that will continue to be a great inspiration to all Member States in the future, and it should be a minimum political commitment for them and, at least in some areas, it should also be legally binding. I will pause, at least, on the fact that it is inconceivable and very unfair for women to still have lower salaries and lower pensions than men, and even in the public sector within the Countries of the European Union. We really need to work on this. Furthermore, I also stop at the fact that the reconciliation of family and working life for women, it is very important that women have greater and easier access for their children to kindergartens, so that these kindergartens are not only affordable, but that there are also enough capacity. And then, of course, there's the approach to health. Discrimination against Roma women has also been mentioned. We really need to put an end to this as soon as possible. And, of course, all forms of violence, domestic violence, sexual assault in the workplace and similar unpleasant sexual allusions that women often encounter even now must be combated.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: – Madam President! Discrimination against the majority of European citizens in all spheres of social, political, economic and private life and at all ages is not acceptable and is not in line with the fundamental principles and provisions of the acquis communaut the acquis. Tackling gender inequality is clearly not being tackled in the right way. Raising awareness of gender inequality through international days such as yesterday's International Women's and Girls' Day in Science is not enough. Unfortunately, even in this House, the majority is purely for rhetorical equality. How can we interpret otherwise the fact that MEMBERS of the LLS and Renew reject key amendments in the resolution to ensure equal pay for men and women for equal work. Or that there is a lack of political will at Member State level and in our ranks to make gender equality and the principle of equal pay for equal work to the work of the European Semester. These are urgent structural measures, without which the future strategy for gender equality will unfortunately be no more than a beautiful bouquet of words for 8 March, International Women's Day.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: – Madam President, I come from Poland, a country in which women are still not properly protected from violence; a country in which women who are living in villages still do not have proper access to health care, in which the burden of childcare is put on women, and only one per cent of men take paternity leave. I come from Poland, a country in which women do not have the right to safe and legal abortion. The list of issues is long and the situation affects even more women with disabilities, the elderly, LGTBI, Roma women and Muslim women, and it is disgraceful that in the 21st century in the centre of Europe there are women who cannot enjoy their fundamental human rights. The ambition of the European Union should be to ensure unified standards and the highest level of protection of women’s human rights in all Member States. It should be the goal of Gender Equality Strategy.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you all for your valid contributions and yes, it’s 2020 and we are still discussing the rights of more than half the world’s population. We’re discussing rights which men take for granted. I really thank you all for the call also for more men to take part in debates regarding gender equality. We all have mothers, some of us have daughters and we are speaking about more than half the population. One of the men here said feminism is not just for women, but for the whole of society. So yes, as has rightly been pointed out, yes, when we are discussing war and armaments, which will kill people like you and me, then many men contribute there. I don’t wish for more women to contribute there but less men. I want to all of us to discuss peace but this is the reality, so it’s important that we point this out and that we look at gender equality as something for all of us, for all of our societies, for all of Europe, for all the world.  The new Gender Equality Strategy will address the many topics which you have highlighted and what was highlighted in the President’s political guidelines. I will set out an ambitious agenda for combating and preventing all forms of violence against women, including online violence. I will present a legislative proposal to ensure better transparency on pay levels in in European businesses and organisations and take other non-legislative measures to close the gender pay gap. I want to finally get to EU rules adopted to ensure progress on gender balance on company boards, because we know that targets work. I want to make sure that the Work-life Balance Directive is implemented in the Member States to help women and men reconcile work and caring responsibilities. Also, I want all major EU policy initiatives to be assessed from a gender lens. I will ensure that the Commission’s work on gender mainstreaming is more comprehensive and systematic than has been previously been the case.  We must pay attention to the gender and equality perspective when addressing some of our society’s main challenges, such as digitalisation and transition to a greener economy, as was mentioned also here. And yes, we are targeting the feminisation of poverty. The gender gap in poverty is, after all, the result of the many inequalities women and girls face in all spheres of life. I reiterate that I count on the strong support of Parliament because equality for all its citizens is one of the founding values of the EU, and we need to make this a reality, all of us together, for all of our citizens.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. – On 4 March, the European Strategy for Gender Equality (2020-2024) will be published with the aim of eradicating the unacceptable discrimination that still persists in Europe, between men and women in the labour market, in terms of pay, social and cultural. The hope is that it will be an ambitious strategy including legal and non-legal measures to combat the gender pay gap and the resulting pension gap, to ensure gender equality in the top positions of the public and private sectors, and to eradicate forms of indirect discrimination, caused by lack of access to care services, which make it possible to reconcile family and professional life in practice. , in particular in the presence of children, the elderly or the disabled; shortcomings which, in fact, continue to deny too many women the free enjoyment of their rights. It will also be imperative to provide for stronger measures to prevent the list of often announced crimes to which too many women are victims from being made a growing list. The dramatic scale of the phenomenon affects every Member State. It will therefore be necessary to establish that all violence against women is recognised as a crime, in accordance with Article 83 TFEC, and to promote that socio-cultural change without which, any regulatory measure can only have a limited effect.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. Gender equality is a founding principle of the European Union, disregarded in so many areas of social life. In Europe, too, we have women with limited rights, who live in conditions of economic inequality, who are not adequately represented in decision-making processes, underpaid in the workplace, who suffer discrimination and violence, not only physical but also moral and sexual. In the new strategy for gender equality, announced by the European Commission, we will need, in addition to declarations of principle, the provision of instruments to combat a twofold battle: it must be conducted both in terms of rights, with binding measures and at the cultural level, the main source of gender inequalities.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: in writing. – The phenomenon of sexual exploitation is full of gender inequality. The majority of humans providing sexual services are women and a majority of them are trafficked into the sex industry by male pimps. These women are victims of sexual trafficking and exploitation. Of all the registered victims of trafficking for sexual exploitation in Europe, 95% are female. Unfortunately, Roma are one of the most vulnerable and more affected group. Paternalistic societies are at the core of that. The demand for sexual services is also mostly coming from men. This means there are several types of power imbalances between men and women in the sex industry. These women also suffer emotional and physical abuse. Violence against women is also a part of gender inequality. This gender inequality is a European problem; trafficking for the purpose of sexual exploitation is a transnational problem. The victims are trafficked across Europe. Human trafficking and sexual exploitation are fuelled by prostitution. The reintegration of victims of human trafficking can be added to the Gender Equality Strategy as well, so as to facilitate and encourage the Member States to support such programmes.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: – The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Council by Evelyn Regner, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on EU priorities for the 64th session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women (O-000006/2020 - B9-0005/2020).

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are celebrating the 25th anniversary of a document that summarises and defines women's rights in a comprehensive and clear way than ever before. The Beijing Declaration, adopted at the 4th World Conference on Women in Beijing, is still one of the most progressive, one of the most comprehensive and clearly formulated documents on women's rights that exist. All areas of life are covered, full equality between women and men is intended – whether young or old, rich or poor, women living in peace, women living in war, public and private life – comprehensively and progressively declared in 1995 all participating governments: "We recognize women's rights as human rights." We have a 25-year-old Magna Carta of Women, which makes all women's rights human rights human rights and puts women on an equal footing with men in all areas of life. The declaration contains comprehensive instructions for action to all governments, NGOs and includes all other multi-level stakeholders in the proposals for action. 189 governments have committed themselves to co-existing, implementing, realizing women's rights in the world, and since then progress has been reviewed every five years. What I would like to emphasise in particular about the declaration is that we are consistently talking about the equality of women in power. "Power equality" - what a modern wording. That full and explicit recognition and affirmation of the right of all women to determine all aspects of their health, in particular their own fertility, is a fundamental condition of their equality of power; that access to economic resources, land, credit, science and technology, vocational training, information, communication and markets should be fully and equally granted – so I quote from this. Twenty-five years after its adoption, however, a bad verdict must be made. No country has achieved full equality for women. No country – not even the states of the European Union – can guarantee women's self-determination over their bodies. We in the European Union are stuck when it comes to joint action on equality for women, and we must not boast of being a good region. The Gender Balance on Boards directive, which aims to empower women in decision-making posts, has been blocked for eight years. This year it should have been fully implemented throughout Europe. We do not have complete equality in access to goods and services. There is still discrimination and areas such as advertising are excluded. We clearly have Europe-wide discrimination in terms of merit. Even after adjusted figures, we see that the pay gap is still wide. 500 000 young women, half a million women and girls, are victims of female genital mutilation – not somewhere outside, but within Europe. These examples, these figures, are shameful for Europe and most governments. I am right to criticise the Council for providing equal support and positive support to governments, which are obliged to represent half of their population, namely their citizens, on an equal footing, until full equality is achieved. Traditional, cultural, religious machism continues to prevent, and more than ever, the dismantling of patriarchal power structures and places women as less valuable than men. That is why we must fight as a guarantor of women's rights as human rights, particularly at European level. That is why we must not allow regression within the EU to take place in individual Member States or as a common global player in the rest of the world. I remind you. It is about half the population! Do not deny the human rights of women! We know that the 1995 Beijing Declaration does not bind governments, but we women in this world have a document in our hands that gives international legitimacy. We will not let go, we will fight for real progress. The document must now be brought to life. The United Nations is now fully behind taking action. But the UN needs the cooperation of governments. It sets up action coalitions, commitment – Mexico and Paris I would like to mention – and tighter controls on progress and implementation are needed. I therefore call on the honourable Members to support my two amendments on action coalitions in the vote that accompanies the question tomorrow. We in the European Parliament want a strong participation and multilateral action. The United Nations thrives on cooperation, common will, joint action. As the European Union, we must make a full commitment to this – together and in diversity. (Applause)

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you for this opportunity to exchange views on the next session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women. I shall also touch on the question of gender equality more broadly. 2020 is a pivotal year for the realisation of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls everywhere. It will also be the year of a series of milestone anniversaries relevant to gender equality. We will celebrate the 20th anniversary of the UN Security Council Resolution 1325 on women, peace and security; the fifth anniversary of the sustainable development goals; and not least, the 25th anniversary of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action. Gender equality matters to all our citizens. It is not just a women’s issue but a social issue and also an economic issue: allowing everyone an equal chance to contribute brings significant benefits in terms of our economic strength. The upcoming session of the Commission on the Status of Women will be dedicated to the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action. At the next session of the Commission on the Status of Women, we should identify gaps in the implementation of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action and reconfirm the full validity of the commitments undertaken 25 years ago. We should re-energise international efforts towards gender equality, the full enjoyment of all human rights by all women and girls and their empowerment. The UN Secretary-General highlighted that process and progress in many areas is lagging behind. This is in particular the case concerning the exposure of women and girls to extreme poverty and violence against women and girls. We also continue to have a gender gap in labour force participation and under-representation in decision-making and a leadership role across all sectors. The EU will set the bar high in all these areas. They should be backed up by substantial financial resources.  When it comes to the negotiation of the political declaration, the EU will demonstrate its strong leadership role on gender equality. The EU’s agreed position is rooted in the EU’s legal and policy framework and is intended to guide our negotiators in New York. Some of the most critical issues include the following: equality and non-discrimination, sexual and gender-based violence, family and family oriented policies, health, education, social protection, decent work, sexual and reproductive health and rights as per the new European consensus on development, and desegregated data collection. Furthermore, the position paper also includes guiding principles on climate change and information and communication technology. The EU will make every effort to ensure that past achievements are safeguarded and that further progress is achieved on the road to full equality among women and men.  The EU will also strive for a political declaration which recognises women civil society organisations and women human rights defenders. They play a critical role in the promotion, protection and fulfilment of the human rights of all women and girls. The EU will therefore pledge to continue supporting civil society and ensuring a safe and enabling environment for them to operate effectively at local, national, regional and global levels.  As to the EU’s political statement at the opening session, we are convinced that the European Parliament and the Council share the same values and interests and the same priorities. We therefore look forward to hearing your suggestions today.  President, honourable Members, on the issue of gender equality more broadly, you rightly underlined in your question for today’s debate that gender equality is not a separate domain, but one that cuts across the whole of society and the economy. Progress in this field, therefore, requires the integration of gender equality goals into all relevant strategies and policy goals. In other words, we need gender mainstreaming as well as specific actions. Precisely in this spirit, in its conclusions from December last year, the Council called on the new Commission to adopt a stand-alone, high-level EU gender equality strategy and I’m delighted that the Commission has undertaken to do just that. The Council, furthermore, called for an effective and systematic implementation of gender mainstreaming in all policy areas. The Council also called on the Commission and the Member States to pursue a stronger focus on gender equality within the different phases of the European Semester process.  Finally, a few words about the Council’s work programme in the months to come. We of course look forward to the initiatives that the Commission has announced, such as measures relating to pay transparency. Meanwhile, as you are aware, gender equality and non-discrimination is one of the priorities of the Croatian Presidency. We intend to table a set of Council conclusions on the impact of long-term care on work-life balance, as we all know women perform a far greater share of informal care work than men and this limits their ability to participate in the labour market. On 30 January the Croatian Presidency organised a high-level conference on the topic: Participation of women on the labour market – Benefit for society! It’s results will be discussed within the UN Commission on the Status of Women. While a lot has been done, there is still a long way to go in order to achieve full equality both within the EU and especially beyond its borders.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members. Thank you for including the preparation of the UN’s 64th session of the Commission on the Status of Women (CSW) in today’s agenda. This is very good timing. The negotiations on the political declaration and the preparation of the EU statements are ongoing, and the aim is that the CSW will start with a strong and action-oriented political declaration focused on the implementation of the existing commitments. At the same time, we are preparing our side events, which will be melting—pots for good practices and new ideas on how to take the Beijing Agenda forward. This is the strength of the CSW – a place to meet and discuss gender-equality which many actors in the field.  The session will celebrate the 25th anniversary of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action. We also celebrate the 75th anniversary of the United Nations and the 5th anniversary of the Sustainable Development Goals. Gender-equality and the empowerment of women and girls is not only a question of justice. It also makes economic sense to ensure that women and men, girls and boys, reach their full potential.  I have read with great interest the report of the UN Secretary-General on the state of play with regard to the situation of women and girls in the world. It is a good, nuanced report based on 167 national reviews and regional review meetings, which took place in various regions across the globe.  While we have seen some progress, we have not advanced as much as we wanted to. Female labour market participation was increasing, but has stagnated over the last five years. Women still carry out a disproportionate share of household work and care. Women’s and girls’ voices and participation are far from being on an equal footing to those of boys and men.  Women are 25% more likely to live in poverty. Gender stereotypes still determine the paths of women and girls. Gender-based violence is a recurrent issue. Next to this, new issues are emerging like climate-change and digital technologies. We must turn these changes into opportunities. Digitalisation can open doors for women and girls, but can also be misused to silence them. As the UN Secretary-General highlighted, gender-equality and empowerment of women and girls is crucial to an economically uncertain world with increasing polarisation, environmental threats and conflict. The unequal distribution of power, resources and opportunities perpetuates gender-inequalities. I welcome very much the input of the European Parliament, including your forthcoming resolution on this topic, and the Parliament’s presence during this CSW. Gender-equality is a priority for the European Commission, both in our internal and external relations and actions. The Commission will present a new gender-equality strategy in March, and still in 2020, launch the third action plan on gender-equality and women’s empowerment in external relations. A stronger, ambitious and holistic approach will address the issues identified globally and for the EU. Our approach will be based on gender—mainstreaming in all policy areas. The task force on equality, with members drawn from all the Commission’s services and the European External Action Service, will be fundamental for this. Next to this, targeted actions on specific gender—equality issues will continue. We will continue to tackle the gender pay—gap and introduce pay transparency measures. We will continue to develop measures to end gender-based violence. We will continue to push for gender-balanced company boards.  I am looking forward to hearing your views and discussing these ideas. Thank you again for putting the CSW on today’s agenda.  (Applause)

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I want to welcome the three speeches that we have just heard from Evelyn Regner earlier. These are actually a very clear outline of the priorities that we should be presenting at the UN Conference. The language is right, the words are right, and we can do our best to bring forward what you’ve heard here today. The priorities that people across this Parliament have outlined: these are the priorities, clearly, that we have to bring to the UN. What’s very clear is that progress has been made, but there are the most extraordinarily serious issues still affecting women around the world. We also have to note that, after the Nairobi Conference on Population and Development, the USA did not sign the statement or the priorities at the end of that conference, and that is very serious. This is, as you said, the 25th anniversary of Hillary Clinton’s famous line: ‘women’s rights are human rights, and human rights are women’s rights’. Hard to believe that it actually needed to be said, but it did, and it accelerated change. There is much more to do. It is a very important year. It’s about acceleration; it’s about implementation; it’s about targets, and it’s also about monitoring. It’s also about budgets, and that has to be a particularly important element of the debates in the UN this year. Also, of course, we do have to watch out for attitudes that are still far too prevalent, where we see everyday sexism. That’s very important to address as well, in terms of the perception of women, the reporting on women, and so on. That is critical. Just a final word on quotas: we’ve heard some criticism of them here today. What does the UN say about quotas? They say they are a temporary, necessary measure. Let’s face it, quotas have been operating on the side of men for quite a long time.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner Dalli, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for her excellent work. The last time I was in New York at the UN Commission on the Rights of the Women, it was shameful that europe lacked a gender equality strategy. This time, those of us who go there to represent Parliament can ensure that the EU takes the lead globally when Commissioner Dalli will now present a strategy. The fact that the women of the world gather in the UN scraper is actually important. Women contribute to conflict resolution and peace-building. Women promote sustainable development, and I look forward to the work of the Women's Commission. I want to push for women's right to their own livelihood, education and jobs. I want to take the fight against violence against women and girls and close the pay gap. We must also have a gender perspective in the climate change transition. This is important not only for all women, all children and young people, but also for all men.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, women’s rights are human rights, and I would love to live in a world where I would not need to stress that women’s rights are human rights. Men and women, the previous and the current generation, have worked hard to reach a point where we can advance on these issues. We should not take these rights for granted, and we should not take our democratic European society for granted. Women’s rights continue to be heavily challenged, and there are recent trends of an organised backlash against women. We must not yield, but evermore show our commitment and use our voices to create a more social Europe – an inclusive Europe where all have the same equal opportunities, including women.  This motion for a resolution is our commitment to the visionary worldwide agenda of the United Nations for the empowerment of women. As representatives of our European citizens, we know that it is important to put into action our commitment for Agenda 2030. Women need to be on board for everything, gender equality is necessary for sustainable development, and 2020 is the year for the rapid realisation of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls. I welcome the Gender—Equality Strategy by Commissioner Dalli, which is due this March. On 8 March, the world celebrates the advancement of women’s rights, but also we review all that still needs to be done. For example, improving the conditions for women in the labour market. The persistent and increasing burden of poverty on women cannot continue, and I urge Members and the Commission to take every single step to make sure women can reach their full potential and have equal access to the labour market and the economic opportunities our European society provides. Let us continue to use our voices and acknowledge the voice of all women everywhere. Our commitment to participate at the 64th Session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women shows that we take this seriously.

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President! The European Parliament is now talking about its priorities for the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women and wants to realise that women's rights can only be strengthened if abortion is finally accepted as a retrospective contraceptive; that women can only make the most of their opportunities if comprehensive LGBTI rights are guaranteed; that women's financial independence can only be guaranteed if they refrain from sharing their lives with a partner; that women could only enter management positions by means of statutory quotas. My God – how presumptuous, ridiculous and sexist it is to say that without the EU, women would not be able to move forward in life! Those who want to strengthen women's rights should ensure, through effective border protection, that women do not become free game for imported groups of men in Europe. One of the greatest achievements of a civilised society is the pacification of public space, and we in Europe have largely realised this, and now we are sacrificing these achievements on the altar of diversity, tolerance and humanity, and even mockingly calling it cultural enrichment. As a woman, I enjoy freedom of movement in Europe, as do every man. So, before we call for ridiculous quota rules in resolutions, thereby opening up completely irrelevant scenes of secondary war, I ask: what is the European Parliament doing to protect us women from supposedly seeking protection?

name: Monika VANA
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which What this debate today clearly shows is what we, as the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council, must work hard for within the framework of the UN with a strong and united voice, and that is the fight against the backlash, this is the fight against the ridiculousness of the fight for equality, and that is the fight for international equality for women in all areas. The Beijing Declaration is the world's most comprehensive policy framework for achieving equality, and 25 years later, as Europeans, we have an obligation to stand out and unite as global pioneers in multilateralism. We MEPs are taking a clear position with a resolution that we will adopt tomorrow, and I hope that the Council too – and the Council is called upon to take a clear stand here and to commit ourselves to the Beijing Platform for Action and to position the EU as a pioneer in equality.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality discriminates against smaller political groups and deprives them of the right to represent voters at the Annual Conference of the Women's Status Commission in New York. Do you really feel good about it? That is why conservative women who want to combine work and family life will not speak at the conference. Women who do not treat marriage and motherhood as the proverbial ball at the feet that interferes with their careers. Nor will there be a voice saying that life must be protected, that life is a miracle and that it is the highest value. However, the voice of left-liberal circles seeking to recognise abortion as a human right and a method of family planning, as well as seeking to sexualise children and manipulate sexuality, will be very strong. That is why I call for me to remember. Therefore, please vote in favour of a resolution which, without unnecessary ideology, expresses concern for the future of women. This is an EMC resolution.

name: Eugenia RODRÍGUEZ PALOP
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, neither will the GUE/NGL Group be represented. Ladies and gentlemen of the Council, we are presenting a motion for a Resolution in which we make a number of recommendations which we consider to be priorities for women in the European Union. But the truth is that, so far, they have not been very encouraged by gender perspective and feminism. The Council is the body in which the most important initiatives for women have been curbed. For example, it turns out that we have an anti-discrimination directive which has been blocked in the Council for ten years. Are you going to do something? The EIGE recently told us that we were moving towards equality at a tortoise's pace and in a clearly uneven way. It also turns out that the European Union has not ratified the Istanbul Convention thanks to the boycott of a number of States in the Council – the axis of Visegrad and its circle of influence and collusion – and thanks to the same religious lobbies that have supported anti-election campaigns in all parts of the world. Each other bent on treating women as incubators and breeding machines, slaves of their partners or their governments. They have managed to prevent sexual and reproductive rights in the Union, although this Parliament acknowledged that the denial of sexual and reproductive health and related rights services is a form of violence against women, in line, by the way, with the European Court of Human Rights. They are the ones who want to eliminate equal education in schools, and those who criminalize the LGTBIQ collective. Let us not forget that Poland, Bulgaria, Hungary and Slovakia are now leading a brutal resistance against the so-called 'gender ideology'. Nor has the European Union adopted a Directive on gender-based violence, because for some States and political groups sitting in this House this violence does not even exist. Just a few months ago this Parliament acknowledged that we were witnessing a visible and organised offensive at global and European level against gender equality and women's rights. The Council will have to elect. I hope you make a good choice.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The conclusion of the latest report prepared by the international humanitarian organisation Oxfam for the recent Davos summit is clear: the global economy is largely based on the exploitation of women. It turns out that investing in equality is becoming less and less profitable, because women and girls around the world do more than three-thirds of the unpaid care work, or 12.5 billion free working hours.  Therefore, equal pay, the removal of barriers to women with disabilities, violence, the professional activation of women over the age of 50, the declining participation of women in the labour market, women's poverty, access to the labour market and the activation of women from rural and remote areas, the impact of climate change on poverty, women's physical and mental health are topics that will certainly be addressed at the 64th UN session, and I hope that we can find effective solutions and accept forward-looking commitments in the political declaration.

name: Maria-Manuel LEITÃO-MARQUES
text: – Mr President, gender equality is a matter of power and power has never been given, it has always been conquered. "I will be clear: it is not about doing women a favor. Gender equality is about human rights and it is in everyone's interest: men and women." Wise words from the Secretary-General of the United Nations. I quote a man who has always been a militant of this cause, not just now in the position he occupies.  What priorities should we bring to the United Nations, twenty-five years after Beijing? Firstly, the struggle for women who have no rights, who have no right to study, who are not entitled to marry, who are not entitled to their sex life, who are not entitled to their professional life. These are the ones that are always ahead of our priorities. Then the priority of the fight against violence, also the new violence, which occurs through the Internet and which, once again, affects mainly women and girls. And then the other inequalities: those that will be inequalities in the future if we do not prevent them now, such as those that relate to the imbalance of the technological professions. I think we have a lot of work to do. With the whole world, together we will be stronger.

name: Chrysoula ZACHAROPOULOU
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, as you know, the right to sexual and reproductive health is the fundamental condition for achieving equality. Unfortunately, in recent years, this right has been receded and challenged around the world—and often with the support of major nations such as the United States. The European Union loses its credibility when it does not speak with one voice. The Nairobi summit for the UN Conference on Population and Development in November is an example. I found it shocking, unacceptable, that Member States, Poland and Hungary, sided with those who question women's rights. Commissioner, Madam Minister, the new generation has never been more aware of the inequalities between women and men. All over the world, she makes her voice heard: in Chile, Argentina, Mexico, Spain, France, Belgium... Because this generation can no longer stand this injustice. This is called the "equality generation." So let the 25th anniversary of Beijing's declaration be their moment! Let us listen to these girls and boys, women and men from all over the world who demand a society of dignity, a society of justice, a society of equality. This is Europe and its values. It is for them that we, as politicians, are committed.

name: Annika BRUNA
text: Mr President, the aim is to set the priorities of the European Union on the status of women.  Our delegation will defend the fight against equal work pay gaps, cyberviolence, forced marriages and genital mutilation. We will also advocate for recognition of the work of stay-at-home mothers and domestic work. Of course, we will not vote for your cartoonish resolution, which calls into question the sovereignty of states and intends to impose the Istanbul Convention.  I take this opportunity to point out a key topic, which is taboo for you: the weight of radical Islam in the abuses of women's rights in the world, but also in Europe. In France, a young girl named Mila, who was harassed in her high school, has been a strong critic of Islam on social media. She received hundreds of thousands of aggressive messages, including death and rape threats. She was unable to return to her high school, as her security was not assured, and was placed under police protection. After three weeks of dropping out of school, she had to change schools.  This young girl symbolizes the daily lives of thousands of women in Europe who are influenced by radical Islam, propagated by unassimilated populations. Feminists, often so brazen, have been totally silent on this subject, obviously taboo for them. Our group called for a debate on this subject at this plenary, but this was refused. Yet it is high time that you opened your eyes to the harmful role of immigration and radical Islam in the living conditions of women in Europe.

name: Diana RIBA I GINER
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, we are living in a time when many rights which we were guaranteed now are now called into question again. A wave of reactionary movements, often tinged with xenophobic and misogious tints, tries to slow down any progress towards a fairer and more egalitarian society, and this affects us, women especially.  The sixty-fourth session of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women is a great opportunity for Europe toband the fight for women's rights internationally and demand a strong commitment to the Beijing Platform for Action. To this day, many of the goals set by this Platform remain just this—goals. Europe must be a useful tool for the world to help curb the global setback in women's rights and, in this sense, more and better can be done. The ratification of the Istanbul Convention or the adoption of the Quota Directive on The Board of Directors remains on the councils. We ask for courage, determination, and haste, and make goals finally accomplishments.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: – Although it has been 25 years since the World Conference on Women held in Beijing, this debate makes us aware that there is still much to be done to protect and strengthen the role of women in different areas. We must answer the question of what has already been done and what steps must be taken to ensure that women around the world stop facing problems such as violence, broad economic inequalities or, for example, discrimination against women as mothers in the employment environment. Perhaps the European Parliament should take the example of the Polish, in which the gender pay gap is among the lowest in Europe and the low rate of violence against women ranks Poland among the safest countries in the Old Continent. At the same time, we say a firm 'no' to the demands of some communities that abortion be one of the methods of family planning, and that the European Union should fund the organisations involved in promoting it. The question is what the European Parliament really intends to do in terms of full respect for women's rights and gender equality. Specifics, timetable, what are the plans for the future?

name: Cindy FRANSSEN
text: Mr President, gender equality does not stop at the borders of the European Union, of course. Twenty-five years after Beijing, following the fourth World Conference on Women, women and girls around the world are still not getting the opportunities they deserve. Gender equality is more than just fighting for parity on boards or breaking the glass ceiling. It assumes international solidarity with all women, from the north, east, south and west. The next meeting in New York will force us to pay special attention and political action to women in vulnerable positions, and I really want to see the vulnerable translated correctly. This is about women in poverty, women as victims of war violence, exploitation of domestic workers.  We, as the European Union, must take the lead and speak with a strong and unambiguous voice, preferably with a huge parlophone. I like to close with a quote from Michelle Obama: To echo Michelle Obama, when you have worked hard and walked through that doorway of opportunity, you reach back and give other women the same chances that helped you succeed.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 25 years have passed since the Beijing Platform for Action Declaration, but gender discrimination has unfortunately remained. Even today, she wonders how a woman who was raped was dressed. There are two countries within the European Union that do not allow abortions and Member States that have not yet ratified the Istanbul Convention. In Europe, women earn 16 % less than their male colleagues and it is considered normal for women to sacrifice their careers for care services. For 25 years we have only filled our mouths with intentions. Today, on the eve of the UN conference, I call on Europe with one voice to reiterate that we no longer accept this stagnation. Women's sexual and reproductive rights must be guaranteed everywhere, in particular access to contraceptive methods, safe and legal abortion, health care and education in schools. Gender equality must be put at the heart of the challenge of climate change, because it will be women who will suffer the worst impact. I trust you, Commissioner, and I trust a woman who leads the European Commission.

name: Mathilde ANDROUËT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, to your small-bourgeois feminism, I prefer that of reality. What do you intend to do, not to improve women's lives, but really to save their lives? Genital mutilation, rape, violence, harassment. Every day, a new atrocity is committed against women. So what will you talk about in front of the United Nations? Of those times when you asked leaders of pro-migrant associations to keep rape quiet, because it was the game of populists? Of the English police who refuse to file complaints against Indo-Pakistani paedophile gangs, for fear of accusations of racism? Prostitution of African, Romanian or Albanian teenagers, because of your sacrosanct freedom of movement? Feminists condemning a teenage girl threatened with death in France for insulting Islam? I wonder. Will you admit that you let the neighbourhood law become the only law? That you abandoned women to their tormentors, just because they were and still are your constituents? I'm not even asking you to be feminists anymore. For you, women are variables of electoral adjustment. Just one thing: remember that you are Europeans and that as such you must regain the courage of this civilization which has made women saints, queens, ministers, empresses or warlords. In front of the United Nations, remember where you came from.

name: Izabela-Helena KLOC
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In her question, Mrs Regner stated that 25 years after the adoption of the Beijing Declaration on Women's Rights, women are still not fully respected. I totally agree with this, because there are women who do not have a voice and cannot decide their future. There are women whose survival depends on the decisions of their mothers, taking into account only their own socio-economic situation. Finally, there are women who are first physically or chemically mutilated and then killed without any consequences for the perpetrators. If you are horrified and outraged by this, it is right, because, in fact, millions of unborn girls are shamefully oued from the fight for women's rights as a result of abortion. However, they have the right to live, to have their own body and to choose their own future. No man should take away this right, not even his mother. The women's rights movement, which does not defend the rights of all women and supports abortion, is pure hypocrisy. Enough of killing unborn children. It's just barbarism.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, since the Beijing Declaration women’s rights have experienced some progress but quite significant backlash also. We haven’t been able to make any significant progress at convention level internationally, not to push women more in politics or other leading positions increase the use of quotas and we know that the funding for women’s organisations for sexual and reproductive rights has been decreasing globally. So I wholeheartedly look very happily towards the new Commission and its initiative to have the equality programme and hopefully seek the leadership globally to push women’s rights and gender rights on the next level on the ongoing negotiations, including proper metering with the SDGs, including gender budgeting, including gender impact assessment of politics and, of course, including the Istanbul Convention and hopefully with Africa strategy some better funding for the female NGOs.

name: Mónica Silvana GONZÁLEZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the Beijing declaration, 25 years later, remains the indicator for measuring gender equality. But let us be realistic, in many United Nations states it is not fulfilled. The Union's priorities for this 64th session of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women are a good opportunity to defend with concrete things the sexual and reproductive rights of women and, in particular, women living in Latin America, from the foreign policy of the European Union. Inequality in Latin America is in tangles with women. Beyond inequality only in terms of economic conditions; in particular, with basic rights, such as life, physical integrity, sexual freedom and reproductive health. Latin America and the Caribbean bear the highest rates of clandestine abortions and deaths from clandestine abortions. Six states do not allow it in any condition and twenty-one only do so if there is a life risk for pregnant women. The European Union must continue to support organisations that advocate safe, free and free abortion. Argentina's green handkerchiefs are an international mobilization. To the cry of education to decide, contraception not to abort and abortion... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Mr President, we celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Fourth World Conference on Women, held in 1995 in Beijing. It was a point and apart. And it was the most visionary agenda for women's equality worldwide.  The changes have been desperately slow and we now have to make an evaluation of this Conference at the United Nations this March. They have been slow because there is still a pay gap, as we have said, a gap in pensions, low-quality employment and low employment for women, difficulties in conciliation, few women in decision-making powers, gender-based violence and so on.  That is why we have to maintain a common position at the United Nations in March. We have to be ambitious. 2020 is going to be a turning year. We all have responsibility—we can't leave anyone behind—and we all have it, not only have it at the collective level, but also on an individual level. I want to tell you that environmental sustainability is fundamental to the planet, but also the sustainability of the dignity of women, justice and equality.

name: Peter POLLÁK
text: – Mr President, poor women are now on the margins of society. I would also like to draw attention to the poor position of a large number of Roma women, who are facing not only socio-economic marginalisation, but many forms of unequal access, such as in the area of health care. Precisely because of social exclusion, lack of education, appalling conditions in which they live, the experience of health care is often silent. In my country, Slovakia, many Roma women from poor settlements do not share hospital rooms with other women. They are placed in separate rooms. Many times women have to endure humiliation, neglected care or uncomfortable access by staff. In the past, many Roma women have been forcibly sterilised without their own consent. In 2016, the UN Human Rights Committee asked the Slovak Government to set up an independent investigative body and ensure compensation for involuntarily sterilised women. In November last year, 15 years after illegal sterilisation, one was compensated. We must also talk about how our Member States treat women with socially disadvantaged backgrounds and ensure that they are well placed and protected. The priorities at the UN commission meeting must also reflect the problems of these women.

name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
text: – Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, equality between women and men is a basic principle, enshrined in the Treaty on European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. This principle should integrate all union policies as well as its external action around the world. It is crucial that we achieve a positive result at the next session of the UN Committee on the Condition of Women, taking a leading role in the implementation of women's and girls' rights and gender equality. We are the largest donor of development aid, which we are proud of. We must also be at the forefront of women's emancipation, combating violence and exclusion, promoting opportunities for education, employment and female entrepreneurship. I hope that an ambitious commitment will be reached and that the intentions will be practical in practice, materialising the 2030 Agenda and the Millennium Development Goals.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I want this new strategy to become a genuine revolution on human rights, and not just at European level, and to be matched by concrete and binding measures. I support this to be translated into a European directive, and I would ask for it in plenary, but I am dismayed by the small number of parliamentarians, especially men, I think that under five present at the moment in the Chamber.  The healthy, easy-to-implement solution would be the adoption of single European citizenship, my soul project, which would make it very clear that the rights and obligations are the same for all. So I ask you today to support this.

name: Silvia SARDONE
