text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a few months ago, a woman lawyer was convicted in Iran defending the right of her fellow countrymen not to wear headscarves. She was sentenced to 33 years in prison and 148 lashes. But equally serious incidents also happen in Europe. In Milan, in my city, last year, a 15-year-old girl was violently beaten by family members because she did not want to wear a headscarf; another pregnant girl was kicked in the belly losing her baby because it was hot and she didn't want to wear the veil. Also in France you will remember the episode of the two women beaten because they wanted to go around in shorts.  So, as the European Parliament hastens to set priorities for the 64th UN session on the status of women, I would like Europe to stop looking the other way, not seeing that certain attitudes are obviously linked to a certain culture and religion.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, the level of equality between women that exists in the Western world is unfortunately not present in other cultural and civilizational circles. The European Union has the opportunity to truly promote women's rights and gender equality through global forums and international organisations such as the UN.  In some cultures, women are so second-rate that society puts a lot of pressure on pregnant women to have abortions. In these cultures, the number of male children is misunderstandingly high, precisely for this reason. They don't even give girls a chance to be born, and we have to fight it with all our powers.  In my view, one of the Union's top priorities at the UN Commission's session on the status of women must be to fight for life from conception and to stop the horrendable practice of aborting girls, which is unfortunately widespread in certain cultures.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the EU will approach the 64th Session of the Commission on the Status of Women with a high level of ambition. It will, from an early stage, engage with all countries in an open and constructive spirit. Our ultimate goal is the adoption of a consensual concise and action-oriented political declaration. This should reaffirm the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action and outcomes of their review conferences. The overall objective of the EU is to reaffirm the full validity of the international acquis on gender equality, the full enjoyment of all human rights by all women and girls, and their environment.  We are all responsible for making things happen. Each EU institution plays a crucial role. I am proud to say that the Council has consistently played an active part in advancing gender equality in Europe and beyond. We look forward to continued cooperation with the European Parliament in the field of gender equality, and I would like to thank you for being so active in keeping this vital topic high on the EU’s agenda.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: I have received two motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 13 February 2020. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. – Equality between women and men is a fundamental principle of the EU enshrined in the Treaty on European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Gender mainstreaming is therefore an important tool for integrating this principle into all EU policies, measures and actions, as well as its external dimension. It is inconceivable that any kind of discrimination between men and women should continue. After all, ensuring gender equality is everyone's business and a daily affair. This fight must be held at every level until equality between men and women becomes an act and an experience for all.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The next item is the report by Roberta Metsola, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Border and Coast Guard and repealing Council Joint Action No 98/700/JHA, Regulation (EU) No 1052/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council and Regulation (EU) No 2016/1624 of the European Parliament and of the Council (COM(2018)0631 – C8-0150/2019 – 2018/0330B(COD)) (A9—0022/2019). I remind you that it is possible to request catch-the-eye and blue cards using both the standard registration and the electronic system. Instructions are available at the entrance of the Hemicycle. Please also be reminded that blue-card questions can be raised only after the speeches on behalf of political groups.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Rapporteur. – It-triq biex wasalna sa hawn kienet waťda twila, imma wasalna. Meta jkun hemm dokumenti li jiżu ffrodati jimminaw is-sigurtá interna fiż-żona Schengen, li hi żona ta' moviment żieles mingťajr kontrolli fil-fruntieri.  Din il-liżi l-żdida tindirizza din il-problema billi tassigura li jkun hemm tisťiť ta' kooperazzjoni bejn il-pajjiżi members tal-Unjoni Ewropea flimkien ma' pajjiżi msieťba, biex jieťdu passi dwar l-awtentièitá jew il-falsitá tad-dokumenti. B'hekk ikun hemm garanzija ta' sigurtá akbar fil-fruntieri esterni u s-sigurtá taè-σittadini li aťna nirrappreżentaw.  Aťna nafu li l-uniku mod kif nistgťu ngawdu l-benefiżèji li żżib magťha ż-żona Schengen huwa li-żittadini tagťna jkollhom fidużja fl-immaniżjar tal-fruntieri external. U din il-liżi hija strumentali u essenzjali f'dan kollu – il-fruntieri, is-sigurtà u l-żlieda kontra l-kriminalità. Il-liżi l-żdida se tgťin biex jiżu identifikati u jinqabdu dokumenti li jkunu żew iffalsifikati. Din il-liżi tipprovdi qafas biex dan isir bla ma jkun hemm telf ta' σin u dan isir bl-assistenza tal-Frontex li tkun responsabbli wkoll mill-qsim tal-informazzjoni mal-pajjiżi kollha parted with jkunu megťjuna u infurmati kif jistgťu jaqbdu sitwazzjonijiet fejn ikun hemm falsifikazzjoni ta' dokumenti.  Il-liżi tiʻara r-rwol tal-Frontex fit-twaqqif tal-FADO. Aťna saťťaťna dak li jaqa' taťt din il-liżi sabiex il-FADO tinkludi iżjed informazzjoni milli tagmel illum.  Aťna rridu uniformityá u konsistenza fil-levelll ta' informazzjoni li l-FADO jkollha dwar il-żenwinitá, il-falsitá u l-iffrodar tad-dokumenti u biex l-informazzjoni tkun ièenentralized.  Aťna ridna wkoll li l-Frontex ikollha l-flessibilitá neèessarja biex tistabbilixxi u ttejjeb il-FADO. Assigurajna li l-Ażenzija tfassal dokument żdid dwar miżuri actual biex jiżu identifikati metodi ta' ffalsifikar.  Naturalment gťamilna dak kollu li stajna biex personal id-data tkun konformi mal-liżijiet Ewropej. Ir-riżultat gťandu jwassal gťal protezzjoni akbar u fl-istess waqt ikun hemm garanzija ta' sigurtá aktar stretta.  Il-FADO hija essenzjali fil-żlieda kontra l-falsifikazzjoni partikolarment fil-fruntieri external. Il-parteżipazzjoni ta' pajjiżi li mhumiex imsieťba fl-Unjoni Ewropea imma li jipparteżipaw fiż-żona Schengen hija wkoll krużjali gťax fl-aťťar mill-aťťar din ikollha impatt pożittiv fuq is-sigurtá tal-fruntieri external. Din tista' tidher bťala sistema teknika wisq, imma hija sistema li naťseb naqblu li hija essenzjali biex tikkomplementa r-riforma tal-fruntieri Ewropej u l-ťarsien tal-istess fruntieri.  F'dawn in-negozjati aťna gťamilna l-almu tagťna biex ir-responsabbiltajiet li jaqgťu taťt dan ir-Regolament jitwessgťu. Dan filwaqt li niżżilna r-responsabbiltajiet speżifiżi tal-Ażenzija u assigurajna li l-ipprożessar tad-data personal mill-Ażenzija u l-Istati Members jkun konformi mal-liżijiet Ewropej.  Assigurajna wkoll li l-Parlament ikollu sehem akbar fil-FADO. Fl-aťar nett jiena nixtieq nirringrazzja lill-Kunsill, lill-Presidencies Finlandiżi u Kroati, kif ukoll lill-kollegi tiegťi minn kull grupp politiku gťall-ťidma kostruttiva ťafna li aťna gťamilna. Jiena nťares 'il quddiem lejn dan id-dibattitu li se jsir f'din il-plenarja biex imbagťad nasal biex nikkonkludi wara l-intervent ta' kulťadd.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this debate. Our citizens consider security one of their top concerns and expect the EU to deliver. Security and freedom go hand in hand, so we need to create a safe space for all Europeans. Being safe is indispensable to live, enjoy rights, work, study and it is also indispensable for the economy. Every person present in Europe has the individual right to be safe. The 2019 Eurobarometer on attitudes towards cybersecurity published recently shows, however, that two thirds of respondents are concerned about falling victim to identity theft. Moreover, a well-functioning Schengen area of free movement requires a common policy on the EU external borders. We need to effectively monitor and control persons crossing the external borders for the benefit of all of us.  The need to strengthen our internal security and our EU external borders has led to the adoption of a variety of recent legislative acts, for example, the European travel and information and authorisation system, the entry-exit system, the regulation of inter-operability between EU information systems and the new European border and Coast Guard regulation.  Today, we have another example, which is the new false and authentic documents online system: a European image database supporting Member States in the recognition of authentic and false documents. I thank both the European Parliament and the Council for your constructive work on this final compromise that ensures real added value. The new false and authentic documents online system is very useful for border guards when performing border checks. It provides information to Member States’ authorities on new forgery methods and new genuine documents in circulation. It contains thousands of descriptions of authentic documents, hundreds of descriptions of false documents, covering more than 30 participating countries, and more than 180 third countries’ international organisations. It helps to detect attempts at identity theft for purposes of irregular migration. The final political agreement will further improve the functioning of the false and authentic documents online system by transferring its management to the European Border and Coast Guard Agency.  Security is a top concern for citizens. They expect the EU to deliver in this area as every citizen has the right to feel and be protected. The rise of threats posed by organised crime, terrorism and the drug market are poison to our societies. This is why the Commission has announced a new security union strategy for the second quarter of this year. As part of the strategy, on internal security, there will be a focus on three priority areas: organised crime, which would include drugs, firearms, corruption, trafficking in human beings, terrorism and radicalisation, and fighting crimes in a digital age. Strong borders to support the area of free movement, which is emblematic for our Union, will also be a key element of the new pact on migration, as announced in the political guidelines of President von der Leyen. In this respect, the timely implementation of all EU information systems will be a key objective of our comprehensive approach to migration, focusing on both external borders and security, but equally on strong and resilient internal procedures, stepping up the legal pathways and fostering integration into our societies. I thank you again for your support and look forward to this debate.

name: Emil RADEV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, honourable Members, document fraud seriously undermines internal security and the Schengen area as an area without internal border controls. The use of false documents by foreign nationals seeking a better life in Europe is common, and the cost of such a document can reach up to 5-6 thousand euros. European. Document fraud is one of the main contributing factors for terrorism and organised crime and is linked both to the smuggling of drugs, weapons and stolen cars, as well as to trafficking in human beings and, especially in recent years, to migrant trafficking. It is not often that the receipt of authentic travel documents is based on false documents of legitimacy. That's what makes exposing them so difficult. In this respect, it is crucial to increase the security of travel documents issued in the European Union, including the related identity management infrastructure. On the other hand, cooperation between different authorities must go beyond law enforcement, as it requires contacting the issuing authorities as well as international organisations, airlines, shipping companies and others. With all this in mind, I call on you to support the proposal to integrate the online counterfeit and authentic document system into the European Border and Coast Guard as a last step towards completing its reform.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner Dalli, do the Member States of the European Union have the right and responsibility to control who enters the Schengen territory of free movement? The answer is yes. Does the growth, multiplication of false documents and identity fraud in this free movement area pose problems? Again, the answer is yes. Is that a security hazard? Yes, to the extent that it may result in criminality, money laundering from illicit business or even terrorism. Does the European Parliament have anything to say? The answer is yes; we're saying it. We are ready to support an instrument to ensure the storage, exchange and verification of false documents, to combat fraud, and we are ready to rely on the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, which we have strengthened with the Regulation we adopted in 2019, to be responsible for sharing that information securely with Member States , with the European Union, with international relations and, ultimately, with all the entities that may be relevant to account for the true identity of people enjoying free movement in the Schengen area. Our requirement is as long as this is compatible with the work we have done to ensure the confidentiality of the data, the fundamental rights. In short, the founding values of the European Union. But it is a fact that we have to combat the insecurity of people circulating in our Schengen area with all the technological tools available and with the necessary legal guarantee. For this we have also supported the interoperability of all this data, always insisting that all this be done with full respect for the fundamental rights enshrined in the Charter.

name: Dragoş TUDORACHE
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the rapporteur, Ms Metsola, for her work. As a new Member of this House working on my first legislative file, I very much appreciated her lead. Now on substance. Verifying the authenticity of travel documents has been turning for quite some time into a pressure point in the work of border guards, because of time constraints, the tremendous increase in the number of travellers in Europe, and the diversity of travel documents that are being used. Furthermore, the sophistication of forgery techniques has been a constant challenge for our law enforcement officials. The new FADO system has already been in use for some time, serving these needs. What we are now doing, and this is very important, is to bring it from the intergovernmental into the Community method by adding it to the list of instruments entrusted to the EBCGA (European Border and Coast Guard Agency) as part of the enlarged mandates that we decided to give last year.  This means increased accountability towards, and scrutiny by, this House, and higher safeguards in the regime applicable to the data contained therein and the measurement of access rights. The protection of personal data was one of the main issues that we had to deal with during the negotiations of this file, and we made sure that the processing of personal data is limited to what is strictly necessary for the purpose of detecting or investigating document fraud.  We also introduced clear rules on accessing the database, with Member States now having an express obligation to determine which authorities competent in the area of document fraud are to have access to the FADO system and their level of access, and then to notify the Commission and the Agency. The Commission, upon request, will now have to transmit this information to this House. The negotiated text complements the reform of the EBCGA and will ensure better protection of the Union’s external borders and more efficient law enforcement.  I therefore encourage my fellow MEPs to support this text.

name: Annalisa TARDINO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs Metsola for her work. In recent years, we have seen a significant increase in document fraud in the Schengen area, both through the falsification of genuine documents and the use of counterfeit documents.  This measure will allow us to frame the management of the system relating to false and authentic documents online, known as FADO, within Frontex, whose management model is now obsolete. The need for defence and security that our citizens are asking us to ensure a very high level of alert against false documents, because criminal instruments are suitable for re-use for different crimes, including money laundering and terrorism, but above all illegal immigration. In fact, counterfeit documents have often been used by asylum seekers trying to enter Europe.  These are conducts that we cannot tolerate and must be stopped. It is therefore essential to provide the police, border guards and customs with a more efficient database, enabling the rapid detection of falsified documents and an effective fight against these phenomena.  For these reasons, we support the proposal, despite our express disagreement that some private individuals should access FADO, even if they are limited. Although we are opposed to the reform of the Frontex agency regulation, we now believe that the use of FADO is important in the activities of combating fraud carried out by the authorities of the Member States.

name: Saskia BRICMONT
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for the good cooperation on this issue. It is an issue, indeed, which is technical, but still requires some more political considerations.  While we understand the legal reasons for the legal change in the basis, we regret that Frontex is entrusted with the management of this database. We will of course be careful that this does not augur well for a strengthening of the agency's mandate - FADO is not a tool to combat migration, but rather an instrument to combat false documents in general. The overall compromise is balanced, notably through the introduction of safeguards so that third parties, the airlines of third countries, can access the database, but with limited access. Although the database contains little personal data, it seemed necessary to make it impossible to identify through FADO documents, which is now the case.  Finally, we will closely monitor the publication of the various delegated acts.

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, thousands of false documents are detected every year at the external borders of the European Union. In 2018, according to Frontex, 7,000 foreign persons were detected who submitted false travel documents at the crossing points of the Union's external borders. Various methods of counterfeiting are used as a genuine multi-purpose tool in the commission of offences – money laundering, terrorism – and an illegal entry key to the territory of the European Union.  This highlights the great importance that the protection of our borders and immigration control have for the safety of our nationals. The Regulation, the FADO system, will promote, taking advantage of Frontex's experience, a rapid and efficient exchange of information, without prejudice to the better development of member states for the detention, prevention and prosecution of crimes. In this case, our group, concerned about this investigation and prosecution of crimes and the rigorous control of the legal or illegal entry of foreigners into our territory, will vote in favour, and we encourage the rest of the House to do so.

name: Sira REGO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, it should be remembered that during the years of fascism in Europe thousands of people were forced to use forged documents to escape the horror. It is worth remembering our history, even in technical debates —apparently technical — of this kind to understand the scope of our measures. This proposal of the System of Authentic and False Documents in Network, in the context of a strong Europe, condemns thousands of refugees to use these false documents. It even contradicts in some respect the Geneva Convention, which recognizes that those forced to flee may use false documents. That is why, in the face of those who strive to shield Europe's fortress and turn it into a mass deportation agency, we will continue to defend human rights, defend legal and secure avenues of access, defend humanitarian visas at source and defend the recognition of the figure of climate refugees.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, falsifying documents is a tried and tested method for criminals and terrorists to stay under the radar. We see that Frontex already detects about 7 000 every year, and that number has been increasing recently in the Schengen area. This is worrying, because where false documents are used, our security is at stake. It is therefore crucial that police officers and border guards across Europe can check the authenticity of documents from other Member States, that they are aware of the technical specifications of those documents from other countries, and that false copies circulating in the EU are actually known everywhere.  There is therefore a real European added value there: sharing information between Member States, ensuring that that information is always updated and ensuring that that information is available and available to all 24/7. This new system is therefore a very welcome new system and much needed, because we are also stronger than alone in the field of security. I therefore congratulate Roberta Metsola for the excellent result, together with her colleagues, and I look forward to seeing the system actually work in practice.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against false documents and their movement in the Schengen area is now a priority for the European Union in the area of cooperation between law enforcement authorities and in combating criminal organisations. For effective law enforcement, however, we need a constant exchange of information, which must not only take place between the authorities of the countries of the Union but also, with the necessary precautions on personal data, with the European institutions, third countries and private bodies, such as airlines, which can contribute to the proper functioning of the FADO system.  Indeed, numerous investigations carried out by Europol have repeatedly shown that false documents are often the means used by criminal organisations to commit other, far more serious crimes, such as trafficking in human beings, trafficking in migrants, or even preparing terrorist attacks. In order to prevent the commission of these crimes, therefore, greater control at the external borders is necessary, among other measures. It is therefore welcomed that the regulation transfers responsibility for the system for managing false and authentic documents to FADO, from the Council to Frontex, thus finally completing the legislative reform of that agency, which will, however, have to be followed by proper and complete implementation in order to make the rules adopted so far truly effective.  I would therefore like to thank Mrs Metsola for her work and I hope that this measure will have the broadest consensus in this Parliament.

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the agreement we are voting on is of a technical nature, but there are at least two political connotations that I would like to highlight. Firstly, document fraud is a serious threat to all of us and the cooperation between the Member States that is inherent in the FADO system is a clear success, one of those cases in which the concept of 'more Europe' is declined in a functional and non-instrumental way.  The second political fact, unfortunately much less positive, can be summed up in the definition of 'data minimization'. The restrictions introduced for the recovery of personal data represent a missed opportunity to effectively combat organised crime and illegal immigration. For the umpteenth time, the left in this Parliament is showing its disconnect from reality.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, Rapporteur, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. In 2015, I was on the border of Greece and North Macedonia. I saw 55 kinds of Syrian passports there, but none of these passports were real. And it is important to point out that many people came here on various fake passports, which were produced everywhere in Europe. That is why this database is important, even if it seems like a technical standard, it is very important to protect EU citizens from people coming here on false documents, and there is also a need for further cooperation in detecting, for example, false documents that are for cars and other technical equipment.  We need to continue to work with this database and for all Member States to make good use of this tool and to make every last good use of this instrument in order to make Europe as safe as possible in the future.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Falsification of documents is often the first step in the creation of organised crime within the European Union: money laundering, terrorist activities and other modern forms of criminal, including mafia, activities. Therefore, it is a very good move, a move in the right direction to create a coherent system, unifie your knowledge and experience to fight against such practices. Therefore, you should look favourably on fado. At the same time, I am pleased that Frontex, which has very positive and good experience in terms of the security of the entire European Union, will have this tool. If the European Union wants to be strong and compete effectively in the world, it must deal with these new threats, including terrorist threats and organised crime. Finally, the rapporteur, Mrs Metsoli, must indeed be thanked for her hard work on this document.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: – Dear Chairman, as we have heard today, the issue of security is today one of the most important issues for citizens of the European Union, and as we know, there are many threats that exist here, consisting of terrorism, organised crime and other illegal activities.  In this sense, the falsification of documents poses an extreme danger, as it allows people who we do not even know who they are and what their identity is to enter the territory of the European Union, who can be terrorists, criminals or deal with similar illicit things. Thus, this system is good, allows the exchange of information on sample copies of documents and known methods of counterfeiting between member state authorities and is precisely one of the answers to this question of security vulnerability that is extremely important to European citizens.  So, I support the introduction and creation of such a database, I support the strengthening of the security of the Schengen area that my state will hope to enter soon, I thank my colleague Mezzola for the great work she has done with this and I call on us to continue to work on strengthening the security of the citizens of the European Union.

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: – Dear Chairman, congratulations on my colleague Metsola's excellent work, greetings to Mrs. Dalla. According to data from Frontex, a colleague and colleague, in 2019 there were almost 14,200 illegal border crossings on the Western Balkans route, which includes the Republic of Croatia, which has been in fado system since 2014. In 2018, Croatian border police discovered 236 forged documents and 60 other people's documents, an increase of almost 40% from a year earlier.  The methods of producing forged documents are increasingly sophisticated and the exchange of high-quality information is needed to detect it. The increased pressure of irregular migration at the external borders of the European Union requires coordinated and enhanced action by all forces using modern technical equipment and the exchange of data collected by Member States respecting human rights. Particular emphasis should be placed on cooperation between Member States.  Finally, I want to emphasize that one of the priorities of the Croatian Presidency is a Europe that protects, the key word is security. Let's not let it be traded.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, of course this is a very important subject, and it is good that we have here a report on the FADO system. Who forges their iDs and who makes impersonation? Not a good person, okay? So from the very beginning those who falsify documents come with the intention of doing something wrong, in a certain state, we can think of crime, terrorism.  Obviously, the system needs to be improved and, as it said here, the more sophisticated the means by which documents can be falsified, the more we must come up with measures, with a system to counter these falsifications. And yes, the thousands of people who crossed the border with forged documents worry us.  Of course, my country is not yet in Schengen, I hope it is, but we are talking here about the whole european Union market, not just the Schengen area, and I believe that the security of citizens, of all European citizens, no matter what country they live in, we must ensure it by means of protection – Frontex, the FADO system or other means by which we can discover these forgeries and ensure the security of citizens.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I very much support this project, which has been presented. Thank you, rapporteur, for your great work. I believe that security is the first common interest of the whole of Europe. It is also important that, by supporting the FADO, we strengthen Frontex, an extremely important agency that aims to work increasingly well for the security of europe as a whole. We have a lot of unpleasant experiences when it comes to ignoring security issues. In this case, I can say that, following in the footsteps Polish, the European Union is building its security. Poland is a safe country, Europe must be a safe place to live, and this project strengthens it well and perfectly.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Ms Metsola for her work and thank all the honourable Members for this debate.  As I mentioned, the False and Authentic Documents Online (FADO) system will help maintain a high level of security within the Union and strengthen controls at our external borders. The final political agreement on the Commission proposal provides significant improvements to the current functioning of the system and contributes to the fight against document and identity fraud. It also provides, as mentioned by several honourable Members, robust data protection and fundamental rights safeguards. In the light of our debate, I look forward to a positive vote on the final compromise.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Rapporteur. – Segwejt b'attenzjoni l-interventi li saru u nirringrazzja l-appożż, nista' ngťid, unanimu f'din il-Kamra, gťal din il-liżi. Naťseb li huwa important li nisťqu gťal darb'oťra dwar xiex qed nitkellmu hawnhekk. Il-FADO hija sistema li żiet maťluqa biex tagťti appożż lill-members tal-Unjoni Ewropea biex ikun hemm qsim ta' informazzjoni mingťajr dewmien ta' dokumenti żenwini, [dawk] iffalsifikati jew even mbagťbsa. L-użu ta' dokumenti ffalsifikati fiż-żona Schengen żdied, kif qalu l-kollegi tiegťi, b'mod konsiderevoli matul is-snin, u speżjalment fl-aťťar snin u gťalhekk huwa essenzjali li nieťdu azzjoni. Il-mod kif jiżu ffalsifikati qed jinbidel u gťaldaqstant irridu nkunu dejjem pass qabel min gťandu intenzjonijiet żżiena. U b'hekk inkunu nistgťu nassiguraw il-protezzjoni aťjar tal-fruntieri esterni tal-Unjoni Ewropea, inťarsu l-moviment sťiť tal-persuni, li huwa punt, per prinèipju, fundamentali li gťandna u niffaťilitaw il-moviment tan-nies bejn il-fruntieri li jkunu qed iżorru fuqhom dokument ta' identità, vjażťar jew valid residence. Dan jgťin lill-awtoritajiet biex jidentifikaw dokumenti li huma ffalsifikati b'gťodod li jeťtieżu u li ilhom jitolbu sabiex sempliżiment ikunu jistgťu jagťmlu xogťolhom u dan kollu jkollu effett pożittiv li jiżu protetti d-drittijiet tal-persuni li l-identità tagťhom tkun qed sfortunatament tiżi użata miż-żrieki kriminali, naturalment mingťajr ma jkunu jafu li qed isir abbuż mill-identity tagťhom. Nixtieq nirrispondi wkoll gťal intervent partikolari mill-kollegi tiegťi, minn tal-Partit tal-Σodor; irnexxielna nsibu l-bilanè bejn il-protezzjoni tad-drittijiet fundamentali u s-sigurtà. Dak li gťamilna u ddiskutejna mhuwiex il-bidu u t-tmiem, fejn jidťlu l-żlieda kontra l-kriminalità, imma dak li qed nagťmlu huma elementi essenzjali meta jiżu magťquda ma' miżuri oťra. Jiena, Sur President, nagťlaq dan id-dibattitu billi nappella biex gťada ningťaqdu f'din il-Kamra b'appożż u nivvutaw favur din il-liżi.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 13 February 2020. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The FADO system is a very important tool to support the fight against illegal migration and the use of false documents. It is an EU online image archiving system set up to support the rapid sharing between EU Member States of images of authentic, false and forged documents.  The criminal world is today using increasingly modern methods of falsiling documents, and the fight against this is a huge challenge for a number of services responsible for our common security. Therefore, the FADO system contributes to maintaining a high level of security in the Union by helping the police, border guards, customs and other law enforcement authorities in the Member States to combat crimes against the reliability of documents. For this reason, the FADO system is an important tool for applying the Schengen acquis.  We therefore call on the Commission to finalise this system as soon as possible, as it is an important tool in the fight against crimes against the credibility of documents, in particular at the EU's external borders, which is an important element in strengthening border control and combating irregular migration.

name: Ondřej KOVAŘÍK
text: in writing. – I will support the Parliament’s legislative resolution on the false and authentic documents online system (FADO) because it is outdated and needs to be adjusted for the new TFEU institutional environment. The regulation that is to be adopted repeals the joint action formerly establishing the FADO, and sets up new legal basis for the updated FADO system with information on authentic documents issued by the EU, the Member States and also third parties, as well information on the false versions of such documents. I believe this will improve our fight against document and identity fraud by working together and sharing information between the relevant national authorities and with other actors as well as with the general public.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the state of play of the EU’s fight against money laundering, in light of the Luanda Leaks (2020/2562(RSP)). I remind you that it is possible to request catch-the-eye and blue cards using both the standard registration and the electronic system. Instructions are available at the entrance of the Hemicycle. Please be reminded that blue-card questions can be raised only after the speeches on behalf of the political groups.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, thank you for inviting the Presidency to contribute to this debate. Let me start by assuring you that the Council, like the Parliament and the Commission, is fully committed to the fight against money laundering and terrorism financing. Together, we have made substantial progress in this area, including with amendments to the Anti-Money Laundering Directive and the Banking Package, the European Banking Authority Regulation and in the Criminal Law Framework. All these recent rules now need to be implemented and enforced. The speculations raised by the Luanda Leaks case are indeed alarming and damaging if confirmed. Damaging not only to the country in question, which may have been deprived of essential revenues, but also for EU banks if it turns out that not all applicable rules were followed. I understand that related investigations are being undertaken, including in Angola and Portugal, which now need to follow their course.  Last July, the Commission published, at the request of the Council, a post—mortem review of alleged money—laundering cases involving EU banks. In that report, the Commission identified concrete problems with the supervision and enforcement of any anti-money laundering rules across the European Union. And I think it is not excluded that we may now see some of these same issues repeated if, in fact, confirmed.  Looking ahead, however, in spite of the challenges and setbacks, there are also causes for more optimism. Indeed, there is a sense of urgency shared by Parliament, the Commission and the Council, and more than that, I would say that there is also a shared sense of ambition in tackling the big problem that is money laundering.  This brings me to the strategic conclusions that the Council adopted last December. In these conclusions, the Council advised the Commission to look into ways to increase harmonisation in the anti-money laundering area, as well as to consider the possibilities, advantages and disadvantages of establishing an EU supervisory body.  The Council is advising on other fronts as well. For one, we still have the Anti-Money Laundering Action Plan, agreed by Ecofin in December 2018, which is running its course and which we continue to monitor.  Additionally, our Presidency has started a broader discussion on fighting serious and organised crime by tracing its proceeds more effectively. We stand at an important crossroads from where we have the opportunity to proceed towards an effective regime to counter money laundering and the financing of terrorism. In this sense, I very much look forward to the Commission’s upcoming initiatives and proposals and I trust that the Commission will take on board any lessons learned in this last case, the Luanda Leaks, as appropriate.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission recognises the importance of this debate and welcomes the opportunity to clarify its approach to matters such as those revealed to be at the heart of the Luanda Leaks. We have consistently stressed that better enforcement of anti-money laundering rules across Europe and stronger supervision are essential to increase the resilience of our financial system. Beyond stability, we need to ensure the integrity of our financial system. It is not a problem of one country. The European Union should have zero tolerance for dirty money. We are willing to apply all of the tools at our disposal and to the fullest capacity. Moreover, we are ready to strengthen them. We will not hesitate to propose changes to the legislative and institutional architecture that supports our fight against money laundering, terrorist financing, as well as tax evasion and avoidance. Following up on the European Parliament’s resolution and the Ecofin conclusions of December, the Commission will adopt a new action plan on anti-money laundering that will seek to improve the enforcement of the rules. Much has been done in recent years. The fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directive, which should have been transposed by Member States by 10 January, allows greater scrutiny of information around beneficial ownership by civil society, including by the press or civil society organisations and contributing to preserving trust in the integrity of business transactions and of the financial system. The legal framework currently in force seeks to ensure a proper balance between the need to ensure protection of privacy and of personal data and the need for more transparency in financial and economic activities. By establishing accessible registers of beneficial ownership information, the Union has achieved the gold standard worldwide in this respect. Regrettably, not all the Member States have transposed the fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directive. Today, the Commission has started infringement procedures against eight Member States which are signalling a complete lack of transposition. However, our real problem is not a lack of rules; it is that the enforcement of rules is done at national level and is uneven from country to country. Recent legislative changes to the mandate of the European supervisory authorities granted new powers to the European Banking Authority to lead, coordinate and monitor the EU Supervisor’s fight against money laundering and terrorist financing. This covers the entire financial sector. The Commission, however, acknowledges that more must be done. There is a need to address structural weaknesses linked to regulatory fragmentation among Member States. This is where European added value lies. The Commission intends to work towards the establishment of a unified, comprehensive anti-money laundering policy, building on existing rules and introducing all necessary improvements. There is scope for harmonising the existing rules. There is need for more information sharing between law enforcement authorities to detect and prosecute criminals and to recover assets. In addition to a more detailed and harmonised set of rules based on regulations rather than on directives, a greater role for the EU in overseeing their implementation is justified. This applies as regards both supervision and coordination of the Financial Intelligence Units. An EU supervisory body for AML is a must-have, but creating a structure should not be our aim in itself. The body, be it a new one or building on the existing one, has to have a clearly-defined scope, powers and, very importantly, efficient governance. We know that we can count on the support of the European Parliament to bring about a revamped and more efficient supervisory and enforcement architecture. This is our ambition.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The Luanda Leaks show once again that the European Union is still appallingly attractive to money launderers, despite five anti-money laundering directives. We have to look at why this is still the case. Of course, one major problem is the slow implementation of the current law. Commissioner, I can only agree with you on this. The deadline for transposition of the fifth directive was a few days ago, on 10 January. At this point have a total of five- to five! – of twenty-seven Member States, the directive has been fully implemented, fifteen only partially – Madam President-in-Office of the Council, even if you are not listening, your country is one of these fifteen – and the rest have not even informed the Commission of its implementation. I very much welcome the fact that you have today opened infringement proceedings against these Member States. If, however, that is the way in which the Member States are tackling money laundering in practice, then all the fine resolutions of the EU finance ministers are just lip service. Since the Member States do not seem to be able or willing – and are not listening now – to take effective action against money laundering, we need to think about how we can combat the problem at European level. Thank you very much, President, that you are listening now again.  After all, this is about the integrity of the European financial system and also about the security of our citizens, because money laundering and organised crime are directly linked. With the European Public Prosecutor's Office, we have a model for building an authority that can also take a European perspective on criminal matters. That is why I am really calling on the Member States to cooperate here to get to European prosecution authorities so that we can deal with this problem on a permanent basis. It will not be enough to wait until the last EU country has implemented everything.

name: Eero HEINÄLUOMA
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, once again we owe our thanks to journalists, independent journalists, who have made valuable revelations when they tell us how, in reality, money moves and against the rules that we have. What is particularly shocking is that this is happening in a country where a third of citizens live on incomes of less than USD 2 a day. Hundreds of millions, billions have been taken out of the country, and many European consultants, lawyers and lawyers have helped in this – even the authorities have been involved in supporting this activity.  Our group has long called for stricter rules of the game, real change. It is now to be said that we are unlikely to survive any longer with these directives, which are implemented in varying ways at national level. We need uniform legislation, and that is what the financial world itself is calling for. This is also the wish of the banks. So it is time for change, and it also requires better supervision at European level.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Mr President, we are not fully, correctly and in a timely transposition of the European directives adopted to combat money laundering effectively. It's a reality! The Commission has today begun infringement proceedings against several states, including Romania for failing to transpose the Fifth Directive in time. Moreover, none of the Member States correctly and completely transposed the Fourth Directive, for which the transposition deadline was June 2017.  There are some clear lines of action that come off, in particular, in light of the latest revelations in the Luanda Leaks scandal. Firstly, we need, Commissioner, anti-money laundering regulations. It's a brave but absolutely necessary approach. Directives are not a strong enough tool. The paradigm needs to be changed.  Then we really need to know the real beneficiaries. Transparency is an absolutely mandatory exercise in the whole process.  Legislative gaps create situations of great vulnerability for the Union and for the Member States. It is unacceptable for one of the four major European consultancy firms, including working with the Union institutions, to provide financial and legal advice to relatives and camaraderie of dictators in third countries to help them launder money, transfer their assets to tax havens and escape the budgets of the states in which they operate. The answer is Magnitsky legislation, horizontally, at European level, as I also requested by letter sent to the Commission in December.  Last but not least, it should be pointed out that investigative journalists have once again demonstrated to us, through the luanda Leaks revelations, how important their work is to the fight against money laundering and corruption. Their protection, including legislation, must be an absolute priority of the Commission and ours.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the When I look at the public debate following the Luanda Leaks revelations, I really feel unwell. It seems to me that we are slowly getting used to such tax scandals. The excitement is diminishing, it seems to the public that politics is powerless in the face of an ever-increasing tax avoidance industry for some rich and powerful. But politics must never stop fighting injustice and injustice for the sake of our democracy, no matter how powerful the opponents are. It is no coincidence that Luanda Leaks is once again dealing with our Member State, Portugal. At the Football Leaks a year ago, Portugal was at the centre of a corruption scandal – and what followed? The whistleblower, Rui Pinto, is in prison, but the real criminals have not been prosecuted. Similarly, Portugal has sold thousands of golden visas and built a tax haven in Madeira. This is how people's sense of justice is trampled underfoot, and we cannot allow that to happen as a European community on the rule of law. The European Commission must enforce European law in all Member States, and it must not wait for infringement proceedings. Unfortunately, it has also watched this activity in Portugal for far too long, while at the same time major scandals were going on – money was not confiscated, perpetrators were not convicted. We therefore have a rule of law problem in Portugal, and the European Commission must address this problem as quickly as possible with targeted infringement procedures. We need the forthcoming revision of the Auditors Directive to ensure that auditors in particular will no longer be able to do business with dirty money in the future, as was unfortunately revealed in the Luanda Leaks. This problem is far from being solved, and we must stick to it.

name: Beata KEMPA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Only a hard law, the crossing of which is punishable by imminent punishment, is capable of stopping international criminal groups. Let me use the Polish example of introducing such rules. In recent years, under the leadership of Attorney General Zbigniew Ziobra, Poland has rolled out heavy anti-money laundering. Thanks to the extended confiscation and sealing of the system, about PLN 4 billion, or about one billion euros, was seized and secured in a short period of time. The Polish consists of ruthlessness, courage, stubbornness of the prosecutor's office and the Ministry of Justice and the introduction of new measures to combat money laundering. Expanded confiscation, enhanced cooperation within international actors and banks, restrictions on tax havens and so-called non-cooperative actors, and fast and ruthless services are the most important elements of the new architecture of the fight against organised crime and money laundering. An important tool is becoming the fifth directive on combating dirty money. This is another important improvement of the system and strengthening cooperation in the fight against the most serious crime.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, the Luanda Leaks scandal certainly has many national responsibilities, also in my country, where for many years the economic elite and the political elite have not seen any problems in Isabel dos Santos' business, and have cooperated with them. And there are also national problems in other jurisdictions such as Malta, which has actively cooperated with the entire money laundering cycle that has been going on. Now there is also a responsibility of the European institutions to realise that if there are national jurisdictions that are facilitating money laundering, tax evasion, financial crime, then the other members of the European Union, and the European Union as a whole, they have to prevent this from happening. And there is a risk that the multiplication of these scandals will end without responsibilities and without consequences for all those who collaborate in money laundering, be they States, or the financial advisory firms that the European Commission hires to work for European institutions and which are also involved in these operations that know to be illegal, and in the financial institutions of the European Union. If none of this has consequences, if at the end of this process the only person responsible is Rui Pinto, who is the person who brought these documents publicly, then the only lesson that citizens will draw from the action of the European Union is that, in these scandals, there are only consequences for those who have not committed crimes.

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, money laundering is a crime with many faces. It has legitimized fortunes and investments, opening the door to the contamination of companies and the economic viability. However, laundered money does not lose its criminal origin. Combating it is more than an economic or supervisory imperative, it is a matter of the rule of law and, not in a few cases, of defending human rights. Determined and solid answers are demanded. Today there are possible infringement proceedings by Member States for failure to transpose the 5th Directive in the fight against money laundering. There is a lack of determination and lack of solidity, because each of the twenty-seven has its own approach, as the Commissioner rightly said in her initial speech. It is in the division that the door is ajar for crime. At the end of March, the Commission will present its action plan. It is up to this Parliament to respond, with even greater determination and soundness, even if directives have to be passed on to regulations, nor if we have to strengthen European supervision and the European Central Bank when national regulators continue to fail.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the revelations in the Luanda Leaks, which also involve operators from certain Member States, confirm that the fight against money laundering must remain one of the European Union's priorities. Money laundering, together with corruption and fraud, is in fact one of the means by which criminal organisations take root on the territory and penetrate the economy, affecting economic freedom and free competition. And money laundering is one of the sources of terrorist financing.  It is therefore necessary to strengthen European anti-money laundering legislation and to harmonise national legislation. And we need to monitor the implementation of the anti-money laundering directives, including the one on criminal matters. It is also necessary to give the judicial and investigative authority full access to the information collected by the FIU and to provide law enforcement authorities with effective control powers already at administrative level and with adequate specialisation, as is the case, for example, in my country, Italy, with the Guardia di Finanza. This is also the case in order to recover the proceeds of these serious crimes, which we now know is only 1 %.

name: Francisco GUERREIRO
text: – Mr President, Luanda Leaks, this scandal mirrors the financial, economic and fiscal system and promotes genuine red carpets of money laundering, corruption and influence peddling. Take the stark and incomprehensible case of the Gold visa system in Portugal. In seven years, this visa regime has not only put pressure on house prices, making them unaffordable for most citizens, but it has been an economic failure, creating only two hundred and thirteen jobs and sixteen businesses. Moreover, the data relating to visas with the entry of dubious capital are so evident that this Parliament itself has already recommended the end of Gold visas in all Member States, a recommendation to which Portugal has made, and does, a blind eye. But Luanda Leaks also reopens the issue of whistleblower protection and the guarantee of the political system's non-interference in investigative journalism. There is an urgent need to ensure the transposition of the 2019 Directive, notably in Portugal, on the protection of whistleblowers and to ensure that investigative journalism has all the tools to carry out its work as guardian of democracy.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, tax scandals such as Lux Leaks and others have revealed to the world a system that promotes opacity and anonymity and allows money laundering. In reaction to such scandals, the European Union has shown that it remains strongly conditioned by the interests of multinationals and not only. Measures taken by elementary people to fight money laundering were stopped and, if anything changed, it was to keep everything the same. As for recent allegations made public, it is for the authorities of the countries concerned to ascertain the existence of illegalities or illegalities and to act accordingly. What these events cannot justify in any case are hypocritical attitudes and interference of those who see an opportunity here to give strength to their ambitions of neocolonial rule. The fight against money laundering, as well as tax evasion and avoidance, remains limited by a node that the European Union is not interested in unearthing: the tax havens with which the European Union lives and is conniving. It is still necessary to untie this node.

name: Emil RADEV
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, today at European Union level we have introduced strict rules enshrined in the Fourth and Fifth Anti-Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Directives, which had to be transposed by the Member States by 10 January this year. But Luandaleaks makes it clear that not all countries and banks in the European Union have yet implemented these rules. It is disturbing that we have a highly regulated sector. We have the necessary tools to detect any potentially money laundering activity, yet nothing has happened. We see that in recent years the threats do not just come from outside, but there are fraught cases of money laundering inside the European Union. Thus, the entire financial market of the European Union is threatened by criminals and terrorists. In this regard, the European Commission must ensure the proper implementation and application of the existing legal framework and, if necessary, initiate infringement procedures against Member States. Thank you!

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: – Mr President, with this timely debate we go back to a recurrent concern of this Parliament. These practices harm the European society because relevant parts of our resources are directed to criminal activities. The scope of innovation in financial transactions is enormous. Digital transactions grow every day and become more and more sophisticated. We have to recognise that regulation in actual practices by the authorities have been insufficient. We need coherent regimes of supervision and on the actual definition of illegal practices. We need much more cooperation between the different authorities in Member States. We need to consider an additional role for the European authorities. We need compliance to step up in the institutions, even through the enforcement of public authorities. For all this to happen, we probably have to step up the legislative and regulatory process at European level, considering seriously the possibility of approving a European regulation. Finally, we need people to trust the banks, financial institutions, public authorities. Therefore, this battle is far from won. Let’s keep fighting the good fight.

name: David CASA
text: – Il-ħasil tal-flus jibqa' delitt diffi大li biex jiġi skopert u aktar diffi大li biex min jaħsel il-flus, jitressaq il-qorti. Ġurisdizzjonijiet sigrieti jagħmlu minn kollox biex jiffa大ilitaw l-attività kriminali. Informazzjoni kru大jali għall-prosekuzzjonijiet mhux qed tingħadda lil min jinvestiga u dan kollu qed iwassal biex il-kriminali jgawdu minn impunità. Naturalment il-ġurnalista Ewropea Daphne Caruana Galizia nqatlet biex i tibqax tikxef il-korruzzjoni u l-ħasil tal-flus; l-istess korruzzjoni u ħasil tal-flus li saru minn kumpanija rreġistrata fid-Dubai. Minkejja dan kollu, l-Emirati Għarab Magħquda jibqgħu jinsistu li ma jgħaddux informazzjoni importanti, li jfisser li l-ġustizzja i tistax isseħħħ.  Għandu jkollna qafas f'postu biex dan it-tip ta' informazzjoni tkun tista' tingħadda kif suppost, anke bejn l-FIAUs fl-Ewropa. Irridu nkunu b'saħħitna biex nassiguraw li pajjiżi terzi jikkooperaw ma' investigazzjonijiet Ewropej dwar il-ħasil tal-flus.  Fl-aħħar mill-aħħar, irid ikun hemm konsegwenzi għall-ġurisdizzjonijiet li ma jikkooperawx. Ma jistax ikollna din is-sitwazzjoni u nħalluha għaddejja kif inhi.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Mr President, she took EUR 2 billion from the Angolan people, bought companies at a great discount, and got loans she never repaid. How did Isabel dos Santos become Africa’s richest woman? Many say it’s corruption, but we only seek money that we can spend, and she did her spending here. Her EUR 50 million superyacht was Dutch; her GBP 30 million mansion is in London. The real enablers of her crimes are those who cleaned her money: bankers from Liechtenstein, tax advisers from Luxembourg, and trust firms in Amsterdam, my hometown. These enablers roam free, while Rui Pinto, the source behind the Luanda Leaks and the Football Leaks, has already been in prison for one whole year. Is he not a whistle—blower? Doesn’t he deserve protection? These are my specific questions to the European Commission.  We need to acknowledge the problem. We need to acknowledge that the problem is also ours, and to protect those that expose these crimes. So let’s fight money laundering. Let’s gather our resources, European and national. Let’s fight.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. EUR 2 000 billion is laundered around the world every year. But we don't just need to look at others; the problem does not start outside the European Union. EUR 110 billion is being laundered within the European Union, which is very close to the ANNUAL EU budget. It is therefore a question of the credibility of the community based on the rule of law, it is a question of the credibility of European parliamentary democracy. It is outrageous that there is still a contradiction between the commitments made and their implementation by the Member States; that the situation is still in place that the fourth Money Laundering Directive has not been transposed, although the fifth should have been implemented since January; and that there is still a permeable patchwork and that we still need a common money laundering watchdog that goes beyond the financial sector, a European financial police force and a European reporting agency. Let us finally do what we have been promising for years.

name: Marek BELKA
text: – Mr President, after discussions connected to the Panama Papers, Paradise Papers, Luxleaks and you name it, here we are again with Luanda Leaks.  Getting into detailed discussions about Ms dos Santos’ potential wrongdoings makes little sense now. What we need to look at is own European plate.  Firstly, if Dubai is so often mentioned in the Luanda leaks as a destination country for illicit wealth, why are the United Arab Emirates not on our European blacklist of non-cooperative jurisdictions? I call on the Commission to look into this issue whilst reviewing the lists.  Secondly, if a Portuguese bank and Maltese financial service providers have helped Ms dos Santos is in her actions, where are the loopholes in our fight against tax fraud and against money laundering? This year’s anti-money laundering action plan and legislative files on taxation have to address these points. While rightly criticising the wrongdoings of Africa’s richest woman, we need to also ask ourselves why in the EU we facilitate such actions.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, we all know that the biggest fault of the Anti—money Laundering Directive lies in the Member States; in poor implementation, lacking European powers on European prudential supervision, poor cooperation between financial intelligence units, the limited scope of powers of the Financial Intelligence Unit Platform to set standards. We know that the system is not working, because it’s not made to be working.  That is the reason, once again reminded, how ineffective we are. What I do hope is that the Commission would consider seriously chasing the anti-money laundering Directive to be a Regulation and to increase substantially the transparency of the beneficial ownership registers, increase the European prudential supervision, and to really set the system on place to function.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Dalli, welcome to this debate against bleaching, which is not the first, has a lot of history, because before Luanda Leaks there were Lux Leaks and there were Panama Leaks, and there was a study and research committee, of which I was a member, which yielded conclusions and mandates for action for the Commission. That is why we have moved from the fourth to the fifth Anti-Laundering Directive, which strengthens the transparency and identification of account recipients; because each of these cases I have just cited makes the background of corruption and influence trafficking worse.  The Luanda Leaks case is paroxystic because it affects Africa's richest woman—the daughter of Angola's former president.  But there is another mandate: to protect whistleblowers, whistleblowers, because it is intolerable that there are countries that have not transposed the Whistleblowers Directive, including Portugal, and it turns out that Rui Pinto, the whistleblower, is the one in jail, when the person who had to be in jail is not the whistleblower, but the criminals and the criminals.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Much has already been said here. Once again, we are debating the scandals, and once again we are wondering whether money laundering is the domain of only the countries of the so-called Third World, or whether it is only Africa, cheap tax havens. On the other hand, it is strange that beneficiaries tend to either invest or spend this money here in Europe. It must therefore be made clear: criminals have always been a step ahead of the democratic rule of law and the services that are fighting it.  No individual country will be able to cope unless there is full coordination. Last autumn, there was a demand from six countries that a single office be set up here in Brussels to combat this. I can also say from my own experience, as a former Minister of the Interior and Administration in the Government of the Republic of Poland, that the successes of the services I oversaw were largely successes resulting from cooperation with other services, with Europol, with Interpol. This is the only way that will allow us to be a step ahead of criminals.

name: Milan UHRÍK
text: – Mr President, in many EU Member States, the legislation regarding money laundering is being made increasingly strict, including by restricting the space for casinos and other games. However, this kind of online gambling remains still quite untouchable because it’s operated on a global, multinational level, and for a single state it is quite hard to touch it and to control it. My question is: are there any further plans for fighting against this kind of money laundering, this kind of criminality?

name: Antonius MANDERS
text: Mr President, in recent years money laundering has become increasingly widespread through large banks in Europe and it is time for the directors of those banks to be given a prison sentence instead of a bonus. I would like to add that, very briefly.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, here we are witnessing international criminal activity, as well as our low powers and ability to deal with this situation. This is a white-collar crime, which is very sophisticated, and I would, of course, like to thank the journalists involved in uncovering this activity, as well as the whistleblowers. It shows what significant gaps we have in protecting whistleblowers internationally. At the same time, it is shocking to me how many European structures, meaning banking or trust structures, have been involved in covering up the very nature of money laundering and illegal activities within Angola. What to do about it? We have 5 directives, it seems that we need to overcome fragmentation, we need better implementation. It is undoubtedly necessary to equip the competent authorities more with competences and, above all, in my opinion, to ensure profits. It is not possible for profits to be secured at such a small percentage as shown, for example, in previous cases.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the Commission, I thank the European Parliament for taking the time to debate this topical matter, and for its commitment to further strengthening all our tools to deal with situations such as the one at stake. We need to act upon all these findings, and I am confident that we have already identified the way to ensure that the Union’s financial systems’ integrity is more effectively protected. We are determined to work with international partners on new threats from innovation and it is critical to already deploy all our efforts to ensure the current legislative framework is applied fully, and correctly. This also includes protection of whistleblowers and to give renewed impetus to the role of the Union in ensuring more effective and coordinated action.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I have followed this debate with great attention, and I have also heard the input from the Commission. I take this opportunity to reaffirm the importance which the Presidency attaches to the fight against money laundering and the financing of terrorism, and I look forward to our continued work on these matters. The Presidency will remain available for exchanges on the subject as needed.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: Writing. – There have been suggestions from the European Commission that a more effective way of combating MONEY LAUNDERING and terrorist financing in the EU would be to significantly strengthen regulation at EU level and to increase supervisory functions to EU level. I am concerned about the relocation of supervisory functions to new EU-level institutions, as the current situation does not confirm that this is necessarily the solution. Instead, strengthening national authorities and greater cooperation between national authorities are the best way to do so. National authorities are able to address the challenges; they have daily close contact with banks, insurance companies, lawyers and have detailed and up-to-date knowledge of local conditions. The effectiveness of a central supervisory body cannot achieve the efficiency provided by the institutions of the Member States. Any further steps should be based on an assessment of the current situation and take into account the practical functioning of the eu-regulatory elements that have already been adopted. All the more so because we do not yet have experience of how the recently introduced legislation works in practice. The further development of the EU anti-money laundering system is, of course, crucial. However, among the modalities of further development, consideration should also be given to approaches that take into account the specificities of the Member States and continue to provide the necessary room for manoe d'2 in the Member States.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the humanitarian situation of refugees at the EU's external borders (2020/2523(SDR)). I would remind you that it is possible to submit requests for intervention in accordance with the catch-the-eye procedure and 'blue card' questions using both the 'standard registration' system and the electronic system, which I absolutely urge you to test. Instructions are available at the entrance to our Hemicycle.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it is the second time under our Presidency that we have the possibility to discuss in the plenary the humanitarian situation of refugees at our external borders. This shows the importance Parliament attaches to this issue and we fully support it.  Our Presidency is closely monitoring events on all migratory routes and will continue to do so throughout this semester. In 2019, the total number of illegal border crossings at the EU external borders was estimated at 139 000 which is a 6% decrease compared to 2018 and the lowest level in six years. However, while the central and western Mediterranean routes saw a decrease of 40% and 50% respectively compared to 2018, arrivals on the eastern Mediterranean route have increased by 50%.  The situation on the Greek islands is, in particular, a source of concern as we all noted during our last debate in the plenary on 29 January. The number of people present on the Aegean islands reached a peak of over 40 000 migrants. It is the first time since the implementation of the EU-Turkey statement that we have reached such a high number. The Greek government is taking concrete measures to improve the situation. It has announced a new national strategy designed to protect minors who have arrived and who are resident in Greece and it aims to increase the number of transfers to the mainland. In 2019, more than 35 000 migrants have been transferred and these transfers have continued at a fast pace since the beginning of 2020.  Arrivals from the eastern Mediterranean route have direct impact on the flow of migrants in south east Europe. In 2019, there were over 14 000 illegal border crossings on the western Balkan route, which represents 140% increase compared to 2018. Since the beginning of 2020, the pressure on this route has decreased, due also to winter conditions. Nevertheless, this winter the pressure is higher when compared to the previous winter.  Our Presidency will continue to devote much attention to the migratory situation and increasing migration management capacities in the entire western Balkan region, with a particular focus on Bosnia and Herzegovina in order to ensure adequate protection of migrant population where, according to UNHCR, more than 8 000 migrants and refugees are currently present, mainly in the North West. The situation in the country remains challenging, but in the last weeks, there have been some positive developments regarding the increase of adequate reception capacities.  On 3 February, the Croatian Interior Minister Božinović, held a meeting with the new Bosnian Minister of Security, Mr Radončić. The ministers agreed to strengthen the cooperation in several key areas: implementation of accelerated readmission procedures, more intense implementation of mixed border patrols and support of the Republic of Croatia in strengthening the Bosnia-Herzegovina security forces in border control. The ministers also agreed to strengthen the cooperation in combating smuggling networks, which was also a topic of a ministerial debate at the informal meeting of EU interior ministers in Zagreb on 24 January 2020.  Minister Radončić commented that Bosnia-Herzegovina lacks over one thousand border guard for better border control, as well as the 93% of EU funds approved to Bosnia and Herzegovina last year were intended for humanitarian treatment of migrants but only 7% to strengthen security forces. The EU will continue to support Bosnia and Herzegovina in its efforts to guarantee the dignity and safety of all migrants, especially the most vulnerable ones, while at the same time seeking a more permanent and comprehensive solution.  We will also continue to support work with all partners in the Western Balkans. The overreaching goal of our efforts is to ensure that the migration flows at our borders are well managed and migrants’ fundamental rights are always respected. We expect the recent measures taken by the Greek government to bring positive change. The new asylum legislation which has recently entered into force in Greece should speed up the streamline of both asylum and return procedures.  The return rate has been very low for far too long. Returns are instrumental in managing the migratory flows. The plan of the Greek government to return 10 000 migrants by the end of 2020 is ambitious but it can be achieved, also with necessary EU support. Effective returns also require the good cooperation of Turkey. To ensure that the situation is well managed, it is also important that our Western Balkan partners enhance their migration management capacities, also in the area of return and particularly assisted voluntary return, conclude readmission agreements with third countries and further align their visa policies. We are ready to assist them in these tasks by all means at our disposal.  On the central Mediterranean route, conditions for migrants in Libya have deteriorated due to security issues arising from the internal conflict in the country. To alleviate the suffering of migrants and detained refugees in Libya, the EU individual Member States have funded UNHCR and International Organisation for Migration (IOM) programmes via EU trust fund for Africa.  IOM is funded to carry out voluntary returns to countries of origin and to provide humanitarian emergency assistance and has done so at an impressive level. UNHCR is funded to evacuate persons of concern to either Niger or Rwanda in view to a settlement in the EU or other receiving countries. These relevant actions require our further support, especially in view of ongoing conflicts in Libya.  To conclude, I would like to stress once again that the humanitarian situation at our external borders is a cause of great concern and we have to work closely together with our neighbouring countries and international organisations to improve it. Let me also express here our appreciation for the work of all humanitarian partners. I will let the Commission further elaborate on the comprehensive assistance the EU provides at our external borders to improve the situation.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you Minister and honourable Members for this important debate. The humanitarian situation of refugees at our external borders is of great importance and of concern to us all. The EU promotes the respect of the rights of refugees, asylum seekers and migrants, both in the EU and outside of our borders in our neighbourhood. Any form of violence against refugees and migrants is, needless to say, unacceptable. Respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law must be ensured without exception. Member States must fully comply with these principles when implementing the EU acquis on border management, asylum and return. Pushbacks are not acceptable. Access to asylum procedures and respect for the principle of non-refoulement, in line with the EU Charter, must always be guaranteed. Member States must have in place the mechanisms needed to prevent pushbacks in the first place. Equally, they need to ensure that they have appropriate mechanisms to guarantee a prompt reply and investigate any alleged pushbacks.
