But challenges at external borders are many, and the Commission is in constant contact with Member States and provides them with support, including financial support for training the national border guards to act in conformity with fundamental rights requirements. The Commission is also closely monitoring the situation at external borders and is in contact with Member States regarding allegations of non-compliance with EU law at the external borders. As Guardian of the Treaty, the Commission will take the necessary action where necessary. Moreover, we now have in place a new European Border and Coast Guard Agency with a significantly reinforced mandate and an increased focus on the imperious need to respect fundamental rights. It is for this reason that a specific Fundamental Rights Strategy has been drawn up by the new European Border and Coast Guard Agency. A fundamental rights officer was appointed to contribute to the Agency’s fundamental rights strategy and monitor compliance with fundamental rights. Fundamental rights monitors will also constantly assess the fundamental rights compliance of Frontex operational activities. They will be deployed as part of the joint operations and they will be the eyes and ears of the fundamental rights officer. The Agency must recruit 40 monitors by 5 December of this year. The new Agency has also set up a complaints mechanism. This mechanism allows any person who is directly affected by the actions of staff involved in the activities of the Agency and who considers himself or herself to have been the subject of a breach of his or her fundamental rights due to those actions, or to any party representing such a person, to submit a complaint in writing to the Agency. What happens at our external borders affects Europe. This is why the EU has always supported and also always stood at the side of our partners at the external borders as well as at the side of refugees and migrants in those countries. The EU is globally a key actor in providing assistance to refugees worldwide, especially in neighbouring countries, and in supporting third countries in developing their asylum system and their capacities to fight against smuggling. For instance, the EU supports Turkey in its efforts to host more than 4 million refugees. The EUR 6 billion facility for refugees in Turkey has been fully mobilised and clearly produces tangible effects. Over 1.7 million vulnerable refugees benefit from the emergency social safety net, the largest EU humanitarian project ever. The EU is also supporting more than 500 000 refugees’ children to regularly attend school. Our Western Balkan partners have proven to be reliable and strong partners of the EU in managing migration and countering security challenges. However, reception capacities, in particular in Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, are stretched to the maximum, and migrants are often living in extremely difficult conditions. Further capacity assistance is needed to help these countries to pursue their efforts to manage migration, addressing the issue of secondary movements in the region and treating migrants in a humane manner. To support all these actions, the EU provides financial and technical support to the Western Balkans through the regional programmes funded under the Instrument for Pre-Accession so that they increase their capacity to build their national migration management system. In addition, the EU has recently provided EUR 135 million in additional assistance to Serbia, North Macedonia and Bosnia and Herzegovina through the Instrument for Pre-Accession and EUR 32.6 million through the EU humanitarian aid. In all these actions inside and outside the EU, the protection of the most vulnerable, especially of children and unaccompanied minors, remains a priority for the Commission. The Commission is doing all it can to help Member States to address the situation at our external borders. The dignity and safety of all affected persons needs to be ensured and protected. A lot has been achieved, but more remains to be done. We need to find a common understanding on how we collectively shape and manage the realities of migration. We must unite around our common values and humanitarian responsibilities and seek to make our society more cohesive and integrated. I count on your continued support and that of the Council as well.

name: Emil RADEV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, honourable Members, it is known that the Western Balkans route is one of the main migration routes to Europe, making it also the busiest. Unfortunately, frontline Member States such as Croatia, Greece and others always bear a disproportionate burden, as due to their geographical location they are always the Member State of first entry. Evidence of this is what is happening both at the border between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina and on the Greek islands, where the influx of migrants is not decreasing. Paradoxically, while asylum seekers can apply for international protection at official border crossing points, their numbers are minimal. Instead, they use unregulated places to cross borders, often even using networks of smugglers, for a single purpose – to reach Western Europe. At the end of 2018, due to increased migrant pressure, the European Commission allocated 6.8 million euro to croatia to support the management of the European Union's external borders. This was done in full compliance with European Union rules ensuring that all measures applied at the Union's external borders are proportionate and fully in line with fundamental rights and European Union asylum legislation. As of the beginning of 2018, aid of EUR 36 million eur 100 million has also been granted to Bosnia and Herzegovina to meet the immediate needs of migrants and asylum seekers. The protection of the external borders can only be achieved in accordance with law and international conventions, as well as respect for fundamental rights and the dignity of migrants. Member States at the external border and the European institutions in good faith protect our borders and apply these rules.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the unprecedented peak in refugee arrivals in 2015 exposed the gaps in the EU’s policies at our borders, but it is now 2020 and the Member States have had five years to find solutions. And yet, in many places, the situation of refugees at our external borders, instead of improving, continues to deteriorate. We still stand by and watch pregnant women and children losing their lives in the Mediterranean Sea. We still accept thousands of people, including unaccompanied minors, living in camps for years in inhumane conditions, waiting for their asylum procedure to advance. And we still consent to people being forced to return to unsafe countries. Detention centres, illegal push-backs and floating sea fences are not the solutions we are calling for. I hope the Croatian Presidency will take note of this debate and our concerns on behalf of the European Council. And let’s not forget that countries surrounding the EU are still taking in the vast majority of refugees. But also let’s not forget that countries who are our neighbours sometimes have their own citizens fleeing from the country, so we must address human rights with countries such as Turkey and Morocco. In this Parliament we often talk about the European values. They include respect for human dignity and human rights. That also applies to refugees seeking protection.

name: Malik AZMANI
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission and the Council representatives for being here this evening. I think it’s high time to get out of the migration deadlock. We owe it to our own citizens to get back into the driver’s seat. In order also to preserve free movement within the Schengen area, we need strong external borders. Awaiting the Commission’s New Pact on Asylum and Migration, Renew Europe proposed its own comprehensive approach a few weeks ago: a Renew pack on asylum and migration. To relieve the pressure on EU external borders we need new international partnerships with third countries on migration. That’s the only way. Meanwhile, we need a common approach for those asylum seekers still arriving irregularly at EU external borders. We want ‘direct registration upon arrival’ amended to read: security checks; humane reception conditions; a first assessment at a European reception centre between potentially failed asylum applications and those that are not; shared responsibility for those people in need of international protection; shared responsibility and effort to quickly return rejected asylum seekers to safe third countries.  I have high expectations for this new pact on migration and asylum and hope that Renew Europe’s concrete proposals will also be taken on board. But I have still two questions: does the Commissioner agree with Renew Europe that the EU must be able to step in when the Member States at external borders cannot or will not deliver? Because that’s what we saw in the past. And how will the Commission address unwanted secondary movement of asylum seekers within the EU?

name: Tom VANDENDRIESSCHE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. Mr President, for a number of years we have been overwhelmed by unwanted migration. But this is just the beginning. The population of Africa has 2000 to 4 billion inhabitants. Hundreds of millions will come to Europe. That's why we have to guard the borders. Not out of hatred towards those outside our borders, but out of love for our own people.  Left-wing activists and rogue lawyers abuse human rights to encourage and promote migration. They want non-citizens to be able to enforce rights in our home countries. Migration wants to elevate them to an enforceable human right, with the cooperation of foreign judges, for whom, by the way, no one has ever voted.  The European Convention on Human Rights, for example, was once intended to protect citizens of European countries from tyranny. Today, however, it has evolved into a tool to ram an open-border policy down the throats of our people. We must solve the migration crisis at our borders. We do this by unceremoniously returning economic fortune seekers. We must take in genuine refugees in the region of origin, and above all we must adapt the human rights treaties to the reality of 2020 so that they can no longer be abused by the migration lobby.

name: Tineke STRIK
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, if we talk about common external borders we also talk about common responsibility, not only for controlling who is coming in, but also how we treat people – if they get access to an asylum procedure, if they are treated with dignity and if the procedures are followed. However, we know that at many borders the rules are not always complied with. Push—backs are widespread in Europe. We know that from reports and judgments, and even tomorrow the Strasbourg Court will come up with a decision on Spain.  Push-backs can also go hand in hand with brutal violence and causing traumas to people, and this is especially the case at the Croatian borders, according to numerous reports and testimonies. During our working visit last weekend, we were shocked by the fact that all actors involved acknowledged this widespread violence and push-backs, but that the Government of Croatia still denies this, and this discrepancy exactly shows that the violence will not stop if the EU continues to shy away and react indifferently.  We can only stick to our rules and values if we care about violations at the borders and if we take steps to ensure compliance. I would therefore urge the Commission to investigate thoroughly the allegations and complaints, and that investigation also needs to be part of the Schengen evaluation.  The Commission informed us that it had financed the monitoring mechanism in Croatia and that this would lead to improvement, but we learned that this money is not spent on monitoring but on border control, and that no monitoring body enters the green area where the push-backs take place. So how seriously does the Commission take these allegations on push-backs? Is it only interested in a smooth Schengen accession or also in banning human rights violations at the border? So I would like to hear from the Commissioner what steps he’s going to take instead of monitoring but also ensuring... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Tackling the root causes of emigration is one of the key elements of effective and crisis-resistant migration management. And what are these root causes? Obviously destabilisation and war in neighbouring countries, but also – it must be fair to say – extremely irresponsible, naïve, often based on a kind of terrorism of political correctness naivety and this famous "Herzlich willkommen" in 2015. Dear refugees, come! We are waiting for you here! This has resulted in very many people – indeed refugees – not being helped because they have been displaced by economic and economic migrants. The Union's impact so far on the processes in our immediate neighbourhood has proved insufficient and the real risks have not been effectively minimised. These unresolved problems outside the Union's external borders may lead to another migration crisis that we may have to deal with. Here it must be said very clearly: the actions taken by the EU institutions must be coherent, deliberate, properly coordinated, and the involvement of The Member States in these areas should be an expression of goodwill.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, it is true that border policy is a European one and cannot be blamed on a Member State such as Croatia. It is also true that asylum and migration policy needs a European solution. I can even understand why, in view of the disaster in the Greek hotspots, Croatia wants to prevent itself from becoming an EU hotspot country. But all this does not entitle the Croatian border police – and that is what I am about – to beat, torture refugees, to hurl dogs at them, to threaten them masked with weapons, to throw them into the border river towards Bosnia, to steal things – money, mobile phones, even food – leaving them with open wounds in the forest and of dragging people who provide help. Unresolved European issues do not justify such sadism towards refugees. Prohibition of torture, non-refoulement, protection of children – these are agreements that Croatia has also signed. Human rights must apply everywhere, and please also at the borders.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the New Democracy Government in Greece — taking the baton from SYRIZA in the EU's repression policy — is building, by legislative act, prisons on the Greek islands, where — on the basis of the German Dublin proposal — the bulk of asylum seekers will continue to be trapped. The majority of them will be deported, very few will be granted asylum and even fewer will eventually go to European Union countries. What is really being prepared is revealed by the return address announced by the Greek government, namely a deportation fund to bring the refugees back to the hell of the imperialist war, which is being inflamed by the European Union, the US, NATO and governments with huge responsibilities. Cancel Greece's signature on the European Union-Turkey Agreement and the Dublin Regulation. Condemn the policy of murderous floating barriers, the involvement and financing of NGOs and tolerance for the action of far-right groups, which is fuelling tensions on the islands, in an otherwise very difficult situation for islanders and refugees. Close hotspots and set up inland accommodation centres to get to the countries of real destination.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: – Dear Chairman, it is incredible to me that here, for the first time, we have to listen to lies, false information and fake news about the so-called illegal push-backs by Croatia. The only source of information for such claims are biased NGOs that have their own political agenda of denigrating Croatia, the Croatian Government, compromising Croatia's entry into Schengen, which base their sources of information solely on the claims of illegal migrants themselves whose identity is most often unknown at all and for which we do not even know who they are, who have tried five or six times to cross the border illegally and now because they failed, croatian authorities are suing around without any evidence. No such case has been identified by the competent authorities, by the court, by the police supervisory authorities, etc.  Croatia controls the European Union's external border, fights external illegal migration, guards 800 miles of the external border in a high-quality manner and last year more than 20,000 attempts at illegal border crossings were detected and prevented. I would also point out that last year alone 995 illegal people smugglers were arrested. Perhaps this, this practice of the Croatian police, is what bothers some here and why they spread such lies and untruths. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card in accordance with Article 171(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure)

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Yes, I am amazed. There is now a lot of evidence that there are mass pushbacks, illegal pushbacks at the Croatian border, and that almost all migrants affected by them have been deported at least three or four times, without being able to seek asylum. Are you aware of this? Have you ever heard of it? And have you heard that many, many refugees, for example, complain that violence has been inflicted on them in the worst possible way? Have you still ignored this or are you prepared to acknowledge what the reality really is?

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Chairman, I have heard many lies in my life, but repeating one lie a thousand times will not make it the truth. Of course, people who are trying to play the asylum system, who are trying to use Croatia to get to the territory of other countries, who do not come at all from war zones, but as the Minister of Security of BiH Mr Radončić said, from countries that are not at risk at all, who are not at war, of course such people who break the laws tell untruths. These are your sources of information and that, to such people, I honestly can't believe. You may be able to, but I can't.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Mr President, we cannot ignore the terrible situation of immigrant refugees in various parts of the world, but above all at the gates of the European Union, as I recently witnessed on the border between Croatia, the Member State of the Union, and Bosnia and Herzegovina. There I had the opportunity to witness and hear the most dramatic reports about the violent, degrading and inhumantreatment adopted by the Croatian police in the removal of people who only seek a decent life opportunity, a search that often results in their death. News of this today has come news of a parliamentary initiative to open an inquiry which I welcome and, in addition to not hurting the sensitivity of this Plenary, I will give the Commissioner some absolutely shocking photographs at the end of my speech. In Bosnia we were able to contact numerous migrants and refugees. Among these I would like to see unaccompanied young people living, like others, in conditions to which no one should be subjected, let alone at these ages. Several of them waiting to be able to meet with family members living in Europe. All this in the face of European marasmus in the assumption of solidarity measures to remove these people from the limbo in which they find themselves. I therefore wonder whether the new migration plan, which is being announced, provides for the establishment of legal channels, expeditious, in particular through humanitarian visas, but also for study, work and family reunification. Our restlessness cannot be equivalent neither in silence nor in inaction. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question in accordance with Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Chairman, colleagues, I come from Croatia.  I would just like to tell you that Croatia, unfortunately, has real painful memories. After Serbia's aggression against the Republic of Croatia we had thousands of migrants, so have no doubt about Croatian intentions and do not talk about something you do not understand and do not know. I live in Croatia and Croatia does everything to ensure that the treatment at Croatian borders takes place in full compliance with Croatian and European laws and international standards and rules. Croatia has no wire and no barricades, unlike other countries.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Protecting borders does not mean violating international law, violating human rights. And if Croatia wants to protect its borders, not by violating international law or violating human rights, why has it not yet implemented a mechanism for monitoring everything that is happening there? And parliament now needs to approve an inquiry in so that the whole truth can be established.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Dalli, let us see, if I am not mistaken and have heard it well, you have said that we do everything in our power. No, it's not true. We don't do everything in our power. We know that the Dublin Regulation does not work and yet the Council has it blocked. We do not have a common policy of asylum and legal migration, which is the way to stop this whole catastrophe. We don't do everything in our power. If I'm not mistaken, you say we've achieved a lot already. We've made Moria hell, that Samos, that Kios is hell. In Libya, where you say that we are helping to alleviate suffering, we will not be able to alleviate suffering if we do not do the most important thing, which is in our power, declare Libya an unsafe country. That's in our hand. When will you use everything in our power, Commissioner Dalli? Fundamental rights are not words. We step on carpet and you're talking about a fundamental rights official who's going to have another 40 officials. When there's misery, there's no time for these things, Mrs. Dalli.

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: Mr President, the famous refugee crisis that began in 2015 is definitely not a crisis. The massive influx of migrants to the European continent, in addition to being continuous, has become a veritable submersion. In Greece, annual arrivals have more than doubled in two years, reaching 75,000 new migrants in 2019. On the island of Samos, their number exceeds that of the inhabitants. Not to mention the access route through the continental border with Turkey, where the crossing of the modest River Evros is enough to demonstrate the total inefficiency of Frontex and the obsolescence of the 2016 agreement with Turkey. We can discuss and be underrant about the conditions in which migrants and illegal immigrants live, but it is to deal with the effects of the problem rather than to solve the causes. All those who, through their political acts or their speeches, incite the whole earth to reach the shores of Europe are responsible for these tragedies. On the contrary, all those who choose a policy of humanist deterrence will avoid these tragedies, both by the means put in place at the borders and by the cutting of all the aspiring pumps in the respective countries. By closing its maritime border with Turkey to detain illegal boats, Greece is moving in the right direction and we should be helping and encouraging it, rather than taunting it. Human rights affirm that every person can leave his country if he is persecuted, but this principle must not and should never justify that the lives, homes and countries of other men are turned upside down in return. Rest assured that the 21st century will be the right of peoples to self-determination and above all to remain themselves.

name: Erik MARQUARDT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I grew up in Europe, and when I was growing up, I always thought that human rights violations, state arbitrariness, that humanitarian crises are something that happens elsewhere, that cannot happen in European Member States. And then I went on a sea rescue mission in the Mediterranean and found that we support Islamist militias there more than the people fleeing these militias. And I was on Lesbos, meeting two young Syrians who asked me: Why is Europe treating us like animals? I have no answer to that. And last weekend I was also in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is by no means just individual NGOs that talk about pushbacks there, but it is also the EU delegation in Bosnia, it is the UNHCR, it is your own human rights envoy in Croatia, a state authority that assumes that there are many pushbacks there. You can see the violence everywhere. So what is actually happening at the external borders? We have given ourselves rules that we do not respect because we have other interests. I do not believe that this is the way in which a defensive democracy will work in the long term. I believe in the European Union, but I would like to believe even more in what we are and not in what we want to be here in speeches. If the Commission is serious about what has been said, then it is now also a question of showing, for example, in Croatia: we are allowing an independent human rights monitoring mechanism there, we are also allowing people there at the external borders to monitor, together with the border guards, what is happening there. It would be very important for Croatia to show that there is nothing to hide. This human rights monitoring mechanism could help. But they refuse to set it up. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: blue-card question. – Mr Marquardt, I was a refugee myself during the war in the former Yugoslavia and I worked in a solicitor’s office with thousands of refugees from the former Yugoslavia. There’s only one way to establish whether the police are doing right or wrong. What you are saying is a lie. It’s a blatant lie. Don’t abuse real asylum seekers by spreading these lies here, please, because you are going against real asylum seekers and real refugees, and you are using these human tragedies in this place by blaming Croatia for something that it is not doing.  One million one hundred thousand Croats live in Bosnia and Herzegovina. They are Bosnian Serbs and Croats, who were given Croatian passports during the war, and we are protecting them as well.

name: Erik MARQUARDT
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I have already said something about this. But I always wonder what does it mean if you just accuse everyone who researches there investigatively, state media in Germany, for example, who find out that there are pushbacks that make video recordings of pushbacks ... and you claim that this is fake news. What is this understanding of freedom of the press? I can't imagine what it's like to have to flee. But I think that if you have had the experience yourself, you would do well to talk to the people in Bosnia who we talked to at the weekend, who were beaten, who were really whipped and who really did not inflict these injuries on themselves.

name: Emmanouil FRAGKOS
text: Mr President, I am addressing the Greeks who see us from their televisions, computers and mobile phones. I address the inhabitants of Samos, Mytilene, Diavata and the rest of Greece, who have seen their place transformed into a vast caliphate. It is now a given that the European Union serves the interests of people like Soros, who through MKOs and Muslims aim to eradicate Christianity and fill Europe with mosques. We must honor the values and traditions we inherited from our ancestors. It is a disgrace that the European Union is using the European taxpayer's money to provide free accommodation and food to illegal immigrants, at a time when there are Greeks who, because of the economic crisis, have arrived to sleep in their cars. We, the Greek Solution, demand a Christian European Union that has at its core the sacred institution of the family and not a multicultural Europe.  (applause)

name: Konstantinos ARVANITIS
text: Mr President, first of all, some groups have lost the substance of the debate. Today we are talking about European borders and we must stress the value of the refugee and the value of the migrant; They are fleeing their own hell, then, from war and experiencing, here in Europe, European hell. That's what I understand. And, indeed, with legitimate state violence: the violence of police officers, border guards, state repression. Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Hungary, Romania. There are hundreds of incidents of violent repulsion occurring every day. We have testimonies, we are eyewitnesses ourselves; And when we — Socialists, Greens, left-wing MEPs — show pictures of police dogs destroying people, croatia's two ministers say it's fake news. And I hear it here. This is an insult to Members; what you are doing is an insult to the political groups. Listen to me! Listen at last! It's far-right rhetoric. You only have the ID and the Far Right left. I would also like to tell you that floating barriers are being installed in Greece. On the Greek-Turkish border, hundreds die from drowning and cold. And I want to ask one question last: will you finally tell us your proposal? No report of ideas; tell us what your proposal is.

name: Clara PONSATÍ OBIOLS
text: – Mr President, we cannot look at refugees as an external affair because being a refugee is a defining right for many of us. Many generations of Europeans, including those in my country who escaped the fascist horror of Franco 81 years ago, saved their lives thanks to their refugee status. Today there are refugee children and grandchildren sitting in this Parliament and who knows whether, unfortunately, there are also parents and grandparents of future refugees?  But being a refugee goes hand in hand with being a welcoming host. Europe, the daughter of refugees, must be a safe haven for refugees. Anyone seeking refuge, fleeing from wars, whether wars fought with weapons or with the economy, must feel that Europe is home – not to atone for the sins of colonialism, but to accelerate progress and peace in the world.

name: Lena DÜPONT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has At the last plenary session, we discussed the situation on the Greek islands. Today we are also talking about the Croatian border. In both cases, our asylum and migration policy can only work if it follows international and European law, if it upholds our humanitarian standards. At the same time, however, it can only work if we finally achieve a rigorous and consistent CEAS. The protection of the external border is a fundamental condition for this. Both Greece and Croatia, as well as all other states with EU external borders, must therefore apply: we expect and support compliance with rules, but we do not leave you solely responsible. That must be the European approach. Here I ask the Council and the Commission: if the situation on the Western Balkans route, the increasing numbers of illegal border crossings or the instability in Europe's neighbourhood do not lead us to launch an ambitious and sustainable asylum and migration package, if we do not use this window of opportunity, what then?

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Dalli, violence, suffering, denial of medical treatment, legal assistance or information, that is a flagrant violation not only of international humanitarian law, but of European law. First of all, from the 2013 Asylum Procedure Directive. And, therefore, the Commission has an obligation to intervene wherever and wherever there are mass expulsions at the border with flagrant violation of Protocol No 4 to the European Convention on Human Rights, in addition to Article 19 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which binds all Member States.  Wherever it occurs, the Commission has an obligation to open an infringement file and to ensure that access to European funds is linked to strict compliance with the fundamental rights standards of all Member States of the European Union, including the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. But the Commission also has to do more. The Commission, of course, has to ensure that no expulsion or return to an unsafe country, such as Libya, is possible. And the Commission has an obligation to open, at once, legal and secure channels of access to the European Union so that people are not obliged to expose their own lives in their efforts. Humanitarian visas, as this Parliament has wanted and ordered in the last parliamentary term. That is the task for this parliamentary term, Commissioner.  (He agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: the question asked by raising the blue card. – I have repeatedly heard from the Socialist faction how we are to be open to the humanitarian reception of thousands of refugees. I agree that the EU must remain a safe haven for those in need of assistance. And I want to challenge you: Contact the Socialist Minister of the Interior in the Czech Republic to accept 50 unassuited children from a Greek refugee camp. Are you going to do that? He refuses. He is a member of the Socialist Party, which refuses to accept only 50 unassuited children.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: "blue card" response. – Mrs Oojdrová, you mentioned in your question the Socialists in this European Parliament and the Czech Minister. And I have not mentioned any political family or any particular country. But I would remind you that whoever entered this European Parliament has done so by representing a Member State which has been bound by the Lisbon Treaty, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which recognises as a fundamental right the right of asylum and which recognises that international humanitarian law is binding on all Member States. Also for yours. And, therefore, there is no escape. Humanitarian law binds us entirely, and that means respecting asylum seekers. Today we voted on the FADO exactly to better control access, at Schengen borders, to the free movement area, but once they are inside, they have absolutely the right to have their fundamental rights, recognised in the Charter, protected by all Member States.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Honourable President-in-Office, we have been seeing for years the coverage of human rights for refugees and migrants at the Union's external borders, among other things, we have already heard, including at the Croatian border.  At the front, as President-in-Office of the Council of the EU, representatives of Croatia sit, and colleagues from that country are also in the Chamber. I know what you want to say again. That there's nothing true, that there's no evidence...  A month ago, a group of NGOs issued a report on what happened there last year. And the document shows that croatian authorities are sending these people back to Bosnia and Herzegovina beaten with sticks, with the consequences of shots fired with air guns, bose, sometimes naked. The Croatian Ombudsman, the United Nations agency, even some Croatian police officers in their anonymous confessions, also points to the developments.  The European Commission, even in its previous composition, has done - what? She said Croatia was eligible for schengen. So much for that. If I have to, I'll go out in person, but overnight and unannounced. Then, I'm guessing, I can show you my tapes every time you tell me where the evidence is. (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card in accordance with Article 171(8).)

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Chairman, respected colleague joveva, it is clear that all persons wishing to seek international protection can do so, clearly, at official border crossing points and with, normally, identity travel documents. I would like to ask you, regardless of all these unsubstantiated allegations you state, which is why you feel that there are a minimum number of asylum applications in Croatia, which is why people who want to apply for international protection who are in Bosnia and Herzegovina do not want to do so with their documents and do not want to do so at official border crossings.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: The answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – Dear colleague Ressler, I have not even spoken about any minimum asylum applications, I have talked about what is happening at the Croatian border, that is, at the Union's external border. Now you're saying there's no evidence that these are lies, that nothing is true. Maybe we're looking at other news or pictures, so maybe we can have a cup of coffee and take a look at all these pictures and videos together, but like I said, if I have to, I'll go to the border by myself. I've been to the border as a journalist, and as a politician, I'm going to go even more. Because I have more codecision power, and I hope that if you don't believe the press, I'll be able to prove it to you.

name: Hynek BLAŠKO
text: – Mr President, as a person, I sincerely regret the situation in which thousands of migrants are located on the EU's external border.  However, as Members of this institution, I am concerned about the approach of the responsible authorities to tackling migration, which has resulted in these dichy conditions. The vast majority of migrants come from countries where there is no war. It is quite clear that he comes to Europe only with the vision of an easy life offered to them in the form of generous social benefits.  Don't we have our problems with the social situation of some of our citizens and pensioners? By what right are migrants preferred to the people who work here and pay taxes? By what right are they preferred to pensioners who have worked here all their lives and paid taxes and whose pension does not equal the benefits of those you prefer?  Finally, remember that you are raising the whole problem with your ill-advised social policy and change it, then you will stop harming migrants and citizens of Europe.

name: Damian BOESELAGER
text: – Mr President, two weeks ago we discussed the situation on the Greek islands, and I’m asking myself how much has really changed on the ground since we talked about it. And the answer is: the situation has got worse. We haven’t done anything at EU level to make the situation better. Yes, we still give money, but in the end, the idea of creating a floating barrier to stop people even asking for asylum and the overcrowding in the camps is still so bad that people are protesting now – both the local population and the refugees. So I would ask us to stop the blame game between the Council and the Commission and act on both sides, as much as we can, to improve the situation on the ground. That means, on the Commission side, triggering the Civil Protection Mechanism today, and, on the Council side, actually accepting minors and refugees, who need our help so badly on the ground. Let us actually act today and not tomorrow.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, dear, I hear that you are criticising Croatia. You have no reason to criticise either Croatia, neither Greece nor Bulgaria, because we, our countries, protect you from terrorists, from Islamists, from jihadists. Because we stop those who come to blow up European cities, and every single country must protect its borders, and it is a sovereign state, and none of you can ask sovereign states to let terrorists into their territory. But I'il tell you why what you're doing is hypocrisy, severe hypocrisy. For none of you— those who claim to be very concerned — has set a personal example. Raise your hand to any of you who have taken an Afghan terrorist or jihadist into your home, raise your hand. Is there one? In your living room, in your bedroom, live with your children. I'm waiting, is there one? No, i won't! Then don't, please, be hypocritical and duplicitous.

name: Maria WALSH
text: – Mr President, I’m surprised that there weren’t any blue cards after our colleague there from the ECR. The challenges we face in keeping our borders secure are immense and growing. We’ve seen an explosion in the numbers of people seeking a better life in the European Union away from violence and poverty and away from climate disasters. The appalling conditions in any of the EU refugee camps, be it in any of the countries we’re talking about tonight, are under severe pressure from the people that are most vulnerable and from the people in the European Union who are forgetting to support our brothers and sisters. The conditions are intolerable, and lip service is not supporting or aiding those we need to support. It cannot just be a small number of countries accommodating everybody. It needs Europe’s help. The European project, dare I say, is a victim of its own success. We need to be compassionate to those who are risking their lives to come here, and we also need to find solidarity: the compassion in supporting our Member States who are most seeing the influx of people coming through. I notice my time is up, and I will say we need a strategic and compassionate solution right now, Commissioner, from the top down. And dare I say, one instant solution we could make is perhaps having this conversation, this much needed dialogue, in the Hemicycle at a time when there’s a little bit more than 40 or 50 MEPs discussing it.

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Twice I was there personally. The humanitarian situation on Croatia's external border with Bosnia remains dramatic, in particular the situation of unaccompanied minors. The local population and local politics are overwhelmed with the situation and rightly feel betrayed, sold and abandoned by the EU. Sunday speeches such as this evening by the Commission and the Council do not help us any further. This head-in-the-sand-sing-s- Please make sure that the humanitarian emergency is alleviated as a matter of urgency – especially the children must be taken out there – and that there should be independent monitoring of the events at this border. Finally, create a common European system of solidarity asylum without ill-treatment and illegal pushbacks. There are only real solutions based on human rights. The EU must finally act professionally, otherwise we will lose our last credibility.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is guilty, hypocritical and cowardly about immigrants, refugees and their conditions in reception centres. Guilty because, thanks to unrestrained immigration policies and reception at all costs, they have in fact come to us in despair, forced to survive in the camps, bivouave in the suburbs and often even delinquency. It is hypocritical, because you tear your clothes off the conditions of immigrants, but then leave the Mediterranean countries alone. I ask myself: why do you not support the rotation of ports? Why don't you do something to stop the landings, and therefore also and above all to block departures? It is cowardly because you applaud Carola Rackete and the NGOs here, but then you actually support those who favour the smugglers. The only one with a clear vision is called Matteo Salvini. We reiterate: stop illegal immigration, fight against traffickers and end the reception business!

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Following the liberal European media, one can get the impression that the migration crisis will end in 2016. In fact, it is still going on in two stages: humanitarian, at the external borders, and migration – within the Union. Official statistics show that the situation is still serious.  These are the effects of the European Union's 2015 policy, when borders were opened to all newcomers, wrongly or knowingly classifying them as refugees, although they were mostly economic migrants. So perhaps we are dealing with deliberate social engineering, which was to bring millions of migrants to Europe in order to speed up the end of nation states and create a new ideological man, without a national identity and without Christian faith. Instead of changing migration policy, the problem is silent. The Union has resources, it only needs a political vision other than a deadly neo-Marxist ideology for Europe.

name: Nuno MELO
text: – Madam President, a Europe with open borders is absolute nonsense that only the utopia of a very irresponsible left defends in this Parliament. There is not a single country in the world where borders are opened. Where anyone who wants to can enter depending only on your will. The European Union obviously does not have to be different. We must respect those who want to improve their living conditions and we have an obligation to welcome people with humanism, but in order for this to be possible with such scarce resources, there must be a great deal of rigour in controlling the entry of the external borders of the European Union. And you have to distinguish what has to be distinguished: one thing is refugees, another thing, they are migrants. Treaties and laws different from the laws that apply to migrants apply to refugees, they are different realities. Those who are considered refugees who flee to save their lives must be welcomed, in accordance with laws or treaties, but those who are only looking for work, who are migrants, must enter, or not, depending on the laws and will of each country, with respect to the principle of subsidiarity. Every country knows about the migrants it needs. Uncontrolled access of migrants to Europe is not acceptable, it endangers people's security, our labour, social and democratic system. And the reception of the real refugees, that is, must of course happen.  (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question in accordance with Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". You pointed out the different legal basis for the treatment of refugees and migrants – that is right. But one question arises: do migrants still have human rights and fundamental rights, or does this not apply to migrants, but only to refugees?

name: Nuno MELO
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. Will you think that if you want to enter Pakistan, India, the United States, Canada, where you want to enter? This does not happen in any country in the world and they have human rights. Countries have the right to regulate migration flows, have human rights and, as humans, also have to respect the laws of countries. If you are a real refugee, someone who wants to escape death, who wants to protect his family, treaties apply, they must obviously be welcomed. But that's why hotspots are so important. That is why it is necessary at the external borders to check very well who wants to enter, because the rest is utopian, beautiful words, but that do not solve any problem and put at risk the sustainability of this common project. And I would like the European Union to last many, many years.

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I am concerned about the people who have already been admitted. We have a humanitarian emergency here, and I am referring in particular to the situation on the Greek islands. We need decisive action. That is what the United Nations demands of the EU and Greece. And it is a disgrace for us together if the United Nations must call on us to act decisively. The situation has become dramatically worse over the last 12 months, and I am talking here about the need to look at the situation of children in particular. A third of those admitted to Greece are children under the age of 12. Here the hygienic situation is catastrophic, here the situation is catastrophic as far as diseases are concerned, in camps that are totally overcrowded. We urgently need a joint conference of the European Commission, the governments of Greece and Croatia as the Presidency of the Council and the United Nations, in order to make the situation humane, especially on the Greek islands.

name: Teuvo HAKKARAINEN
text: – Mr President, which one of us wants our homes full of uninvited guests, potential terrorists? We in Finland, in the north, have a situation where 35,000 refugees came under the refugee's name then in 2015. As a result, rape of children and adolescents explodes. So who's going to watch this job when these kids get here? According to the media, women and children came to Finland too, but I personally went to see the border there: 500 people a day, I counted them. They were all young men. In the evening, the media pretended to us that women and children came from here. My eyes don't lie. I think journalists and the media have some kind of lens on their heads. Who takes responsibility for the fact that such an illegal immigrant now slit the throat of a young woman in Finland? Who's going to take responsibility for these? (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 171(8)).

name: Erik MARQUARDT
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". You said that you should not accept anyone at home who has not been invited. However, it is also the case, for example, that I did not invite you here at all, that we have not invited all of you here, but it is your right to sit here, because we have a constitutional state, because elections are taking place, the rule of law and you have been elected. And it is also the case that you have an asylum system where you do not have to invite people, but where they have fundamental rights. I actually wanted to ask you what you think, who is actually coming. Because we know that there are also many problems in the world, many refugees. Would you really say that they should not have access to the rule of law at all?

name: Teuvo HAKKARAINEN
text: answer to the blue card question. "This is about human trafficking. At the moment, it is similar to the drug trade, and it has even bigger money than the drug trade. The rules are also the same, so that the rule of law cannot tackle the crimes committed by these people, who themselves do not care anything about anyone's human rights.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, the European Union needs migration, controlled migration. What happens, however, is uncontrolled migration, it means trafficking in human beings.  For this reason, people who reach the borders of the European Union are in danger from the first moment they have left their country. They have to go through transit countries, where organized crime networks bring them to the boat on which they climb and cross the Mediterranean. We have an obligation to stop the illegal migration process from the start. We need readmission agreements, we need agreements with transit country governments to neutralise organised crime teams, and we need member states' military fleets to return illegal migrant boats back to their ports of departure. That is the solution, otherwise, for years we will have the problem of illegal migration, wondering what we are doing in the Greek islands, what are we doing in Croatia? We need to put migration under control. ... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Bernhard ZIMNIOK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Over and over again, we debate the unresolved migration crisis in this House. And why? Because the EU still refuses to recognise the realities at its borders and to respond accordingly. We are discussing how to deal with so-called refugees, let the asylum industry tell us what is human estates and how we have to act. It is no longer possible to be unrealistic. It is not so difficult to solve this problem. close down borders, deny entry to any illegal. This also means that the boats will be returned safely to their place of origin. Illegal migrants must be repatriated, if necessary, with some pressure on the countries of origin. If a country refuses, effective sanctions must follow. On the one hand, we happily let every illegal person into the country without any control, on the other hand, you need a plant health certificate when you bring plants and fruits from your holiday. How absurd is that? Let us finally send out the right signals! Let us finally face up to our responsibility for the European citizen, prevent the many deaths in the Mediterranean, prevent the brain drain in the countries of origin and let us finally stop the emotion! Let us close the borders!

name: Andor DELI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support This is a very important topic. At the same time, there is one aspect that has not been discussed so far and which left-wing members consistently put in place. And this is how the citizens of Bosnia, Serbia and the greek islands are living through the fact that for years masses of migrants have been passing through their settlements, occupying public areas, parks, occupying empty houses, so that after dark, local people barely venture out into the streets. I am from Vojvodina, northern Serbia, so I know exactly how hopeless the situation is. In 2015, the pressure was so great that life in some settlements was made impossible. The pressure on the Western Balkans route is now increasing again and public security is deteriorating in the border settlements. In addition to Greece, the EU should also provide increased assistance to transit countries in the Western Balkans. These are not rich countries, their resources are limited, and local people feel that everyone is only concerned with the rights of migrants and they are forgotten. Let us finally represent the interests of Europeans in this debate. Thank you.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, what the EU is facing at the border is indeed an extraordinary situation. The humanitarian situation of refugees in some hotspots is truly disastrous.  I myself visited moria hotspot, and I know how these people live there, and yet they don't want to come home. Most of them have nowhere to go back to, especially Syrian refugees. Millions of people have set in motion, whether from Syria, Africa, Pakistan, Afghanistan, and this is not the normal situation for which we have been prepared. We must say that today, in 2020, the EU is better prepared, and that is why I agree with what my colleagues in Croatia are saying here, that the Croatian Government and the Croatian Border Force are doing what they are supposed to do. They simply have to protect the EU's external border.  Of course, let's be human.  Here, I think the main group most at threat is the kids. Unassanied children, children with mothers and they should be helped in the first place.

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: – Dear Chairman, the extremely difficult living conditions of migrants, but also the difficult situation of the local population testify to our unwillingness to deal with migration. The shocking scenes we see in Greece, but also along the only land route to the European Union, are not only a matter for the border member states, but really of the entire European Union.  Croatia also proved its heart and solidarity in the 1990s by taking care of over 1 million refugees and displaced persons, but also contrary to allegations of alleged inhumane treatment of migrants, Croatian police protect the European border and rescue migrants in life-threatening situations brought in by traffickers and traffickers during this debate.  But also, Croatia, nor the European Union, must not give in to the political pressures we have witnessed in this debate, which seek to change the policy of effective border protection against irregular crossings, clearly, with the full protection of human dignity.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Madam President, thank you very much for allowing us all to express ourselves in this very important debate. I think it has become clear in this session that this is an issue concerning the defence of fundamental rights at Europe's borders. And we have raised this because they are being violated, not just on the border between Croatia and Bosnia Herzegovina, of course. Clearly we do not live up to our values and our legal obligations – as my colleague Juan Fernando López Aguilar, Kati Piri, Irena Joveva and other groupmates have said.  So, clearly, when the Council talks about illegal crossings... But, let's see: if a person shows up at the border and can't file an asylum application at the border, how can you talk about an illegal border crossing? Or, when we are not allowing asylum applications to be filed in consulates and embassies, how do we get the attention of people presenting the most at Europe's external borders? That is what you, Madam Representative of the Council, must answer to us.

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: – (beginning of the speech when the micro is switched off) ... and things are shifting further and further back. This is a gross lyane of the other Members here who want to speak on other issues. So you finally start to lead the session and then close it after a minute. That is not the way to go!

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Madam President, as I have already said, this is very emotional for me because I come from Bosnia and Herzegovina and I went through the war. The question of asylum seekers and refugees is a very emotional one, and I will read my speech in order not to get into deeper emotions about the people who are abusing the situation of these poor people. ‘Someone has been asleep in Bosnia and Herzegovina for the past three years’, said the Minister of Security of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Fahrudin Radončić. Last week in Zagreb he requested the assistance of the Republic of Croatia. He mentioned how the migration crisis in Bosnia and Herzegovina should no longer be treated as a humanitarian crisis but as a security one. The country urgently needs over 400 extra border guards. Out of EUR 40 million allocated from European aid, only 7% is earmarked for the support of local institutions in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Local institutions have endured most of the pressure since the beginning of the migrant crisis. The only ones who profit from this crisis are human traffickers. The Croatian police arrested 95 of them only this year. Human traffickers are so present that the Deputy Director of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), Bonnie Glick, stated that America will have to cut their assistance to Bosnia and Herzegovina if institutions don’t intensify their fight against it. It’s a fragile country. Don’t play with Bosnia and Herzegovina here. Shame on you.

name: Pernando BARRENA ARZA
text: – Madam President, we Members of this Parliament are aware of the fundamental rights violations occurring at the European Union borders and particularly the systematic practice of violent push-backs by Croatian law enforcement authorities. These places in Bosnia and Croatia are critical points as regards compliance with human rights, but highlights could also be made on another borders, like the French-Italian one, or the southern border of Spain, where push-backs also occur very often. One a month ago a Spanish coastguard returned migrants to Moroccan authorities hours after they landed on Spanish soil. This is a violation of the protections granted by the European Court of Human Rights. It’s time to say once again that border control cannot under any circumstance violate current laws on human rights. Furthermore, European authorities and Member States should facilitate the priceless work that NGOs carry out rescuing people in the Mediterranean Sea, like the Basque ship Aita Mari, which rescued 158 people earlier this week.

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: – Dear Chairman, one of the four priorities of the Croatian Presidency of the Council of the European Union is a Europe that protects by strengthening the internal security of its citizens and protecting its external borders more effectively.  Croatia advocates, once again I will repeat, the efficient and humane management of migration and migrant routes. My country has the longest external border of the European Union and despite the different situation in our neighbourhood, Croatian borders are open, they will remain so. There will be no wires, there will be no barricades.  On this occasion I would like to emphasize that the treatment at Croatian borders takes place in full compliance with Croatian and European laws and I repeat once again, international standards and rules. Croatia faces people on a daily basis who do not want to stay in our country, they aim for Western Europe. We must be aware that the problem of migration is not a question of just one country but of the whole Union.  I'll finish, our political views don't have to be the same, colleagues and colleagues, but they have to be the same human ones. So we want legal migration and humanity first and foremost.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, the right to asylum is not a choice, but a duty. A duty related to international conventions on the status of refugees, the fundamental principle of which is non-refoulement and to which Member States are parties, including Croatia. But it is also Article 2 of the Treaty on the European Union, according to which the Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy and equality. Border management must therefore be done in accordance with the treaty and international commitments. However, in order to limit the flow of migrants, the European Union and the Member States have not respected this legal framework and have also outsourced migration management through bilateral agreements with countries that often do not meet the material, but also legal, sufficient conditions to ensure the protection of migrants. All the reports and testimony tell us that the conditions are not being met. So a simple question: do you think that the Member States today are respectful of the Convention on the Status of Refugees? If not, what do you want to do to make them? And finally, do you think that dealing with and outsourcing migration to Turkey, Bosnia, Libya, Mauritania, Morocco or other structurally solves the migration problem, with the guarantee of compliance with our international commitments?

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the European Commission for its efforts in favour of refugees and migrants. But we have reached a marginal point. In my view, the Dublin rules need to be changed in order to give refugees and migrants more humane treatment. In other words, change the rules and share the burden; I understand that this is politically difficult, because many countries and many governments are in shock after the 2015-2016 crisis, but it is the only way to get a positive result. There is also a proposal by the Greek Prime Minister for 4,000 unaccompanied minors stranded in Greece, lest we be able to share them in the European Union. There's a first response, but it could be better.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, the same European Union which proclaims itself as a great defender of human rights fuels one of today's greatest humanitarian crises, thus recognised by the UN. The most diverse criteria, selective, restrictive and inmane, are created to choose one and abandon others, forcing them to remain in authentic concentration camps, overcrowded, in inotherstanding, deplorable and degrading conditions. The European Union is continuing its efforts to consolidate the concept of the strong-willed EU by promoting the outsourcing of its borders, even in the light of decadent and criminal agreements, such as the agreement with Turkey or Libya, a country destroyed by the direct intervention of the European Union and its powers, among other so-called "partnerships", imposing its migration policies on third countries , also conditioning development aid and the implementation of restrictions on migration flows. Once again we say that we need to put an end to destabilisation, interference and aggression on third countries and scrupulously comply with international migration law.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you all for your interventions. I take from this debate that the respect for the fundamental rights, including the principle of non—refoulement of all people, is a priority, independently of their status and whether they are inside or outside the EU. I agree with you that there should be no physical violence against migrants and refugees – I guess this is an understatement here – and we should ensure that adequate measures are in place to address the needs of the most vulnerable, notably the children, at all steps of the migratory routes. Border guards and police should carry out their duties in full respect of fundamental rights – that goes without saying. We have revised our legislation to ensure that safeguards are in place in case of alleged violation of fundamental rights. It is important that these mechanisms play their role. On our side, the Commission will continue to monitor the compliance of the situation at the borders with EU law. We will continue engaging with our partners and neighbouring countries, notably in the Western Balkans, to provide assistance to migrants in third countries to avoid them falling into the hands of unscrupulous smuggling networks. Regarding the question posed by you, Mr Azmani, the Commission also considers that the core challenges at our external border are inherently linked with those of the situations Member States have inside the EU. So therefore, these challenges should be addressed jointly. Many of the issues you raised tonight, such as secondary movement, border controls and cooperation with third countries – and, of course, also the humanitarian situation at our border – are key issues that will be addressed in the new pact on migration. Migration is among the most significant challenges the European Union has faced in recent years. We cannot stay idle to the suffering of the migrants at our borders. We need to find a common understanding on how we collectively shape and manage the realities of migration. We need to work together to address this phenomenon that is here to stay, in full respect of the dignity of the persons involved. We count on your support.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, let me thank you for this debate. There is no doubt that the situation at our external borders must be addressed in an effective and timely manner. As I have already stressed, we are committed to improving reception conditions for migrants, especially those of vulnerable groups. On a broader note, I would like to reiterate that the Croatian Presidency intends to continue focusing on implementation with regard to the comprehensive approach to migration. We will do our part to ensure coherent action at EU level in terms of more effective control of the EU external borders and increased external action, as well as to address internal aspects. Regarding the alleged push-backs and the situation at the Croatian-Bosnian border, as you’re all aware, I’m here today in my capacity as the Presidency of the EU Council, not nationally. However, I would like to comment on this, because I feel that Croatia has been unjustly portrayed regarding alleged mistreatment of illegal migrants. I can assure you that there is zero tolerance for violence in Croatia. This is strongly underlined by my government in all areas. We take all allegations of police violence against migrants very seriously. Therefore, there is especially no tolerance for unlawful use of coercive measures by the Croatian police against any population, as well as for non-prosecution of any crime or misdemeanour committed by police officers. Every single complaint is carefully investigated by the Croatian Ministry of the Interior. I can assure you that Croatian police respect the fundamental rights, safety and dignity in the treatment of migrants in full compliance with international, EU and national law. Croatia as an EU member has the task, in accordance with the Schengen Border Code and national legislation, of protecting the state border and preventing illegal migration. Regarding the common European asylum system reform, it remains our common priority to tackle the key issue from a broader perspective and to search for a comprehensive solution to the challenges. Extensive work has been done by the previous presidencies, and it is our intention to continue building on the foundations they set with the new Commission. We will continue working towards the approach with balanced responsibility and solidarity, in line with the European Council’s new strategic agenda. The Croatian Presidency hopes this issue will be adequately addressed in the new pact on migration and asylum, and we look forward to its presentation. Regarding the situation in Greece, it is a positive development that the new Greek Government has adopted a new legislative framework for asylum and related issues like return and reception facilities. It entered into force on 1 January 2020. We look forward to its speedy implementation. An efficient asylum system is key to managing migration flows, as well as for the implementation of the EU-Turkey statement, notably on readmissions.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: Writing. – In December, a saga of dehumanisation of more than 1,000 individuals in the Vučjak refugee camp took place on the EU's doorstep, to which I and my fellow MEPs and Members pointed out in a letter to the Commission.  The passivity (including European) policies since the summer of 2019, when refugees and migrants were temporarily settled in the area, could turn into a wider humanitarian catastrophe with implications for regional security. This threat persists, and neighbouring countries, in addition to the complex internal political situation, contribute to the practice of blocking access to asylum procedures and by violently deporting refugees and migrants.  The Commission cannot be indifferent to the creation of a fortress europe that is defended by gross human rights violations. It is essential to ensure that countries, primarily EU members and (candidates for) Schengen members, establish effectively independent control mechanisms to supervise the implementation of border controls, which should include a careful review of the protection of fundamental human rights and freedoms.  It is necessary to continue to find a solution to the upgrading of the Dublin system for a common and joint and several European asylum policy. I do not want the EU crisis management mechanism to have to intervene in our neighbourhood simply because of the lack of policy of the Member States, especially those where the ruling political elite accumulates its electoral votes at the expense of human distress.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: – The next item is the Commission's statement on the Debate on a Better Internet for Children (2020/2547(RSP)).

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, our debate today cannot be more topical, as yesterday we celebrated the Safer Internet Day across Europe and the world for the 17th time since its launch in 2004. We want to ensure children and young people grow up to become confident adults, skilled and respected both online and offline. Making the internet safe for children remains a priority. Children are one third of internet users and an estimated 800 million of them use social media. Let me also recall that one of this Commission’s top six political priorities is to build a Europe fit for the digital age, allowing everyone in Europe, including children, to benefit from technology within safe and ethical boundaries. The Commission has been very active on this issue over the years, with actions ranging from funding and coordination with Member States to hard law. The European strategy for a better internet for children – the big strategy – is our framework for making the internet a trusted place for children and young people. It has been in place since 2012 and has successfully brought together the European Commission, Member States, the ICT industry and civil society to deliver solutions for a better internet for children through coordination, self-regulation and funding. Our policy is rooted in the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, to which all EU Member States are party. A strong concern with child safety online cuts across EU legislation. The e-Commerce Directive, the directive on combating the sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography, the Audiovisual Media Services Directive and the general Data Protection Regulation all contain provisions to protect minors online. As to future plans, the Commission will first of all be working on a comprehensive new strategy on the rights of the child, including their rights online. The strategy should include actions to protect vulnerable children, protect their rights online, foster child-friendly justice and prevent and fight violence. We will also strengthen and modernise rules applicable to digital services in the whole EU through the Digital Services Act. We will start with a broad consultation to make sure we get the balance right and propose measures. We will also work with Member States for the full transposition of the revised Audiovisual Media Services Directive, which includes a new obligation on Member States to ensure that video-sharing platforms put in place specific measures to protect minors from harmful content online. These include mechanisms allowing users to report, flag or rate harmful content, age verification or parental control systems and transparent easy-to-use and effective complaint-handling procedures. The revised Directive also ensures that children’s data collected by audiovisual media providers are not process for commercial use, including for profiling and behaviourally-targeted advertising. Furthermore, we will present a revised digital education action plan to equip children with the skills and competences needed to thrive in this digital age. Through the current Digital Education Action Plan, the Commission is supporting outreach to schools in order to improve online safety, media literacy and digital skills. For example, the Safer Internet for EU campaign reached 30 million Europeans in 2018, and in 2019 the EU Code Week involved 4.2 million people, with 92% of the 72 000 activities taking place in schools. The Commission plans to update the plan, focusing on digital literacy and aiming at equipping young people and adults with the skills they need for life and work in the digital age. As regards the European Strategy for a Better Internet for Children, the Commission has informally consulted the main stakeholders to assess its relevance and role. These stakeholders include the Safer Internet centres, industry and civil society and Member States. The preliminary feedback is positive. The strategy’s four pillars and its holistic approach are still relevant, despite emerging risks such as disinformation, cyberbullying, online hate speech, live streaming of illegal content, and new ways for children to use technology. Any possible update of the strategy will have to be flexible enough to be future-proof as the digital ecosystem continues to evolve, with children and young people among the most ardent and avant-garde users of technology. Any Commission decision on next steps will take into account the results of the latest big policy map, a study on how the strategy is implemented in Member States, the results of a new European Parliament pilot project supporting cooperation between industry hotlines and Member States’ authorities for the swift removal of child sexual abuse material online, and, of course, the work on the new strategy on the rights of the child. What we can already anticipate is that work in this area will continue to keep a fair balance between protection and empowerment measures for children and young people in formal and informal education. I thank you and I look forward to your comments on this.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for More than 90% of European teenagers have access to the internet at home and this is the first generation that does not remember analogue times. The Internet is part of the modern world of the child, whether we adults like it or not. Children and young people are less and less likely to get entertainment and knowledge from books, television or radio. Everything they need is on your phone and tablet.  Yes, it gives great opportunities for creative development of the child and acquisition of valuable abilities and skills. The Internet can become a tool for levelling the playing field for children at risk of exclusion or children with disabilities. However, the growing internet and social media carry risks that often our children and parents are not prepared for. I am afraid that parents and children are often left alone with problems such as hate speech or harassment on social media. This applies both to children who are victims of such behaviour and to those who commit it. The same is true of young people's growing dependence on the internet and computer games.  As the European Parliament's coordinator for children's rights, I hope that the Commission will take into account not only the point of view of the internet industry and parents, but also the needs and concerns of both children and young people as part of the planned strategies and changes already existing in the legislation.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: f'isem il-group S&D. – Fiż-żmien li kont nagǎmel programm ǎurnalistiku fuq it-televiżjoni flimkien mat-tim tiegųi, konna investigajna s-sigurtà tat-tfal fuq l-internet.  Waǎda mill-membri tat-tim gǎamlet tabirruųha li gǎandha erbatax-il sena u daųlet online f'grupp pubbliku biex tiǎǎettja, u f'temp ta' ftit sigǎat ikkuntattjawha xejn anqas minn tletin raǎel ta' litter età. Ǎafna minnhom staqsewha biex tiltaqa' magǎhom. L-akbar wieǎed kellu tmienja u sittin sena. Wara li rrispondiet, tmienja minnhom bagǎtulha l-informazzjoni personali tagǎhom u fejn gǎandha tiltaqa' magǎhom, u ǎamsa minnhom tfaǎċaw biex jiltaqgųu ma' tfajla ta' erbatax-il sena, imma ǎarbu malli raw il-cameras. Ovvjament ųarbu gǎaliex kienu jafu li kienu qegųdin jagųmlu ųażin.  Imma qed insemmi dan il-każ gǎaliex it-tfal tagǎna faǎilment jistgǎu jispiǎǎaw f'dawn in-nasbiet mingǎajr ma jirrealizzaw.
