U llum smajna; it-tfal gǎandhom inklinazzjoni naturali gǎall-internet. Imma filwaqt li online huma kapaǎi aktn minn dawk ikbar minnhom, fir-realtà huma esposti ųafna u ųafna aktar gǎal riskji kbar. U naf kemm huwa importanti li nfasslu "policies" u kampanji mas-"sevice providers" differenti, sew jekk huma kumpaniji tat-telefonija u anki jekk huma kumpaniji diǎitali kbar.  L-interess tat-tfal gǎandu jkun ta' kulųadd; tal-ǎenituri tagǎhom, tas-settur privat u anki l-gvernijiet u anki tal-Kummissjoni Ewropea, gǎaliex flimkien biss nistgǎu verament naǎdmu biex naǎǎretaw li jkollna internet aktur gǎat-tfal. Gǎax bl-istess mod kif irridu lit-tfal tagǎna jkunu siguri fit-triq u l-iskola, irridu naǎǎaw ruǎna li uliedna jkunu siguri online ukoll.

name: Yana TOOM
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, when this debate was announced, I immediately expressed my interest in taking part in it. During the previous legislation, I was the rapporteur on education in the digital era and also shadow on the Audiovisual Media Services Directive (AVMSD). So I went to do my homework. I was disappointed when I found out that the last time the Commission addressed the issue was in 2011, and since then we have just forgotten the approach which was agreed. Let me give you an example. Ten years ago, we were against the fragmentation of the market, but, two years ago, we adopted the AVMS with the famous moral development of children to be defined by Member States. The good news is that, in 2019, the Commission announced the creation of a new Expert Group on Safer Internet for Children. So we took only eight years to take the first coordinated steps. Since then, the group has had three meetings, but we’re still far from a solution. Why? I believe we have to take into account at least two important things. First, children grow fast and we have to act accordingly. Ten years for a political decision means one generation at school. Second, we cannot solve systematic problems by projects, but this is exactly what we are doing. We have of course adopted some good directives, which we have already mentioned: combating sexual abuse, xenophobia, hate speech, GDPR, and so on, but this is not enough.  What we need is a comprehensive European approach to the digital education of children, not on a project basis but in each and every school, compulsory, with good teachers, a clear curriculum, an agreed set of criteria and assessment system. But what do we have in practice? Some Member States where 60% of schools do not have an internet connection. What digital education can we speak about? I strongly believe that we have to act, but act quickly and invest proper funds, not just in the meetings or working groups, but in the schools. Otherwise eight years later, it will be the same.

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her If any nonsense appears on the horizon, one thing is certain: the EU is there. Studies, but also many teachers, confirm that the increased use of the Internet leads, firstly, to a reduction in the ability to concentrate, secondly to the reduction of social skills, thirdly to the transformation of thin children into thick couch potatoes and, fourthly, to the loss of writing ability, since this technique can only be anchored in the brain at a young age through constant exercise. We are not even talking about the dangers of the Internet in terms of content, whether it is spying, grooming or confronting violence, pornography and fake news. The EU should therefore not promote the use of the Internet by children, because even the supposedly harmless, but mostly infinitely stupid, games lead to a loss of concentration and take the time for other nicer, more important things. Nor should the EU see itself as a vicarious agent for the digital industry, which wants to have access to ever younger consumers as early as possible. Just as you protect children from alcohol and pornography, you should also protect them from things that make them stupid.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, safe internet for children is vital indeed. Children should feel safe to go online, they should remain curious to discover, to learn, to innovate. However, having looked at the web page of the Safer Internet Day, I discovered with horror that, during the Safer Internet Day, discussions were focused on how artificial intelligence can be used to identify and remove child sexual abuse material. We, as legislators, are just about to analyse and address the opportunities and the pitfalls of these technologies. Therefore, it seems to be premature indeed to consider AI a silver bullet to solve all problems. And I am glad that education was mentioned by the Commission representative because I believe that future initiatives from the Commission related to safer internet should focus on education and development of technical skills of kids, which should not mean promoting the use of one specific company’s tools but encouraging the use of interoperable solutions and free and open—source software.

name: Anne-Sophie PELLETIER
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, Commissioner, today 75% of children in Europe use the internet. The internet is a wonderful tool for opening up to others and the world, but it is a space of risk. You are right, Commissioner, when you say that we must protect our children, who are at particular risk due to their age. I welcome the fight against cybercrime, as well as the fight against violent content, against slut shaming concerning young girls. You are right. However, Commissioner, in your communication, you regret that young people are just consuming on the internet. You are right, but I will go further by talking about the regulation of advertising content which today shows our children a consumerist and particularly materialistic view of the world. Finally, Commissioner, in your communication, you call for a digital for all. You are in charge of improving the conditions of people with disabilities and tonight, not a word! A zero pointed on this subject. This is a missed act, Madam, you should have taken this opportunity to also talk to us about the urgency of creating an inclusive digital.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, Commissioner Dalli, I am sure you know that half of the 11 to 16 year olds in Europe have been exposed to one of the main dangers of the internet: cyber bullying, sexting online, grooming or fake news. As an ambassador for the safe internet for all, I carry out student information events in Greece and ask them to show us how they are protected when they enter the internet. The results are spectacular, our children are suspicious. But they need help and help has to come from us and it has to come with the recruitment of technology. All studies show that companies active in internet applications, whether they are games or social media, have the technological ability to identify problematic material on the internet aimed at children, detect harassment and interrupt them. I think that is where we need to focus and that is where we need to emphasise their funding. At the same time, we must emphasise the information of teachers, parents and — ultimately — children. We must protect the digital citizens of tomorrow.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for the younger generation, the online environment is an important living space. It can also be an area of participation and emancipation, as shown for example by the "Fridays for Future". However, we need to create the conditions for the online world to be safe for kids. Some phenomena are on the rise: multiple discrimination and online abuse, dissemination of child pornography, revenge porn, sexual extortion, cyberbullying. We are faced with serious violations of children's rights, which result in very serious trauma. We must step up our efforts to combat these phenomena. We can improve prevention tools, digital literacy, internet conscious use education, quality content production for entertainment purposes. We can strengthen the tools of detection and removal of specific material from the network and those of active contrast. During the last parliamentary term, right here in Strasbourg, we tabled a draft law that was passed in Italy precisely on cyberbullying, which I believe is still extremely important. We must therefore exchange best practices, and we need a strong partnership between legislators, industry and civil society. We need a specific focus for empowering everyone to combat abuse. We cannot afford this to be yet another challenge in which reality remains one step ahead of the legislator. A safe online environment must be a priority for us to take immediate action.

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: – Madam President, in this digital era it is even more important to preserve the rights and dignity of children and protect them from online abuse. The internet is definitely a powerful tool with enormous opportunities, but it also comes with some risks and only with proper safeguards in place can we ensure children’s online safety and protect them from hate speech, misleading advertising or cyber-bullying.  Such safeguards can only be achieved with a wide collaboration of all stakeholders such as policymakers and technology companies. However, parents still have the most important safeguarding role as children continue to turn to their parents for help with online issues. We should therefore ensure a safer online environment where children can safely enhance their education, communication and connections.

name: Alex AGIUS SALIBA
text: Għalkemm l-internet joffri diveri opportunitajiet, dan qiegħed ukoll ipoġi quddiemna diversi riskji spe大jalment għall-aktar persuni vulnerabbli fis-so大jetà tagħna – b'mod大大jali t-tfal.  Fid-dinja diġitali, it-tfal jistgħu jkunu, anzi huma spiss esposti għal material illegali, kontenut perikoluż, imġiba bħal cyber-bullying, fastidju sesswali, pornografija tal-minorenni u vjolenza. Illum it-tfal qed jgħixu f'dinja u realtajiet digitali li jilagħbu rwol importanti ħafna f'ħajjithom, realtajiet bħal dawk illi jirrikrejaw rwieom, jilagħbu, jitkell ma' sħabhom anki jieħdu formazzjoni successful.  Fil-preżent għandna diġà għodod li jgħinu lit-tfal tagħna sabiex jaffrontaw riskji f'realtajiet barra mid-dinja digitali. Iżda nistaqsi, għandna l-għodda meħtieġa, il-protezzjoni, l-għarfien u s-salvagwardji sabiex it-tfal ikunu siguri wkoll fuq bażi online? Ilkoll kemm aħna għandna responsabilità morali billi nipprovdu dinja diġitali aktar sigura għat-tfal tagħna. Irridu għalhekk li l-Gumsjoni, b'mod urgenti, tirrispondi b'mod effiíjenti u effiikei għal dawn ir-realtajietġ diitali sabiex id-dinja online tkun waħda aktar sigura għal uliedna.

name: Stelios KYMPOUROPOULOS
text: Madam President, it was World Safe Internet Day yesterday and as a psychiatrist I am concerned, Commissioner. In Greece alone, one in five children has been the victim of online harassment, 61 % have been exposed to inappropriate content and children are exposed to hate speech, psychological attacks, blackmail and financial fraud. Half the children say this hurt them psychologically and pushed them into social isolation. Many parents leave children with their cell phones in hand. Children's dependence makes them vulnerable, aggressive and isolates them.  The internet is not a game. We need a modern education that will fortify children from these dangers. We must force providers and software companies to provide us with free or — at least — very cheap child protection software. It is necessary to have up-to-date European parents who can resort to an easy-to-use and available European toolbox. We need to communicate the time and manner of healthy use of the internet. This is a double-edged sword that we must use and, at the same time, protect against its negative and dangerous consequences.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, we want to build a safe internet for our children. A partnership with internet providers, content creators, social network ingeproviders is needed to come up with a set of best practices, recommendations and concrete solutions to make the internet a safer space and thus avoid possible incidents.  A recent study conducted in my country, in Romania, shows that one in three children between nine and sixteen years old have been harassed online and reported cases of cyberbullying are unfortunately multiplying. Worse still, almost half of those harassed did nothing, believing that things would work out on their own. Perhaps that is why, according to statistics, adults sometimes publish personal data about their children on the Internet, believing that the online environment is a safe place.  As the representative of the European Commission said, we need to support digital education, to involve relevant actors at European, national and local level, parents, young people, to involve schools, in order to prevent such situations. I therefore welcome the European Commission's initiative to make such a communication, and I reiterate my conviction that the internet is a safe space if we learn to use it in an appropriate manner.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Research shows that in some countries, 10-year-old children are already digitally independent and this age is constantly declining. And we probably won't stop this trend, although, as we hear from doctors, psychologists and psychiatrists, too frequent or hours of internet or computer use kills social ties, kills contacts between peers, which is very negative.  Nevertheless, it is important that we do everything to ensure that our children in the virtual world, on the internet, are safe, that the content is adapted to the age of the recipient. Undoubtedly, young people find important and necessary information on the internet, but there are also many threats like hejt, such as pornography, such as harassment, such as paedophile content or paedophile acquaintances. That is why I support initiatives such as yesterday's Safe Internet Day, which is a day of social action around which to raise awareness of how to use the internet safely, how to counteract all this, which is a threat to our children in the modern world. And I support the European Commission to take all measures to ensure that there are as few threats as possible in this digital world.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Madam President, yes, the Internet, in Slovakia it is said that the Internet, like fire, is a good servant, but a bad gentleman. That is, we cannot allow the Internet to take over our children completely. We cannot change our responsibilities to raise and devote to children by handing them a smartphone or tablet. Indeed, we must do everything we can to make the Internet safe for our children and we must prevent all data about our children from accessing merchant networks, for advertising purposes and not to stab paedophile networks. It is something terrible, because really children often also come across the Internet with various advertisements offering them a sexual program, or sexual contacts, abuse and so on. We must do everything we can to prepare an education programme together with parents, with school, with the governments of the Member States, but also with us at European Union level, because the Internet will not replace education. It's just a tool. But when it comes to education, we and our parents and schools need to address it.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, we must strive for a secure Internet for children at European and national level. I do not want and do not have to describe all known dangerous yet repetitive practices, sexual abuse, internet risk challenges.  Commissioner, I agree with you that the implementation of the revised Audiovisual Services Directive is a Europe-wide instrument for improving child protection, and we, as Members, must oversee implementation in our national legislation. But prevention is the most effective tool. This means that we need to teach children to behave safely and that we need educated teachers and parents who will guide children well. Here, Commissioner, I would also like to draw your attention to a number of very interesting and effective programmes developed by our universities, such as the Czech Palacký University in Olomouc, which develops an educational application for teachers and parents who can thus recognize and reduce these risks. They need to be used.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Madam President, the world has changed, that may be a good thing, but children are the most vulnerable and that is certainly not good and there are multiple concerns.  Firstly, related to the content of the Internet, and here I am talking about paedophilia, about child pornography, about harassment and blackmail. Secondly, it is the duration of the use of this internet, because, unfortunately, I am in a position to treat at the Nicolae Oblu Emergency Clinical Hospital in Iaşi more and more children with internet addiction phenomena or with neurological conditions complicated or triggered by the misuse of the Internet. And thirdly, negative things happen even though there are multiple laws in this area.  So, Commissioner, I am asking you for an integrated, if possible, legislative, educational and technological approach, to make the Internet a safer place, and I am really asking you today what are the first three steps you will take to do so?

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – In the use of the Internet by children there are risks of violation of privacy, commercial use, or instrumental profiles, health risks, appearance of addictive phenomena and distorted relationship with reality and with one's own identity. Other problems concern sexual invitations, online gambling and commercial scams, cyber-harassment and sexting, and age-inappropriate digital consumption, such as inappropriate advertising, violence, sex and other situations that cause fear and anxiety in children. It is necessary to ensure that children are exposed as little as possible to these hazards. However, we need to refer our reservations to possible measures that can be implemented and that should not impose restrictions on the rights of freedom of expression and must respect privacy and data protection. We also believe that this debate cannot be disconnected from the importance of the public service in ensuring a secure service and universal access in the fight against digital exclusion.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank you all for your contributions and have taken note of all your comments with regard to the measures which will be taken. I have already mentioned these in my speech before you started commenting on the content of the speech. So, the Commission is also glad to see that this subject remains a high priority and is confident that new measures in this field will receive the support of the European Parliament. At the same time, the Parliament can count on the full support of the European Commission in advancing child online safety. We are strongly committed to promoting EU leadership in child online safety ,delivering high standards of protection and stimulating appropriate action from the industry. The children of today will be the drivers of tomorrow’s European economy. Equipping them with the relevant digital tools is an investment in the future of Europe. So, I thank you President and I thank you honourable Members for your contribution to this debate and, as I already said, we have taken note of all your contributions.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Ioan-Rareş BOGDAN
text: in writing. – Making the internet safer for our children remains a priority, especially since they account for a third of internet users. The Commission aims to develop a new comprehensive strategy on children's rights, including online rights. The strategy should include actions to protect vulnerable children, protect their online rights, and prevent and combat violence. Another step will be to strengthen and modernise the rules applicable to digital services across the EU through the Digital Services Act. The Commission wants to work with Member States to have a full transposition of the revised Audiovisual Media Services Directive, which includes a new obligation for Member States to ensure that video sharing platforms implement specific measures to protect minors from harmful content online. There will be mechanisms that will allow users to report, indicate harmful content, age verification or parental control systems and easy-to-use transparent complaint management procedures. We need to support digital education, involve relevant actors at European, national and local level, parents, young people, involve schools, to make the internet a safer space and thus avoid possible incidents.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The next item is the Commission's statement on the Coronavirus: a debate on ensuring fundamental rights and a coordinated European response (2020/2565(RSP)).

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it is more apparent than ever that our greatest challenges, from the rise of antimicrobial resistance and the spread of communicable disease to the climate crisis, are collective ones. The coronavirus outbreak is clear evidence of this, and it highlights the urgent need for close collaboration and coordination across the EU and beyond. The European Parliament is a crucial partner in these efforts, and I am glad to have an opportunity to discuss the EU’s response with you this evening. The Commission has mobilised its services and agencies, notably the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDE), and is working on all fronts to support efforts to tackle the outbreak. This includes ongoing coordination with Member States to share information, funding vaccine research and offering support through the EU Civil Protection Mechanism. I will share some more specific examples of our efforts and some ideas for an improved response, but first I think it is important to salute the commitment of all frontline medical personnel, who are operating in very difficult circumstances. Last week we expressed special condolences for the death of Dr Li Wenliang, who was among the first to warn us about the coronavirus. A few words on the importance of cross—sectoral coordination at EU and Member State level would be in order here. On 28 January, President von der Leyen triggered the Commission’s crisis coordination mechanism. My colleague Commissioner Lenarčič, in his role as the European Emergency Response Coordinator, has convened meetings of the Crisis Coordination Committee with the participation of all relevant services, from health, civil protection, through research to transport, but also development cooperation and communication, to name just a few. He repeatedly emphasised that this challenge requires a joined-up collective effort and using all the tools that we have at our disposal. Relevant Commission services and the European External Action Service are constantly assessing the situation and deciding on the actions needed for a swift and coordinated response. Consular coordination and cooperation between EU Member States is ongoing in order to address repatriation and other consular needs. Thanks to the EU Civil Protection Mechanism and on the initiative of some Member States, such as France and Germany, hundreds of EU citizens have been repatriated from Hubei province. Commissioner Kyriakides has been in regular contact with the Ministers of the Member States where cases have been confirmed. Under the cross—border health threat decision, the Commission coordinates with Member States through three key mechanisms: the Early Warning and Response System, the Health Security Committee, and the Communicators’ Network. Effective cooperation is key to their success, and I assure you that these mechanisms are active, sharing information and building preparedness and mitigation strategies. At the same time, the Commission has provided EUR 10 million for research on the virus, and the EU-funded PREPARE project has been activated. This will launch clinical trials across a network of 3 000 hospitals and 900 laboratories in 42 countries. Currently, Member States are implementing a variety of measures at points of entry to the EU. However, we should work with Member States to develop a common position on external borders in line with international recommendations, whilst protecting freedom of movement and the health security of all EU citizens. We also need to coordinate with key partners like the World Health Organization (WHO). The Commission is planning to mobilise funding to support the WHO’s Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan in order to tackle the outbreak, to contain its spread and to foster research and investigation. Capacity reinforcement is especially important in countries with already fragile health systems. Access to personal protective equipment is a critical part of the wider response. The Commission is looking at the needs of Member States in this regard. In parallel, the Commission is reviewing country capacity for quarantine and isolation. Understandably, there are varying levels of capacity across Member States, including around personal protective equipment. Should EU transmission of the virus greatly expand, this may require cross—border solidarity and cooperation. It is important to contain the outbreak to reduce the risk of it spreading further. In addition to ensuring preparedness in the EU, we need to focus on assisting China. This helps the Chinese, but it also decreases the risk for the rest of the world. The Commission is working closely with China, both at technical and political levels. The EU has already provided 12 tonnes of protective equipment to China. This is a clear sign of our solidarity. We have been in contact with Member States and private companies to identify stocks of protective personal equipment that go beyond EU needs and could be shared with China. Yes, we need to make sure that stocks at national level are sufficient, but we also need to focus on where our support could have the greatest impact by tackling the outbreak at source. We are also looking into setting up a joint working group between EU and Chinese experts on public health aspects of the virus, which regards the potential for indirect consequences of the outbreak. One issue of particular concern is the potential for xenophobia, both online and offline. Discrimination against Asians or persons perceived as Asians or any other race or ethnicity is contrary to EU law. The Commission will not tolerate any racial discrimination in whatever form it takes. The Commission is in contact with the European Medicines Agency and networks of Member State authorities to assess the situation of the Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (API) and of finished medicinal products available for the European pharma industry and the European market. So far, the outbreak is not affecting the availability of medicines in Europe, but obviously we will remain vigilant. However, the outbreak highlights the need to examine the domestic production of APIs and finished medicinal products. This is something that we are currently reflecting on, and it will form part of the pharmaceutical strategy to be launched later this year. The Commission has mobilised all the assets at its disposal in order to meet this challenge inside and outside the European Union. Our success depends on rapid communication, information sharing, political will and close coordination. All of these efforts are underpinned by European solidarity with all EU citizens and with others who are vulnerable to this virus. I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, on the eve of the meeting of the ministers of health tomorrow, I think it’s only fitting and thank the Commissioner that we are discussing this subject tonight. And let’s be clear, there’s no need for panic in Europe, but people are quite rightly looking towards their national authorities but also towards the EU for answers. I want to, first of all, compliment the European Commission for their coordination efforts. I’ve seen previous outbreaks that were less coordinated but here, for example, the initiative taken for the coordinated approach about the repatriation of people deserves our compliments. But I also want to express a warning. Ministers of health tomorrow will be very inclined to underline that health is a national competence, and they will be right, but people at the moment don’t want to talk about the Lisbon Treaty, they want to see solutions. And, therefore, for the EPP, we expect a number of things: first of all a capacity check as to the preparedness of all Member States and I honestly get a bit worried when I hear the Commission say we might have to organise solidarity for the protective equipment in Member States where they have less access. No, we need to do that, actually, now. We need this capacity check. We need a common approach on people entering from the region into the EU, a clear communication strategy that avoids conflicting advice, which we’ve seen between Member States in the past, cooperate the vaccine – you’ve said enough about that – but also, that’s my last point, up—to—date data. How come, officially, we have data saying Africa has zero cases? That either means they have zero cases, which I find highly unlikely given their contact with China, or they just don’t check and that would be a worrying thing for a neighbouring continent like the EU. Therefore, we are, as the EU, as strong as our weakest link, and what the ministers need to do tomorrow is to make sure that there are no weak links at all.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Thank you, Commissioner, for your important start to this debate. With 40 000 confirmed cases globally and more than 1 100 tragic deaths, we must take the corona virus very seriously. We should be well aware that the number of cases in Europe has not been so great, but preparedness is important for managing and protecting the population. The world health organisation's work to understand the outbreak and the action of the virus is extremely important, as we do not yet really know how to spread. I am therefore pleased that you are mentioning the EU's efforts in the field of research into the virus. I think that is very crucial. Similarly, the work of various expert groups to identify the source of the outbreak is very important, to ensure that we can prevent similar outbreaks going forward. We do not yet know whether we are doing enough, and it is unfortunately impossible to know until we have better knowledge of the virus, its emergence and how it works. I call on the health ministers of the various EU Member States to be vigilant and ready to deal with any new cases and to disseminate all information and help each other in this. Measures to protect infection are of the utmost importance and must be given priority, while the isolation of persons and quarantine .m. We must also ensure that the corona virus does not contribute to suspecting people or leading to the spread of false information. Having said all that, it is good that the Commission is on the move, that you, Commissioner, are here today, that you are showing that your preparedness is great and that together we are looking to spread all the knowledge we have, investing in research efforts and ensuring that we have the correct information in order to protect the citizens.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, there is hardly a day that goes by without new breaking news about the coronavirus, and as we are more connected than ever the world is holding its breath anticipating the outbreak of a truly global pandemic. That’s the wrong approach, I think. This global attention has a very clear downside: deliberate misinformation; fake news; misleading reporting about the coronavirus are all around us. In Hungary, two people were detained who were spreading fake news in social media about a disease reaching hundreds of thousands of people according to investigators. That’s nonsense. And other internationally wide-spread posts claimed that more than 60% of humanity will get infected in the near future.  Let’s face it. Europe has not done much to address this issue of the spreading of fake news and hysteria. There is certainly of course a global crisis unfolding, nobody denies that, but in the face of the crisis, Europe must remain calm and composed. This is why we should not ignore the rising misinformation campaigns that spread fearmongering and mistrust. A coordinated European response must include fact-checking and providing regular and credible information to our citizens. We must never forget that their trust is our most precious asset, and misinformation is sometimes even more contagious than the coronavirus.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, in this crisis we express our solidarity with the Chinese people and, in particular, with the people of Wuhan. We mourn all the victims and we send our condolences to the families of the deceased. We declare our high esteem for the service of the Chinese frontline medical workers under the very difficult circumstances and high risks, and I want to hail, in particular, the courage and the sacrifice of Dr Li Wenliang and others. We welcome the fact that the EU and the Member States have shown first responses in offering support to China. We must continue to provide assistance and cooperation wherever possible. This health crisis is not over. That is why we have to make sure that there is a strong and coordinated effort within the EU and, in particular, between the Member States, and in that regard, I fully support what has been said previously by colleagues. International cooperation more generally is of paramount importance. This is why I want to explicitly emphasise that Taiwan must be fully included in the WHO—led international efforts. Lastly, there is a deep concern – and I am grateful to the Commissioner that she mentioned it – about the increasing number of reports of anti—Chinese or anti—Asian xenophobia in some countries, including in the EU, in the context of this crisis. This is completely unacceptable. We want to show solidarity, not allow xenophobia and racism. And in that context, we also have to battle against fake news and fearmongering.

name: Joanna KOPCIŃSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Given the increasing urgency and the need for a comprehensive strategy in response to the possible increase in the incidence in Europe, I have a few questions that I would like to address to the Commission. Can the Commission make any comments on tomorrow's extraordinary meeting of European Union health ministers? Can the Commission explain how ECDC, DG Santo and china's disease control and prevention centre are coordinating their responses to the new coronavirus? And can the Commission give a date for the fifth risk assessment of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control? Moreover, can the Commission explain how the European Union coordinates with other third countries? In particular, is it considering contingency measures in the event of the spread of the virus in Africa, which could create additional burdens on the health systems of the countries in that area? The Director-General of the World Health Organisation has stated that the vaccine may not be available for more than 18 months. Is such a timetable in line with the Commission's current assessment?

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the coronavirus is now less deadly than a normal flu, but the social alarm generated is infinitely higher. Stereotypes and mis-management of information are fuelling discrimination against Asian people, in one more example of xenophobia and intolerance. The virus is not combated with racism, but by ensuring access to public, universal and free health systems with decent living conditions. Universal access to health is a fundamental right, and we also use this debate to call for a roll-out of austerity measures and cuts in public services that have attacked the universality and quality of health care in many parts of the world, but also here in Europe. It is essential to remember that human rights must also be strictly respected in the management of such crises. And finally, we call for a zero-tolerance approach to racist attacks on people of Asian origin, because there is no worse virus than xenophobia.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – Madam President, as we know today, there are already more than 1 000 victims of coronavirus and more than 40 000 infected people. Still today, Taiwan is the only country with confirmed cases that has been excluded from the World Health Organisation (WHO) meetings. This not only creates a serious gap in the global health security system, but it also undermines Taiwanese people’s fundamental human right to health. Taiwan is the most important international hub in the western Pacific, and the disease does not know borders. Taiwan is the fourth country successfully isolating the sample of coronavirus. I’m sure that now is the time to work together and to use all the expertise that we can. I therefore ask you, dear colleagues, to support our common call on all the individuals blocking Taiwan’s participation in the World Health Organisation. Taiwan should be included in all WHO activities. We can beat this fearful disease only together with people who want to help.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Madam President, the European Union really must prevent the spread not only of the coronavirus, but also of the spread of propaganda that is spreading around this virus on the Internet and on social media. The European Commission and the competence bodies must take the necessary measures in due course. I think that what has been done so far is a good thing, but we cannot fall asleep, even if we think that cases of coronavirus spread are isolated in Europe so far. It doesn't have to be that long. In particular, we must share information and we must continue to communicate information to our citizens. It's about our people knowing how to prevent this, how this virus spreads. I now want to pause on one thing, and that's prevention. Because prevention is always better than cure, and unfortunately, for example, masks are a lack of masks on the market. Only some masks are effective, and it must be said and communicated to citizens, that the infection spreads mainly through the mouth, nose, but also through the hands and through solid materials, so people and especially children at school need to be informed about this. Otherwise, when it comes to masks, of course the most effective is the FFP3 protocol, so please, too, that the European Commission should make efforts to do this and get this information directly to citizens.

name: Véronique TRILLET-LENOIR
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the emergence of coronavirus confirms the global nature of health crises. No, viruses do not stop at borders. As you pointed out, Commissioner, the European Union has played its role of coordinating and supporting member countries: recommendations for health workers, organisation of the repatriation of European nationals to China, research funding of EUR 10 million to find new medicines and vaccines.  We have heard very critical comments about the Chinese government in recent days. This is not a time to give lessons, nor to use a public health crisis to make it a political subject. This is the time for solidarity with the Chinese people and their doctors who are fighting alongside them. The time is also the time for the hand outstretched to the countries, and I am thinking of Africa, where the health system is fragile and will not contain an epidemic.

name: Petra DE SUTTER
text: – Madam President, no single country or organisation can stop this coronavirus outbreak alone. The EU should closely collaborate with Member States, the WHO, the Chinese Government and other international partners, including Taiwan. The international community should support all efforts to end this outbreak, but human rights should not be a casualty of the coronavirus.  Several international rights groups have signalled that the Chinese Government has been withholding information, suppressing freedom of expression and denying access to food and medicines. On the other hand, elsewhere in the world there is an increase in anti-Chinese or anti-Asian xenophobia and discrimination. International law is very clear that during a time of public health emergency, any restrictions on human rights should be based on legality, necessity, proportionality and grounded in evidence. I count on the EU to protect our health and to protect human rights, within the EU and elsewhere.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I too would like to express my condolences to those affected, and above all my condolences to the families of the victims. I too support what the Commissioner has said – that we in Europe must work together. However, if we look at the title of the debate on human rights, we must underline once again clearly that a blatant violation of freedom of expression has led to a worsening of the crisis and that we also have a major problem: that part of the world community, namely Taiwan, is excluded from coordination measures – for ideological reasons. I think that should be an important message: ideology must not be above health. This must now also be made clear in China.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the Rapporteur on his excellent This is an important debate. The Corona virus is causing concern in the world. The number of infected and dead has increased sharply in the last 24 hours alone. It is therefore of the utmost importance that we, the Commission and the Member States constantly provide our citizens with accurate information about the virus and its risks. Knowledge and research are crucial. Of course, we shall also work to ensure that quarantine and isolation for people with symptoms are used in a proportionate manner, so that it does not violate fundamental human rights. We shall condemn the increase in the number of racist attacks against people of Asian appearance. We must now direct all measures and efforts to prevent the spread both in the Member States, within the EU and globally. I would like to thank Commissioner Dalli for a very clear description of responsibility regarding the EU's responsibilities in this work.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: Madam President, if freedom of speech had been respected in Wuhan, coronavirus would eventually have had a chance to be contained. Li Wenliang is the name of the doctor who had already warned in December of the risks of this virus. What happened was that the doctor was summoned by the authorities, was obliged to keep it a secret, and was even obliged to declare that he had violated public order and made false statements. If the authorities had put the same energy into scientifically monitoring the doctor's claims, today we probably would not be there. Transparency, moreover, in health matters, must prevail, as must common sense. Let's allow Taiwan, affected by coronavirus, to participate in WHO. Li Wenliang himself, who suffered from coronavirus, died last week. He has become a hero to Chinese Internet users who link his name to a call for freedom of expression. Images taken around the coronavirus are erased from the internet. People are threatened and end up in jail for making them public. The truth has been hidden from the world. There have been dramatic impacts. All of this is unacceptable and we must point the finger at it to prevent it in the future.  I would also like to thank deeply all the medical and scientific staff who work tirelessly. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation).)

name: Véronique TRILLET-LENOIR
text: 'blue card' question. Mrs Wiseler-Lima, in French for my French colleague, I would just like to know if you have read a book entitled La Peste, by Albert Camus.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: answer 'blue card'. "Yes, absolutely, Mrs Trillet-Lenoir.  at the end of this book, a sentence says that "the plague bacillus never dies" and that one must be very vigilant. Camus was referring to the fact that freedom is something that must be safeguarded. He was referring to the brown plague, to Nazism, and to the fact that we must always remain vigilant and that fundamental freedoms are freedoms that we must always, always, preserve. Thank you very much, I'm really glad you mentioned The Plague.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Madam President, China itself recognizes that there are difficulties and failures in its response and, because of China's lack of transparency, uncertainty about the extent of the outbreak remains. We don't have any information from Africa either. It is therefore a public health emergency that is testing nations— the resistance of nations—public, private institutions, workplaces, schools, major economic events— such as the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, which this afternoon has been cancelled by the coronavirus.  The citizens of the Union are asking us for concrete actions and European solutions. We therefore demand a single line of response, coordinated and harmonised with WHO and all Member States. We need a joint and immediate communication strategy that gives peace of mind and security to all Europeans, because only in this way will we combat misinformation, fake news, stigmas that only cause alarms. I myself, as a European citizen, miss in public centres information on how we can prevent coronavirus. We have therefore taken the initiative in the People's Party with concrete measures. The first is a clear communication strategy that inspires confidence; cooperate in vaccine research; have big data, for which we have proposed a questionnaire for passengers entering European territory; and, above all, cooperate with the rest of the world. And so tomorrow, we demand that the Ministers of Health and the Commissioner give a united and effective response to the... (the chairperson withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the position of the European People's Party is very clear. We support the Action of the European Commission, but we call on the European Commission, as early as tomorrow morning, to ensure that there is a coordinated response from all the Member States of the European Union. United with the same measures, we can deal with an emergency that has dramatically affected China and that we do not want it to hit Europe. That is why we need unity, we need measures. We have proposed a questionnaire to find out whether those arriving in Europe have spent days in China in the regions with the highest contagion. It is a concrete proposal that we have made to the Commission. We must move forward and if we want to avoid panic we must act quickly and concretely. Lastly, China has not done everything it should and continues to do, not what it owes. There was a lack of information, it started late. The Chinese are the first victims of a system that is doing as the Soviet Union did with the Chernobyl affair. Hiding tragedies means creating enormous damage to one's own citizens. The Chinese are the first victims of the Chinese Communist regime.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Madam President, at the time of this debate, the number of cases has increased more than a thousand times since the first month and there are 1,118 deaths.  No country can fight such a phenomenon on its own, and from this point of view, I believe that the right to health is a fundamental right that we must all defend, beyond any political colour.  I was the first to call for an integrated European action plan in the plenary of the European Parliament, and I am pleased that some of these measures have been taken, this rapid alert system, the activation of the European Civil Protection Mechanism.  But know that when we are in such a situation, we should also prepare for intervention. We are talking about European countries that have unequal health systems, we do not yet have a European standard of quality in health, and, in the face of such a phenomenon that can create great problems, we should have a unified attitude.  And I hope, Commissioner, that tomorrow morning you will set out that way of integrating the health response system, even if it is, and perhaps we will need to, at least prepare for that European medical body to intervene. And, as I volunteered when it came to the Ebola epidemic, as a doctor, an emergency doctor in Iasi, in Romania, I volunteer and if necessary to intervene in such a situation. I congratulate you on the measures taken and believe that good things must continue.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, in Ireland, we have over 2 000 excess winter deaths as a result of fuel poverty and a bad health service, from a population of 4.5 million. This virus has led to the deaths of over a thousand, and while I regret every one of those deaths, we have to maintain a sense of perspective and we have to, as the Commissioner said, let this matter be dealt with by science and in calm, emphasising research, clinical trials, containment and close collaboration. I have to salute the efforts of the Chinese, who have done their very best to contain this virus in difficult circumstances, and I think all Member States have to reciprocate and redouble their efforts. The Commissioner said Member States have introduced a variety of measures at entry points to the EU. I have to say my own country, Ireland, has been poor in that regard, but I do welcome your points to help China. I think that’s really important and to ward against the discrimination that surrounds this issue.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for your report and I agree with many previous speaker. I think that rapid information and cooperation is needed. It is all the more incomprehensible to me that China, which is calling for solidarity and assistance, has thus refused the help of Taiwan, which has offered medical devices and assistance with treatment. Taiwan is a country that has one of the most developmental health systems. I agree with my colleagues that we must push for Taiwan to have its representation in the bodies of the World Health Organisation. I think that health takes precedence over politics, and that is why I want you, Commissioner, to verify this report, whether it is true that China has indeed refused this aid. I want to say that we are not opposed to solidarity, on the contrary. Even in the Czech Republic, a wave of solidarity has risen, and ordinary people send funds and material assistance to China. Health takes precedence over politics.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, it was really good to hear that the EU is ready and willing to tackle this dangerous outbreak in cooperation with Member States, of course, and also that the EU is already working with China to help and assist in fighting that. Let me remind you that the EU and China have been strategic partners since 2003. We have already seen some impact on the global economy and growth because of uncertainty, and because China is too important a global player. So if it is internally hit by the disease, it will also have global consequences. If the EU wants to be a global player and it wants to show global responsibility, it’s time to revive that strategic partnership, like Mr Bütikofer rightly pointed out, to better include China within the World Health Organisation (WHO) framework. It should also fight the general anti-Chinese or anti-Asian moods that have been spreading throughout Europe in the last month at least, because they are very dangerous.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, in 2009 the swine flu broke out in the US. It spread to 100 countries and over 10 000 died from it. This year alone in the US, 19 million people got the flu; 10 000 have died, 180 000 have been hospitalised. I actually find it amusing that the manner in which people have used this to try and undermine the Chinese State is a bit scary. If the Chinese have a problem with coronavirus, do you not think that they need our solidarity and our help and our cooperation? They don’t need us to panic, they don’t need us to kick them around the place because they have a problem. They built a hospital in 10 days. We wouldn’t even get the paperwork done in six months because there are so many people wanting a piece of the pie. The fact that they’re not a neoliberal state – they’ve actually been better fitted than most to actually deal with the crisis. We should be applauding them, and in fairness to the Commission here, they’ve actually been pretty positive about the Chinese reaction; the WHO have been pretty positive about it – but do you know what? For people in Europe to throw stones at them and to use human rights issues and whatever to actually undermine the Chinese position is pretty sickening. Do you know what? We’ve a lot to learn from the Chinese.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank you and the honourable Members for an informed and valuable discussion. I have taken note of all of your comments. But, regarding Taiwan vis—à—vis the WHO, we promote practical solutions without formal involvement regarding Taiwan’s participation in international frameworks when this is consistent with the One—China policy. With regards to Chinese services, we are in daily contact and we have no reason to doubt the information which they give us. I also want to put your minds at rest that we are in contact with the African authorities, and that the EU has a cooperation agreement with the Chinese Centre for Disease Control. We are making sure that we are prepared, and therefore no panic, but vigilance. I appreciate the fact that we share a common objective on this issue to ensure an effective, coherent EU—level response to the coronavirus outbreak. We are working closely with Member States and doing all that we can to ensure that we succeed. However, success also depends on coordination with, and active participation from, all key stakeholders, including the European Parliament. It also depends on political will, which has been demonstrated here today. The EU Council Presidency, as we have already said, has organised an Extraordinary Health Council, which will be taking place tomorrow. This will provide another important opportunity to enhance our coordination.  Success also requires alignment of preparedness and response measures, including at the EU’s external borders. This would support China’s efforts to contain the virus and mitigate any further transmission within and into the EU, as well as assisting third countries with weak health systems. In fact, this should be our ultimate goal: to support China and the international response whilst protecting European citizens, and it is possible. We will continue to monitor the situation very closely and take the necessary actions, and we will keep the European Parliament abreast of all the developments.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The debate is adjourned. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Manuel PIZARRO
text: in writing. – The global threat of coronavirus is a test of the effectiveness of EU internal health cooperation. But such cooperation will not be sufficient if it is not articulated at WHO level with all the countries of the international community affected, with a view to containing and, in the long term, overcoming the epidemic.  In this sense, the EU must ensure that Taiwan, home to 23 million people, does not remain the only country with confirmed cases of coronavirus excluded from WHO technical meetings, as has been the case since the outbreak began. This exclusion is not only inexplicable but irresponsible. In the past, Taiwan has been able to participate in WHO meetings with observer status. The exclusion of this country from meetings related to the response to coronavirus is therefore even more incomprehensible. The inclusion of Taiwan in these arrangements, as well as in the 73rd WHO Assembly to be taken in the near future, should be the subject of démarches by the European authorities. Furthermore, reports of discrimination against Asians in Europe in the context of this epidemic, which are inadmissible in the light of the Union's values, must also be investigated.
